Posts.Title: Repeat prescriptions from GP

Posts.Content: Afternoon OMG,  Sorry to see you here in the club no-one wants to join. Best thing is when you go in tomorrow ask if it's possible you could have some lymph fluid build up as your arm doesn't feel right to you. They will soon check it out and even if you have, be very doubtful it will make surgery a problem. Assume by removing breast lump you are talking about a lumpectomy rather than a mastectomy ? Fingers crossed they will get what they call clear margins which means they get all the cancer and a small clear area around it, if they find from histology they haven't they may have you in again to take a little more until it is "clear"  Don't fret if this happens as it is quite common. It's a fine line between taking too little tissue from the breast to leave you with some boob and taking too much and making you lopsided and mis-shaped.  As for not knowing how many nodes, have you heard them mention anything like sentinel node where they take from one up to four nodes and check to see how many could be affected or a "clearance" where they take most if not all of them ? It is nearly always a sentinel node check first  if one or two are affected, they will take more but rarely take all of them first time around unless they already know from biopsies etc. Again, do ask, don't be kept in the dark about any of your treatments ( surgery, chemo or rads and anything else for that matter ) You can deal with it so much better if you know what they are doing and what is going on. You will have to wait around 10 days for the results on grading and stage from histology dept who will examine the tissue removed , also if you are hormone positive ( tumour feeding off your own hormones ) Which will dictate wether you get Herceptin and/or any hormone based tablets like Tamoxifen or Letrozole later on. Try not to worry too much while waiting for results (hard we know) and do keep firing questions at us as we only have until tomorrow to answer them before your surgery. Also have you been given plenty of booklets to read up on breast cancer and treatments ? as they are available as free downloads on this website. If you need more info just holler and we'll point you too them. Take care,  George & Jackie.

Posts.Title: NED?

Posts.Content: Evening Rosalyn,  A Dexa scan was given to Jackie just before starting Letrozole her onco consultant arranged this we knew nothing about this type of scan at the time.  Assume you read our reply to an earlier post with the dexa link ? You may have been signed off as Herceptin isn't a chemo drug it's what they call an monoclonal antibody targetted therapy. Either way you surely were given follow up appointments with the onco ? as he / she is the one who can refer you for a dexa. If you don't have one they are clueless to any bone thinning the tamoxifen may cause. If you have an appt coming up ask about a dexa scan then, if not get in contact and ask if they plan giving you one. I don't know if a GP can refer you for a dexa scan, maybe worth asking if you have a helpful GP ? Ten years is a long time if this bone thinning happens and during that time you could have been taking tablet to lessen this. The Breast Cancer Care site has this info page about tamoxifen and osteo problems. Mentions Tamoxifen about half way down the page. There is this too - Osteopenia Decreased bone mineral density (a measurement of bone strength) but not low enough to be diagnosed as osteoporosis. Osteopenia. See also Dexa scan link to NHS. G  n' J
Posts.Title: bone scan question

Posts.Content: Winter  must be coming, another Blue Tit has appeared. Seriously though Dawn hope you are feeling ok this morning apart from feeling sore after your WLE. When they inject the blue dye they are looking to see how many sentinel nodes you have ( sentinel meaning being the nearest ones to where the breast fluid drains to ) obviously from the dye marker you have just the one, some people can have up to four sentinels out of from 12 to over 20 nodes. So they only take the dyed ones. Because you are grade one as you said they are not expecting to find it infected but they have to be certain as it affects further treatment. If it does come back clear great, but if it doesn't then they will have you back and take some more and check those out. The more they take the more chance of lymphoedema as the fluid has to go somewhere so they don't take more than they feel they need to at the start. Jackie's was 8 mm grade 3 and she had 3 sentinels removed during MX which luckily came back clear and she had only very minor probs with lymphoedema. They will probably also include "zapping" the lymph area during any future radiotherapy treatment. I'll put in a link to the Maccy SLNB webpage incase you haven't read it. Best wishes for a speedy wle recovery, George & Jackie.  http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertypes/Breast/Treatingbreastcancer/Surgery/Checkingthelymphnodes.aspx

Posts.Content: Hi sunriser52  Roughly, Pathology covers everything body related - including post mortems which is why everyone is familier with the word from the world of TV Forensic Pathology = Silent Witness etc  :)) There are several depts which come under pathology like haematology (study of blood) microbiology (infection) and the one that covers disease in human tissue which is where histology comes in. No one would ever remember histopathology although it is the correct term, so most just call it a pathology report instead :) KISS  -  Keeps It Short n' Simple....... G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi NuttyMare,  There are two types of bone scan - The more common one associated with cancer is the bone scan they use to check for secondaries and the other is the Dexa bone density scan. Perhaps your gp thought you were referring to the 'secondaries' type scan unless you specifically mentioned dexa ? Think a lot of the confusion is in the term GP (General Practitioner) they generalise, and a lot of the time they cannot be 'arsed' or won't spare the time to look stuff up.  It's ok for them they aren't the ones getting the side effects :-( I would have another go at chasing one up either through a gp or maybe even your onco team. G n' J

Posts.Title: good evening

Posts.Content: Hiya Kazza, At only 7 stone the types of recon offered may be limited as with 'ahem' larger ladies they can use back or tummy muscle but only if you have some to spare. So if a recon is on the cards it may be the implant and/or expander type. You could have a look here at Keeping Abreast uk which is a breast reconstruction support site. I'm afraid you probably won't find out about needing chemo for sure until the removed tissue pathology results come through about a week after surgery - that is where they get most of the final diagnosis and treatment pointers from. Don't fear the answers from questions as no amount of worrying will alter the outcome - it's better knowing even if scary than not asking and forever worrying about every thought that pops up. Because of your family history has anything been mentioned to you about taking the BRCA gene test ? as you sound like a prime candidate for it, so it would be worth asking about this as it takes a couple of months to get the results through. It's not only breast cancer that has brca gene links, but it also can include family history of ovarian in women and prostate cancer in male relatives. If you find your appetite has gone awol, try eating a little on a small plate often rather than a couple of full meals every day. G n' J

Posts.Content: Afternoon  Dawn,  Can take up to a week to get a general anesthetic out of your system, and yes as you found it puts you on a real downer.  As for the numbness it's probably down to cut nerve damage and it can take quite a while for the cut ends to heal or knit back together and you can get a lot of misfires while that is happening too like hot spots, shooting pains and the wound just feeling a bit weird. If it continues to cause you discomfort see if they can give you something to help also keep an eye on it for any increasing redness that could be a sign of infection. Stitches can also fail ( a common problem with those who try to do too much too soon after the op) so make the most of getting plenty of rest for a few days. So pleased to hear you feel much better today, take care, hugs,  G  n'  J

Posts.Content: Hiya       ^ ...  ^            /   O , O   \             |  ) : : : (  |           ===w=w=== Blimey, delving into a grey area here ? When you say come back do you mean local recurrence in the same area (same breast if you had a lumpectomy for instance) or secondaries elsewhere in the body, mastectomy site or the other breast ? Within the first couple of months post treatment In normal cases you can be fairly sure you are safe, but as usual there are loads of exceptions which can make this possible :-( Some types of BC are more aggressive than others (Inflammatory and Triple Negative for example)  sometimes a few cells can be missed during surgery, in the breast if clear margins are not obtained, or any that remain in the lymph nodes - single cells are not usually a problem because they either get zapped by chemo, rads or tablets, or your own immune system, but if they are in a cluster somewhere and go unaffected and unnoticed things can get scary.... You can check this out here at CRUK. Any particular reason you are asking Ali ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi juley68 I'm afraid it is bang on cue for Docetaxel :( You tend to get a 3 day honeymoon period while it fully gets into your system then it can feel like you got hit by a truck. Not everyone gets this in a severe way, but joint and muscle aches are one of the more common side effect of docetaxel/taxotere - although some can find it painful just climbing stairs. If this starts getting a bit too much let your onco unit know about this and they will either advise some form of pain relief and possibly reduce the dosage by 20% next time around. Do check out the September Chemo Discussion (link) and get chatting to others going through similar treatments to share the chemo baggage. Hope it eases off soon, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi SusieMcc,  Oestrogen is one of the 'feel good' hormones, so as the tablets deplete your oestrogen levels it can make you feel a tad down it just takes time for your body to adjust :-( Do as some of the other ladies have mentioned and try to find a 'brand' that you can cope with better. There are at least six different makes and they all seem to have slight differences. Doctors will always say the main drug is the same, and it is, but some of the fillers and coatings used vary greatly. Fingers crossed your treatment pains ease and your lump checks out ok. Posts.Title: breast concern

Posts.Content: Hi HelenM17 This was the case up to the introduction of Herceptin trials pre 2010 as Grade 3 HER2+ Positive was just about the most agressive type of breast cancer to be diagnosed with and a very poor prognosis; it was known as 'the widowmaker' because of the much higher risk of mets -  It may have taken a while but for a lot of patients the mets were just to severe in the end :( Since the introduction of Herceptin and the newer Perjeta (also other newer drugs on the very cusp of being made available) these are game changers for HER2+ cancers and is now no longer seen as a death sentence even for those with invasive HER2+ BC That is why when those with HER2+ post as new members asking about not having chemo makes me shudder, because without the chemo they don't get the good stuff  :-/ For some even with the newer drugs regime it just doesn't work out and can come back as a secondary somewhere but the chances of that now is a lot less. If this is what happened with your friend has she has been very unlucky or hers was found late and more advanced ? J was diagnosed with HER2+ (ER/PR+ positive too) in May 2012 when Herceptin was a still postcode lottery drug and her onco said if we were in the next county she wouldn't have got it - Luckily just after that NICE approved funding it for everyone, but even now it is still £1,300 per dose.... As for the last comment, nearly everyone would never say you are 'cured' as there isn't the technology yet to find single cancer cells within the body but they will class you as NED - No Evidence of Disease which is as good as it gets. Hope this helps a bit, hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning Kath, Whoever said Tax doesn't need to be Taxing, obviously never had it. You are a bit like Jackie, That Dizzy-Taxel fella took an instant dislike to her too. Think she suffered just about every side effect going and a few free ones on top. Luckily her feet/hand probs were peripheral neuropathy not PP which is evil, it's all you can do to walk anywhere as just putting your weight on your feet is so painful. Have a word with your onco unit and/or GP and ask about Pyridoxine tablets they have been prescribed for others here who have had palmar plantar and taken throughout chemo. Another great help is Udder Cream originally formulated for care of cows teats - well you imagine being topless outside in all weathers. You can buy these from Amazon - Proper Udder Cream seems to be better than the Udderly Smooth one which has a slight scent but it's a tad greasy and doesn't readily absorb as 'real' udder cream does. Use it on hands and feet. If you are lucky you may even be able to get it prescribed, if not Just go to amazon and put udder cream in the search box, there are loads of dif types. They may reduce the dose of your other T by 20% that may help take the edge off the side effects without compromising it's good work meanwhile don't suffer in silence, make sure they know how rough you are feeling and don't accept you have to put up with this discomfort. Hope you get to feel a bit better in the next few days Take care Kath, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Aches and pains with Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hiya, They certainly do not give BC'ers facing chemo anywhere near enough information about Peripheral Neuropathy (link) it is briefly mentioned on the leaflet as a side effect and that is about it. From what we see in the group at least half of those having chemo will suffer some symptoms of PN and being nerve related it is not only numbness and tingling it can also get painful, or feel very hot like your feet are burning - This can go on for quite a while after chemo too. PN can also go on to become what they term Palmar Plantar which is Hand / Foot syndrome where the skin can actually blister and crack making walking almost impossible. Please read this old post about hand foot syndrome it could help you if your  hands and/or feet get painful. Although the symptoms do ease off quite a bit PN can leave you with permanent slight numbness. Jackie finished her chemo in October 2012 and still has some numbness in her big toes. Chemo - That gift that just keeps giving  :-/ G n' J

Posts.Title: Aches and pains with Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi Pixielix,  Femara was the company that trialled and manufactured Letrozole originally and until they recovered their R&D money were the only makers. It was then de-licensed and around 6 other companies now make it. The drug Letrozole itself is the correct dosage but the fillers to make up the tablet size and the coatings can vary between makes.  This is what causes the variations in side effects of those taking it. If on your repeat prescription it says Femara that should be what you get, but if it says Letrozole you could get it by any maker. If that is the case and you are getting different makes from your pharmacy it may pay you to make notes of the makes and how you feel while taking them, then you can try to only get the makes that agree with you. Femara still make letrozole but they are the most expensive that is why usually you get a one of the other makes like Teva, Sandoz, Accord, Rambaxy etc Oh, and any of these hormone inhibitor tablets (letrozole, tamoxifen, arimidex etc) can cause a bit of weight gain but not everyone is affected by this ? Hope this helps, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Loulou, Welcome aboard the Runaway Mine Cart club, sorry to see you joining us. The pain and twinges you describe sound very much like cut nerves trying to knit back together post surgery. Sometimes they feel like sharp stabbing twinges, nips, or little electric shocks they will fade but it can take a while. Do keep up your physio excercises although painful they will help and the sooner you ease the tension the more arm shoulder mobility you will have. Keep an eye out for any signs of Lymphoedema after they remove your drain as it can be a problem after a complete clearance because you now have no nodes to clear away any lymph fluid so it has to find another route. Just click the green link for a bit more info. If you have any other concerns or questions don't hesitate in posting a New Discussion we're all here to help each other through this. Take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Content: Hi Baki  Know this must be so tough to cope with when you seem to be forever getting knock-backs or yet another piece of bad news. It's something you see mentioned quite a lot in either of the Incurable Groups. The one thing above all else in their attitude to being classed as incurable is that they will tell you they are "Living With Cancer, not dying from it" The glass half full way of looking at this opens up a whole new way of thinking about how you cope with making the most out of the future you still have. there is no reason why you couldn't still be enjoying a reasonable life for years to come. While there is still treatment for you there is still hope this can buy you lots of time -  Fingers crossed you can turn this around and start enjoying what you still have, rather than beating yourself up over something that was totally out of your control. {{Group Hugs}}  G n' J

Posts.Title: Corded vein pain

Posts.Content: Hi  Dooby,  As long as you can read the replies, we'll get through somehow. The most commonly used chemo drugs for breast cancer are FEC which is 3 different drugs given together  FEC A combination of the chemotherapy drugs 5-flurouracil (5FU), epirubicinand cyclophosphamide. See combined FEC Docetaxel also known as Taxotere or T   -  Usually you are given both written as FEC-T There is also Taxol also known as Paclitaxel which is sometimes used but is given in smaller doses weekly - and several others less commonly used. They all have their own common side effects but everyone gets a different 'journey' some have a tougher ride with one and are ok'ish with the other. Do you know what you will be given as yet ? so we can let you have more specific answers. Best wishes,  George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Chemo? Are there different types and different symptoms? (sorry i...

Posts.Content: Hi RadDad, Welcome to the club no-one wants to join. Just to let you both know how you are feeling is totally normal - we were all rabbits in the headlights when you first get the shock diagnosis. You have got through the agonising wait for results and have a treatment plan set out it's getting to grips with all the questions you must have regarding surgery, tissue histology for grading etc You wife seems to have fantastic attitude to all this, underneath she must be wondering what the hell is happening but accepting what has to be done to get through all this. It may get to her a bit, so be prepared for the odd angry outburst and teary sessions she may have concerns for how you may feel after surgery towards her altered body shape, just help wherever you can and be her rock even though you may be falling to bits too. Like me you probably won't notice too much, but it comes as a helluva shock when she first sees the breast missing. They are a great bunch here and will help you both as much as pos, so post as often as you like. Do either of you have any specific questions gnawing away at the moment ? With surgery coming up if you have answers it will help ease your concerns. My wife (Jackie) had a left mastectomy (grade 3) , chemo, herceptin and radiotherapy and we're well over a year out the other side of the treatment tunnel. Just one thing please don't google stuff, a lot of the info is either way out of date, or wrong and really scares the crap out of you, when in reality breast cancer treatment has come on in leaps and bounds over the last couple of years. You take care, we'll keep an eye open for your posts, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Nervous huband

Posts.Content: Morning Louise  / Loulou1007  The most common chemo regime for BC was FEC-T 3 or 4 cycles of each. A lot of oncologists started dropping the F part as it was causing more problems than benefits, leaving it called EC. Nice recommends for breast cancer an anthracycline has to be given with any chemo regime which means they have to use either Epribubicin, the E part of FEC or Doxorubicin (also called adriamycin hence the A) So it's mostly EC or AC now followed by T (a taxane)  if needed. Why an oncologist chooses one over the other I have no idea (perhaps one is kinder to the heart or liver ?) but both A and E are similar drugs with the same outcome. The C part is the same in both and is Cyclophosphamide. You can check out AC Chemo clicking here. Don't forget the October Chemo Club is here if you have any questions about it once you start. Colds rarely have any effect on postponing chemo, a chest infection may be a different case though. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: AC Chemo

Posts.Content: Hiya Darryl, Oh, bugger it's those pesky hormone tabs at it again.... Lets see if we can describe this. Wake up some mornings and have to hobble about for 5 mins to get your joints working, feel like you aged twenty years overnight some days, it's even painful to just turn over in bed on occasions ? Jackie has been on Letrozole (femara) for about 18 months now and although the side effects evened out at around 6 months they haven't eased much since. She is taking nsaids ( meloxicam) 15 mg but as you say it's a no,no if you are on warfarin etc. I have no idea if there is an alternative for those that are on blood thinners ? Out of curiosity have you had a quick DEXA scan for checking bone density, after J had that she was given AdCal and Alendronic acid tabs to take to counter some of the effects of the oestrogen stripping from the Letrozole as it has caused her to become osteopenic which has helped a bit with the bone pain. Do make a note of which maker name of Letrozole you are being given (pharmacy's are buggers for always getting the cheapest at the time) and  swapping them around. Different makers use different fillers to bulk up the tablet size and sometimes it's these fillers that can cause problems. If you happen to get given any that appear to be less of a problem see if you can always just have that make.....  The hot flushes etc should ease off after a while, but do get help with any side effects, you are on these for 5 years so don't be a martyr, sometimes you just have to shout a bit :-)  Hope this helps, they certainly don't make recovery easy for you, do they. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: letrozole and side effects

Posts.Content: Afternoon Dollie, Please don't fret about all this, hard though it is to put out of your head. Nothing drastic is going to change over a couple of weeks. It's only natural now you have set the wheels in motion you just want to get this agonising wait over with and have some answers, but unfortunately at the start waiting is all you seem to be doing and it is a terrible time on the emotions. Hopefully you will get your letter in the next couple of days and you will have new worries to focus on - the fear of the unknown about what they will do to you at the breast clinic and then another wait for those results. It is all very new and scary for you but you are among friends here who know how you are and how frightened you must be. If you haven't heard anything by Monday (doubtful they will keep you waiting much longer) do phone and ask as they may have contacted your GP before you. As for being brave, it is just a case of getting on with kicking cancer where it hurts and trying to keep some control and normality going on. Our lives revolve around the calendar and the many appointments that never seem to end but at least we already have that, you at the moment have nothing but too much time to wait and worry. There is a word for what you are feeling - we know it as Scanxiety and it is thought of as a worse time than being on treatments. What you are feeling is totally normal but do hope for the best. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Paying for Letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi Vicky, Welcome to the breast group, we hope for you this will be a short visit and your fears aren't confirmed. I would try to speak to your GP and ask if the information about you finding a new lump and having a swollen armpit on the other side needs to be added to the referral notes she sent to the breast screening clinic ? Do mention this at your breast clinic appointment as well so they can check out 'both' sides. It is unusual to have breast cancer discovered in both breasts at the same time but not unheard of. Hopefully because it seems you have issues in both this is something like fibroids which is a lot more common. You can have  read of Understanding Breast Screening here (link)  - You can probably expect ultrasound scans and if anything out of the ordinary is visible on screen biopsies using a hollow needle are taken for further examination. In some clinics they can give you results fairly quickly but most you have to return to a week later for the results. Do make sure you take someone with you to chat to and take your mind off it a little - they can also support you if you get the impression something isn't right too. You are into a tough emotional waiting time now and all the 'what if's' can get to you, do keep posting here with any questions or if you just want to have a chat. Fingers crossed for you, take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Oncotype dx

Posts.Content: Morning Fiona, We agree with the replies here and have come to the same conclusion, just eat a little healthier - Fresh over produced wherever possible. Buy fruit and veg when they are 'in season' so they actually have some flavour (had enough of tasteless foods during the chemo weeks) If you feel you would like to cut out, or cut down of white flour products that is fine too. Eat what you like, when you like - everything in moderation and variation :-) Try not to use diet as a means of gaining some control back in your lives as it can become a bit of a obsession (some even taking it to extremes) and don't have too many plant and chemical based therapies. Especially if they have no proven long term track record concerning collateral damage. One or two supplements that you have proved helps you with side effects of hormone tablets etc is fine but be aware if you get hooked on taking more various types of supplements it can deplete your bank account quicker than you can say Holland & Barrett :-) Now where did I put those cripsy rolls and bacon :-) G n' J

Posts.Title: docetaxel has floored me

Posts.Content: Hi KiwiCardi  Welcome to the Breast group :) This sounds very much like the cut nerves trying repair themselves. It can feel quite weird at times and the feelings can change a bit from pins and needles to hot / cold, little zaps, even wet ? It does ease off as they gradually heal but may always feel very slightly numb. A lot of ladies will tell you node clearance is more painful than the breast surgery. Node clearance can be quite deep and it's a very sensitive area with lots of muscles and tendons for the arm / shoulder in. Good luck for a quick recovery from the surgery and the infection but do keep a check on it for fluid build up now the drain is out as the fluid has to find others routes to flow now a lot of the nodes have been taken out.  Have you had your post surgery pathology results yet ? Oh, and don't hesitate creating a New Discussion if you have any specific questions or concerns, we're all here to help :) Are you a kiwi in the land of the long white cloud, or you in the UK ? Kia ora, G n' J

Posts.Content: Afternoon Dollie, I would take someone with you, because if you have any biopsies taken you may feel a little sore afterwards and for a  few days, also the fact they took some samples will play on your mind and cause your worries to start so it would be better to have someone to talk to rather than face the journey home alone. You can find all you need to know about Understanding Breast Clinic Screening clicking here. Very few hospitals unless they run a 'one stop shop' will give you much information on the first visit, they may say you have something suspicious showing on the ultrasound screen that they need to take needle biopsy samples of and that could possibly be from the breast and/or a lymph node, they usually call you back around 10 days later for the results - so another agonising waiting period :-( It usually takes around an hour, but if the unit is busy may take a little longer. Hope this helps, good luck, G n' J

Posts.Title: How do I change my perspective of a death sentence?

Posts.Content: Afternoon  Billybunter, Surely I am too young to remember that schoolboy ? So sorry to read about the worries with your wife and seeing you joining us here :( I don't want to alarm you any more than you already are but an inverted nipple was my wife's only symptom :( and she was diagnosed with breast cancer - it was only 8m/m and right behind the nipple and too small to feel.   OK, that is not what you wanted to hear but... That was over 5 years ago and she is thankfully still here and finding me jobs and decorating to do. Fingers crossed this is something like scar tissue from her previous surgery pulling it in, but if your fears are confirmed the treatments have improved greatly over the last 10 years so please put away these worries you may lose her. Obviously we would all prefer you both don't have to go down this road again but unless it is very advanced (which sounds doubtful) this may well be treated as recurrence and not secondary cancer. Keep chatting to us here and asking any questions you have until you know where this is going. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Inverted nipple

Posts.Content: Hi Julie,  Bit of a bummer you not being able to have 'any' of the hormone inhibitor tablets.  Assume you are post menopause now ? or you probably wouldn't be on Anastrolzole (arimidex) anyway.... Most of your oestrogen is produced by the ovaries so by being post meno they will be producing very little if any oestrogen now, but the Adrenal glands also make a little oestrogen and a small amount is also made from your bodies fat cells so this is all you will be producing. If this is still a concern for you ask to see a dietician as I think some foods can increase oestrogen production. If you can find out which, you can change your diet to avoid these. I'm not very well 'up' on this so do please check it all out with your onco unit. After all, they said no, so they should have some alternatives ideas to fall back on ? As for re-assurance about it not coming back, unfortunately after being bitten once none of us can have that luxury I'm afraid - we just plod on and hope for the best. A lot of the triple negative ladies don't get offered herceptin or any hormone tablets but mostly seem to be fine. Hope this is of some help, G n' J
Posts.Title: Allergic reaction to anastrozole

Posts.Content: Hiya, The thing with chemo is it works best on cells that divide more rapidly (cancer cells) problem with that is there are several other types of cell in the body that divide rapidly and also do that and take a 'hit' during chemo. The most obvious one being hair follicles and good mouth/oral anti-bodies. Most will know about the white cell count being lowered but the red cell count takes a big dip too. Meaning not so many red cells to carry oxygen around your body, which in turn makes your heart work harder - result feeling breathless and shattered a lot more easily :( It's all a bit pants - G n' J Christmas Wishes.

Posts.Title: Can I avoid hormone therapy if I elect to have a double mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Hi Karen  /  Karen1908  You shouldn't be paying for any prescriptions anyway ? Once given a cancer diagnosis you qualify for a 5 year exemption card - This should have been explained to you by your GP :( Ask your GP to fill in the form for the exemption - If you are having any treatment related to cancer or its effects, you can apply for an exemption certificate. You need to collect form FP92A from your GP surgery or oncology clinic. The card covers ALL meds given by prescription, not just the cancer related ones. There is more info here. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: what is sentinal node biopsy?

Posts.Content: Hi Gina, Welcome to the Mac Breast Group. You have found a great place at a tough time. Although breastcancer.org is a good site it is USA based - I'm sure when recommending breast cancer sites it is Macmillan and BreastCancerCare which are both UK based are top of the list. It's easy to get BCC and BC-org mixed up but treatment in the usa can vary a lot compared to what is given here. This is all very new, scary and a sharp learning curve for you at the moment. Treatment for BC has come a long way even over the last few years and it has one of the highest recovery rates (currently around 90%) There are a lot of members here who are years past treatment and stick around to help those newly diagnosed to hopefully ease your worries and provide honest answers. Take care and good luck with your results, G n' J
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed and terrified.

Posts.Content: Hi Gina, My better half (Jackie) was diagnosed May 2012 - She had surgery first (mastectomy) then over the course of a year they chucked everything at her to give her the best possible prognosis. Chemo, Herceptin (targeted therapy) Radiotherapy and 5 years of tablets, which she is just over halfway through. We were exactly the same as you at the start, fearful for the future and our world seemed to be imploding. You can't live like that so after the dust settles and you get your treatment plan it all becomes so much clearer and you can get on with 'stuff' a lot better. She had her 3 year review a couple of months back, the results came back 'No Evidence of Disease'  Woo-Hoo! There's no easy way about it, the treatment can be physically and emotionally tough at times but you get there, mainly because you have to, but once the results are in and they take the brakes off your life revolves around appointments for just about everything the time goes very quickly. You get off the Runaway Mine Cart Ride battered and bruised but back into the sunshine and living the new normal. Take it all one step at a time and with the support of your family and this lovely bunch of misfits, you'll do just fine :-) A good sense of humour is needed as much as a positive attitude (whatever that really means) you will see from some of the posts here, we all seem as mad as a box of frogs but it helps deal with the treatment baggage. Best wishes Gina, G n' J
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed and terrified.

Posts.Content: Hi  Lynne,  Sounds like a touch of peripheral neuropathy to me. Probably down to the Tax, (the gift that keeps on giving). Macmillan have an info page about it - I'll paste the link in at the bottom. Have you mentioned it to your onco team ? as I'm sure they will offer some help. Jackie had this also in fingers and toes it gradually inproved but takes a while post chemo for the nerve damage to repair itself. Finished chemo way back in Nov and only her big toes still have a very minor numbness. She did lose all 20 nails though, so perhaps hers were worse affected than yours are They were persistent about being careful regarding nerve damage as it may lead to burning your fingers / hands if you cannot feel how hot things really are like hot tap water, getting things from hot ovens etc Hope the link helps, if it's not clickable just copy paste it into your browser.   http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Livingwithandaftercancer/Lifeaftercancer/Lateeffectsbreast/Possiblelateeffects/Peripheralneuropathy.aspx Best wishes,  George & Jackie.

Posts.Title: A big step today

Posts.Content: Afternoon R, An SNB (Sentinel Node Biopsy) is carried out to see if any lymph nodes are affected by any cancer cells - Have they told you this is what you are having along with your mastectomy ? If yes, you can read about an SNB here. It is where they inject a blue dye as a tracer and take 2 or 3 nodes nearest the tumour to check for cancer cells. but if you say they already know from the underarm biopsy your your lymph nodes are affected they may well remove all of them what they term as a node, or axillary clearance. These are thoroughly checked alongside the breast tissue in the pathology lab to see how many are affected. Has anyone actually told you which one you are having ? G n' J
Posts.Title: what is sentinal node biopsy?

Posts.Content: Hiya toxophilite Well there I was sound asleep (alright for some) and out of nowhere this arrow hits me in the arm :) Relax WhatHappened it's the old Grade vs Stage confusion thing - Your M doesn't mean mets. The differences are TNM (is for stage) and TPM (is used for grade) TNM is used to describe the STAGE of cancer. T stands for tumour N for node involvement M for metastases However, the GRADE is defined by using TPM. Tubule Formation = T Nuclear Pleomorphism = P Mitosis Count = M That's about the description of the cells and how much they look different to normal body cells. Each category is scored 1, 2 or 3. Tubule Formation (% of Carcinoma composed of tubular structures like a normal cell) Score: over 75%  = 1 10-75%  = 2 less than 10%  = 3 Pleomorphism (Change in cells)  Score: Small, uniform cells  = 1 Moderate increase in size and variation  = 2 Marked variation  = 3 Mitosis Count (Cell division)  Score Totals: Up to 7  = 1 8 to 14  = 2 15 or more  = 3 Add the three scores together TPM - If you score 8 or 9 you are classed as Grade 3 6 or 7 is grade 2 Yours adds up to 2+2+1 = 5 so that is why it is grade 1 Relax and enjoy your breakfast :)) Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Ruby Rock, Bit late but welcome to the breast group.... A great place at a tough time! Micro-calcifications in themselves are quite common and although not cancerous they can be a pre-cancerous condition - Hence the biopsies. There is some info about Calcification both here at Macmillan and also at Breast Cancer Care so you can use both these links to have a read if you haven't been given much info about them. Understandable you are worried, but hope for the best rather than fearing the worst. Best wishes for something positive from your results appointment, but if your fears are confirmed chances are whatever it is as you mention has been found early. Keep posting during this (what seems a lifetime) waiting results period you sound like you could do with some reassurances from us misfits :-) Good luck, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Luceylocket, Yes that is one massive list, you did well to actually reach the A's  :)   The actual Macmillan Community has been going for around ten years now and has so many new members joining daily (Macmillan as a cancer charity was started way back in 1911) and has built over 100 cancer centres throughout the country. Our local hospital cancer unit was funded and built by Macmillan too, that's why we help out here. A huge percentage of those community members will be no longer active but the accounts are kept open for those who need to return, be it for those who are diagnosed with secondaries or recurrence, bereavement or cancer being diagnosed in other family members etc. When you think of all the other cancer type specific charities worldwide as well, it makes you realise just how many get affected by this damn disease :( Definitely good to talk...  G n' J
Posts.Title: You are not alone

Posts.Content: Hi MonaLisa, As you are HER2- negative I think you fall into the realms of being eligible for the Oncotype-DX Test (link) which has finally been approved by NICE. Has your oncologist mentioned this test for you. It determines the % rate of recurrence risk between having or not having chemotherapy. Obviously those who are HER2+ have to have chemo to get the Herceptin so it doesn't apply, but in your case I'm sure you qualify for this test. It used to be done privately at a tad over £2k but can now be done through the NHS Personally considering as you opted out of axillary clearance of nodes I would either try and get the oncotype test done if they will allow it for you. I think the results take around 10-14 days to come through. Having surgery and getting cancerous tumours removed is the first step in being cancer free, all the other treatments are insurance to try and keep you that way. Last thing you want is to turn chemo down to find it bites you in the bum in a few years :-( These meds folk shouldn't put patients into this position, they understand enough about your diagnosis to make that choice, we don't and it's almost impossible to find reliable up to date enough information to make informed decisions about something so important. Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY

Posts.Content: Hi one n' all, There are new guidelines published by NHS England that restricts the issue of items on prescription that can be prescribed by GPs if they can be purchased over the counter. THE GUIDANCE IS NOT MANDATORY  Local CCG's across the country could interpret the guidance differently - the postcode lottery - if you get Free Prescriptions using your Exemption Card they should be continued to be prescribed as most suffer from some form of long term cancer treatment side effects. You should speak to your GP and have it confirmed that the practice will continue to prescribe as usual if you are recieving meds for any of the conditions listed below...... Conditions included on their 'hit list' are Mouth Ulcers, Oral Thrush, Dry/Sore Eyes, Diarrhoea, Infrequent Constipation etc Hopefully your GP's common sense will prevail making these meds still available via free prescription exemption cards to you, but it won't stop some pharmacists from meddling :-/ Just don't get me started on ® Registered Drugs vs Generics  lol Take Care, G n' J

There is more info about Herceptin Biosimilars at the US BreastCancer.Org website, as they tend to be more open with data than the UK sites. You can read the BreastCancer.Org article clicking here. It also contains some trial figures from a 3 arm trial using Herceptin and a Biosimilar. It would be interesting to find out if anyone here has been given the biosimilar herceptin as you would assume the patient would be informed they would not be getting the original (or would they) ? Posts.Content: Hi Hazey,  It could well be the Tamoxifen - It's early days as yet allow your body a little more time to get used to them and you should find the headache eases and goes away.  Jackie had the same with Letrozole and the muzzy head cleared up after about three weeks. If it doesn't you could ask your gp or pharmacy for a different brand, it can help, but sometimes you are just swapping one lot of side effects for another set  :-( Unfortunately all these pesky hormone tablets come with baggage - you end up taking tablets to counter the side effects of the side effect tablets and start rattling when you walk  :-) How did you get on with your consultant about your concerns with that 'lump' you mentioned earlier ? Best wishes, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Headaches on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Ho oliviaruby  Yes both you and Croxley are right. Fluoxetene had contraindications with both Tamoxifen and Docetaxel because it contains an enzyme which inhibits the effectiveness of both tamoxifen and docetaxel. Taken from EMC drugs database - Tamoxifen: Fluoxetine, a potent inhibitor of CYP2D6, may lead to reduced concentrations of endoxifen, one of the most important active metabolites of tamoxifen. Therefore, fluoxetine should whenever possible be avoided during tamoxifen treatment (see section 4.5). Anti-depressants are often given as a type of pain relief. J is taking Amitriptyline for letrozole bone/joint ache side effects. Assume it is ok to have these before you need either of the above - you could ask how long you need to be 'off' Fluoxetene to get it out of your system before having T though ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Now I know.....

Posts.Content: Hiya Shaz, Like Susie says, age doesn't come into deciding if you need chemo and rads as a high priority. It all depends on how aggressive, size of tumour, type of breast cancer etc. Jackie was diagnosed at 56 and had mastectomy, chemo, rads and herceptin and is now on Letrozole for 5 years being diagnosed as ER+ PR+ HER2+ The underlying facts with younger ladies who get a BC diagnosis is because the breast tissue is denser in younger women it may not be picked up so easily by mammograms, ultrasound is far better and also if ER+ positive the Oestrogen produced by your ovaries may have been feeding the cancer cells. Which could explain why one of your tumours is large. Regarding Friday - Will this be the first time your lymph nodes have been needle biopsied or is this what they call a sentinel node biopsy (SNLB) ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning Sarah,  This choice question comes up quite a bit and it is a tough, very personal choice to have to make. You don't mention what stage your tumour was, so the 'aggressiveness' of that should also be taken into consideration. All the considerations you mention just muddy the water when trying to decide. Yes, chemo and the side effects can be tough, and yes if you decide to have it you will know you did all you could to avoid re-occurance but if you did decline chemo and heaven forbid it came back you would be wracked with guilt for your children and kicking yourself for declining it. Until you get some other replies, here's a couple of links to posts where this has been discussed before Post Thread One - Post Thread Two. Some members went for it, some didn't. Not a lot of help for your decision I know, but it gives you others views. Hope this helps, take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Help with hair thinning

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy-B I'm wondering if it is your head position while on the table -  Do you get the same feeling by tilting your head the same way at home ? Could be a type of Vertigo called Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo or BPPV  Did you get any dizziness prior to rads ? or maybe it was placing your head at an unusual angle has caused some of the crystals in your inner ear to move into a different area upsetting your balance. J had this for about a week and was hanging onto the walls trying to walk a straight line, room spinning while laying in bed etc She was given the EPLEY manouvere by her GP and it moved the crystals back to where they should be and it never returned. Do check this out with your Radiology unit as it may take a while to get a quick GP appointment. G n' J
Posts.Title: Dizziness

Posts.Content: Morning Shaz, It is all a bit of a guessing game to start with as they have limited information from just biopsies. It is different if you have surgery before chemo because the full diagnosis from removed tissue comes through from histology a lot quicker. Most diagnosed with BC get radiotherapy either just to the breast area but also the underarm lymph area if they find there are any affected nodes there (even if only a few cells are found)  As Julie mentions have you been informed about chemo prior to surgery to shrink tumours down or are you still in the scary land of the unknown about most of it ? If you are found to be HER2+ positive (around 1 in 5 are) you will need Herceptin and this is always given in conjunction with chemo. It isn't as effective if given on it's own, so NICE don't fund it to be used this way. Did you have your nodes checked last Friday or is it this Friday coming ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Phew!  That sort of explains why a bit. If you are already taking some form of Biphosphonate it overules the need for the dexa scan.  I assumed they had just dropped the Letrozole onto you without taking any osteopeania into consideration.  It was the Activis company that Accord took over quite a few ladies here have Accord as their brand of choice, so seems to be one of the better brands regarding side effects. If anything has changed it may be just the E numbers used in the coating ? It is tough when you have cancer treatment related issues causing conflict at work. J struggled as her job entailed lots of manual handling, walking corridors and using stairs. She never got past the 16 hours a week phased return stage and eventually had to leave a job she loved. We jiggled our finances around to get around the loss of income, made some lifestyle changes and have never looked back. Think the hardest thing to come to terms with if when you realise that changes may have to be made but can't see a way to easily fix it :( Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Awake and upset

Posts.Content: Morning Linmo Seeing as you are on Letrozole have you had a Dexa Bone Density Scan recently to see if you are more osteopaenic now ? J had hip issues with letrozole and GP referred her to physio sessions under the Hip Pain Pathway - must admit they did little to help and the physio sessions were a bit painful. She finished her 5 years of letrozole back in May, still has some hip pain and uses a stick if going out involves a fair bit of walking. Prior to the physio sessions she was taking paracetamol and Ibuprofen, then onto co-codamol for a short while - Came off those and was placed on Meloxicam and Amitriptyline which did help ease the hip pain to some extent. J was never offered a steroid injection, so cannot say if that would have helped. Fingers crossed your jab will help, G n' J
Posts.Title: Awake and upset

Posts.Content: Hiya Linmo That is bad of them :( Everyone who is placed onto Letrozole or Anastrozole should be given a Dexa bone density scan first (or early on) to get base level figures of their bone density. Another scan 6-9 months in to see if there has been any change and calcium boosting meds prescribed if needed. Whoever told you you will ony get one AFTER 5 years of being on them is talking rubbish..... There is more info about bone health Aromatase Inhibitors (letro and anastro) on the BCC site here (link) See Aromatse Inhibitors and how is osteoporosis diagnosed about halfway down the page. I find it hard to understand why with all your hip pain and being on Letrozole why the most obvious Dexa Scan option wasn't offered :(  See your GP and get them to arrange a dexa scan for you. This may need referring to a private unit as not all hospitals have a dexa scanner. It only takes around 15-20 minutes and is painless. My wife after her 6 month dexa scan was given Adcal+ Vit D daily and an alendronic acid tablet (one a week) to counter bone loss. What brand of Letrozole are you taking by the way ? as some have found just changing 'brands' helps. Hugs, G n' J

Jackie has been on Letrozole for just over 3 1/2 years and had this for the first year or so but it hasn't got any worse since.  Her hair was quite thick to start with (post chemo growth) so isn't so noticeable. Maybe other ladies here who have had similar thinning issues can offer some advice about anything they did to help with this. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Books on breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi  Cazza,  I wanna jump in here too, being a bloke and seeing things from the "other side" I cannot understand how he took this route unless he felt there were cracks appearing beforehand ? All I can say is that from the initial diagnosis all I wanted to do was help wherever I could and be a wet shoulder, punchbag, rock, huggybear, taxi, and chemo buddy .  Sure it seemed that this invader was taking over our lives and it was running out of control but we got our heads around it and took the ride a day at a time. It's bad enough being a bloke trying to figure out what to buy for birthdays and christmas pressie's this bloody BC gave me the chance to show how much I cared and brought us a lot closer together. Sorry, I don't buy the "being a breast cancer husband so stressful i'll escape by having an affair " idea i'm afraid. That must seem as the ultimate insult just as you have lost a boob and feeling pretty crap about self esteem and reconstruction issues.. The easiest thing to do is "just be there" for your wife/partner "who really does have all the stress" and it's our remit to try and ease that as much as possible. I know a lot of blokes have the "out of sight out of mind-put it on the back burner" train of thought but it's def not the time when someone you love is going through any form of cancer. Even if in denial you cannot turn and run away, you have to face up to it as a team.  I really feel for those who have to take this crap journey on their own, it must be a lonely nightmare, but when you have a husband/partner and are still expected to mostly do it alone is cruel beyond belief. There's a saying along the lines of "The way people treat you is a statement of who "they are" as a human being - It's not a statement about "how you are" as a person"   Although hard, try not to stress, what will be will be, if he feels he cannot face the future, you may part, if it he is really sorry and has deep regret and you can forgive it may be repairable but the trust you had will never be the same :-( Really hope things work out for you, you must feel you have your own black cloud at the mo. George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Unfaithful husband

Posts.Content: Hi dl99  Lovely to read you have some more boxes ticked off - Hope you post op recovery is speedy and hassle free. Some ladies do get leg / hip aches from the sub-cut Herceptin while others just get the drippy nose thing happening so it may not be as bad as you are expecting. Are you taking any meds to help with the phlebitis or just using pain relief and/or heat pads ? G n' J
Posts.Title: journey update

Posts.Content: Morning Edwina  / taralou Tricky one really, as there are so many options to try and rule out as being the cause. Assume the arm is the same side as was used for chemo or is it surgery side?  Could be chemo damaged the arm veins and the ZA is somehow making this worse, or if surgery side nerve damage from any removed armpit lymph nodes.  It is possible this is still peripheral neuropathy as it can take ages (up to a year) for most of the chemo baggage to ease off and some can become more permanent. J still has numb big toes from over 5 years back. Whatever this is, it sounds very much like the ZA is aggravating it, may be worth asking if there any other of the bisphosphonates you could have instead ? J was taking one Alendronic tablet (70mg) per week for 5 years while on Letrozole, so didn't have the ZA infusion. Have you tried using a hot water bottle or one of those microwaveable wheat packs to see if it eases the pain ? Not much help really, but hopefully someone else here will have had exactly the same experience with ZA and can pass on some advice. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Zoledronic Acid Infusion???

Posts.Content: Hi abigail1607  That's what everyone here wants to read and to know all the rubbish you have to go through can end with a crock of gold at the end of the rainbow :) Hugs and Best Wishes, G n' J
Posts.Title: Cancer free

Posts.Content: Hi,  i'm just bumping this topic which was started by lemongrove to give it the attention it deserves. I saw a documentary about the Cyberknife awhile back. Despite the name no surgery is involved. Fantastic piece of kit delivering all your radiotherapy sessions in one hit with pinpoint accuracy. Imagine what around 100 zaps all at once can do to any cancer cells in a 1cm square area. I have just signed the petition and sent requests to a lot of our facebook friends. This petition needs quite a lot of votes so please look it up at cyberknife dot com and prepare to be amazed. I hope posting the link is not breaking forum rules, but this shows a great future for radiotherapy treatment.  Regards,  George. http://www.causes.com/causes/795457-fund-cyberknife-stereotactic-radiotherapy-treatment-now-uk/actions/1689583?causes_ref=email&template=activity_mailer%2Fcustom_activity_mail&utm_campaign=custom_activity_email&utm_medium=email&utm_source=causes

Posts.Content: Evening Daphne, So sorry to read about your recent results and the other breast now being affected. There are a couple of members here who have had a bilateral mastectomy with or without reconstructions, so I'm hoping some will reply with their experiences of how they made the decision and how it went for them. I'm thinking along the lines of what you mentioned about a lumpectomy, if they couldn't get clear margins and you had to go back in for second surgery it would heartbreaking. Just a thought - Is there, or has there been any history of breast or ovarian cancer with your immediate relatives ? Grandparents, aunts etc... If so wondering if it is worth asking about having a brca gene test carried out ? If you feel like having a rant here to unload please do, you must be emotionally all over the place having that news dropped on you. Good luck, G n' J

Posts.Content: Wendy, Fretting about every little twinge or ache is something you have to accept but put on the back burner or the constant worries will stop you enjoying getting used to your new normal having some fun now you are free of this millstone. Kargus, I can only assume that Wendy's secret is not being on any hormone tablets - I think Wendy may be ER- negative so doesn't have to put up with the side effects of these pesky tablets for 5 years plus ? Very common side effect of Letrozole (and all the other hormone therapy type tablets) is weight gain, so you are probably fighting a losing battle to not gain 2 dress sizes while taking them -Jackie is the same, about halfway through her 5 years worth and has given up and just accepted this will be her for another 30 months :-( There is a fuller explanation as to why here. Posts.Title: Lymph node recurrence after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey, This sounds like the Peripheral Neuropathy mentioned above by LondonLass, but if this is as painful as you say, it could also be what they call PPE (Palmar Plantar) Both these effects are due to the Docetaxel (the T part of FEC-T) it can come on even up to 6 months after your chemo sessions have ended. If you have a look at the links you could figure out which one it seems to be and use the what will help sections to try and ease this. Whichever one it is friction makes this condition worse. So try to be careful with things like walking up and down hills and staircases trying to walk flat footed rather than just having the balls of your feet taking all the weight, and to help your hands getting affected get help or one of those gadgets to undo bottle and jar lids (worse thing you can do is use an unscrewing action) Do keep a close eye on this as it can get worse before it gets better :( Take care, G n' J Tray41
Posts.Title: Side effects of fec-t on feet and body

Posts.Content: Hi Nic, Great you are getting this checked out....Like Sianikb said it is not age related there are a couple ladies been here aged 23. Also great is that they are giving you an ultrasound scan check, don't be fobbed off with just a mammogram as the tissue in younger women's breast is a lot denser and mammograms are not so accurate for this type of tissue. Be prepared for them taking very small needle biopsy samples if they do spot anything they feel needs checking out further but not alarmed at this either. Just because they spot something doesn't automatically mean cancer. Blocked milk ducts, calcification, cysts and benign lumps will show up too. I'm putting in the link to Macmillan Breast Page if you click the green text link and check it out. For info  about ultrasound and biopsy select the diagnosis button. Jackie's first symptom was a nipple that started to invert slightly so it can be a sign, have both your nipples always been inverted or is this something that has happened over time ? It is very rare to get it in both breasts at the same time.... You say you are not worried yet, but this may change if they take biopsy samples and you enter a waiting results stage which can really mess with your head, some centres can let you know same day, others can take up to 2 weeks :-( Depends on how big their centre is and what facilities they have and depends on the types of checks and tests they carry out on the tissue. Hopefully it will be confirmed to be nothing dodgy, but do keep posting any questions and concerns you have Nic, we're all here to help. Take care and good luck, George & Jackie

It may encourage anyone else who has 'the urge' to take up crafting of some sort to help themselves get through this Breast Cancer malarky. You can read Rachel's feature blog here and there is a link to her sew I have cancer blog and a chance to see the lovely 'BagsfromtheForest' she produces on Etsy. High Five Rachel, G n' J
Posts.Title: Moonbat's 'Shed Therapy' Featured as Community Blog

Posts.Content: Hi Radwoman,  Think I can figure this out. It looks like the score they give cells when they are examined under the  microscope to give the  grade. There is a huge dif between TNM (Stage) and TPM (is for grade) TNM is used to describe the STAGE of cancer. T stands for tumour N for node involvement M for metastases However, the GRADE is defined on by using TPN. Tubule Formation = T Nuclear Pleomorphism = P Mitosis Count = M That's about the description of the cells and how much they look different to normal body cells. Each category is scored 1, 2 or 3. Tubule Formation (% of Carcinoma composed of tubular structures like a normal cell) Score: over 75% 1 10-75% 2 less than 10% 3 Nuclear Pleomorphism (Change in cells)  Score: Small, uniform cells 1 Moderate increase in size and variation 2 Marked variation 3 Mitosis Count (Cell division)  Score: Up to 7 1 8 to 14 2 15 or more 3 If you score 8 or 9 you are classed as Grade 3. So you scored 3 in the first 2 categories and 2 in the last category, your total is 8 which is Grade 3. Hope this is near enough correct, as I'm not medically trained. Just picked up lots of 'stuff' on the way :-)   It's your body if you want it all clarified do ask them to explain it. Regarding Stage, what type of breast cancer were you diagnosed with ? This may help a bit too 'Understanding Your Pathology Report' G n' J
Posts.Title: Understanding Breast Cancer Staging problem

Posts.Content: Morning Bowbelle  Unfortunately nothing could be further from the truth :( The letrozole 'drug' part is obviously the same but that only makes up 2.5mg of the tablet and various other fillers are used to bulk the tablet up to a convenient size - These fillers are not stanardised and it's these variations which can cause so many problems finding a particular brand which works best for you. There is a lengthy discussion started about a month ago which you can fine here (link) which may be worth you having a read through. You don't mention which 'brand' you are taking at the moment but there are at least 8 generic brands of Letrozole besides the original Femara make. Water retention is a listed side effect of Letrozole, are you taking any Diuretic tablets to help with that - and it's those causing you to visit the loo so many times during the night ? Hope this is of some help, G n' J

Posts.Title: Breast cancer drugs stopped by Mr Cameron

Posts.Content: Hiya Lucy, You are not alone, we all get these 'what if' feelings when treatment ends, it's a bit like when you were a kid learning to ride a bike and they take the stabiliser wheels off. You are all a bit wobbly and unsure about how it will end up. Does it all work out and you pedal off into the sunset or crash into a ditch. Only thing you can do is box up all your worries tape it down well and shove it right to the back of your mind hopefully never to be opened again. You can't live the rest of your life fearing the worst it will stop you enjoying the new life you have been given. It may not seem much of a life compared to the old one you were living and loving with both boobs and no cancer worries but that Lucy has gone now and been replaced by an upgraded version who is a bit battered and bruised but minus the cancer but is struggling to accept her second chance ? You may find this a good read - After The Treatment Finishes - Then What? by Dr Peter Harvey. This is a free read, just click the link. It starts a bit slow but bear with it, it does make sense and can help you understand what the hell just happened. Hope this helps a bit, take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Finding the uncertainty unbearable at times

Posts.Content: Evening Butterflybaby  Warm welcome to the breast group there are loads of ladies here some of which who are having, or have had the 12 weeks of Taxol (Paclitaxel) and can reply to advise and support you :) Would be better to not look that far ahead as yet though and just concentrate on the 9 weeks of EC first. The E part makes your pee pink for a day or so so don't go thinking this is blood in your urine. Hope you are recovering well from your surgery ? - mastectomy with immediate DIEP can be a tough call for a while. Best place for chemo discussions is our regular monthly chemo club. This group is so large it has it's own - You can find Junes Chemo Club here posted by Julia (crystaljuju) Good luck with the Paxman do be prepared for the 'ice cream' headache without the Haagen-Dazs :( Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: June 2017 Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi clover3  My wife was HER2+ Positive and had exactly the same treatment 3 x FEC 3 x T Herceptin and Rads. The T part may be tough some days as it can cause aching bones between days 4 and 10 so sis may need more reassurance this is do'able - Once the T (docetaxel) part is out of the way the path doesn't seem to be so rocky. Good news is there is hardly any of the nausea with T. J just had her 5 year clear review as she was diagnosed May 2012.  Treatment can be tough, it has a tough job to do. The end may seem a long way off but it works and the sessions soon get ticked off - tell sis she is almost halfway though it's like wading through mud but she can do this... Hope this helps, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi clover3  I wish our lawn was  :) Yes she had a left side mastectomy surgery prior to chemo which was started about 3 weeks later for 18 weeks then 18 x Herceptin but back then it wasn't an injection - they used to use the pump and bag method same as for chemo. Have you checked out the July or August Chemo Club discussion in the main breast group ? There are some chemo aid tips in the first message each month. G n' J

Posts.Content: Evening  Binny, I not long ago posted a link in a reply about bone scans to Stoksie's thread "Bone Scan"    I'll put the same cancer research link in at the bottom. If you look at todays previous posts you will find her question. This may well be a look and check out scan for them to see if you are getting bone / joint pain from osteoporosis caused by the Tamoxifen or radiotherapy damage. If it's a four hour scan it'll be the scan they perform at the Nuclear Medicine radiology dept where they inject you with a low dosage isotope give it a few hours to get into your bones then scan for bone damage. Not going to sugar coat this but unfortunately it is also the same type of scan they use to detect bone mets damage. We're not going there yet it's way too early to tell............ So tell the fear and panic to bugger off. http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/cancer-help/about-cancer/tests/bone-scan Everything crossed for you next week Binny, you take care, Hugs,  George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Mouth ulcers

Posts.Content: Hi Rosiero, Readings above 90/60 and below 120/80 indicate that the pressure in your arteries is considered normal for most adults - so 105/75 falls well within this. It probably is chemo related but I'm not medically trained so can't advise further than that. All I can suggest is maybe see how you feel in the morning if nothing has changed get the dizziness checked out. Jackie got Labyrinthitis during chemo and her dizziness got quite bad and she still gets bouts of it now and again 2 years on. I don't think that is a common side effect though. G n' J
Posts.Title: 2 fec feeling dizzy

Posts.Content: Hi Larner   Femara is the brand name of the original registered founder of Letrozole, which is Novartis (and still by far the dearest) Letrozole is the name of the main drug. When other companies were allowed to make Letrozole tablets they had to make it under their own brand name. So only Femara is the original make, the others are generic brands. These other brands are a lot cheaper, so they are the more common ones placed onto your repeat. There is a bit more to it regarding different 'fillers and coatings' used between brands but the drug content is near enough the same. If you think of it like if it says letrozole on your repeat prescription you can be offered any brand of letrozole, but if it says Femara you should get that only. G n' J Edit - As you have found out Sandoz is the generic drugs section of Novartis the owner of Femara®  :)
Posts.Title: Letrozole..... Femara brand

Posts.Content: Hiya tej,  These are classic side effects of both your meds. The Avastin / Bevacizumab can raise your blood pressure slightly which can lead to slight random nose bleeds and/or a bit of a runny nose. As for the numb, tingling fingers and toes these symptoms are caused by the effect of Paclitaxel / Taxol on nerves. It’s called peripheral neuropathy. You may also find it hard to fasten buttons or do other fiddly tasks. Tell your onco doctor about both these symptoms. They sometimes need to lower the dose of the drug. The symptoms usually improve slowly after treatment finishes but in some people they may never fully go away. Another quick point worth mentioning is if you have numb fingers be careful with hot water as it may be hotter than you are feeling it to be to avoid scalding and if the tingling starts getting painful do ask about help with this early on, as this can get quite bad if left even to the extent of having problems walking. You can help your hands and feet by reducing friction which can make it worse. Take care walking up and down stairs or hills and be careful using your hands / fingers in a twisting motion like undoing bottle or jar tops, using screwdrivers etc Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: numbness in fingers and toes

Posts.Content: Hiya Amanda865 The numbness you refer to is probably nerve damage caused during surgery, it can repair itself to a certain level but commonly leaves you with some nerve 'baggage' The lumpiness sounds like scar tissue especially if this seems to be tightening as time progresses; but this may also be a touch of AWS more commonly called Cording. Is this just in the armpit area, or has spread down the arm at all ? Could well be worth contacting your breast care nurse and asking about this as it may just need some physio to help loosen things up a little. G n' J

Posts.Title: Any advice for mastectomy op?

Posts.Content: Hiya, That is not a very professional attitude. Seems like the appointment was for their benefit more than yours :( Did you ever get a copy of your post surgery pathology report and know anything about your diagnosis apart from it being DCIS ? (grade / stage, any nodes involved, hormone level figures etc) What you are feeling at the end of treatment is totally normal, you get a little lost when you lose your security blanket. You are certainly not alone in worrying about the what if's you just sort of learn to not let it get in the way of getting back to the new normal. Don't miss today's sunshine worrying about tomorrows rain - it may stay sunny..... G n' J

Posted by Dreamthief
2 Mar 2016 3:40 PM

Hi Dulcie,

Don't know when you start your AI's but they were the game changer for Jackie.

Up to then she had got through Surgery, Chemo, Rads, Herceptin etc but the accumulative baggage from the Letrozole (Fermara) brought about her having to leave work.

She was placed onto Anastrozole for a while and those seemed worse, so went back to Femara. Her work entailed a lot of stair climbing and corridor walking and it all got too much for her legs and hips.  She seriously considered coming off them but being HER2+ & ER/PR+ and a higher % of recurrence without the AI's as back up had little choice but to stay on them until her 5 years is up. Now takes pain relief and calcium meds and uses a stick if walking any distance :(

Until you are on these tablets for a few months you won't know how bad (or not) they will affect you and how that may impact on your work life balance ?

That's us now 'church mice' but much prefer being hard up and happy, to having it all work and no play.

G n' J

Posted by Crystaljuju
2 Mar 2016 3:50 PM

To be fair Dulcie, to move on from this it wont help you to know what your life term survival is. The trick is to move on like its never going to happen again otherwise you live in fear and that will prevent you from moving on well and living. 

You can use the NHS predict tool that  will give you a five year and ten year outlook. My outlook was in the late 80 early 90% but I live life knowing at the moment I am in remission and living for the here and now works for me. 

You could start by looking at if you can realistically work less rather than retire at all but then if you can live being poor than retire now. I was all for retiring after my diagnosis but quickly realized at 41 years that wasn't realistic. I have reduced my hours and have a healthier work life balance.

None of us know what will get us eventually But  it probably won't be cancer. 

Julia x 

Cancer may start the fight but you can finish it

Posted by June_H
3 Mar 2016 9:02 AM

When I had my last consultation following surgery,chemo,rads and herceptin I actually asked the oncologist about the future

I do not know if she used the NHS predict tool or something more specific but like Julia was given an 88-91% success rate and also told that 5 of the remaining who did not survive were affected by illness or events not related to cancer

Also like Julia I live in the moment and have just had my 4 year all clear yesterday 

I am happy to be a NEDDY as I know the word cured is not used. I am working full time and sometimes struggling with Anastrozole and the joint pain but determined to continue and have this control; 

When you are in the middle of this then things seem really uncertain and when treatment stops there are concerns about recurrence etc

However many and most all survive and it is important to hang on to this 

Good Luck

June
