Posts.Title: Survival rates, life expectancy ? Do they give you an idea / guess...

Posts.Content: Given this old nugget a fresh dusting, fully updated it - and reposting again :) Alphabetical cross referenced list of anything and everything Breast related (click any green text)  Please Click 'Save to My Favourites' under Discussion Tools to save this to your profile page favourites. All links are to reliable Macmillan, NHS, Breastcancercare, CRUK etc support sites. ================================================================ A Ablation (Ovarian) Stopping the ovaries from producing hormones by surgery or other means such as hormone therapy or radiotherapy. Used for pre menopausal patients who are Oestrogen (ER+) positive. Abraxane Nab-Paclitaxel A chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer that has spread to other parts of the body. Abraxane is an Albumin Bound version of standard Paclitaxel which is solvent based. AC chemotherapy A chemo combo using Adriamycin (also known as doxorubicin) and cyclophosphamide.  AC chemo Adjuvant Treatment given in addition to other treatments, for example chemotherapy or radiotherapy given as well as surgery but usually when referring to surgery first, then other treatments post surgery. Adriamycin see Doxorubicin Advanced breast cancer Breast cancer that has spread beyond the breast and the lymph nodes under the arm to other parts of the body, also known as secondary, stage 4 or metastatic breast cancer. See also Locally advanced regional recurrance. Afinitor is a kinase inhibitor given as either Everolimius or Afinitor. In tablet form can be used along with Exemestane (Aromasin) for patients with breast cancer that has spread. Ai See Aromatase Inhibitors   (Letrozole, Anastrozole, Exemestane) Usually given post menopause if ER+/PR+ Alendronic Acid (Fosamax) A Bisphosphonate drug used to counter osteo related issues from cancer treatments. ALH Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia. Cells in the lobules that look different to normal cells, but aren't cancer but contain more cells than there should be. Anaemia Usually develops from lack of haemoglobin in red blood cells and can be caused by chemotherapy treatments which also brings about fatigue. Anastrozole A hormone therapy and one of a group of drugs called aromatase inhibitors. It may be known by different brand names, the most well-known being Arimidex. ALND Axillary node dissection. Surgically removing a node/s. See Axillary dissection / clearance Anthracyclines A group of chemotherapy drugs commonly used to treat breast cancer. Examples include doxorubicin (also known as Adriamycin) and epirubicin. Anti-Sickness / Anti-emetics Drugs used to reduce nausea or vomiting  Odansetron, Domperidome or the newer Emend. Usually given in conjunction with Steroids during chemotherapy. More information on anti sickness drugs at Cancer Research site. Arimidex see Anastrozole Aromasin see Exemestane Aromatase Inhibitors (AI's) Main hormonal Inhibitor therapy used in post menopausal women. Arthralgia Pain in the joints see also general (Joint Pain) Ascites Too much fluid in between the two layers of the peritoneum, which lines the inside of the abdomen. It is a symptom of cancer and other conditions such as liver disease. Ascites Aspiration Using a syringe to remove fluid. For instance draining a Seroma. Avastin  is one of the drugs grouped as monoclonal antibodies see Bevacizumab AWS Axillary Web Syndrome. Associated with cording after surgery or rads. See Cording Axilla Under the arm, the armpit (lymphs) Axillary clearance An operation to remove all lymph glands from under the arm (axilla) Axillary dissection An operation to remove some of the lymph glands from under the arm (axilla). See Sentinel Node biopsy. B BC Breast Cancer - Macmillan Main Information Page BCS Breast conserving surgery. See Lumpectomy or WLE Bevacizumab A targeted therapy, also known as Avastin. It works by inhibiting the ability of the cancer cells to develop their own blood supply, known as angiogenesis this can help to stop the cancer from growing. Benign Not cancerous. Bilateral (or Bi-Lat) Affecting or about both the right and left sides of body. For example, a bilateral mastectomy is removal of both breasts. Options for women at risk of BC Biological therapies Also know as Targeted Therapies for example Herceptin. Biopsy Removal of tissue to be examined under a microscope. Biopsy info at BCC breast clinic appointment. Bisphosphonates  Range of drugs that can be given to protect your bones from cancer or the effects of some cancer treatments. Typically Alendronic, Zoledronic and Ibandronic Acids -  Clodronate and Pamidronate. Some are in tablet form, others injected. BIRADS Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System score. Indicator of radiologists opinion of the absence or likelihood of breast cancer. BM(x) Bilateral Mastectomy (removal of both breasts) Blood count The numbers of red and white blood cells and platelets in a sample of blood. Bone metastases Also known as secondary cancer in the bone. Cancer cells that have spread from the first cancer site, such as the breast, and are growing in the bones. Bone Health Information about drugs to treat  'Osteo' problems caused by cancer treatments. Bone or Nuclear Medicine Scan.  Used to assess any increase or breakdown in bone growth. It can help identify changes, such as injury or healing, or disease such as cancer. Also used to check for secondaries. This is not to be confused with a Dexa scan - NHS link BRCA1  An altered or faulty gene passed on at birth from either parent that causes a permanent change in a person’s DNA. People who inherit an altered BRCA1 gene have a much higher risk of developing ovarian cancer and some other cancers compared with the general population. BRCA  Beginners Guide to BRCA 1 & 2  Royal Marsden Booklet. BRCA2  An altered or faulty gene passed on at birth from either parent that causes a permanent change in a person’s DNA. People who inherit an altered BRCA2 gene have a much higher risk of developing breast cancer and some other cancers compared with the general population. Breast calcification Areas of calcium deposit in one or both of the breasts. Calcification Breast care nurse (BCN) Trained to provide information and support to anyone diagnosed with breast cancer. Breast-conserving surgery (also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy)  The removal of the cancer with a margin (border) of normal breast tissue around it. Breast Reconstruction See Macmillan Booklet covering all aspects and types of reconstruction. Breast Screening (for those under 50) Use of digital mammograms and family history influences. C Calcification Calcium salts specks that can be seen on a mammogram benign but can be a pre-cancerous indicator. If calcifications are suspicious looking a biopsy can be arranged. BCC link Capecitabine Also known as Xeloda. A type of chemotherapy drug taken as a tablet by mouth. Cardiotoxicity An umbrella term for a range of possible complications of cancer treatments that make the heart work less efficiently or damage it. Central iv Lines. Hickman or Groshong are types of central lines fitted upper chest. Chemotherapy Treatment aimed at destroying cancer cells using anti-cancer drugs, which are also called cytotoxic drugs. Chemotherapy Information Drugs Index CISH (chromogenic in situ hybridization) or FISH. Two ways of measuring HER2 levels in cancer cells. CMF A combination of three chemotherapy drugs – cyclophosphamide, methotrexate and 5-fluorouracil (5FU) CMF chemo regime. Complementary therapies A varied group of therapies used alongside conventional medical treatments. Core Biopsy or needle biopsy is performed with a hollow needle which takes a sample of tissue about the diameter of pencil lead which can be used to determine if and where cancer cells are present. For a lot more information on biopsies see also the stereotactic BCC link. Can also be performed with the needle attached to a mammogram machine and computer for more precise positioning and measurement. Known as Stereotactic Biopsy. Link to BCC Cording Pain in armpit traveling down arm (feels like a tight cord) post surgery. May require physio/massage to ease discomfort. Also known as AWS (Axillary Web Syndrome) CT (computerised tomography) scan Also known as a CAT scan. A type of scan that uses x-rays to take detailed pictures across the body. CUP (Cancer of Unknown Primary) Term used when a secondary cancer is diagnosed but the site of the primary cannot be found. See also Occult. CyberKnife see Stereotactic radiotherapy (also known as radiosurgery) A very precise radiation treatment used in secondary breast cancer. Designed for brain use but also used for lungs and liver. May also be referred to as Gamma Knife or Cyberknife CYCLOPHOSPHAMIDE Is a chemotherapy drug and is also the C part of  FEC. Cyclophosphamide D DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ) An early type of breast cancer where the cells have not yet developed the ability to spread outside the walls of the ducts into surrounding breast tissue or to other parts of the body. Sometimes called a pre-invasive, intraductal or non-invasive cancer. DCIS Denosumab also known as Xgeva. given to treat bone secondaries from breast cancer. Hypocalcaemia = Lower than normal levels of calcium in the blood. DEXA (scan)  Dual Energy X-ray NHS link. Uses low dosage radiation x-ray scan to check bone density for thinning and/or osteoporosis caused by hormone tablet therapy. This not the same as the bone scan performed at a nuclear radiology dept. DIEP (deep inferior epigastic perforator) flap A type of breast reconstruction that uses the skin and fat between the belly button and the groin to form a breast shape. More refined version of the TRAM flap. DIEP also see types of reconstruction. Differentiation How different cancer cells are compared to normal cells. Well differentiated cancer cells look almost normal (a similar size and shape to normal cells); moderately differentiated cancer cells look less like normal cells (often larger and more varied shapes); poorly differentiated cancer cells look most changed and are usually fast growing. Distant recurrence Also called metastatic or secondary breast cancer. When cancer cells from the breast have spread to other parts of the body such as the bones, lungs, liver or brain. Docetaxel A chemotherapy drug derived from Yew also known as Taxotere. It is one of a group of chemotherapy drugs called taxanes.  The T part of FEC-T regime. Not to be confused with another Taxane type Paclitaxel / Taxol Doxorubicin A chemotherapy drug also known as Adriamycin. It is one of a group of chemotherapy drugs known as anthracyclines. E EC Chemotherapy  Is the same as FEC minus the F (fluorouracil / 5fu) part, and is becoming more popular option. EC Echo Cardiogram uses sound waves to check heart is working normally. Can be used to check for side effects. Usually an ECG is performed at the same time - see below. ECG Electrocardiogram. An  ECG tests the electrical activity of the heart and checks how well it is working. E-CMF Epirubicin and CMF chemo regime. See CMF EGFR (epidermal growth factor receptor) Proteins on the surface of cells.  When there are higher than normal levels (known as over expression) on cancer cells, they stimulate growth. Human epidermal factor receptor2 = HER2 EPIRUBICIN Is mostly used with the chemotherapy combo (FEC) Epirubicin Eribulin aka Halaven Can be used for secondary BC where other chemotherapy regimes have been used previously Erythropoietin Treatment for anaemia. Low red blood cell count (see also Anaemia) ER status In breast cancer, whether or not the cancer cells have receptors within the cell that bind to the female hormone oestrogen and stimulate the cancer to grow (known as oestrogen receptor positive or ER+ breast cancer). ER negative (ER-) means the breast cancer doesn’t have oestrogen receptors link to BCC. Americanised from US spelling of Estrogen. See also PR Everolimus is a kinase inhibitor given as either Everolimius or Afinitor. In tablet form can be used along with Exemestane (Aromasin) for patients with breast cancer that has spread. Excision Surgical removal. Exemestane A hormone therapy drug, also known as Aromasin. It is one of a group of drugs called aromatase inhibitors. F Family Genetics including BRCA1 / 2 and other gene related risks. Faslodex also known as Fulvestrant. Used to treat ER positive metastic breast cancer. Fulvestrant ideally to be read with information on secondary breast cancer. FEC A combination of the chemotherapy drugs 5-flurouracil (5FU), epirubicin and cyclophosphamide. See combined FEC FEC-T A combination of the chemotherapy drugs 5-flurouracil (5FU), epirubicin, cyclophosphamide and Taxotere (docetaxel). Usually given as FEC first (see above) followed by T when FEC is completed. Femara Aromatase Inhibitor (AI) drug used to treat ER+ breast cancer in post menopausal women. See Letrozole Fibroids Fibroadenoma  Benign breast lump. Thought to be caused by sensitivity to oestrogen. Fibrocystic A benign (not cancer) breast condition when multiple cysts or lumpy areas develop in one or both breasts. Any suspected cysts or lumps should always be checked out. Filgrastim Is a growth factor (GCSF) to stimulate bone marrow to produce more white blood cells. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) Using a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells for analysis under a microscope. FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization) A way of measuring HER2 levels in cancer cells. FLUOROURACIL (5FU) Chemotherapy drug also used as part of FEC combination. Fluorouracil Fractions Each radiotherapy treatment is known as a fraction. Treatment involves several fractions given over a few days or weeks. Breast cancer radiotherapy. Fulvestrant A hormone therapy drug, also known as Faslodex. G Gabapentin and Pregabalin Used to treat nerve pain including Peripheral Neuropathy. Gamma knife see Stereotactic Radiotherapy (SRT)  Very precise multi point beam radiotherapy can be used on secondary brain tumours. GCSF (granulocyte-colony stimulating factor). A drug that boosts the levels of white blood cells in the body when they are low, for example during chemotherapy treatment. See EGFR Gemcitabine A chemotherapy drug, also known as Gemzar. Grade The system used to classify cancer cells according to how different they are to normal breast cells and how quickly they are growing. Grading & Staging. Goserelin An injected hormone therapy drug, also known as Zoladex H Hand and Foot Syndrome (Palmar-Plantar Syndrome) Uncommon side effect causing very sore, sometimes blistered or cracked hands and feet from some chemotherapy drugs. See also Peripheral Neuropathy. Halaven aka Eribulin  For secondary BC where other chemo was used previously HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2) A protein involved in the growth of cells. Around 20% of breast cancers have higher than normal levels of HER2 (known as HER2 positive) which stimulates them to grow. See Herceptin below. Herceptin Monoclonal Antibody given to treat those diagnosed HER2 positive. Usually 18 sessions 3 weeks apart (one year). Also known as Trastuzumab Cancer Research UK (CRUK) Hormone receptor Involved in the growth of cells. In some breast cancers they bind to hormones within the cells (known as hormone receptor positive) and stimulate the cancer to grow. Written as ER/PR status. Hormone therapy (HT) Use of drugs to block the effect of hormones on cancer cells; only used if the breast cancer is hormone receptor positive. Hormone Therapies Not HRT see below. HRT (hormone replacement therapy) A combination of oestrogen and progesterone. Information explaining HRT cancer risks at CRUK Hypercalcaemia Higher than normal levels of calcium in the blood. Can be caused by cancer affecting the bones. Hyperplasia An increase in the number and growth of cells. Also known as Atypical Hyperplasia  ADH is Ductal ALH is Lobular Hypocalcaemia Lower than normal levels of calcium in the blood. Can be a side effect of taking Denosumab Xgeva for bone secondaries of breast cancer. I IBC Inflammatory Breast Cancer an uncommon type of breast cancer. Symptoms = skin of the breast can become pink/red, orange peel texture, and may feel warm and tender (‘inflamed’) with no palpable lumps. Not to be confused with the much more common Invasive Breast Cancer (IBC) IDC Invasive Ductal carcinoma. Most invasive cancers (around 80%) are of this type. ILC Invasive Lobular Carcinoma. Accounts for 15% of breast cancers. Immunosuppression Reduction or prevention of the immune response. May be caused, for example, by chemotherapy or radiotherapy causing low white cell count. See Neutropenia Infertility Unable to get pregnant; may be temporary or permanent and can be caused, for example, by chemotherapy. Cancer and Fertility. Infusion A method of delivering fluids or drugs by drip, usually into a vein. i.e. iv chemo In situ (DCIS breast cancer) Has not developed the ability to spread outside the ducts, either within the breast or elsewhere in the body. In situ = in one place. For example DCIS or LCIS Intraductal see DCIS above Intravenous (IV Therapy) An injection into the vein. Invasive cancer Has spread beyond the layer of tissue where it developed. i.e. lymphnodes, vascular invasion. IV Line Hickman or Groshong Central iv lines or intravenous tunnelled catheters. Usually fitted under local anaesthetic where veins are compromised and used for administering chemo drugs during treatment and can also used for taking bloods. Alternatives can be PICC lines, similar but fitted on the upper arm and Implantable Ports (portacath) which are hidden under the skin. J K Kadcyla  also known as T-DM1  New treatment for targeting HER2+ Metastatic cancers. Now funded by NICE for some secondary cancers. Trastuzumab Emtansine (Kadcyla®) for HER2+ secondaries or as part of a trial. L Lapatinib A type of targeted therapy, also known as Tyverb, and one of a group of cancer drugs called tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs). LCIS Lobular carcinoma in situ. (in situ = in one place) Sometimes called Lobular Neoplasia. A Pre-Cancerous cluster of abnormal cells which means you could be at higher risk of developing it later in life. LCIS LD Flap Latissimus Dorsi Flap. A type of breast reconstruction using tissue from the back. LE Lymphoedema is a build up of fluid in the body tissues caused by damage or surgery to lymph nodes which hinders the lymph fluid from draining away. NHS Lymphoedema help about treatments and massage to ease discomfort.  Letrozole A hormone therapy, also known as Femara, and one of a group of drugs called aromatase inhibitors. Femara is the original brand name several other generic makes are now available. Locally advanced breast cancer Breast cancer that has not spread to another part of the body but may have spread to breast skin or muscle and also has lymph node involvement. Lumpectomy (Sometimes written WLE) An operation to remove an area of breast tissue with or without a margin of healthy tissue; in breast cancer may also be called wide local excision or breast-conserving surgery. Lymph nodes Also known as lymph glands. Small oval-shaped structures found in clusters throughout the lymphatic system, for example under the arm (axilla). Lymphatic system The drainage and filtering system of the body, made up of lymph nodes (lymph glands), vessels and fluid. Helps to get rid of waste products and fight infection. Lymphatic system Lymphoedema Swelling of the arm, hand or breast area caused by a build-up of lymph fluid in the surface tissues of the body. It can occur as a result of damage to the lymphatic system, for example because of surgery and/or radiotherapy to the lymph nodes under the arm (axilla) and surrounding area. See LE  Lympho-Vascular Invasion (LVI) When breast cancer cells spread into (invade) the lymph and/or blood vessels within the breast, and can be seen in these vessels under the microscope. This can increase the chance of chemotherapy being offered. M Malignant  Uncontrolled growth. Invasive cells that have the potential to spread elsewhere within the body. Mammogram A breast x-ray. Newer digital mammograms are better at checking the denser tissue found in younger women. Breast screening for those under 50 Mastectomy (full) Removal of all the breast tissue including the nipple area. Metaplastic Breast Cancer quite rare type and little researched at present. Metastasis Cancer cells that have spread from the first cancer site and grown elsewhere in the body, for example the bones. Also called mets, advanced cancer, secondary cancer or secondaries. Where breast cancer cells have "metastasised" spread elsewhere. Mets also Metastasis or Secondary breast cancer where the cancer has spread elsewhere. Symptoms of secondaries. See also "all about" secondary breast cancer MLD Manual Lymph Drainage. Method a lymph nurse uses to massage lymph fluid away from the affected area to ease lymphedema. MLD MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scan Uses magnetism and radio waves to produce a series of cross sectional images of the inside of the body. MRI Multi-centric When there is more than one area of breast cancer in different quarters (areas) of the breast. Multi-focal When there is more than one area of breast cancer but all in the same quarter (area) of the breast. MUGA Multi-Gated Acquisition (muga) scan. Using injected isotope shows moving image of heartbeat and records muscle and chamber ejection pressures. Used before or during chemo and Herceptin MX Mastectomy (breast removal) also BM(x) Bilateral (both sides removed) N Navelbine see Vinorelbine Is a chemo drug  classed as vinca alkaloids and can be given either through an iv drip or as tablets. NED  No evidence of disease, or remission. What we would all like to hear... Needle Aspiration (FNA) Fine needle aspiration. Using a fine needle syringe to remove a sample of cells and or fluid. Also term used for removing seroma fluid to ease swelling. Neo-adjuvant Cancer treatment, such as chemotherapy or hormone therapy, given before surgery mostly to shrink tumours. Sometimes called primary, for example primary hormone therapy. See Adjuvant (after surgery) Neulasta type of G-CSF see Neupogen below. Neupogen A type of G-CSF one of various medications used for boosting white blood cell production during chemotherapy. Neuropathy Also know as Peripheral Neuropathy is nerve damage side effect which can affect some people being treated with Taxotere  (docetaxel) or  Taxol (paclitaxel) family (Taxanes) of chemotherapy drugs. Sometimes referred to as CIPN Chemotherapy Induced Peripheral Neuropathy. See also the more severe Hand and Feet Syndrome (Palmar-Plantar Syndrome) CR link  Neutropenia When the number of white blood cells falls below a certain level; may happen as a side effect of chemotherapy. If there is also a high temperature (above 37.5°C), it is known as febrile neutropenia. Notify your oncology unit at once if this occurs to avoid any possible infection taking hold. NSM Nipple sparing mastectomy. Type of mastectomy where some of the skin and nipple (NAC  nipple area complex) area is saved to help with reconstruction. O Occult  Secondary cancer where the primary cannot be seen even on detailed scans. Sometimes defined as Cancer of Unknown Primary (CUP) Oestrogen receptors Proteins within cancer cells that bind to the female hormone oestrogen and stimulate the cancer to grow (may be abbreviated to ER, from the US spelling of oestrogen/estrogen). Oligometastatic disease  refers to small isolated secondary breast cancer(s) that are stable (not progressing) and usually present only in one site of the body (oligo means ‘little' or 'few’). Can be treated by Stereotactic radiotherapy (also known as gamma knife or radiosurgery) A very precise radiation treatment for people with one or more small secondary breast cancers. Oncologist A doctor who specialises in cancer (oncology). An oncologist may be a medical oncologist (cancer drugs specialist) or clinical oncologist (radiotherapy and/or cancer drugs specialist). Oncoplastic surgeon A breast cancer surgeon with specific training in plastic surgery and reconstruction. Osteopenia Decreased bone mineral density (a measurement of bone strength) but not low enough to be diagnosed as osteoporosis. Osteopenia. See also Dexa scan link to NHS. Osteoporosis Literally means 'porous bones'. Decreased bone mineral density  meaning thinner, weaker bones that are more likely to break; usually diagnosed with a bone density scan (often called a DEXA scan) NHS link. Can be a side effect of taking some hormone tablets. Ovarian Ablation Stopping the ovaries from producing hormones by surgery or other means such as hormone therapy or radiotherapy. Used for pre menopausal patients who are Oestrogen (ER+) positive. P Paclitaxel Also known as Taxol. A chemotherapy drug and one of a group of drugs called taxanes. Palliative Care Focuses on symptom / pain control and support when an illness cannot be cured; usually involves a team of healthcare professionals such as specialist nurses, doctors, social workers and physiotherapists. Palliative treatment Aims to control symptoms and slow down the progress of an illness and provide pain control. Palmar Plantar  (Hand and Foot Syndrome) Uncommon side effect causing very sore, blistered, cracked or peeling hands and feet from some types of chemotherapy drugs. Starts by feeling like peripheral neuropathy but soon gets worse and very painful. CN link Paget's Disease Causes eczema like change in the skin of the nipple. Paget's Disease - usually found in conjuction with dcis, so read about this in conjunction with DCIS. Pathology The branch of medicine that looks at how disease affects the body’s cells and tissues. Each time you have tissue removed a report is written by a pathologist (a doctor who examines the tissue). PBM Prophylactic Bilateral mastectomy. Where no breast cancer is found but removal of both breasts is performed to reduce risk of it occurring at a future date. Also known as Risk Reducing Breast Surgery.  See also BRCA1 and BRCA2 Peripheral Neuropathy  Nerve damage caused by some chemotherapy drugs. In very severe cases can lead to Hand and Foot Syndrome (Palmar-Plantar Syndrome) CR link Perjeta  also known as Pertuzumab. Targeted therapy for treating HER2 + breast cancer. Pertuzumab, Trastuzumab and Docetaxel is a chemotherapy treatment used to treat breast cancer that has spread or has come back in the same breast but can’t be treated with surgery. Also known as Perjeta, Herceptin and Taxotere PET (Positron emission tomography) scan A scan that produces a three dimensional image giving details on both the structure and function of organs or tissue being looked at. It is sometimes combined with a CT scan. Then written as PET-CT. PET-CT  Use of PET and CT scan combined. Phyllodes Tumour Rare type of breast tumour can be benign or malignant. Phyllodes PICC Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter. IV access used for administering chemo. Sometimes known as an "arm port" PortaCath. An implantable Port sometimes used instead of a PICC Line to delivery Chemotherapy drugs. Plastic surgeon A specialist surgeon trained in plastic surgery techniques such as breast reconstruction. Pregabalin and Gabapentin Used to treat nerve pain including Peripheral Neuropathy. Primary breast cancer Is the site the cancer first started to grow (breast) Sometimes cancer cells break away and spread from the primary and get trapped in the lymph glands which are part of the body's natural defence system or into the bloodstream. See How a Cancer Spreads link to CRUK Progesterone receptors Proteins within cancer cells that bind to the female hormone progesterone can be receptor PR+ or PR- (also written as PR). Not routinely tested for as ER Oestrogen receptors play a more important role. Prognosis The likely outlook of a disease, whether it is likely to be cured or affect the person’s life expectancy. Prosthesis An artificial breast form used to restore shape when all or part of the breast has been removed. Prosthesis Not to be confused with breast reconstruction. Q   R Radiotherapy (Breast) The use of high energy x-rays radiation to destroy cancer cells. Main BCC in depth information page. Also External Beam Radiotherapy explained Radiologist A doctor who specialises in the use of imaging (for example x-rays, ultrasound, CT, PET, MRI) to diagnose and treat disease. See Specialist Staff found in Radiology and Other Departments Rad Onc Radiation Oncologist. See above link. Reconstruction (breast) surgery rebuilding breast shape after all or part of the breast has been removed. Pro's & Cons of types of recon. See also Breast reconstruction and also Macmillan Booklet Understanding Breast Reconstruction. This contains post surgery images ! Recurrence When a disease or condition returns. There are several types of breast cancer recurrence. Link to BCC on Reccurance Regional recurrence (also known as locally advanced) Breast cancer that has come back and has spread to the tissues and lymph nodes (lymph glands) around the chest, neck and under the breastbone. Recurrence Distant  Also called metastatic or secondary breast cancer. When cancer cells from the breast have spread to other parts of the body such as the bones, lungs, liver or brain. Remission when the signs and symptoms of a disease can no longer be found; this may be temporary or permanent. Often written as NED (no evidence of disease) S Secondary breast cancer when breast cancer cells spread from the first (primary) tumour in the breast through the lymphatic or blood system to other parts of the body. Also called metastases, advanced breast cancer, secondaries or stage 4 breast cancer. Sentinel Node Biopsy (SNB) Identifies whether or not the first lymph node (or nodes) are clear of cancer cells. Selective internal radiation therapy (SIRT) A type of targeted internal radiotherapy which uses radioactive beads to deliver radiation to the cancer. Can be used to treat breast secondaries. Seroma  Many people who have had breast cancer surgery or lymph node removal develop a collection of fluid called a seroma. This can either be under the arm and/or in the breast or chest wall. The build up of fluid may cause some discomfort, but is not a cause for concern and is usually reabsorbed by the body over time. If the seroma is large, restricts arm movement, causes discomfort or doesn’t subside, your specialist or breast care nurse may decide to draw off (aspirate) the fluid using a needle and syringe.  This is usually a painless procedure as the area around the wound is still likely to be numb. Sometimes a seroma will refill after it has been aspirated. Some people may need to be aspirated several times over a period of many weeks before it goes completely. Stage Staging  The size of the cancer and how far it has spread. See Staging and Grading. STB Stereotactic core biopsy Taking a sample of tissue using a needle biopsy device connected to a mammogram machine and linked to a computer; helps locate the exact position of the area to be biopsied. Stereotactic radiotherapy (also known as radiosurgery) A very precise radiation treatment used in secondary breast cancer. May also be referred to as Gamma Knife or CyberKnife.  At the Royal Marsden Steroids Helps reduce allergic reactions to chemo and has mild anti sickness  benefit. Steroids are usually given in conjunction with anti-emetics (anti sickness tablets) Commonly Dexamethasone or the newer Emend. More information on anti sickness drugs at Cancer Research site. Subcutaneous injection or sub-cut.  An injection into the fatty tissue under the skin. Surgical margin How close the cancer cells are to the edges of the whole area of tissue removed during surgery. See Clear Margins. Systemic Treatment  Drugs that treat the whole body, for example, chemotherapy, hormone therapy or targeted therapies. T TAC This is a chemo combination not to be confused with Taxol/Taxotere only. Consists of Docetaxel (T) Adriamycin (A) (also known as Doxorubicin) and (C) Cyclophosphamide©) TAC Tamoxifen An anti oestrogen hormone therapy drug. Tamoxifen Usually given if pre-menopausal. Targeted therapies (also know as biological therapies) A group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer by mimicking substances that occur in your own body interfering with the biology of the cancer cells. They target specific processes in the cells that cause cancer to grow. Taxol A chemotherapy drug. see Paclitaxel Also sometimes used in private clinics using lower dosed weekly sessions instead of the three weekly nhs Docetaxel sessions to lessen side effects. Taxotere Chemotherapy drug originally derived from Yew (Taxanes) see Docetaxel  (The T part of FEC-T) TC Chemotherapy combination of Taxotere (Docetaxel) and Cyclophosphamide TC TCHP New treatment regime for neo-adjuvant (before surgery) treatment of HER2+ Positive BC. Consisting of  (docetaxel, carboplatin, trastuzumab, pertuzumab) Taxotere (Docetaxel)  Carboplatin and Herceptin and Perjeta  also known as Pertuzumab T-DM1  also known as Kadcyla New treatment for targeting HER2+ Metastatic  cancers. Now funded by NICE for some secondary cancers Trastuzumab Emanstine (Kadcyla)® for HER2+ secondaries, or as part of a trial. TE Temporary Expanders used in some types of reconstruction. Temporary Expanders TN or TNBC Triple Negative hormone breast diagnosis. Triple Negative for PR / ER and HER2. Tram Flap Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. A type of breast reconstruction using skin, fat and muscle obtained from the stomach area. TRAM is another version of the DIEP flap method but muscle is included for Tram flap use but muscle is not used for Diep flap. Trastuzumab Also known as Herceptin. A targeted therapy used to treat HER2 positive breast cancer, and one of a group of drugs called monoclonal antibodies. Cancer Research UK (CRUK) Tumour markers Substances produced by some cancers or by the body itself as a response to cancer and can be detected by blood tests or by other means as an aid to diagnosis. Notably marker CA15-3 for breast cancer levels are mostly used to monitor responses to treatments rather than for diagnosing. Tyverb see Lapatinib  Given in tablet form as a treatment for HER positive breast cancer that has spread to other parts of the body. U Ultrasound scan Uses high frequency sound waves to produce an image. Ultrasound V Vacuum assisted biopsy (VAP) Use of a vacuum assisted hollow needle syringe and local anesthetic to remove breast tissue for examination under a microscope, often when a previous biopsy was difficult to perform or more tissue is needed to make a diagnosis. Sometimes it can be used as an alternative to surgery to remove a whole area of breast tissue (called a vacuum assisted excision biopsy). Vascular Invasion Term used if cancer cells have spread through the walls of tissue or vessels and affected or invaded nearby blood supplies. i.e. Lympho vascular invasion Vinorelbine also known as Navelbine. Is a type of chemotherapy drug known as vinca alkaloids which can be given either through an iv line or as tablets. W Wide local excision (WLE) Surgery to remove breast cancer with a margin of healthy tissue. Sometimes called breast-conserving surgery. WLE Lumpectomy. X Xeloda Chemotherapy drug given in tablet form. see Capecitabine X-ray Used to produce images of dense tissues in the body such as bone or lungs. Another name for Mammogram when referring to breasts. Can be a digital mammogram for those under 50 due to denser breast tissue. Y   Z Zoladex An injected hormonal therapy drug. see Goserelin Zoledronic Acid  (Zometa®) A Bisphosphonate used to treat osteoporosis.   Last Update 26th April 2018 Hope this helps, please let us know of any broken links or subjects to add. George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Abbreviations and Terminology Used For Everything BC Related - Indexed...

Posts.Content: Morning XjulieX Great when you get back to work and replace hospital and GP appt's with a bit more normality isn't it ? Just be cautious about stepping up to longer hours before your body can cope with it - If you hit 'the wall' it will knock your confidence and you start getting doubts about moving forward from what you have just been through. G n' J
Posts.Title: First week back at work completed!!

Posts.Content: Hiya CC, I have heard very little more about this since the story of VD's BC broke but I had wondered how she feels now she has probably had her pathology report and am curious as to what her full diagnosis now is ?      If it's HER2+ and/or she needs chemo the media will have a field day :( G n' J
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Hi Nefertiti  Scalp cooling can be a way of avoiding total hair loss through chemotherapy. It has varying degrees of success - Most but not all chemo units have this facility available. You can read more about Scalp Cooling / Cold Cap here. G n' J
Posts.Title: Taking the haircut plunge!

Posts.Content: Hi Lobdobs   Warm welcome to the group hope you are recovering well from surgery and not finding the exercises too painful. DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ) actually is a cancer, but it is "in situ" which is med speak for in only one place (so not spread)  It was found before it reached the invasive stage which is why some say it isn't cancer, because it isn't yet invading, but it would have done if left :( The real clue is in the word carcinoma. If you are being offered radiotherapy with no other follow up treatments like Chemotherapy or hormone inhibitor tablet if ER+ positive then rads is going to be your only way to make certain any cancer cells that although unlikely, could have been missed are zapped by the radiotherapy to reduce the risk of recurrence in the future. Because you had a lumpectomy and still have most of your original tissue even with clear margins the radiotherapy is insurance to avoid future risks. 15 sessions is the standard rads regime =  daily sessions Mon-Fri for 3 weeks. Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: DCIS and radio

Posts.Content: Hi Funda, Welcome to the Breast group, just about the busiest group within Macmillan unfortunately.... Pleased to read you seem to be recovering well, having said that a mastectomy still comes as a shock as it all seems to happen so  quickly :( Have you had your post surgery pathology report as yet ? Just wondering if you know your ER / PR (oestrogen and progesterone) and HER2 (positive or negative) results yet as these will have some bearing on your treatment plan. Assume you haven't seen the oncologist yet so you won't know what type of chemo you will be having at the moment ? There is a rolling monthly chemo club here too - You can find the November Chemo Club by clicking the green text link. Please don't fret too much about them finding some cells in your lymph nodes it is fairly common to have some found there, that is why they carry out the sentinel node biopsy. What parts of diet are you having problems getting your head around, most here eat what they like when they like - It's part of the reward system :-) There are times on chemo when your taste buds go wacky and you can feel a little nauseous so can lose your appetite at times. Take care Funda, look forward to chatting some more, G n' J
Posts.Title: New to this - saying hello and looking to connect

Posts.Content: Hi Mistia, Welcome to the breast group - Hope you are recovering from surgery well. You may feel a bit down for a few days. It's a side effect of the annaesthetic. If you have any questions regarding post surgery issues or exercises do ask, we're all here to help. There are quite few TNBC ladies here who you will get to 'meet' over the next few days while you settle in here. Don't know if they will give you the standard FEC-T chemo regime and see how it goes, or they may jiggle your chemo around to compensate for your type 2 diabetes. As there are other chemo combinations they can use. There is a November Chemo Club discussion you can find clicking here. Most chemo is at 3 weekly intervals and for 6 sessions - So expect it to go on for around 18 weeks.... Sorry if this timeframe is a bit of a shock for you, don't know how much you have been told about chemo ? When are you hoping to return to work ? Some find they can work a few days during chemotherapy but most find it's just too tiring and can't concentrate very well either. Look forward to chatting and seeing you around, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: New to this - saying hello and looking to connect

Posts.Content: Hi Mistia, I hope you aren't alarmed too much by reading some of the posts in the chemo club. Folks only post on their bad days when they need the support, advice and some hugs - there are good days too and although there seems to be an endless stream of side effect issues please bear in mind these are from everyone here going through it. Apart from the fatigue, most only have a couple of side effects to cope with but these can be so varied from one person to another. G n' J

Posts.Title: Abbreviations and Terminology Used For Everything BC Related - Indexed...

Posts.Content: Evening Lizane,  What you are describing is typical of Peripheral Neuropathy courtesy of our good friend Docetaxel (the gift that keeps giving) Dorothee pasted a link to the Maccy info page on PN in answer to similar post yesterday, i'll put the same link in at the bottom. Seeing as it's a big read, i'll just paste some of it in for you to read now, you can check the link out when you have a bit more time on your hands. PN can be a bugger so please be careful with your hands etc with hot water, as the water may not feel very hot to you, but can lead to scalding .....  Take care  George & Jackie.  http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Livingwithandaftercancer/Symptomssideeffects/Othersymptomssideeffects/Peripheralneuropathy.aspx Symptoms of peripheral neuropathyBack to top The symptoms of peripheral neuropathy vary depending on which nerves are affected. Anti-cancer drugs that cause nerve damage are most likely to affect sensory nerves, but some can also affect the motor nerves and the autonomic nerves. Peripheral neuropathy often affects the hands, feet and lower legs. This is because the longer a nerve is, the more vulnerable it is to injury. Nerves going to the hands, feet and lower legs are some of the longest in the body. Symptoms of peripheral neuropathy are usually mild to begin with and gradually get worse. A change in sensation You may have a feeling of heaviness, burning or pins and needles in the affected area. Alternatively, you may notice unusual sensations, such as a feeling of warmth or burning when touching something cold. Increased sensitivity You may find that even the lightest touch or pressure in the affected area feels uncomfortable or painful. Pain This can be mild or more severe. The pain may be felt as sharp and stabbing or as a burning sensation, or it may feel like minor electric shocks. There are treatments to help relieve pain. Numbness There may be a loss of sensitivity or feeling in the affected area. Often the feet and fingertips are the first places to be affected. Muscle weakness A muscle may lose strength if it isn’t being stimulated by a nerve. Depending on which muscles are affected, this may make it difficult to walk, climb stairs or do other tasks. Difficulty buttoning clothes or picking up small objects If the nerve endings in the fingers are affected, you may not be able to do ‘fiddly’ tasks, such as fastening small buttons or tying shoelaces. Difficulty with balance, walking and coordination You may find that you stumble or trip when walking; uneven surfaces may be particularly difficult. You may feel clumsy at times or you may feel that your body isn't doing what you want it to. Your sense of where things are around you may become less certain. Constipation and feeling bloated This can happen when the nerves that control the rate that food passes through the bowel (autonomic nerves) are affected. Let your doctor or nurse know if you're having these problems. Feeling light-headed or dizzy when you sit up or stand up These symptoms are sometimes caused by a sudden drop in your blood pressure, known as postural hypotension. This can happen when the nerves that control blood pressure and heart rate (autonomic nerves) are damaged. Your doctor can see if this is the cause of your symptoms by checking your blood pressure when you're lying down and standing up. Anti-cancer drugs and peripheral neuropathyBack to top There are many different anti-cancer drugs. The types that most frequently cause peripheral neuropathy are: Vinca alkaloids, which include vinblastine (Velbe®), vincristine (Oncovin®),vinorelbine (Navelbine®) and vindesine (Eldisine®). Vincristine is the most likely one of these drugs to cause peripheral neuropathy. The platinum based drugs cisplatin, oxaliplatin and carboplatin. The taxanes docetaxel (Taxotere®) and paclitaxel (Taxol®).
Posts.Title: Is this normal.... Chemo is over but .. 3 wks after and feeling worst...

Posts.Content: Hiya Amanda865 The numbness you refer to is probably nerve damage caused during surgery, it can repair itself to a certain level but commonly leaves you with some nerve 'baggage' The lumpiness sounds like scar tissue especially if this seems to be tightening as time progresses; but this may also be a touch of AWS more commonly called Cording. Is this just in the armpit area, or has spread down the arm at all ? Could well be worth contacting your breast care nurse and asking about this as it may just need some physio to help loosen things up a little. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi wsarahw  What some consider drastic others would consider a wise move ? Maybe you would be up for being our cold cap guinea pig - cutting your hair pixie short to ensure a better cap fit sounds really logical. If it helps you keep more of your hair perhaps this could even become a better way of going about cold capping :) I'm not sure how much your hair would have been insulating your head though - It may seem a lot colder next time :-/ Time will tell, hair loss can start anywhere between days 12 - 25, so it has only been around 2 weeks for you as yet.... Good luck with it, G n' J

Posts.Title: Seeing Oncologist - what will it involve?

Posts.Content: If anyone is thinking of trying the 'fasting' prior to and on the day of chemo there is some 2018 info about it here. Nothing has been proved but if you try it and it seems to work for you it would probably do no harm, and may infact help you ward off some of the extra kilo's cancer treatments can give you. Only thing is it may help with some types of chemo drugs but not others ? and may not be the way to go if you can't afford any further weight loss on top of that some cancers can cause or if diabetic etc. So do check this is suitable for your cancer type especially if abdominally affected. G n' J

Posts.Title: Is this normal.... Chemo is over but .. 3 wks after and feeling worst...

Posts.Content: Hi Val,  Yes, think it's just coincidence that there are quite a lot of posts with various pain concerns at the moment - Try not to let it get to you and over think and worry about all this. This is them, not you and it may not apply to you very much at all. Don't try to react to what may happen in the future, concentrate on all this one small step at a time. Their treatments may be a lot more invasive like full mastectomies and total node clearance, pain from secondary tumours, reactions to chemo, big hits of radiotherapy, there are a whole host of reasons but even if this does occur it is only usually a temporary thing until it either clears up or pain relief eases it until you recover. There are well over 1,000 breast cancer cases diagnosed per WEEK in the uk - Most don't post here if things are going ok, you usually only get to read about the problems, so please bear that in mind :-) Try to do things to take your mind of it a bit, and enjoy a sunny Sunday, G n' J

Posts.Title: Appointment today

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline,  Gotcha' - Rads are mostly very do'able. They have you in around a week before your sessions start to give you a bit of a pep talk about what goes on and possibly will show you the 'room' with the linear accelerator in it. Make a note of any questions you may have beforehand as this will be a chance to ask about any concerns you may have. Also ask about free parking (see below) At this time they will give you some tiny black pin point tattoo's which are used to line the machine up with so they get precise areas treated - this can take a while fiddling about getting you into the correct position but only needs doing once.  Also ask if they supply cream, some don't so you will have to buy your own - any unscented aqueous cream will do but some prefer the extra healing qualities of an Aloe Vera based cream. Oh and don't use any underarm deodorants, wet wipes are fine. If you intend driving yourself to your sessions it's ok to start with but gets progressively more tiring so if you can get someone to take you if only for the last week that will help. Take something to kill the waiting time, a book,  iPad / games, puzzle books etc - The session only takes around 15 minutes but there can be a bit of a wait to get in at busy times especially if they are running late which sometimes happens. You will usually be given a gown to change into when you arrive so wear clothing that is easy to get in and out of. Most hospital car parks have free parking for Radiotherapy patients. This can either be by a pre-paid card you can collect on your first session or by recovering the cost after treatment. To get a card you will need your appointment sheet with all the dates on as proof. Check online or by phoning your unit to see about this. You can get some sunburn or slight blistering nearer the end of treatment cycles as long as the skin doesn't break it should be ok but this sunburn feeling does carry on for around two weeks after the sessions end. This is the BCC booklet about 'Breast Cancer Radiotherapy' there can be side effects so here is the link to a Macmillan Radiotherapy Booklet 'Breast Radiotherapy, Possible Long Term Side Effects' too. Hope this is of help, G n' J

Posts.Title: Abbreviations and Terminology Used For Everything BC Related - Indexed...

Posts.Content: Hi Kath, Yes, very much agree with what Ethel said - Your treatment is tailored to suit you and your diagnosis and only you. OK most here have very similar treatment regimes but there are so many tweaks that are made from what they find in histology after surgery. There are also very many variations of BC, DCIS, LCIS, Pagets, IDC, ILB Triple Negative then you have all the hormonal variations ER / PR HER2 + or - You can see the number of permutations are huge. One quick comment on your steroids, don't take any after 4 pm try and work it so they are in your system early or you will have one heck of a problem getting to sleep you'll be so wide awake with nothing to do except either worry about everything or getting up and doing some housework - neither are a good option at 2am  :-) You are doing fine just don't be alarmed if you feel really tired and achey in a couple of days it takes a bit longer for Tax to get right into your system. Any problems, just holler there's always someone about here. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Difference in treatments. Why so much! Confused.

Posts.Content: Hi Factseeker, Well you have found yourself in the right place for facts  :) Would be interesting to see if any Lobular BC members here were originally diagnosed with ALH and went on to get LCIS or ILC at a later date ? Lovely to read you have dodged that bullet, but as you mention ALH can mean you have a slightly higher risk of developing Lobular BC later. Although ALH isn't even a pre-cancerous condition it is used as a marker for being at higher risk. Especially if any close relatives (grand parents, parents, siblings, aunts etc) have also had breast cancer themselves. You may have found this researching but in case you missed it there is this page about Hyperplasia at breast cancer care uk. and further info specifically about Lobular Hyperplasia here. You say they have penciled you in for yearly mammograms now - It may be better if you actually had ultrasound scans as well as the mammogram because these are a lot more accurate at picking up any changes earlier. I don't think this is a minor issue, you are gathering info and being vigilant which is great for your future health :) Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia

Posts.Content: Hi Syl, Cramp is a fairly common issue. You could see if taking Magnesium tablets, or possibly Vitamin B12 could help ease these. If you would prefer to go the non tablet / supplement route. High Quinine content drinks like Fever Tree brand may be a way forward. These are available in most supermarkets in fact I think Asda have them on offer at the moment. Hopefully others who have suffered cramp can let you know what worked best for them. Hugs, G n' J AntsNest

So pleased you have got the ball rolling and you are getting yourself checked out. Hopefully it will be something not to worry about but when you go for results do take someone with you 'just in case'  Let us know how you get on and if you need more answers just holler. Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Jackie  /  jacks77  Here ya' go - hope this helps :) Waterjel Radiotherapy Gel and Lotion  R1 and R2 Frequently Asked Questions page. IF you can persuade your GP to prescribe some most won't because it costs £70 :( The pharmacy ordering PIP codes for R1/R2 are - Six weekly pack:  PIP code for R1:  356-4432 and the code for  R2:  383-4918 Smaller weekly treatment packs:  PIP code   367-3613 If you manage to get some Waterjel R1/R2 prescribed great, but if not and you can't easily afford to buy it over the counter don't depspair there are lots of other cheaper options it is just that R1/R2 has been formuated specifically for radiotherapy treatment. However you cannot use R1/R2 if you are Lactose Intolerant. Oh! and and if you need it ? Here is the Macmillan Radiotherapy for Breast Cancer Information page link. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Morning Joanne, Don't know if you have seen this but it may help when and how you decide to tell your children. 'Talking With Your Children About Breast Cancer' Please don't beat yourself up over this, it's just the control you had has been taken away for a little while and normal life seems to have gone missing. This will return when you get your treatment plan and you can take it all one step at a time. You are in a scary place at the moment diagnosis is always traumatic - fear of the unknown, treatments, the future, your children, time off work, finances and all the other stuff you over imagine. Were all here to help you through this. Take care,  George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Really scared

Posts.Content: Hiya Lizzie, Think the over riding outcome from cancer for us as a couple is a huge reality check. We now work to live, rather than live to work. I used to work rotating 12 hour shifts (60 hour week - print trade) and Jackie also worked full time. Luckily ? The company I worked for got bought out and I was one of the many who got made redundant just before Jackie was diagnosed which was fortunate as it saved me the hassle working out caring. We now both work part time and it is a move we should have made years ago.... George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Can good things come from having Cancer?

Posts.Title: Two year milestone reached

Posts.Content: Morning Gillywigs, It's a shame you feel this way but unfortunately is quite common when you feel and see how cancer has left you feeling 'broken' compared to how you were before. I'm not wanting to upset you, heaven forbid I would never do that but you seem to be in the half glass empty camp, maybe suffering a little depression too, understandable after what you have been through but it doesn't have to be this way. Have you thought about seeing your GP and getting a short term low dose pick me up or some counselling to help you top your glass up and hopefully bring a few smiles back into your life ? If you are down at heart it also brings down those who visit or phone and they find conversations very hard to deal with, so the visits and calls get less which is the last thing you need. Your life is may seem empty and worthless at the present time, all you just need a some support to lift you a little - be it in the form of a course of tablets or a new found interest in your life, but it is a ball you will have to start rolling to help you move forward. Unfortunately there is a lot of truth in that old saying 'Smile and the world smiles with you - Cry, and you cry alone' :-( Do hope you can find yourself some help to turn this corner. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Can good things come from having Cancer?

Posts.Content: Hiya Julie  / XjulieX Think it depends on how tired you are with the hours you are presently doing and if your shifts are a full 5 day (night) working week or if you have gone back doing 3 or 4 shifts first to see how you get on. A 5 night week will mean an extra 10 hours weekly, do you think that is do'able after 2 weeks ? If not maybe ask about another couple of weeks at 4 hours (depending on your finances)  Have no idea what the job entails but maybe it it any stretching / lifting affecting scar tissue that is causing some discomfort ?  Is there any way to make whatever could be causing this discomfort easier for you ? G n' J

Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi Deirdre  /  optimum  Your first one may well be just for measuring / ct scanning; small dot tattoos and a look around. You could ask what (if any) booster sessions they may add to give a more intense burst to the area you had the extra capsular in ? Also which creams they recommend, do they supply them or will you have to get this yourself :( If you have a sympathetic GP you may be able to get a prescription for R1 and R2 Waterjel (you need both) which is specifically formulated for radiotherapy but as a 5 week course is around £70 they may just offer you a script for a cheaper large tub of generic cream - saying they don't know about it - state your health authority area doesn't supply if (or whatever excuse fits)  :) If you want more info about R1 and R2 (link) also their Frequently Asked Questions page can be found here. Ask about free parking too, as most hospitals provide free parking for Rads patients, but you will need to show your appointment dates letter as confirmation. Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: First Radiotherapy meeting

Posts.Content: Hi GMc  Yes, unfortunately cancer does cause a lot of break ups for many differing reasons. Post cancer people re-evaluate their lives, cancer can bring out the worst in couples, or put added financial / emotional stress onto a relationship that already is showing signs of cracks.  Depending on her post surgery pathology report there may be other long term treatments she has to still go through as yet as well :( Radiotherapy, hormone inhibitor tablets, maybe even chemo ? It's definitely a long haul on a rocky road, all you can do is try your best and hope it all works out for both of you. Sorry, our messages crossed paths - Think the best way to put this to her is to get her to understand how she felt when you needed her help and support and possibly also felt a bit guilty about getting it and now it's payback - as it's all about her this time around. G n' J

Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Hi Jo  peachesxxx  It sounds like a double edged sword - while on chemo you are at risk of picking up flu so it makes sense to have the flu jab first, as having chemo lowers your immunity..... The flu jab doesn't contain live flu virus so you won’t develop flu from having it. But you shouldn’t have the flu vaccine if you - Are allergic to egg (the vaccine is made from hen’s eggs) As Ronstar mentions do check this out with your oncologist, they will probably recommend it, but I have no idea if being diabetic makes any difference to your risk ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Feedback on cold cap please?

Posts.Content: Hi GMc  This is far more common than you would believe - with both genders. Some men with cancer can be pure evil to live with for a while when cancer comes to call :( You learn to be a bit of an emotional sponge soaking up all her fear and anger that having been told you have cancer causes. The first thing you think of when being told is 'I'm going to die'  Next thing is how do I protect those who love me..... and an irrational mind will say put up protective defences, drive those who care about me away so I don't have to feel guilty about what my diagnosis and treatment will put them through. You are bearing the brunt because she loves you and you are probably the only person she can unload to and get away with it. It's nothing personal, although it may seem that way. Hug her, tell her you love and are going nowhere and you will survive this as a family but don't stifle her or wrap her up in cotton wool try to find that fine line between trying to be normal and stepping up to the mark when she needs support, a listening pair of ears or a comforting shoulder to lean on. What stage of treatment is your partner at, just diagnosed or having treatment - as this stage usually eases after awhile. It can be just as tough for the carer as it is the patient - If you take a look through the Carers Group you joined there are so many posts very similar to yours, so you are definitely not alone in this. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Hi Fidelys, Warm welcome to the breast group, a club no one wanted to find themselves joining but a great place to be at a tough time. They can give you a stage at the moment which denotes size but any other diagnosis information won't come through until after your removed tissue results come back from the histology / pathology unit around a week after surgery. It is for the most part this information which they use to plan and tailor any other treatments you may need. For instance if you are found to be ER+ and or PR+ positve it means your oestrogen and/or progesterone would have been helping to feed the cancer cells so you get long term tablets for this. Your tumour will also be 'graded' from 1 - 4 most ladies here come in around 2 or 3 if you are lucky it will be a 1, nobody wants to hear there's is a 4 as this means it has invaded other areas/ organs. A 4 is rarely found at this early stage, you would no doubt had other symptoms if this were the case, so don't fret over this. Your HER2 status is also found at this time if you are found to be HER2+ positive this will definitely guarantee chemotherapy as you have to have the chemo in order to be given Herceptin which is the primary drug for HER2+ (don't worry about not knowing all these terms) you'll soon pick them up. Other factors also may result in chemo, grade 2 can be borderline, grade 3 is where chemo is offered and any lymph-node involvement is taken into account. Being classed as triple negative where you are ER/PR and HER2 negative (for all three) will also mean chemotherapy for sure. During your mastectomy they will no doubt take a few lymphnodes to sample (called a SNB - sentinel node biopsy) , if they find any cancer cells there, they may either remove the rest of your nodes at the same time, or call you back for this surgery a week or so later. Just letting you know a little about what could happen next, but don't worry about any of this for now, just concentrate on your surgery and recovery - one step at a time is the way to go. If you have any specific questions you would like answered by the lovely ladies here do create a New Discussion and ask away - (there is no such thing as a silly question) to get some support and advice, we're all here to help. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: New to the site after being diagnosed with breast cancer a week a...

Posts.Content: Hi  Allison,  Trying to figure out when is best to return to work is a tough one. Depends on what you do, how much stuffing the treatment has knocked out of you and how long it takes for all the side effects to wane. Jackie had mx 3 fec 3 tax and 15 rads and was off for a total of 8 months. She felt she could have gone back a month or so earlier but because she works with mrsa patients and the ever present dreaded norovirus threat she was given an extra 2 months off. First 2 weeks back she worked 2 hours at a time only, then 4 hours at a time for the next 2 weeks testing the water before going back to normal hours thereafter. Her work entails a lot of patient handling, corridor walking and stairs to tackle so the extra 2 months off made a great difference. It will always hit you hard to start with, using muscles that have had a long holiday while you had to fight the BC battle. LIke other advice here start things off slowly and see how it goes and if your manager/boss tries to get too pushy, tough they'll have to cope, it's your life and if they don't value you as an employee use your slow return to work to find alternative job. Most employers are brilliant when shi* like this happens but there are always some who couldn't care less and try to lay a guilt trip on you. If you can financially afford to grab some more time off and make the most of the change in the weather that's supposed to happen next week  :-) I think SSP is payable for a max of 28 weeks, dunno how long you have been off so far ? Hope you get plenty of info and ideas to help you decide if it's  going to be feet up, or nose down  LOL Good luck and best wishes,  George & Jackie.

Posts.Content: Hi,  Must admit to agreeing with Rebecca about it being the least of our concerns whilst going through treatment. The main reason for such extensive cctv is to make sure they can maintain close observation for patient body movement that can throw the guidance off. It only has to be a cm out and it could target areas not meant to be treated. The margins can be quite close to lung, heart and other sensitive areas and arteries that is why they take so long setting the alignment marks so precisely every day. They have almost certainly seen it all at one time or another, from those who have a panic attack to patients shaking with fear. Bit like having a midwife and maternity nurses close up at a birth, it's all for your benefit so try to view it as a safeguard. Hope this helps,  George & Jackie.

Posts.Title: ANASTRAZOLE

Posts.Content: Hiya Leen, Welcome to a great place but at a tough time. As you are finding this is a steep learning curve so lets help to see if we can at least help you find the 4 corners and if we're lucky some edge bits too :-) Please do think long and hard about this nipple choice. I'm fairly sure most here would not want to keep a nipple that has been anywhere near close to a tumour in case it comes back to bite them in a year or two's time. Last thing you want is to have to go through all this treatment again. Another point to bear in mind is that the surgeons do try to take the minimum amount of tissue to keep as good a breast shape as possible, the down side to this is 1 in 4 get called back for a little more to be taken because they don't quite get clear margins of cancer free tissue.  The 'feelings' you get from a reconstructed nipple will be nowhere near the same either but at least you will have something as a focal point. You could go the 3D tattoo route depends on if it can be matched to your other nipple. Just to make you aware the pathology information from the removed tissue and sentinel nodes can change your treatment programme depending on the results you won't find this out until two weeks after the surgery. The MRI and/or CT scans are standard so yes, normal but not everybody gets one - they just try to gather as much info as possible so they can fine tune and tailor your treatment programme post surgery. Hope this is of some use, if you have any more questions even if they seem 'silly' ones just holler. We're all here to help, take care George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed invasive ductal carcinoma.

Posts.Content: Morning Nicky, Yes, that's a good info page - Remember reading that quite a while back and posted something very similar into this reply (see below) about oestrogens back in August. Oestrogen plays such an important role throughout the body, zapping it's production is bound to have knock on effects :( Hugs, G n' J SpicedTea  Oestrogen is one of the bodies feel good hormones and there are 3 types of it (one of which is still made post menopause) and it circulates around the body in the bloodstream so gets everywhere. What does Oestrogen do in the body? Oestrogen controls the first part of the menstrual cycle, causes changes in the breasts and uterus, regulates various other metabolic processes, including bone growth and cholesterol levels and keeps organs such as the brain, liver and heart healthy. Symptoms of an Oestrogen Imbalance One of the difficulties with identifying an oestrogen imbalance is that many of the symptoms associated with oestrogen deficiency can be the same as oestrogen dominance. They include; Temperature issues such as hot flushing Irritability or depression Poor concentration and forgetfulness Fatigue and lethargy Loss of confidence Aching joints Weight gain, especially around the stomach and thighs Osteoporosis Digestive complaints Endometriosis Fibroids Infertility I think your Oncologists WD40 metaphor is pretty damn good as research shows a lack of oestrogen can cause lower fluid levels around joints. This where the hormone inhibitor tablets (AI's) stop the production of the third oestrogen type (Estrone) after the menopause and also where ovaries have been removed or chemically stopped - which is there to take care of joints after the menopause :( Estrone is given to horses to soften tendons and ligaments so a lack of it must surely affect people (stiffness) in the same way too ? Declining oestrogen levels are also directly linked to declining levels of serotonin, and this lack of serotonin can lead to low mood, and even trigger symptoms of depression. Besides serotonin, oestrogen also blocks the production of cortisol, the stress hormone that triggers your 'fight or flight' reflex, and progesterone has a calming effect. With lower levels of both hormones, you may find yourself feeling more panicky and experiencing symptoms of anxiety, making it very difficult for you to feel relaxed. These two hormones, progesterone and particularly oestrogen, therefore play a really important part in helping you maintain a positive sense of emotional wellbeing and, as their levels decrease, you become increasingly vulnerable to these distressing changes in mood. As for PN this can take a whole year to repair itself as best as it can, but anyone suffering from chemo induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) may be left with some permanent residual damage like numbness or nerve pain - (mostly affecting toes and fingertips) Hope this helps and doesn't have too many 'should's and maybe's :) Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: swelling of arm

Posts.Content: Hi Jacky,  Can give you a bit of info but if you use the cancer information button and type in work or disability and equality there is literally loads of info about this. 1 = Not just for employment, it can cover things like a blue badge for parking - Benefits and allowances DLA / PIP / ESA, free prescriptions etc 2 = They will never say you are clear as they cannot guarantee every cancer cell has been eliminated. Best you will get is NED (no evidence of disease) which isn't quite the same thing. 3 = It is best you do - because you will then be covered by the disability / equality acts. This is taken from the book 'Work and Cancer' which has a section about looking for a new job on page 76. Many people with cancer don’t consider themselves to be  disabled, and if they’re asked in general terms whether they  consider themselves disabled they’ll say ‘no’. However, if you’re  asked by your employer if you’re disabled, you should say ‘yes’ for  the purposes of the Equality Act and the Disability Discrimination  Act. This is because everyone with cancer is covered by these acts  and the term ‘disabled’ has a specific meaning under the acts. Hope this helps, G n' J
Posts.Title: Cancer diagnosis = disability?

Posts.Content: Hiya Jacky, Yes it's a minefield - so many terms each with their own meaning :-( Some people post cancer are left in a bad way others appear perfectly normal depends on the cancer and how much they chucked at you during treatment.  You can be classed as cured as that is the aim of the treatment but never clear that is why they use this NED comment - all they can say is at the time of checking they found nothing. It's a bit like you get sick you take medicine and are cured but that doesn't mean you won't get that same illness again sometime. You get on with your life and try to think no more about it. Just try to carry on life as near to the new normal as you feel up to doing. Don't let cancer make you a prisoner you can do whatever you want to do  :-) Onwards and Upwards, G n' J BTW Peanuts Mum -  Prescription charges for cancer patients were abolished on April 1 2009. Exemption certificates will be issued to those applicants who, in their doctor's judgement, are receiving treatment for: cancer the effects of cancer, or the effects of current or previous cancer treatment As Jacky said get one either from the hospital or a GP - It's valid for 5 years
Posts.Title: Cancer diagnosis = disability?

Posts.Content: Happy Easter Monday Morning - Hope you saved some choccy egg for today  :) A lot of the onco folks will try to dissuade you from using scalp cooling as it adds to the chemo units already busy workload, and adds cost to your treatment but it's your choice and if you want to try it you should be allowed to without feeling you are putting them out. It works by narrowing the capillaries which restricts the blood supply reaching your hair follicles - some doctors are concerned that the caps may prevent the chemotherapy medicine from reaching any cancer cells that may be in the scalp - studies in Europe, where cold caps have been used longest, found that scalp cooling does not increase risk of scalp skin metastases. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Deb,  How did you get on at your appointment yesterday ? Very similar scenario to Kath. Jackie works in a residential nursing home where the work can be physical at times and originally was told to take the full 6 months off to fully recover but because of some residents being MRSA and C-Dif sufferers, coupled with lots of stair climbing and corridor walking our GP gave her an added two months. She went back on a phased return but because of ongoing 'baggage' from Letrozole she stepped up from 10 hours a week to 16 hours and for her that is now plenty. Seen plenty of posts here from those who in retrospect made the wrong choice and went back too early considering the battering they had just endured and it affected them emotionally feeling they could no longer do their job as before. So maybe if you feel up to it and you feel your job is do'able, give it a go, but do expect to only be able to cope with doing half your normal hours as you may find just after midday all your get up and go, has got up and gone  :-) Don't underestimate the chemo fatigue, take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Content: Hi  Chris,  When you had treatment for BC were you given any of the 5 year hormone inhibitor tablets like Tamoxifen or Letrozole ?  Reason for asking is that there are two types of bone scan. One is a DEXA scan which checks for bone thinning caused by lack of oestrogen caused by those hormone tabs which can lead to being Osteopaenic and feeling a bit arthritic. If this is the case and they find bone thinning you'll just get adcal and sunvit and maybe alendronic acid tablets to take. The other type of bone scan is usually performed using a CT or MRI scanner.  Did they tell you which type of scan you are to have ? Best wishes and good luck on the results for whichever scan you have. Oh, and put £5 in the swear box for using Google  :-)
