Posts.Title: I don't quite understand

Posts.Content: Hi Kimlinda, Yes, a Breast Nurse isn't just for Christmas :) Once you get assigned one you can contact her long past treatment for opinions and advice. Like MM said it could be something like eczema or a late side effect of rads ? The symptoms of Paget's are - The most common symptom is a red, scaly rash involving the nipple, which may spread to the areola (the darker skin around the nipple). The rash can feel itchy or you may have a burning sensation. The nipple may be inverted (pulled in) and there may also be discharge from the nipple. Paget’s disease can look like other skin conditions such as eczema or psoriasis. But there are differences. For example, Paget’s disease affects the nipple from the start while eczema generally affects the areola region and only rarely affects the nipple. Also, Paget’s disease usually occurs in one breast while most other skin conditions tend to affect both breasts. You are doing the right thing getting it checked out if only for answers and peace of mind. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Crusted nipple

Posts.Content: Evening pinkshoe  It's just another way of being able to tweak your hormone therapy tablets to suit your particular diagnosis. The aromatase inhibitors (letrozole, anastrozole & exemestane) are better for post meno women because their ovaries have already gone into shutdown. As the AI's aren't as effective as Tamoxifen for fully halting oestrogen production from the ovaries - hence the Zoladex to take care of this. It no doubt will be because you are prone to thrombosis as Tamoxifen does have a slightly higher risk of this, so for you this is probably the best way forward :) Good luck for minimal side effects, G n' J
Posts.Title: letrozole and zoladex

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny,  As Juju says Taxol (Paclitaxel) is like docetaxel but with velvet gloves on and most find they don't get slapped around anywhere near as much  (good cop - bad cop)  LOL Same side effects but mostly milder. G n' J
Posts.Title: Weekly taxol side effects

Posts.Content: Hi Simba,  Sounds like the tamox is busy gathering up all your oestrogen which can effect your serotonin production ( feel good hormone ) in the process. A bit like how oestrogen production drops right down after pregnancy and can cause post natal depression. Slight feelings of doom and gloom are not that uncommon with tamox but seeing as you have only been on them for 10 days you may find it gets better after a while longer on them. Phone your onco nurse/ dr  tomorrow and tell them how tamox is making you feel, they may suggest you stop for a while and see if you improve. If that's the case they may be able to switch you onto an alternative. Mind you an alternative may not be any better just different side effects. Just a thought, don't know if you take them morning or evening, if you are taking them of an evening and wake feeling like that, try switching to taking them in the morning - might help - anything is worth a try, but don't keep this to yourself, they wouldn't want you suffering, you are going to be on them for a while, so you have to get  something sorted out to help bring those smiles back. Best wishes and good luck,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: PMS and Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi, Just wanted to add tuppence worth... We were both long term smokers and tried using patches, then Champix - which messed sleep patterns up so much we soon gave those to the bin :-) Both bought Exhale e-cigs online that use the 'flavoured fluids' and rechargeable batteries and found it easy. You still get the nicotine so the craving is minimal and you can wean yourself off that by gradually reducing the nicotine content in the fluids. Been 3 years now and was the best move we made. G n' J
Posts.Title: Nxt hurdle

Posts.Content: Evening Syers, As you have probably figured out EC is the same as FEC but without the F part which is Fluorouracil also known as 5fu. Don't worry yourself you are missing out as everyones chemo regime is tailored specifically to them taking everything into consideration. Perhaps there is some medical history that makes Fluorouracil chemotherapy unsuitable for you. If you would have benefitted from it, they would have offered it. There is an info page about EC here. As for recovery from surgery - some take longer to heal and develop more scar tissue than others. This will subside but can take quite a while as long as you are doing the post op arm exercises to help with mobility and movement. If you have any other concerns or questions, don't hesitate to ask, we're all here to help and there is no such thing as a silly question :-) Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: EC vs FEC

Posts.Content: Hiya, Like lestony said in J's case she was also referred by her GP (this is the more common way) so it will probably be your GP who gets the results as it is they who will prescribe on a repeat any anti-ostopaenia meds if the results deem you need them. If it doesn't seem your GP is telling you much about the results, do ask. G n' J
Posts.Title: dexa scan results

Posts.Content: Hi Bunty-ann  Welcome to a great place to be at a tough time. You didn't post your other message in the wrong place :)   it's just the new to site group is like a landing pad so regular members can reply and direct you to the the most suitable areas here. From what you describe this sounds like nerves that were damaged during surgery trying to repair themselves, this can cause some really weird and varying sensations at times but does ease off quite a bit, however it can also take quite a while and in some cases can leave you feeling a slightly numb in some areas. This effect is quite common and quite a few ladies here have had this. It may also be an internal stitch rubbing  if those were used - if that is the case it should ease when any swelling has gone.? Depending on how you recover from surgery chemo can start as quickly as 4 weeks but the average is around 6 weeks, some even longer. You will usually get about a weeks notice and go in to the chemo unit for a pre session assessment where they weigh and measure you as the dosage levels are worked out on BMI The thought of having chemo can be a scary trip into the unknown there are common side effects but there are also ways of dealing with those, so don't keep secrets :) Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Im newby here

Posts.Content: Hi JJ, PICC lines can be great - Did you get much info about them when you got offered one ? If not just click the link. As for the feeling crappy bit - When and how crappy is the $64K question. You could feel a bit nauseous later tonight or overnight, you may be lucky and not suffer too much with FEC at all it effects everyone differently. Do take all the meds to keep on top of the nausea even if you feel well as it's easier to prevent sickness than stop it once it has started. Drink plenty of fluids 2 litres a day at least. Hairloss can start 10-22 days from first session and a sore scalp is a good clue to this starting to happen. Any questions keep us posted and we'll all help where we can. If the steroids are keeping you awake try to take the last one no later than 3pm. Good luck with any side effects, G n' J
Posts.Title: How soon will I feel crappy?

Posts.Content: Hi Bunty-ann  Please don't get overwrought from reading all the chemo 'help me' messages here. People only post when they have a problem, those who are doing OK have no need to put up a message so you get a very one sided view of chemo :-/ It's only after you have been here a while you tend to notice 'I didn't have many problems with the FEC or T' messages, or I found one was OK but not the other etc. If you are the type who gets travel sickness or had issues with morning sickness when pregnant you could be one of those who does get the feelings of nausea worse with FEC but there are better anti-nausea tablets you can get if this happens. You just don't know how either will affect you until you start your sessions, then you have to ride out your own particular storm be that breezy with showers or a whole week feeling crappy. For most is is just the first week with FEC and days 4-10 with T that are the worst and it soon passes and you come back out of the chemo fog almost overnight :) However there can be some longer term issues as uncommon side effects - the trick is not to keep secrets. If anything seems different tell your Onco or breast care nurse and write about it here to get answers / advice so you can keep on top of "stuff" a lot of the time it is something that soon passes but can be a sign of a problem in the making that needs nipping in the bud. Either by reducing your dose by 20% or possibly switching  to another chemo drug. The only silly question is the one that isn't asked, so just ask -  we're all here to help :) Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Chemo consult

Posts.Content: Morning Suse, Your fears about re-ocurrence or spread raising their heads again eh :-(  Please don't keep torturing yourself about this. They do check your 'bloods' for cancer markers so if nothing is found there is no need for a scan to confirm what they already know. You just need to have a bit more faith in your team to get you through this. Worrying about tomorrow will stop you enjoying today!   The effect of chemo is harsh and accumulative and can take from six months to a year to be anywhere near to feeling back to normal, it will be awhile as yet so don't expect too much too soon, your poor body has been through a lot since diagnosis. You will be CT scanned again at your radiotherapy planning / assessment appointment which must be coming up (around 4 weeks after your last chemo) Keep an eye on the calendar and get ready to say goodbye to the chemo unit :-) Onwards and Upwards Suse, your'e nearly there :-) Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer Nov 14'. Lumpectomy no spread in lymph...

Posts.Content: I'll drink to that - I already am actually. I have a bottle of my fave Hobgoblin open at this very moment. I could be persuaded (very easily) to drink a toast to all you lovely ladies tomorrow too :-) and NO, it's not me on the label  LOL G n' J
Posts.Title: Raising a glass to everyone going through treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Skippy,  Assume the Lenograstim is to build up white cells ? Is she on chemo at the moment then, as it's also used for stem cell transplants......... This is a list of the side effects of Lenograstim. Very common: More than 1 in 10 people who have Lenograstim can have Back pain, bonepain, diarrhoea, fever - (seek immediate medical advice if you develop a fever), hair loss, headaches, infections, inflammation of the mouth, nausea, sepsis, vomiting,weakness. Reason for asking about chemo is that the list of side effects is about the same, so if she is undergoing chemo, the feeling of being run over by a bus could be from that. Paracetamol may help but it lowers the temp so could give a false thermometer reading when checking for infection. Would be better if she rang her unit to check the side effects with them. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Lenograstin injection

Posts.Content: Hiya Carol, Sorry to read your dad has to have chemo. Unfortunately there are literally loads of different chemo drugs. Some fluid, some taken as tablets, a few even injected. Given that and the fact they also use combinations of drugs (like the FEC for breast cancer) until your mum can find out the name of what he'll be having it's a needle in haystack job. It will probably be one of the more common types of chemo for his type of cancer but that only narrows it down a bit :-( You can find the list of individual chemo drugs here, so at least when you know which type he will be having you can look it up and just click on the name. If he getting a combi-chemo regime there is a link for that at the bottom of the left hand list. (combination regimen) Good luck to him with it, and you as well, G n' J
Posts.Title: Confused daughter

Posts.Content: Evening Marg,  Loads'a hugs and best wishes for tomorrow. Fingers and toes crossed you get no infection or seroma hassles. Think your biggest problem for a few days will be finding a comfortable position to sleep in. Don't forget it can take up to a week to get the anesthetic out of your system and a known side effect is it may make you feel a bit down. Won't be too long before you can have bags of Pina Colada's hanging from your drip stand  LOL Take care Marg, G n' J
Posts.Title: op day tomorrow

Posts.Content: Morning Kelly, Welcome to Maccyland but sorry to see you joining. Notice you have been there, done most of that and now enjoying getting to know the new you. Hope you are finding things do'able. There have been a few posts here about the Strattice pocket hammock and implant recon and most seem happy with the results problem is as you say not all hospitals carry out the strattice procedure and they won't do it if you are going to have radiotherapy after surgery either as it is harmful to the strattice. They can use either pig or cow skin to get around some religious issues. If you type strattice into the search this site box there's bound to be a couple of links if you want more info. oh, and btw tram/diep is where they use stomach skin, tissue and/or muscle to use for the recon. Best wishes, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Selfies and donations

Posts.Content: Hi Jeanette, Seeing as you have just completed 3 sessions, is your chemo regime due to change for the other sessions, or are you continuing with the same type of chemo + Could you name them please ? As in some cases they can reduce the dosage by 20% which makes it more doable but it all depends on which drugs you are having..... The only one they can change from 3 weekly to weekly is switching from 3 weekly Docetaxel also known as Taxotere to weekly Paclitaxel also known asTaxol. G n' J
Posts.Title: Can I change the frequency of my Chemo?

Posts.Content: Hiya, Vibration plates are supposedly good for helping with lymphoedema by getting the lymph fluid moving. I think this is where the scare mongering comes in - as some say 'IF' there are any cells floating around in lymph fluid this will move them around more ? but lymph fluid is moving around all the time and the chemo and rads etc should have zapped those (hopefully) anyway. They are also reckoned on being helpful if you have some osteopaenia issues (not arthritis though) A lot of fitness centre's  will need a doctors note to say using these is OK before they will let you use them but this wouldn't apply if yours was at home. There is a lot on conflicting info about these, so If in doubt ask your GP for their opinion, but as Julia says any activity will get your fluids moving around. Having said that, half of the med's folk can't agree on this subject either :-/ Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Vibration Plate

Posts.Content: Morning Improudofme, and so you should be. You don't know how strong you are until being strong is the only option eh ? Sorry to read you have to endure another week of waiting results - It's a tough enough time as it is without having an extension.  There's no easy way of getting through the time. If this was pre surgery you could have done things, or gone places with the kids but you are probably still a bit sore and fragile so limited to what you can do. I'd love to type a bit more but have to leave for work in a bit, but you will soon get some other replies. If you own a tablet or laptop candy crush is a good time waster :-) Take care and good luck with those results, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Stupid lab machine broken, results postponed ...

Posts.Content: Hi, Seeing as you are continuing with the Doc-Carbo (clickable link) and you have already had 3 Docetaxel I don't think they will change the Docetaxel to Taxol now as it may alter the effectiveness of the Carboplatin part, and it would create problems and probably not be workable as the Taxol would be weekly but the Carboplatin and Herceptin would still be 3 weekly. What you could do is contact your onco team and explain the problems you are having and ask if they will reduce the dosage for you. You could also ask about Taxol instead of Docetaxel but don't get your hopes up with that option. Good luck getting a reduction - 20% may not seem much but it helps a lot with the side effects. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: ECG feel exposed

Posts.Content: Morning  Gillie, Shaky, achey, bit like you are coming down with flu, typical start to FEC. Days 3-6 are usually the worst then you slowly come out of it although for the second week you are more prone to picking up bugs while your white count is low and you will be feeling lethargic. Then you day by day perk up just in time for round two. Some suffer more s/e's than others - Fingers crossed you are one of the lucky ones who sail through it just feeling slightly crap. Be prepared for the odd duvet day on the sofa and daytime tv or a dvd though. You did the right thing checking your temp it's quite important to get to know your routine. Temps can shoot up overnight if you have picked up a bug so if you notice it reaching 37.5 give the onco dept a ring, they may have you in and check you out, maybe give you some antibio's. Keep up any sickness meds wether you feel you need them or not because if you are sick you won't know if you brought up the tabs then it's a bugger trying to keep on top of it. As for the hair Jackie's head started getting sore and as her hair was long the weight of it pulling on the dying roots was making it feel worse so she had a short pixie cut (instant relief) until it started falling out a week or so later, then she got me to shave it for her. I called her my Bad Ass Biker Chick  :-) Are your 6 chemo's all FEC, or 3 x FEC and 3 x Tax ? Reason I ask is that they both effect hair dif, J's head hair started growing back quite quickly when she started Tax, she was a peach within 6 weeks but her eyebrows and eyelashes fell out as soon as the Tax got into her system. Keep us up to speed with how you are getting along Gillie so we can help you along and don't "put up" with any side effects that are getting you down mention it to your onco team as there are remedies for all the baggage that chemo brings. Just treat chemo as your friend. Best wishes and good luck for the coming week, George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: woke up feeling shaky - 3 days after starting Fec

Posts.Content: Hiya Suse, Know where you are coming from. Lost my dad to asbestos related emphysema and mother to lung spread from breast cancer. Think it alters your outlook and makes you more aware of what could happen - but you can't dwell on that, they are not you and medicine has moved on a great deal even over the last few years. You want survivors, Jackie has just got the no evidence of disease result from her 3 year review (diagnosed May 2012) Left breast mastectomy, 3 x FEC 3 x Taxotere, 18 Herceptin and 15 Rads, now enjoying being halfway through 5 years of Letrozole (not) but halfway is better than just starting :-) Re - going back to work, don't jump in try to do too many hours too soon, a staged return is definitely the way to go. Holiday, do what you would like to do as a reward. Time to be nice to yourself, you've earned it :-) Your light is at the end of the tunnel, you just got to wait for the sun to burn off the chemo fog. G n' J
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer Nov 14'. Lumpectomy no spread in lymph...

Posts.Content: Morning Yvonne,  Like a lot of replies mention, unfortunately the old you may never fully return. You have to get used to the new you - All the treatments are giving you a whole body upgrade. May not seem like there is much 'up' about it, but when rads are done with and your treatment ends you will have the label "No Evidence of Disease" that is a definite improvement and gives you a future you may not of had if this was all left untreated  :-/ It's going to take a while longer getting used to life in the left hand lane. Some days you'll be able to go up a gear and, move over and do some overtaking on other days you'll just cough and splutter and no matter how hard you put your foot down nothing much happens, and if it does you soon end up having a rest in the nearest lay-by :-( Think you are suffering a bit of fatigue, so I'll stick in the link to Maccy info page about that just to see if it helps you get your head around the total body tiredness thing. You can find it here.... Have you got much travelling to do for your daily rads  ? - ours was a 70 mile round trip and that can get a bit tiring too on top of radiotherapy, so hopefully your unit will be closer and less travel hassle. Your'e not quite out of the woods yet Yvonne, but you have got all summer to enjoy your recovery. Best wishes, G n' J

Posts.Title: The Royal Marsden Cancer Cookbook

Posts.Content: Hi Fifelass, Heather77 here was on Letrozole for over a year before surgery - I've 'tagged' her name so hopefully she will be notified of your post and will reply but Heather hasn't posted for around a month now. You can read one of Heathers posts clicking here. There may be a few others here that were on Letrozole long term prior to surgery but it is an uncommon treatment regime. Usually it is either chemo first to shrink the tumour or surgery first then depending on the pathology results, whatever comes next. Has anyone explained the reason why they are going about it this way ? G n' J
Posts.Title: Letrozole before surgery.

Posts.Content: Hopefully you'll get some replies from others here who have had Taxol (Paclitaxel) (link) which isn't the same as Taxotere (docetaxel) As you mentioned taxol is given weekly and the side effects are usually a lot easier to deal as the weekly doses do not make such a hard hit on the body as the the three weekly Docetaxel.  The side effects listed are about the same but any you get are usually at a lot lower level. Taxol is mostly used in private healthcare clinics. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: taxol

Posts.Content: Hi, When you start getting to the reconstruction stage (most surgeons prefer you to wait until after radiotherapy) as it can have an effect on their good work. If you are larger breasted they will mostly offer you a reduction on your good side. There are a couple of reasons for this. They tend not to perform large reconstructions because of either not enough tissue for flap types from the donor site plus it makes the reconstruction heavy pulling on sutures with the possibilty of complications and taking longer to heal. I'm uncertain as to what size the implant type of recons can safely be expanded to ? If this reduction is OK'd they may do it at the same time, but could also want you to wait to see what size your reconstruction ends up at post surgery to gauge the amount of reduction needed for symmetry at a later date ? If this reduction isn't mentioned do ask about it. Without this you will be left  a bit 'unbalanced' Maybe those who have had recon's could comment about size and balance and offer some advice ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Hi Eni  Warm welcome to the breast group, just about the busiest group here. Which is a good thing as there is always someone at the same stage of treatment that you can share with and of course advice and support from those who have been there, done that :) They can only tell so much from scans and biopsies - It's not until any removed tissue is examined in the pathology lab and you get their report through you get all the finer details of your diagnosis. Some of these tests like HER2 can take around 10 days. Most find they get nearly all their pathology information a bit sooner but still have to wait a few extra days for the HER2 findings. This is used by your MDT (multi disciplinary team) to work out a personal treatment plan. Like will you need chemo, radiotherapy and if you need long term hormone inhibitor tablets ? In a word yes things change, and often do,  tumour sizes can be found to be different and also the grade can change up or down. There is always something they can still offer you. Once you get this information and know how this is going to pan out you can cope much better as it gives you something to focus on rather than all this waiting and worrying on the full results period. Please don't get distressed over another couple of weeks wait, nothing drastic is going to occur as a result of a the extra wait. Try to do enjoyable things in this quiet time in the run up to surgery, rather than worrying about what if's and things you can't change :) Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Results after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hiya, Good call from Helen. R1 & R2 are fairly new radio products and have now been made available on prescription so if you can't get these from the rads unit, do see your GP to grab some (gotta love free prescriptions) R1 is used straight after each session and R2 during the evening and for 14 days after your sessions end. Another which can help cool but not help with any burning is 90% Aloe Vera from the fridge but if you can get r1 and r2 you shouldn't need that. Similarly if you can't get the r1 & r2 and you do start to get a bit of burning something like Flammazine would help. Also do check out with your hospital about parking. Most offer free daily parking for Rads patients, either in the way of a free swipe ticket or refunding parking costs after treatment. You could check this online, you will need to present your appointments schedule letter to confirm this so you could ask at the desk when you go for your pre-rads appointment. G n' J
Posts.Title: Hormone & Radiotherapy Consultation Tomorrow - what should I ask ...

Posts.Content: Morning Gem1981  Not that we like seeing new members but warm welcome to the breast group, a good place to find yourself at a tough time. IDC is the most common type of breast cancer so has plenty of successful treatments to get you free of this pesky invader and has a 90% recovery rate. The other 10% are those found really advanced, elderly or have underlying health issues that eliminate most of the treatment options. No doubt you have lots of what if questions that have popped up since getting through the emotional waiting results period, so fire away - We're all here to help and there are loads of us here all at various stages of treatment. You could have a look through this 'Invasive Ductal Carcinoma' booklet to get an idea of what may lie ahead but do take all this one step at a time to avoid getting information overload. You can save this to your device if you find it helpful. You only really need to know about what the first stage of your treatment regime will be. That could be surgery, or in some cases chemotherapy is offered prior to surgery to shrink things down to minimise surgery. Chances are being stage and grade 2 it may well be surgery first - Is your next appointment with a surgeon or oncologist as this would be a clue ? Anything goes here from typing the fear or anger out to getting friendly, honest replies and sharing the things that make us laugh. You can do this, hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Manila honey & vitamin d3

Posts.Content: Reworked this pam ayers classic for BC - from her old poem (wish I'd looked after my teeth) Not trying to make light of this, but you have to keep things upbeat sometimes.   G n' J ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- They were prodded and poked positioned and squashed A mammogram taken and all hope is lost It’s too late now to count all the cost I wish I'd felt both of me tits.   Next step is the surgeon that you have to see He recommends node clearance and mastectomy My eyes are now teary, surely this cannot be Oh I wish I'd felt both of me tits.   His work completed and my heads in a mess How can I now wear that new low cut dress When I'm now so uneven, I sob in distress Oh I wish I'd felt both of me tits.   With picc line inserted and chemo to follow You begin to worry but mostly feel hollow What is the outcome, what sort of tomorrow Oh I wish I'd felt both of me tits.   Your hair all falls out, your suddenly bald even on warm days you always feel cold On with the hat now permanently installed Oh I wish I'd felt both of me tits.   The next step in the process of this little show Is radiotherapy, how much will I glow ? I could lay an egg there and cook it you know Oh I wish I'd felt both of me tits.   I’ve twisted and turned, with this roller coaster Been cut and poisoned and put on a roaster The future will tell if we killed this imposter Oh I wished I'd felt both of me tits.

Posts.Title: Lymphangitis

Posts.Content: Evening Macrad Thanks for checking it out and commenting. It's great to get some input from those with experience in the field :) There seems to be a lot of positive outcomes from those that have used R1 & R2 either through prescription or buying over the counter. Hopefully as more evidence is gathered it will either be generally accepted as fit for purpose or not. I think a lot more info could be gathered if Rad units did follow up exams post treatment to check on post rads effects depending on which product is given or used. Don't know if this is still the norm but in our case post rads (Oct 2012) there was no other radiology appointment to check on healing progress or after effects - So unless there is substantial burning or lung clipping damage it would seem there was no direct info being fed back on patients aftercare to the radiology unit. Getting Flamazine and anything else was done via GP. At the pre-rads appt Jackie asked about cream and was just told to buy any aqueous cream or something like E45 as they didn't supply any - also we got no information about how or when to use it either. Hopefully things have changed in those 3+ years :) Thanks a bunch, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy, You have had some great advice already - There is this Mac Information page about 'Work and Cancer' which covers just about everything work related. Your company may well feel they are helping by giving you a lighter role but they aren't allowed to just do this without consulting you and you agreeing to the move, even on a trial period. Some companies just don't know about cancer and rights at work, others either don't care or think they can just shove you around as they know you are probably too knackered to argue about it :-/ Do please use the free support line 0808 808 0000 after 9am and speak to one of the work / financial advisors, they are great. Good luck getting what you want out of them, G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning zaf37  I think with the ROSCO Trial it is only the chemo that can be stopped if you get a complete pathological response - your Herceptin will probably still continue for one year. There is a separate PERSEPHONE Trial where herceptin for 9 cycles was compared to 18 the results of this are to be published later this year but looks promising. If however during treatment your herceptin gets put on 'hold' for whatever reason as the herceptin is only licensed by NICE for one year and that year runs out any remaining doses won't be funded unless you are metastatic (secondaries) J had a 2 week break for heart muscle recovery about halfway though her herceptin so wasn't allowed the last dose as her year was up. For anyone curious ?  Herceptin is around £1,250 per dose :-O Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Scared about today

Posts.Content: Evening Sally,  Sorry to see you here, really knocks you sideways when you get diagnosed eh :-( When you say Oestrogen and HER2 free you mean ER and HER2 negative ? Have they mentioned PR (progesterone) negative as well or are you unsure about that one. If you are negative for all three that is known as Triple Negative, and as you say the hormone targeted tablets will be of no use because they are taken to counter receptors that feed off your own hormones only if you are positive for ER or PR likewise (Herceptin is for HER2+ only) These are not the HRT tablets you are thinking of, these hormone targeted tablets do not replace hormones they actively reduce hormones to a level where they starve the cancer cells of food. If it turns out you are Triple Neg there is an Macmillan info page here. Obviously bon't bother reading it until you know either way. It's there if you need it. Have they given you a stage/grade from histology of the lump removed or are you still waiting results from that ? In a sentinel node check, taken from nearest the lump chances are it was the nearest one with some cells in it. The others to be taken will give a much clearer picture as to if it has spread to these or not but for obvious reasons they have to be looked at. It's the nodes job to trap these cells and produce antibodies so they were doing their job. That is why you will have to be careful to not injure that arm after removal as your antibody producing nodes that side will be gone and infections in that arm can be a problem. You are not even allowed blood pressure cuff to be used or blood taken for testing (no needles)  from that arm afterwards. So always offer your good side arm. There is a lot going on at the moment for you to get your head around, once some sort of treatment plan is in place you can take it one step at a time.  As for your hockey, can't see any reason why you couldn't get back into it, but you only you will be able see if you are up to your usual fitness post treatment and can still give it your all. Take care Sally, keep posting, there's no such thing as a silly question. George & Jackie
Posts.Title: New Cancer patient

Posts.Content: Morning Andrea, Sorry this is a quick answer as I have to go to work. This sounds like hand foot syndrome also known as Palmar Plantar. There is some info about it here.  It's chemo damage to the capillaries in your hands and feet. Try not to rub or massage them as more pressure can make it worse. Please let your onco unit know about this and see your gp to get some medication to ease the pain. Hopefully you'll get some more answers as it is fairly common with Tax they may reduce your last dose a bit to help lessen the effects which will help. Lowering the dose 20% or so won't put you at any risk. Take care, George & Jackie P.S.  Back home now so I can give this some more time. As you are finding this is a very painful condition and the more you walk or handle things the worse it seems to get as it spreads the residue chemo about damaging more capilleries. So try to avoid anything that causes friction to hands or feet. The best info page I found that can be easily understood (medical jargon Huh) is the american cancer.net info site. A lot go into detail about what is and how it is caused but only this one seems to give you helpful things to do the ease it. You can find that here. Hope this helps, like I said do mention it to your onco team and your gp as you may need him/her if they think vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) would help which has to be prescribed. G n' J

Posts.Title: Breast Surgeon With Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hiya,  Well apart from the constant battle between constipation and the opposite during chemo Jackie's biggest problem was taste issues rather than foods giving her stomach ache. Everything tasted 'Tinny' or like cardboard so she only craved highly flavoured foods like chilli and curry based meals with rice or pasta. Which we probably lived on for around 6 months, none of which caused any problems or reflux.  Some things fell by the wayside, even now 30 months on she still cannot eat milk chocolate or drink coffee but dark chocolate is def now on the menu :-) If reflux is a problem you didn't have before it may be worth asking about it - If it caused by heartburn (or reflux) which can be a side effect of cancer treatment there are several dif tablets that could help Some tips to help try and reduce heartburn are - Limit your caffeine intake – for example, reduce canned drinks, coffee, chocolate and tea Raise the head of your bed when sleeping or lying down, or higher pillows. Don't eat for 2 or 3 hours before going to bed Reduce fatty foods in your diet, such as deep fried foods Avoid foods and drinks that may cause heartburn, such as citrus fruits (oranges, grapefruits), mints and alcohol  Get some anti heartburn tablets prescribed from your doctor but let them know if they are not helping as there are several types you can try. Doesn't say anything about reducing cake intake LOL Cakes are the new flowers, so tell all your friends to  - :-)   G n' J
Posts.Title: Food changes

Posts.Content: Hi Bandele, This info is routinely handed out to patients in Canada and the US, so I'm wondering if you are across the 'Big Pond' or if the NHS in the UK has started giving this helpful advice also ?  If this is the same info, it only applies to the first 48 hours after the session :) Information regarding bodily fluids - Does it read something like this.... ? How can I protect myself and those I live with while I’m getting chemo? There are many things you can do during and after chemo to keep yourself and your loved ones from being affected by the chemo drugs while your body is getting rid of them. It takes about 48 hours for your body to break down and/or get rid of most chemo drugs. Most of the waste comes out in your body fluids – urine, stool, tears, and vomit. The drugs are also in your blood. When chemo drugs get outside your body, they can harm or irritate skin – yours or even other people’s. Keep in mind that this means toilets can be a hazard for children and pets, and it’s important to be careful. Talk to your doctor about these and any other precautions you should follow. During – and for 48 hours after – chemo: • Flush the toilet twice after you use it. Put the lid down before flushing to avoid splashing. If possible, you may want to use a separate toilet during this time. If this is not possible, wear gloves to clean the toilet seat after each use. • Both men and women should sit on the toilet to use it. This cuts down on splashing. • Always wash your hands with warm water and soap after using the toilet. Dry your hands with paper towels and throw them away. • If you vomit into the toilet, clean off all splashes and flush twice. If you vomit into a bucket or basin, carefully empty it into the toilet without splashing the contents and flush twice. Wash out the bucket with hot, soapy water and rinse it, emptying the wash and rinse water into the toilet, then flushing it. Dry the bucket with paper towels and throw them away. • Caregivers should wear 2 pairs of throw-away gloves if they need to touch any of your body fluids. (These can be bought in most drug stores.) They should always wash their hands with warm water and soap afterward – even if they had gloves on. • If a caregiver does come in contact with any of your body fluids, they should wash the area very well with warm water and soap. It’s not likely to cause any harm, but try to take extra care to avoid this. At your next visit, let your doctor know this happened. Being exposed often may lead to problems, and extra care should be taken to avoid this. • Any clothes or sheets that have body fluids on them should be washed in your washing machine – not by hand. Wash them in warm water with regular laundry detergent. Do not wash them with other clothes. If they cannot be washed right away, seal them in a plastic bag. Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Guilty, To give you something to browse until you get a few replies from those who are also taking Arimidex you could have a read of this BCC Anastrazole / Arimidex booklet. I don't think the side effects from these are any better or worse than any of the other Oestrogen inhibitor tablets. Everyone gets differing issues from these AI's so until they get into your system you will be playing a bit of a guessing game. Jackie is halfway through 5 years of Letrozole and for her the biggest issue is osteopenia and joint pain. There is quite a long list as there always is (get out clauses and covering all the bases) but most only suffer a few, not all of these - thankfully. Take care, G n' J

Posted by anncg
22 May 2016 8:58 AM

Hi, that's the same as I had (Doxetacil (T) & Cylophsphamide). Before I started I was terrified I would get all the side effects listed on the info sheets I was given.  

As it was I was relatively lucky so to speak, I did get very tired which got a bit worse with each one, the 4th being the worst. The horrible mouth feeling and lack of taste, seemed to live off ice lollies & tomato soup for days. I had all sorts of different things to drink.

I only got a short period of joint pain a few days after the 1st, could be because I only had the one injection 24 hours after chemo for the White blood cells.

Apart from Imodium a couple of times, I didn't need any extra medication.

It is a shock to find out you need chemo, my biopsy results were 44mm of DCIS with a suspicion of a micro invasion. The results after the surgery were 8mm G3 ductal + 8mm DCIS sentinel node was clear.


3 months later I feel really well, also not having any real side effects from Tamoxifen. I'm seeing the consultant next week, to discuss have the expander replaced with a permanent implant.


Take care, keep thinking in a few months the chemo will be behind you. xx

Ann xx

Posts.Title: Chemo - long term implications for treatment

Posts.Content: Hiya Jrip, There are quite a few TNBC ladies in the breast group - You will gradually get to meet them through posting questions while getting settled in here. TN is a bit of as bummer as it mostly affects younger women but there are members here with TN leading almost normal lives (no-one is completely normal after being diagnosed with any type of BC) and have learnt to just be aware of anything that doesn't feel 'right' but are years past original diagnosis. Just make sure you don't miss todays sunshine worrying about tomorrows rain. It's so easy to let this take over your life and worry yourself into meltdown for most this is do'able so don't let it make you a prisoner. If the T takes a dislike to you it can be a tough regime but you may not get clobbered so hard next time. Keep an eye on your temps and aware of bugs during the middle week when your white cell count is at it's lowest to lessen the risk. Easier said than done as most of the bugs which infect you are from yourself (mostly oral thrush thanks to the steroids) :-( Hope this helps, take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Kaytee, Sorry to see you here with us other misfits :-) but nice to see you are settling in and seeking help and reassurance. Her2+ means you will probably be given Herceptin which in our case was 18 x 3 weekly. So it's about a year of treatment. Herceptin is a monoclonal antibody ( targeted drug ) About one in five breast tumours are her2+ so there are plenty of us around to ask about stuff. Macmillan have an info page dealing with Her2 you can find it here. http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertypes/Breast/Aboutbreastcancer/Typesandrelatedconditions/HER2%20positive.aspx If after reading it you have further Q's fire away, we're all yours. Hope this helps, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Struggling to drink recommended fluids after chemotherapy!

Posts.Content: Hi Maxine  /  maxinem2  Although you finished chemo a couple of months ago this could be late onset CIPN chemo induced peripheral neuropathy (link) However there are cases of Tamoxifen also causing PN, so unless you can pin it down, it could be caused by either :( It is hard to say if changing brands would help seeing you have got used to Wockydoodah especially if this is due to the chemo and not lack of oestrogen ? Some ladies have got help to ease this with Gabapentin but it depends if you want to add yet another smartie to your collection. Hopefully you will get more replies on how others coped with this. Have you had a chat with your BCN about this ? Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen (for probably the millionth time)

Posts.Content: Hiya Sal  /  LondonLass  TBH I have no idea if PN can reccur but I would have thought a more plausible option would be for it to have been caused by successive follow on treatments ? There are so many cancer drugs which can cause PN it could be a case of one lot of chemo (Docetaxel for instance) to be the initial cause but later on be caused again by a different drug regime especially in those with secondaries who go on to have different chemo or other drugs the second time around. Have any of your meds changed in the last six months ? There are some brilliant (if lengthy) CIPN videos here at MSKCC. Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen (for probably the millionth time)

Posts.Content: Hi MaggsT  J is coming towards the end of five years on Letrozole (luckily Femara) but still gets joint pain. Mostly hips and feet she also has Alendonic Acid weekly and Adcal+ D3 chews twice a day. She is also taking Meloxicam which is a NSAID (non steroidal anti-inflammatory drug) and Amitriptyline daily and paracetamol as a back up if needed. Over the first 6 months or so she tried Anastrozole which she found worse so switched back and after juggling pain relief around has settled on the above as what works best for her without the feeling of being spaced out by anything stronger like some of the opiate based drugs. All she wants is to hear is that she can finish these AI's in a couple of months - If they try to push her onto another 5 years worth I'm certain she will tell them to shove them :) and take her chances. Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Mazzamo  Ahem! - You rang ma'lady - in my best 'Parker' voice..... Having a raised ESR could just be a sign of inflammation / infection - but the test doesn't state where only that there is something that needs finding out, usually by using other tests. Suppose it all depends on how much it is raised. You can read more about the ESR test and the findings they get from it here. Hope this is of some help, apart from that I'm a bit  'Clueless in Suffolk'  G n' J
Posts.Title: Mets

Posts.Content: Hi triumph We had this issue over 4 years ago - J had 2 months worth of Femara from the onco to start with - As soon as she needed to obtain them from her GP they switched her onto the 'generics' After trying 3 different brands and even a 2 month spell on Anastrozole we managed to get the GP to actually name Femara on the repeat so that is all she can be given - and apart from twice when the practice pharmacist tried to change it back to a generic (he got a sharp talking to) has been on Femara the whole time If it just states Letrozole they can give you any brand.  I think the Femara from the onco unit comes from hospital cancer drug funds but as soon as your GP takes over the extra cost comes from the GP's practice  so they try to penny pinch :( It amazes me that they can spent upwards of £30K (if you include Herceptin) to fix you but claw back (by comparison) such small sums which leaves you needing even more meds to cope with the damn side effects :((( Do try to get your GP to write up Femara because a lot of the time it is the pharmacies who will give you the cheapest one they can get their hands on - Currently, a GP branded prescription cannot be switched by a pharmacist to a generic substitute – but a GP generic prescription can be swapped for a branded one. So if you can get Femara (Letrozole) - Arimidex (Anastrazole) or Nolvadex (Tamoxifen) written up on your repeat you shouldn't be given a generic  :) It's the same with the R1 and R2 Radiotherapy gels - some can get it easily while others are told NO  because it's a one off payment of £70 compared to £5 for a tub of axle grease  :( Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Sleepy Mushroom  Being diagnosed Occult or CUP is a bit scary as it's always good to know exactly what you are dealing with. Some ladies even push for same side mastectomy as a preventative measure because they are scared it is lurking there but cannot be seen / found and don't want to spend the rest of their life worrying when it will show up :(   Do read SusieMB's comment about this further down.... Depending on whether you have a few nodes taken (Sentinel Node Biopsy) to check those first or want to have all nodes removed, do get an agreement that you will have regular MRI's or at the very least ultrasound scans to check to see if your primary later becomes visible. There has also been occult cases where after pathology checking the nodes the cells found are HER2+ positive which will then mean Herceptin. G n' J
Posts.Title: Advice on Axillary Lymph Nodes Dissection / Lymph Nodes Removal

Posts.Content: Hi Pfom  So it would appear if you are BRCA and Triple Neg you get offered Taxol and if Triple Neg with no genetic issues probably Taxotere ? Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, There are indeed two T chemo drugs Taxol and Taxotere also known as Paclitaxel and Docetaxel. Either can be used whether you are node positive or not. Docetaxel (taxotere) is nearly always given at 3 weekly intervals and the Paclitaxel (Taxol) is mostly given weekly. If you click the links you can read about both although the side effects are very similar the weekly Taxol is considered slightly easier to cope with of the two. You could be given either but it in most cases is the 3 weekly Docetaxel one, in combination with possibly FEC or EC Good news with those node results :) G n' J Jojo4

Posts.Content: Hiya, TBH, they don't really like you taking any random supplements while on chemo as there are so many different formula supplements out there they don't know if there could be contraindications with the chemo drugs but vitamins can be a different matter. I know some take high grade manuka honey, cod liver oil with calcium and a few others, but you would be better asking this question in the July Chemo Club discussion to get more feedback on what others are taking to help. There's no getting away from it - chemo is harsh but it's doing a tough job try to see it as an argumentative best friend -  It may seem like a never ending runaway mine cart ride at the moment, but honestly the chemo time does go very quickly. If you click the BC books link under the image there is a whole shedload of helpful stuff there. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Maca root extract for VA VA VOOM

Posts.Content: Hiya Peeps,  Whoever said Tax doesn't need to be Taxing - Obviously never had it :-) No, seriously I'm not going to say much (that makes a change) 'Quiet at the Back there" !!! Jackie had so many side effects from Docetaxel I'd end up with blisters on the two fingers I type with.... But, hey ho, for everyone who gets hit by 'the train' there is another who found FEC really rough and the T part a doddle, even to the extent of working through it. J was off work for 10 months having said that a lot of it was down to our GP and J working with MRSA and C-Dif patients loads of stairs and corridors etc Maccy Mantra (Everyone is Different) You won't know how T is going to be 'for you' until around day 4 after the first session - slightly longer honeymoon period with T. Whatever effects you get, there is always a remedy - so don't be a martyr and tolerate it, get some help. If you would like to know all J's side effects, just ask and I'll spill the beans but it may make depressing reading for anyone facing Mr T (Quit yo Jibber-jabber! You ain't hurt, yo pathetic!, Argh! If I ever catch you acting like a crazy fool again, you're gonna meet my friend pain!) Gotta do it with a smile ladies, G n' J

Posts.Title: Not diagnosed but terrified

Posts.Content: Hi Sam, Sorry to see you joining us here and reading about your mum. This is always a tough decision to make - Most would probably go for the mastectomy to be certain all suspect tissue is removed but it is a very personal choice. No doubt it is emotionally hard looking down and seeing where your breast used to be but there are reconstruction types she could possibly have if she wished and if her team are willing - ok it's not the same but it gives shape but they don't always reconstruct at the same time, especially if they feel radiotherapy will be offered at a later date. Chances are if she has lumpectomy number 2 she will be quite mis-shapen post op anyway :-(   A lot depends on her age and if she feels this is a threat to her finding happiness with another fella somewhere down the line or whether it's the surgery itself she has problems with.  If it is the former anyone she 'meets' who is worth getting to know better will accept her as she is - we all carry some 'baggage' as we get older :-) You may find this website helps - It's the BresDex info pages for making choices about breast surgery put together by several university teaching hospitals. No doubt some of the other lovely ladies will reply explaining what choices they made and why, which will also help a lot. One thing that has crossed my mind is, seeing as you mum has had her ovaries removed has she been asked about having the BRCA gene test ? and have any other members of her immediate family had problems with breast or ovarian or the men with prostate cancer previously ? Keep posting and if you have other questions about either surgery option, fire away. We're all here to help. Edit - See Mistlymoley has mentioned Keepingabreast - thanks for that {hug} - Click the link to read their reconstruction page. Take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors - All Brands of The 4 Hormonal Therapy Table...

Posts.Content: Hi Aneesa1  No doubt you are more than a little apprehensive about what you are facing, most here will tell you it can be tough at times but is do'able you just have to not keep secrets about any side effects so you find out how to ease them and to try and buy a few basics before you start to give you a quick fix without having to trawl around a supermarket when you feel knackered. I'll list a few items hopefully others here will reply and add to it :) Something for constipation and diarrhoea as one can quickly turn into the other - definitely a cheap'ish digital thermometer - ginger nut and arrowroot biscuits - a few bottles of multibuy flavoured water (still or fizzy) - Ibuprofen (don't have to be branded ones) & paracetamol, so you can alternate between the two - Tin of pineapple chunks (honestly) - Chlorhexidine mouthwash - Bicarbonate of soda - soft babies toothbrush. These may seem really random but are cheap enough and better to have them handy if needed as they all serve a purpose :) Assuming you will have the 3 x FEC (3 different drugs given together) part first and then herceptin injections will start when you switch to the T part. All these are given at 3 weekly intervals, so you can forget about the T and herceptin for a while. If you can try to fit in a dental check prior to starting chemo, but explain to the dentist you are going to be having chemotherapy, so definitely no drilling or extractions as this will push back starting chemo - and no flossing during chemo either. Last thing you want is a mouth infection starting :( Don't know if you are aware but with a cancer diagnosis you get all prescriptions free for 5 years, so see your GP about getting an exemption form sent off. It is a stressy time, but honestly facing this is a lot worse in your head than the reality on the day you start. Has your oncologist mentioned anything about fitting a PICC Line or Portacth in your arm for chemo ? Some health authorities do this as standard, others can be persuaded if you have small veins - do they normally have problems getting blood samples from you ? I seem to have rattled on a bit, but you have a couple of weeks to take all this in. Hope it is of some help, if it raises any questions, just reply someone will know the answer :) Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Her2 and hormone receptor positive

Posts.Content: Hi jemilyxx  OK, this isn't the news you were both hoping for, but it is what it is - so be reassured her team have decided this is the best, albeit tough way for her to kick cancer where it hurts. Was this decision made from her lymph node results or for another reason like being classed as HER2+ positive for instance - could you also mention which type of breast cancer they say it is as that can play a part on whether surgery or chemo first may be better for her  ? Several ladies here have had the surgery part first then found from tissue tests to not need chemo afterall, that's why it helps to know why they have suggested it. Chemo first is usually to shrink tumours down to minimise surgery which can mean a lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy but that isn't always the case. If a mastectomy is needed that is usually carried out prior to chemo. Have they mentioned which type of surgery your mum will be having if she opts for surgery first ? There is a lot of hype regarding chemo and being permanently sick, some types of chemotherapy are more prone to making you feel nauseous that others. Most of the time it is controlled so you only feel sick without it actually happening, if you are actually sick there are better meds they can give to avoid this happening next time around. Years ago it was always surgery first but now at at a guesstimate I would say around 60% are given surgery first (termed adjuvant) leaving 40% having chemo prior to surgery (termed neo-adjuvant) ? but these figures could be for varying reasons :-/ The protection against recurrence is around the same for either method, so there is a lot of information to gather to be able to make the best individual decision. Hope this has helped rather than confusing you even further ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Advice on Axillary Lymph Nodes Dissection / Lymph Nodes Removal

Posts.Content: Morning Gay  /  wombat.23  Although she still had about 10 Herceptin to go J was told she was NED when she had the Onco review appointment post radiotherapy sessions. Sure surgery removes the tumor but the chemo is a whole body (systemic) treatment supposedly to wipe out any stragglers. NED (no evidence of disease) is as good as it gets as they haven't the equipment for finding single cells yet. I would say you are a NEDdy how do you feel about it ? Welcome to the Paddock  lol   G n' J
Posts.Title: So what am I?...

Posts.Content: Morning  Anne,  Just wanted to add to the good advice already posted, but from a different angle. You haven't said what chemo regime they are giving you. FEC only, FEC+T or another combo ?  Reason for asking is that you may feel work is more do'able if you are on FEC maybe only working part time as it isn't so harsh on your joints/muscles as Taxane based chemo but side effects can be accumulative -It's all very hard trying to pre-empt the outcome as (you know what is coming here) "Everyone is Different"..... Some find their first chemo session is the worst, and side effects apart from the sicky feeling bearable, others are not so lucky.  If you are going the FEC+T route and you do work during your FEC part be prepared for feeling more wiped out by midday and whole body tiredness during the Tax stage and expect to have the odd duvet day on the sofa. You may find Tax better than FEC, only time will tell. Considering your type of work you would be better not working at all during the second week when your white count is really low on "ANY" chemo as the last place you would want to be is in a school full of snotty winter bug laden children. It would be like walking blindfolded through a minefield. If you pick up a bug when neutropenic (week two) you will be spending up to a week as an inpatient on iv drips and antibiotics...... Even something as minor as oral thrush can take over what is left of your depleted immune system and floor you, so, (not trying to scare you here) but be careful at this time. If needs must, try and arrange for work you can do at home during that period. Also take full advantage of family and friends offering, "read" (press ganged) into becoming your domestic slaves, it will free up some of your energy to put to good use recovering. Now, tell that cancer to bend over and give it a Damn Good Spanking  :-)   George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Back to work?

Posts.Content: Hi  shovel, Just read your profile and thought I was going nutty for a minute. Realised this was you originally posting about your dad. Ok, you found a lump... Could be a cyst, calcification, benign piece of tissue. Main thing is you didn't ignore it and you are on track to get it diagnosed. Depending on your age and how dense your beast tissue is you are more likely to have an Ultrasound scan but they may do both with the mammogram done first - I will warn you first off - they will probably take biopsies while using the US scanner but this still doesn't mean anything sinister. It just means what they are seeing needs checking out further. Then you have to endure the terrible waiting results stage which can really do your head in unless you can find things to do and places to go to take your mind off it all. Here's a read for some info about breast screening units and biopsies so you don't get any unexpected surprises. Just click the green text link. Do keep posting so we can help you with the emotional side of all this is it or isn't it worries and please don't google too much - A lot of the info out there is either way out of date or very misleading. Afraid at the moment it's a case of hope for the best but your biggest problem at this time will be keeping this a 'secret' from your son until you know more about what you are dealing with without him realising something is going on - he's bound to notice subtle changes. If you do decide to inform him this guide may be helpful in getting the conversation started 'Talking to Children and Teenagers When an Adult has Cancer'  Please realise this is for those diagnosed but this isn't you - and hopefully won't be. Best wishes and very good luck with your scans and the following scanxiety. George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Breast reconstruction with GAP flap

Posts.Content: Morning  Jackie, Anyone diagnosed with cancer is covered by the DDA (Disability Discrimination act) now know as the Equality Act and as such employers have a legal responsibility to make allowances for any employees that fall into this category regarding returning to work and making alterations that allow them to return to work and co-ercing you back too soon is simply not fair. The Health & Safety Executive have a webpage with more info and several links listed on the right hand side which may help.  I'll paste the link in below. Totally agree with what you say about moving on vs finances but it does seem to take ages before you start to feel anything like you old self. http://www.hse.gov.uk/sicknessabsence/legalguidance.htm Hope this helps a tad, best wishes,  George  n'  Jackie.

Posts.Title: Farewell to Chemo!

Posts.Content: Hope this post is of help to anyone who gets prescribed any AI's Aromatase Inhibitor / Hormonal therapy Tablets. Macmillan has an information page about Hormonal Therapy Tablets here - Do select the 'Read The Details' button to open the page right up. Here is a list of all the registered make and 'branded' makers of these tablets. This is by no means a complete list as trade names vary throughout the world and there are just too many but does contain the more common brands available in the UK Tamoxifen.... Nolvadex ® Astra-Zeneca original maker. Arrow - Bayer - Merck - Mylan - Orion - Sandoz - Schering - Teva - Wockhardt Anastrozole.... Arimidex ®  Astra Zeneca original maker. Arrow - Accord - Activis - Aventis - Cipla - Sandoz - Teva - Zentiva Letrozole.... Femara ® Novartis original maker. Accord - Activis - Arrow - Orion - Sandoz* - Teva * (note Sandoz is also owned by Novartis)  Exemestane.... Aromasin ® Pfizer original maker. Accord - Actavis - Arrow - Aventis - Ranbaxy - Sandoz - Teva In most cases the original make does tend to have less 'baggage' but everyone is different so this may not be the case for you. However the originals are always more expensive so unless the original name is on your repeat (i.e. Femara instead of Letrozole) your pharmacy can give out any of the cheaper versions as they go by the drug name. Good luck finding a friend amongst this lot. G n' J

Posts.Title: Time between lumpectomy and chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Paige, So sorry to read about your mum but you have found yourself in a great place at a tough time. Hope the chemo was kind to your mum, that can be an ordeal in itself ? Her scans will be to see how the chemo has acted on her tumours prior to determine other treatment or surgery. If they have shrunk significantly they may offer a lumpectomy rather than a mastectomy but don't rely on this as we don't know the extent of her lobular type. The chemo will also have had some effect on her ovary and bone spread but an I correct in assuming the chemo was mainly to treat the breast tumours ? When you say lobular and ductal are these in the same breast or lobular in one and ductal in the other and now her chemo has finished what other treatment in the form of tablets perhaps is she taking. Sorry this sounds like a game of twenty questions, but the treatment options are so many and varied we can help you better if we know what she is taking. You are correct in saying hormone receptive is a good thing but it will most probably mean your mum having to take a daily tablet long term to keep her oestrogen/progesterone levels minimal - Has her team mentioned anything about her HER2 status, if your mum is HER2+ if she is she may need Herceptin as well. Do get back to us, we're all here to help where we can. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Stage 2 breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Janie236  Sounds very much like you are having Taxol aka Paclitaxel then, as that is nearly always given weekly as opposed to the 3 weekly sessions for (F)EC - T. The side effects are very similar to Taxotere aka Docetaxel but to a slightly lesser extent. Having said that because they are weekly they can get a bit accumulative with less time spent for recovery between your chemo sessions. The main thing that takes most by surprise is the tiredness. Great to read you have been given a port,  it makes the sessions quicker and far less hassle. Have you done the pre-chemo shopping aids thing yet. There are some must haves to make life easier :) At least you have a couple of weeks to prepare yourself with advice and information. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: fec

Posts.Content: Hi,  Seeing it's a colour you have used recently before, either something has changed with your nails (unlikely) 9 months after chemo, or maybe you had the residue of something on your nails before you painted them and it got sealed onto them. Had the previous remover completely dried before re-applying, or you been using bleach, oven cleaner anything containing harsh chemicals beforehand ?  Sounds like one of the pigments leached out. Did you use a different varnish remover to last time ? Have heard of nails getting discoloured during or just after chemo but not this long afterwards. It's a bit of an elimination process. Hope you soon get an answer or the yellowing gradually fades. Good luck with it,  George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Yellow nails

Posts.Content: Hi Annetha Warm welcome to the Breast Group, pleased to see it looks like you managed to survive the waiting results stage with your sanity intact. No doubt some of the lovely ladies here who had mastectomy and immediate recon will be along shortly to pass on some support, tips and experiences. Don't know how much information you have been given regarding the implant type of recon but it is covered in the Macmillan book Understanding Breast Reconstruction 'clickable link' (see pages 23-35)  Do be aware though it does contain some post surgery images. I'm assuming by primary lymph nodes this is also called a sentinel lymph node biopsy where only 3 or 4 nodes are taken as a sample ? If you have other questions just holler, we're all here to help as there is no such thing as a silly question. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Pre-op nerves

Posts.Content: Hi, Just want to add my two pence worth about this.... Yet another of the (I did it my way) everyday national newspaper cancer story lines. It's the idea that they somehow almost make you feel guilty or inadequate if you cannot afford to do it their way which isn't very nice :( Most of us when diagnosed have more concerns about still having enough money coming in during treatment to pay the bills if you can't work for six months and have to go onto SSP or cap in hand to the benefits office to those who are single parents with young children or on a pension and can ill afford any extra expense. It pains me to see these more affluent patients advising expensive ways of easing treatment side effects when some are trying really hard just to keep a roof over their heads, stay warm in winter and put food on the table. To those promoting the book they have just written about it all at a time when a majority just want to get through it with their mojo intact and hopefully enough spare cash for a week away to recuperate/celebrate.  Not knocking cancer books but the better ones tend to be written by people who don't have the connections to push sales, or are 'free to read' blogs. Didn't realise I still had my soap box in the shed  :)  G n' J
Posts.Title: Decca Aitkenhead in the Guardian

Posts.Content: Evening Daft Bird,  Does make you wonder why when at the start everything goes at double speed and you feet don't seem to touch the ground, then you get a pause like this and you wonder what the heck's going on. The surgery has removed the tumour and like you say the rest is for mopping up any stragglers. Your lymphs were clear so chances are you are too. The rest is insurance against recurrence, it takes ages for any cells to develop into a cluster so even what seems like forever to you is still within guidelines.  it's a PITA really, just adds to the time you get to worry about what treatment lies ahead when all you want to do is get on with it. Try to enjoy the break with family and friends, do stuff and go places to try and take your mind off it. Once the assessment is done you will soon be back on the Runaway Mine Cart. Take care DB, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Need more help girls....

Posts.Content: Hi Frances  /  kumihimo   You could start with the Waterjel R1/R2 FAQ page here (link) There are a lot of NHS  'stick in the muds' regarding this newish product (been around over 2 years now) It was specially formulated to help avoid radiotherapy dermatitis. They either say they know nothing about it (read more expensive, so can't be bothered) or just hand over the same old creams they have been using for years because they are cheap. This is available on prescription; several here have got it that way, it is just they try to dodge spending £70 when there is an £8 option available :( Beggars belief when they can offer you chemo, herceptin etc which costs thousands - then pull up short on an item that costs £70...shame on them! The pharmacy ordering PIP codes for R1/R2 are Six weekly pack: PIP codes R1:  356-4432 R 2: 383-4918 Smaller weekly treatment packs: PIP code 367-3613 Hope this helps a bit, G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning Binny, Sorry this isn't a proper Valentine's Day message, as you can see who sent it..... but we can send you a {{{HUG}}}  So you had the bone scan, which came back clear which is brilliant as they could well have been looking for bone mets. So the next stage will probably be the CT scan which will give them a 3D image of the tissue to check it out for either rads damage or any cells that got missed. If it turns out to be a tissue problem, being tissue it will be treatable/operable. If I remember rightly you are not triple neg, so did you ever have chemo or was it surgery , rads and hormone tablets ? Know you must be fretting about all this going on but at least they are not going to be happy until they get you some answers.  Take care Binny, hope you get some positive answers soon, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Need more help girls....

Posts.Content: Hiya, Under the data protection act you can have copies of any or all of your medical records including diagnosis, also any including scans including bone, surgery reports, doctor or surgeons letters/notes, treatment regimes etc even if applicable recordings of meetings of the multi disciplinary team discussing your treatment being finalised. So if they do not comply with your wishes for copies they can actually now be taken to court for not complying. They may try and get away with it saying, you won't understand them as it creates a bit of work for them, digging out the paperwork and making copies, but hey if you don't ask, you don't get :-) As for us two, we just got back from the supermarket shop and have plenty of chocolate and drinks to help us tolerate this rubbish weather. You take care Binny,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Need more help girls....

Posts.Content: Morning  Gillie,  Good for you, you have made a great start but nicotine plays with your brain a tad when you stop smoking. That little voice on your shoulder saying " well one won't hurt will it "  :-) We were both long time smokers ( roll your own type ) until like you cancer and chemo makes you take stock of your lifestyles. With taste buds doing their own thing during chemo it may be the best time to quit especially if they taste foul, but a lot suffer so much hassle and stress it is the worst time for them and find they need the crutch of a ciggy now and then to help them chill out. When we first stopped we used a couple of those refillable / rechargeable Exhale e-cigs ( type CE5 ) as a stop gap to give us the nicotine we craved while not getting all the tar and chemicals from cigarettes. The fluid comes in loads of flavours and has varying strengths of nicotine content right down to nicotine free. If you can go a couple of weeks before caving in to cigarettes then a low dose would suit you fine and it certainly does takes the edge off.  You can easily find exhale-uk through google if you want to check them out but if you feel you are so close to being able to do this unaided, then bite the bullet and go for it. I just checked they are still online and see their CE5 starter kit is on a special offer until the 28th. With us both being smokers we put the money aside each week and we have saved over £1200 since Christmas - It's amazing to see it mounting up and makes you realise how much smoking actually costs in money and health. Good luck but don't beat yourself up if you lapse, you will get there in the end.... George & Jackie.

Posts.Title: Time between lumpectomy and chemo?

Posts.Content: Morning Charly,  All these hormone reducing tablets come with baggage and although if you read the package leaflet they all state roughly the same shedload of side effects you "could" get, what they don't tell you is that these can vary by quite a lot between different medications. It's common for doctors to change from Tamoxifen to Aromasin after 2 or 3 years as "the figures" state there is a better chance of reducing re-occurance by changing. What they don't tell you is by how much of a % it is better, or take into account the fact that everyone is different and what might mean 5% for one person may only be 1% for another. Mood swings, PMT type symptoms,  sleeplessness and fatigue all add up, no wonder you are noticing a change it must be a bitch for your wife waking up feeling 80 every day. If you are both unhappy with the way things are going think you both ought to see your GP and explain the problems since going on Aromasin and ask if it is really worth all these extra hassles for the sake of what may be a low percentage of advantage and get back onto the Tamoxifen or even ask if there is another alternative tablet that does the same job to try out. She may just end up swapping one set of side effects for another though. At the end of the day she has another 3 years to go so it makes sense to make those 3 years as do'able as possible. Don't just go along with it, if you don't tell gp's about problems they will think she is ok on them and nothing will change. Hope this helps, best wishes to you both,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Aromasin - Personality change

Posts.Content: Hi Jane P 24  /  Jane, This may seem a bit dumb, but if your doctor thinks this is nerve pain why didn't they offer you nerve pain related pain relief meds at the time ? Don't know how long post surgery you are assuming your reconstruction was carried out after your chemo etc. So this could be nerve damage from surgery or seeing as it's affecting both hands, peripheral neuropathy from the chemo. Are your feet affected at all ? Either way do try to get in to see about it - the sooner you get it checked out the sooner you can get something to ease it. G n' J
Posts.Title: Pins and needles

Posts.Content: Hi Pinkshoe, Warm welcome to the breast group, a busy but brilliant place :) Sorry to read about your post surgery problems, it's bad enough having to go through this when it's straight forward without all these spanners being chucked into the works :( I hope it's just that you want to get on with the rads rather being worried the delay could cause cancer problems. Please be assured that after chemo and surgery the cancer will be gone and the rads are just a bit more insurance against recurrence that's all. When you say you had a bone scan was it a 40 minute Dexa scan or the longer 3-4 hour nuclear scan ? I'm thinking it was the first one which is usually carried out if you are going to be placed on hormone inhibitor tablets later ? If it was a dexa scan don't fret all they are checking for is bone density figures which will be monitored if you do get placed on the tablets. Has it been mentioned to you that you are ER/PR+ positive ? because if you are that will mean you getting these. Fingers crossed they can get on top of this necrosis without the need for yet more surgery, I'm thinking you feel you have been through enough already. There are few ladies here who have had necrosis problems hopefully they will notice your message and reply. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Post-surgery waiting for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Morning Heather,  Drats, isn't it always the same, never what you want when and where you need it. Best thing would be to start a New Discussion titled something like 'Anyone Around The Newcastle Area Up For a Meet / Chat' - The 'meet' may not happen but you will get to find others around the area who you can chat with by using the private messaging / friends service here. As for things changing, yes the pathology results do tend to get tweaked when they can take a better look at any removed tissue. They find things like if you are HER2 positive up or down grade and of course the size - yours will be much smaller after having chemo or hormone inhibitor tablets to shrink it. Radiotherapy isn't anywhere near as bad as you may be imagining - any particular reason for thinking about avoiding it ? Have they mentioned anything about using chemo as insurance for re-occurance or have you got away with that ? Catch you later, take care, G n' J
