Posts.Title: Lumpy Boobs Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Morning Coastal-lady  Please don't have a knee jerk reaction and get your tablet brand changed from Arimidex anytime soon... I think Lynn / Kacang is taking Arimidex and may be able to help ? Arimidex is the original registered maker of Anastrozole and considered the best (and most expensive) for minimal side effects. This rib pain could be down to the tablets or lack of oestrogen from them but if so you may well be getting joint pain and aches in other places too ? You mention being back at work on a phased return and also driving with long car journeys - Could this rib pain be caused by a shift in the way you actually sit now post surgery (a posture thing - slumped forward a little in chairs) coupled with the car seat belt ? or even down to a chest muscle / rib strain rather than anything sinister ? Most Occy health folks are pro-employer,  totally clueless about long term cancer issues and have no personal experience of cancer to draw on so that comment doesn't surprise me in the slightest. Think the best way forward would to contact your BCN first rather than GP and see what they recommend. if your BCN was a bit useless then go the GP route and get this looked into. If this pain is near the centre of the chest (ribs) and seemed to move from left to right it could be the lack of oestrogen is affecting the costocartilages which is the cartilage either side of the sternum like it affects other joints? OK i've run out of ideas now :)  Hope you find a unworrying (is that a word) answer to this soon and a simple fix to ease it. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Rib Pain - Arimidex

Posts.Content: Hi,  My missus had to have her 2nd FEC delayed for one week because her liver  "ALT" enzyme was low. As the liver has to process and clear all the chemo drugs from your system. The Maccy unit said although Paracetamol are good, your liver doesn't like them and coupled with chemo can get a tad  overloaded. She was advised it would help her liver along while on FEC & T by keeping Paracetamol based pain relief to a low dosage and take mostly Ibuprofen based tabs as the liver takes a big hit whilst on chemo. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Pre chemo blood results are low

Posts.Content: Hi Genny, As mentioned Fybrogel or something like Dulcoease can help soften stools. There are others available so it may be worth phoning / asking a pharmacist which one they consider works best. G n' J
Posts.Title: Endgame!!

Posts.Content: Hi Rubix, Warm welcome to the breast group. I don't really understand what is meant by controlling your metastatic load because according to your TNM you have M0 which is no mets  ?  It's as if they have you confused with someone else - Is it definitely your name, date of birth and patient number etc on the letter ? Have you had any surgery yet, or is all this information from the preliminary scans and biopsies ? If you are HER2+ positive then you will be given Herceptin and this is only ever given in conjunction with chemotherapy - You won't be offered Herceptin on it's own as it only licensed to be used with chemo. Because you will need to have Herceptin for a whole year 18 x 3 weekly sessions it is common to have surgery first, then chemo and herceptin start a few weeks post surgery. I'll add more to this reply in the morning but for now this is some info on the breast cancer TNM scale from Cancer Research UK I'm sure you will get more replies to this as what they have told you doesn't really make much sense. If you have trouble understanding your consultant phone their secretary or your breast care nurse (I assume you have been assigned one) and get them to explain the letter a section at a time and where you are being referred to next (surgery or oncology) as you need to know what is happening next regarding treatment and when it is likely to start. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Bi lateral masectomy with immediate construction - I'm terrified

Posts.Content: Hi suzyjane, I'm pleased you have an expert at work who thinks you will only be off work one week....   :-0 Tell them this isn't a cosmetic enlargement this is 2 operations in one - double mastectomy and double LD flap reconstructions. This will mean about 6 hours in theatre and a good 6 to 8 weeks recovery (at least) possibly even 3 months. I'm sorry to be the bearer of news that you probably didn't want to hear but you need to know this. There is no way you could carry on as normal soon after surgery, and you shouldn't feel expected too. Time to put yourself first for a change, because you are worth it. There is more info about LD flap recons here - select the 'read the details' button to open the page right up. Be aware it contains a couple of post surgery images though. G n' J

Posts.Title: food

Posts.Content: Hi Bushy, Welcome to a great place at a scary time for you. It's more likely the thought of you having a couple of days delay was the straw the broke the camels back. This teary session was something that was bound to happen sooner or later as there is a limit to how much emotional pressure you can take in without your safety valve blowing or you would crack up completely. You are at the stage everyone here hated - waiting results is a nightmare and seems to take forever. It may only be a couple of days but in this situation 2 days seem like 2 weeks :-( Don't ever feel the need to say sorry here, it's a great place for a good rant, bin kicking and getting it all out in the open. There may not be much of a delay because all these scan type images are digital now and everyone who needs to see them can just access them from their hospital computer. I assume your husband knows but your son doesn't as yet then ?  Please don't feel the need to keep the fact you have been crying from your husband at least it shows how worried you are - so many people when asked say I'm fine when really they are feeling in bits - It's a shame everyone feels the need to be strong towards the rest of their family when at this time it surely needs to be the other way round. Don't know how old your son is but he probably will have guessed something isn't 'right' kids pick up on all the changes and little signs more than we think they would. No doubt you have a head full of questions (no such thing as a silly question) so do please ask. We all know exactly how you are feeling at the moment and there are loads of us here to help. Take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Recommendations on bras/ post op tops.

Posts.Content: Hi Frillyflower  Warm welcome to the club no one wanted to join :( Noticed you as I was logging in and thought you may need a few words of reassurence as news like this messes with your head as all the 'what if's' come out to play... Ductal is one of the more common types to be labelled with; 2cm is about average when first noticed as smaller lumps tend to go unoticed hiding amongst the tissue unless your breasts are small sized. This is so'ooo treatable - BC these days has a huge arsenal of varying treatment options which are now tailored exactly to your diagnosis and pathology lab results - Recovery rates for BC is over 90% and of the other 10%  being found at a very advanced stage and not being able to have some treatments like chemo because of frailty, or underlying health issues play a big part in this. Have you been given any other information about who you will be seeing next, surgeon or possibly oncologist ? My wife was diagnosed May 2012 and we're still happily kicking around she was still 'No Evidence of Disease' at her 6 year review. Any questions niggling at you or if you just want to chat, just holler - we are all here to help and this is one mega busy group :) Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: ER positive clear nodes grade 3 and waiting on oncotype results.....

Posts.Content: Hi  Rhonda, Sorry to hear about you losing your mum, we're all a bit fragile around here, so you are in good company. You probably still have collateral damage from the chemo and it takes ages to get anywhere near to feeling your new normal but it does def get better honestly. The Herceptin as you are probably finding is a lot more doable than chemo, it just seems to go on forever until number 18 but the Tamoxifen like all these hormone tabs comes with baggage ( a wide and varying collection of side effects ) anyone of which can affect you. The lack of oestrogen can lead to being osteopenic so ask about getting a Dexa scan if you start getting really bad bone / joint pain in your hips, legs, knees, shoulders etc. They can give you tabs to help build up calcium and strengthen bones etc if the scan shows you need help to ward off osteoporosis in later life. Open a bottle and top up that half full glass of yours and we'll toast your happy future, 'cause you do have one, your'e just having trouble seeing it with those hurdles in the way :-) Best Wishes,    George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: triple positive breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Barfy  /  WhatHappened  There has been and still is a lot of chest infections around over the last six weeks; both of us have had it. J first then myself and they were so very similar to how you describe - breathing vibrates the tickly thick mucus just around the lower throat area that causes a severe cough which shifts very little but soon starts tickling again :( We were both sent via GP to hosp for a chest xray, ecg and bloods and meanwhile given 10 days worth of Prednisone (corticosteroid) and Amoxicilin which cleared it up - all hosp tests came back normal. This will hang around for ages or can get progressively worse if you just hope it will go away, so it is worth getting it prescribed for :) G n' J
Posts.Title: phlegmy cough sometimes dry and tickly - am I mad ?!?

Posts.Content: Hi tammj  Warm welcome to the club no one wanted to join - Hopefully yours will be a short stay. Everyone here will agree the waiting results period is a very tough time on the emotions, you try to hope for the best but those what if thoughts scare the pants off everybody. If only these professional people would realise finding out over the phone (even if it is bad news) is so much easier to cope with mentally than all this drawn out waiting time :( Though your appointment is with a surgeon this could be a benign lump that needs removing as even benign lumps grow and require surgery. Nearly all breast lumps (cancer included) are fairly slow growing so you would be unlikely to notice any changes over a month or so. There are government targets for treatment - 2 weeks maximum between a GP referring you and being seen by the breast unit - The current treatment targets are No more than 2 months wait between the date the hospital receives an urgent GP referral for suspected cancer and starting treatment Starting treatment no more than 31 days after the meeting at which you and your doctor agree the treatment plan Must admit I'm a little surprised they didn't call you back to discuss the results of the biopsies before getting a surgeon on the scene. It may be there is some information you haven't received - You could see your GP and ask if any information has been forwarded to them from the hospital ? I was like your husband when my wife was diagnosed nearly 5 years ago now - it's like someone set off a cluster grenade inside your head - you are lost, confused, angry, scared and in disbelief this could actually be happening to you :( No amount of worrying will alter the outcome, you just have to keep those fingers tightly crossed. One thing is for sure once you see the surgeon things usually happen quickly and that can come as a bit of a shock after all the waiting. Over the next 10 days do things, go places, chuck yourself into a hobby in fact anything that takes your minds off clock watching and over thinking things. Hope this is of some help at a tough time, fingers crossed for you both, G n' J
Posts.Title: awaiting results for a breast core biopsy

Posts.Content: Hiya,  So the wig doesn't look like you, don't fret - Be someone different have an alter ego now is the time you can be a bit eccentric - You can blame it on chemo brain. As for feeling so rough while your insides are turned to soup, think of a chrysalis and the beautiful butterfly waiting to emerge at the end of it all - or, If you think of this as a journey you must be at the top of that huge hill you had to climb, now's the time to just take off the brakes and free wheel for a bit. Don't know where the strength comes from but it does, and so does the end of treatment just keep ticking off the weeks. Group Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Anyone used hyperthermia?

Posts.Content: Hi SFGS29  sorry, don't know your first name. There is a very active monthly Chemo Club within the Main Breast Group you should check out and get involved with - It has a chemo tips link in the very first message. You can find the June Chemo Club clicking here. The main items to get hold of are something for both constipation and diarrhoea as one can quickly turn to the other :-/ A digital thermometer (doesn't have to be a really expensive one) We used a cheapo from Asda which we found accurate enough. A packet of Ginger Nut and Arrowroot biscuits they both help in different ways - Ginger Nuts help with taste issues and Arrowroot with nausea or queasiness.  Generic brands of Paracetamol and Ibuprofen because if needed you can alternate between the two at 2 hourly intervals instead of just 4 hourly with paracetamol only - Don't double up with any other tablets that may also contain paracetamol like Co-codamol though... Supermarket multi buys of various bottled flavoured waters (still or fizzy) as you need at least 2 litres of fluid daily while on chemo as Tea / Coffee may taste awful... Soft (baby) toothbrush in case your gums get sore and some Chlorhexidine antibacterial mouthwash - Lloyds, Superdrug and Boots all sell their own brand at a round £3 a bottle to help avert oral thrush. Tin of Pineapple Chunks which you can open and put in the fridge in case you need to sooth your mouth. Are you having 4 x EC only or switching to something else like Taxotere afterwards ? Hope this is of some help for now and that the EC is kind to you, G n' J
Posts.Title: 1st cycle of EC on Monday - advice please

Posts.Content: Hiya, Welcome to the group - This is going to take a bit of untangling, so bear with us a bit.... So your nan has had the BRCA test and has been told she carries the gene mutation - Do you know if this is for BRCA1 or BRCA2 ?  and you don't want to stress your mum to get the test done for herself at the moment ? I assume your nan with BC is your mum's mum not your dad's mum ? There is an online risk assessment tool here you can use but you will need family information to enter to get an accurate reading. Click this link to take the OPERA Test. What you need to know (and possibly enter) is any incidences of Breast or Ovarian cancer in any of the ladies and Breast or Prostate cancer in the males within your immediate family group. By this I mean parents, grand parents, all of your sisters and brothers, aunties, uncles, nieces and nephews. The information can then be noted or printed off and taken to your GP to back up any need you may require to be put forward for BRCA testing. I'm not saying you need to worry, but you do need to know your risks and if you need to be tested. Any incidences of the above cancers in relatives get a score which is used to either put you forward for the test or not. Just because your mum hasn't had breast cancer doesn't mean she doesn't carry the gene mutation as it is possible to be brca 1 or 2 and not get cancer. If anyone has the brca mutation there is a 50% chance of passing it down. So your mum may not have it ? There is more information here about Gene Faults and cancer at Cancer Research UK. You could just try mentioning the test again after Christmas in a casual manner just to test for her reaction and if you get no positive answer from her tell her of the worries you are all facing by not knowing. Hope this helps for now, if you need any more information just reply back. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Endgame!!

Posts.Content: Hiya Yvonne, Sorry to say but hair thinning is a known side effect of Exemestane - How long have you got to take it for ?  If it's any consolation Jackie is taking Letrozole and is having the same sort of problem. Not a lot of hair loss at any one time, but over time it is starting to notice a bit. It's a bummer to think after everything you go through during a year of treatment, just as you think you are out of the woods these bloody tablets just keep adding to your problems when all you want to do is get on with your life and forget about it all. Changing the tablets cure one problem but cause another - you feel like you just can't win. If you owned a duck it would probably sink :-( Sorry we can't wave a magic wand to fix it but we can send you a big {{HUG}} Best wishes hun, G n' J
Posts.Title: I'am sure my hair is coming out?

Posts.Content: Hi Alison  Redkite26  Most definitely. It's been described as feeling like you have too tight a ponytail at first then your scalp starts getting painful.If you still have long hair and are not cold capping now would be the best time to have it cut shorter as the longer the hair the more painful it will feel - (It's the weight of the hair pulling on the follicles) Hairloss usually starts anytime between days 12 and 24 :( Paracetamol doesn't help much but other ladies here will say it was almost instant relief after the hair was cut short. If you are contemplating this move, don't leave it too late as it can get so painful even cutting it is ouchy. Losing lots of very short hair is nowhere near as emotional as shedding long hair everywhere. G n' J

Posts.Title: tamoxifen different brands

Posts.Content: Hi Warcol30  It is standard practice to have coils removed if ER+ and/or PR+ positive, don't know if you are 'into' health foods or supplements but Flax seeds shoud be avoided as well as flax has a high plant oestrogen content. Must have already been looked into but (if applicable) any HRT products should be stopped as well. Did you get any other diagnosis information when your BC was confirmed you may have questions about, or are you still waiting the full results ? Good luck for your further scan results, G n' J
Posts.Title: ER+

Posts.Content: Evening  Gillie,  Nails are a bit like hair. Some folks take a bad hit and others seem to have only minor problems with either. Trouble it is like the chemo and the cold cap you don't know until you try these things if they are going to help you personally. Quite a few here have used nail varnish and it certainly seems to help, as the chemo is uv sensitive and the darker varnish acts as a sun block, so well worth a try, but as we always say, everyone is different. You may use it and still have nail hassles they just won't be so severe. If you are not really into black you can always use the black as an undercoat for another colour, purple, dark red etc One thing to bear in mind if you do use varnish make sure you try to get an Acetone free varnish remover as the Acetone is a really harsh solvent. If you do still get nail problems like "lifting" from the base don't use false ones as the glue may get into your nail bed and interfere with the new nail growing underneath. Hope this helps until you get more replies from Maccy Angels.  George & Jackie.

Posts.Title: Hello all my lovely friends

Posts.Content: Morning Rhonda,  As you found triple positive means they can use every tool in the shed at their disposal to help you beat this crap into submission and give you the best prognosis. 14 out of 16 nodes is quite a high figure but the chemo, rads and Tamoxifen's job is to mop up and wipe out any stray cells that the surgery missed or eliminate their food supply and starve them to death and they do it very well. There are quite a few still here in Macland 5 years + some a lot longer and probably a helluva lot more who after a year of treatment find they no longer feel the need to come here and be reminded of a dark time in their lives and drift away to get on with their new lives post cancer who we never hear of again  :-) There are others who unfortunately come back 2, 5, even 12 years later when cancer revisits them and they have to go through surgery and chemo again there are no guarantees but hey,  they have been through it once they know what to expect and willingly bite the bullet again to gain more time with their loved ones. My mother in law has had BC 3 times in the last 15 years and just celebrated her 80th birthday by having way too much wine and falling over while dancing. My own mother had it twice and passed away aged 84 ( not through bc ) and my wife is also grade 3 triple positive and 18 months post MX,  Fec & Tax chemo, Herceptin and now on Letrozole. We all have that sword hanging over our heads but don't dwell on it, we just take each mammo as it comes and keep our fingers and toes crossed and hope each twinge we get is just that a twinge and nothing more sinister. The NHS has a breast cancer predict tool website where you enter in all your diagnosis and treatment stats and it gives you a guide as to how much extra time all the treatments have gained you. This is obviously done on percentages but as a guide it shows you how far treatment has come on in leaps and bounds over the last few years. It is that though, just a guide nothing is written in stone. If you feel you would like to punch in the numbers and see your results you can find it here.  http://www.predict.nhs.uk/predict.shtml It can be scary, but most are pleasantly surprised at how good their prognosis is quoted. Take care Rhonda and best wishes for a lovely Christmas, George  &  Jackie.

Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: Hi  Gillie,  Back again  :-)  Love the "Fabulous Maccynistas" idea. You could be setting a trend here. Here's some more detailed nail info and tips for anyone about to journey on the Chemo Express. Hope it helps,  George  &  Jackie   Just as chemotherapy affects your hair because of the rapidly dividing hair follicle cells, it also affects your nails. You may see a line in the nail related to the cycle of chemotherapy. This line is not permanent and grows out with the nail, usually in about six months. There may even be multiple lines and indentations reflecting the different cycles of chemotherapy. Your nails may become pigmented or discolored. They may become more brittle, so they will not grow as long as they used to and may break more easily. The area around the nail bed may become dry, and your cuticles may fray. Do not rip or peel off the loose cuticle. Cut it carefully with a CLEAN pair of nail scissors. The nail may actually lift off the nail bed. While this, too, is reversible, you need to be very careful, for two reasons. First, the nail is more vulnerable and may fall off. Second, because the nail is not tightly bound to the nail bed, it can become a site for bacteria to enter. So be sure to practice excellent hygiene to avoid infection. Nail care is first-line prevention for lymphedema, a condition that develops when lymph fluid accumulates in the soft tissues of the arm, causing it to swell. If you have had an underarm lymph node dissection (with mastectomy or lumpectomy), you should be particular careful of damage to the nail, such as hangnails or cuts or burns on the hands or fingers, which could lead to infection. Tips for Better Nail Care Clip your nails short. Imperfections show up less in short nails. Do not cut your cuticles. Use cuticle remover cream or gels and push your nails back gently. Do not bite your nails or cuticles, particularly on the hand on the same side as your affected breast. If you have a hard time stopping, consider wearing thin white cotton gloves around the house to help you break this habit. Massage cuticle cream into the cuticle area daily to prevent dryness, splitting, and hangnails. Wear gloves while doing chores, such as washing dishes. Excessive exposure to water can lead to fungal infections of the nail bed. Wear nail polish to help keep nails strong and protected from the environment (and looking nice, too). If your nails are very dry or falling off, you might want to consider a nail moisturizer instead of polish. Dry nails can become weaker or more brittle during chemotherapy treatment. To take off polish, use non-acetone-based remover, which is less drying than acetone. Do not use acrylics or other nail wraps. Fake nails can trap bacteria that may cause infection. If you have a professional manicure, bring your own instruments, regardless of how the salon cleans theirs.
Posts.Title: Before I ........

Posts.Content: Morning Tina - I did reply to your new to site group post, but seeing as you have joined this group I'll paste the reply in here too. Hi Tina, I misread this when I first spotted it earlier - I though you were a Tuba player :-) Great name though...  A lot of onco's switch people from Tamoxifen to Letrozole or one of the other AI's after a 2 year period on them and I can see where he is coming from. The joint and or bone pain can be a bit rough. To the extent of needing Adacal tablets to build up calcium to help against bone thinning and non steroidal anti inflammatory's for the aches. Must admit it's the first time I have heard of an oncologist advising stopping altogether. Anyone else here heard of this ? You seem fairly well 'genned up' on this but there is an info page about AI's here if you want to have a read about any of them in particular. Jackie my better half is halfway through 5 years of Letrozole and they can knock the stuffing out of you for sure, but her Predict % rating was much higher than the 1% you were given so for her it's a no brainer. Can't really advise as this has to be a personal choice - Talk about caught between a rock and a hard place. Damned if you do, and could be damned if you don't :-/ Personally for the 1% gained I think Jackie would have said no but whatever choice you make, make it with no regrets. Sorry for a sort on non answer, but hope it helps a bit. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Op day at last...

Posts.Content: Hiya, No doubt there is a lot of confusion over these clutch of anti-hormone skittles. Tamoxifen is given if pre-menopause but as soon as you reach the menopause (usually after around 2 years) either naturally or caused by treatment they can switch you to one of the AI's (Letrozole, Anastrozole or Aromasin aka Exemestane) Mainly because these are more affective against recurrence than Tamoxifen but AI's cannot be given if pre-meno as they don't stop the ovaries producing oestrogen.  Of these AI's Letrozole is considered the better option statistically but it is more powerful - so worse side effects and possibly more of them. They prescribe the one they think you need based on the info they have from all your results so if you don't need the full metal jacket you won't be given Letrozole (sledgehammer to crack a nut) They do weigh up the benefits of particular type tablet against the effectiveness so what they offer you should be your best option. If you are finding a particular type of AI unbearable you can always ask about changing to something else for a trial period to see if things improve. If you are taking Tamoxifen there isn't really an alternative to that as yet apart from (ovarian ablation) which entails tablets to stop your ovaries oestrogen production or having them both removed surgically :-( G n' J
Posts.Title: anastrozole versus tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Evening Lorylinge, Was this what they term as  Lymphoscintigraphy (scintigram) ? It is used sometimes instead of carrying out a SNB sentinel node biopsy during surgery. If so, they are quite accurate and it could well be that your nodes were not affected so didn't need removing. Lymphoscintigraphy is a test to find out how well your lymphatic system is working. You have an injection of a small amount of radioactive substance into the lymph vessels. Then you have a scan. The scan shows the dye moving through the lymphatic system and shows up any blockages. I would phone and ask about the results though, you could ask for a copy too, it's handy to keep papers like this in case you need to refer back to them for info later on. Anyone else had this in place of a sentinel node biopsy ? G n' J
Posts.Title: I would appreciate some knowledge ladies-and gents

Posts.Content: Hi  Bee,  It's a bummer having to be a member of the club no-one wants to join. They are a great bunch of Maccy Angels on here though  :-)  Grade 1, might not seem like it now, but that's a nice low number to be the owner of and Marsden have a brilliant reputation for treatment. Being hormone receptive is also a good thing which means they know what is feeding it, which gives more treatment options than hormone negative results. The Letrozole (Femara) will gradually wipe out your oestrogen which your BC is hormone receptive for, basically cutting off it's food supply which has to be a good thing. Causing shrinkage, slow down of growth or stopping it altogether and helps in case any rogue cells escape the lumpectomy and rads. Yes,  there are side effects but everyone is different and of the long list you may only be affected by one or two and you can get other drugs to help counteract those which makes it more do'able.  Treatment is not a walk in the park, but it's also not the life sentence it was even 10 years ago. Fingers crossed you get clear margins from the lumpectomy and it's a nice small growth. Rule 1 - Don't google,  stick to Macmillan and Breastcancercare websites that way you'll know the information is up to date and factual,  there is a lot of crap info out there. Rule 2 - Cancer is a word NOT a sentence,  don't let it make you a prisoner. Rule 3 - Anything goes here,  so if you have a question,  need to have a rant or just need to know you are not on your own just holler , you'll soon get some replies  :-)  Assume you have already read macmillan's Letrozole page but if not you can find it here. http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertreatment/Treatmenttypes/Hormonaltherapies/Individualhormonaltherapies/Letrozole.aspx  Best wishes, and very best of good luck,  George & Jackie.

Posts.Title: Help/Emotional support/what to do next / Brest Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn28  It can get a bit confusing at times especially when they use terms like local and regional recurrence which mean different things. There is this page which explains recurrences here at BreastCancerCare UK Secondary or Metastatic (mets) are when the cancer cells from the first primary travel through the lymph system or bloodstream to other parts of the body - More commonly with breast cancer this means secondaries in the Bones, Lungs, Liver or Brain. Hope this helps get you head around it all, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Flowerburn, Warm welcome to the group. Do you know if this new trial drug (unnamed) goes by the number GDC0941 which is a biological therapy being trialled with Anastrozole or something else - and do you keep taking it with the anastrozole of just carry on with the ansatrozole on it's own ? I don't think it really makes much difference which hormonal therapy tablets you take, they all have similar side effects but if the regime you are on is do'able it makes sense to stick with it (better the devil you know) and all that. To be honest it can take 2 weeks to a month to start getting these tablets into your system so it is early days as yet for side effect issues :-/ When do you start your rads and have you any questions or concerns regarding that ? Hope you are recovering well from surgery - Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Hiya, Luvvin' some of these comments :) Have no idea if this is right but it seemed to work. J's hair was very lightly wavy but when her curly brillo pad grew back she was told if she cuts it, it takes longer for the curl to grow out as it keeps coming back curly, but to leave it because as the hair gets longer it reaches a tip over point where the weight helps draw the curl out. It straightened out eventually but if was about 6 months growth and around 4" long before that happened - No idea how long it would have taken if she had it cut a few times though ? G n' J

Posts.Title: A new day - week off to a classic.....flyer!

Posts.Content: Hi SFGS29 Everyone here will probably confirm that pineapple whether that be chilled chunks from the fridge or the juice helps during chemo as it contains an enzyme (bromelain) which can help avert mouth problems like oral thrush, is clean and refreshing which helps kick starting your taste buds. It may not stop oral thrush altogether but can slow it down enough for mouthwash or meds to deal with it quicker :) Tinned is a little better than fresh as it is slightly less acidic - Those on Warfarin or other blood thinners as far as I know are the only people who need to avoid pineapple ? There is more info about Mouth and Oral issues during chemo here at CRUK. Any left over goes into your Pina Colada's  :)) G n' J
Posts.Title: 1st cycle of EC on Monday - advice please

Posts.Content: Hi SunnyMaz, Nice to read you seem to be recovering from surgery well :) Were you given a DEXA bone density scan before being put onto the Letrozole ? as letrozole over time can cause slight bone thinning so base figures will mean they can keep a check on this.... If not you should be able to get one arranged through your GP. As for the Rads - You will given as assessment appointment which will be around a week before your rads start. You will get a little guided tour and a chat with the radiographers and chance to ask any questions you may have and you will also be aligned on the machine and have 3 or 4 very small black tattoo dots that they use to line the machine up to daily. It saves a lot of time measuring everything every day. Do ask if they supply the cream for use during rads, some do, some don't... If yours don't you must get some before the sessions start. You may well be given a CT scan at the assessment as well - this is purely for their information they are not 'looking' for anything so don't be alarmed by this. One thing you may want to ask about is car parking if you will be going by car. Most hospitals allow free parking for rads patients either with a free parking voucher or claiming parking fees back. You could have a look online at your hospitals website to check their parking policies as they do differ area to area. You could have a read of this - Radiotherapy For Breast Cancer. (link) Hope this helps, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: New to here

Posts.Content: Hiya Sam, Node sample box ticked off - that is another hurdle jumped Sam - pleased to see your fears about SNB were unfounded :) Try and see chemo as trying to keep on the good side of a stroppy unpredictable best friend. When you find out what chemo drugs you will be having and when you will be starting, let us know and we can help you out with advice about easing any side effects etc. Best wishes for a hassle free SNB recovery, G n' J
Posts.Title: New to here

Posts.Content: Hi Vicki  /  Tratatoria   Very interesting topic, hopefully there are other members out there who also have a Septic or Eco system and can offer you a more experienced reply. I had to have a browse around and from what I was reading - Yes the chemo can have an effect on the bacteria and upset the balance of the 'flora'. Even if it doesn't kill it all off it can cause less breakdown of solid waste and toilet paper making the chances of a blockage a possibility. Maybe it's a case of it would be so diluted it would have little effect ? There are bacteria booster / enhancers you can add but I'm unsure if these would suffer the same fate. It would be worthwhile phoning your water supplier or tank emptying service about this to see what they advise. It must be an issue they have come across before ? Anyone ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Picking up the pieces

Posts.Content: Hi  Sue,  Lovely piece of early morning news and nice to hear you are feeling more positive. Tax itself can drag you down and give you your own personal black cloud for a few days while it does it's magical work, but for all it's many and varying side effects is a brilliant drug for crushing and wiping out space invaders. Posts.Title: Where can I go from here ?

Posts.Content: Hiya Judith, Sorry didn't reply last night was up at 04:30 yesterday so half asleep later last night. I can only give you a few pointers and J's experience but hopefully it may help. Tamoxifen originally was the only inhibitor tablet available given but because of endometrial risks and other complications these other types of tablet were formulated and are considered better post meno. Tamoxifen is the one that is given mostly if you are pre menopausal or borderline as the other two don't work if the ovaries are still producing oestrogen. Then after a year or so with no periods you may well be switched to Anastrozole or Letrozole (other sweeties are available) To be totally honest I have no idea what criteria doctors use to prescribe Anastrozole over Letrozole or vice-versa. They both work in the same way and have similar side effects but they are different so if you can't get on with one maybe the other is more do'able. What with that and the obvious fillers / coatings issues from all the various makes (which even if denied we ALL know does has some bearing on the many side effects) makes this a minefield to find the ONE that suits you the best. Jackie was given 2 months worth Femara (letrozole) by her onco unit right from the start. When these ran out she was given through our local pharmacy several different other types Teva, Accord and Heinz-57 :-) and felt even more cra* with these. Luckily our GP is brilliant and made her repeat out for Femara and she has been having these for over two and a half years now (whoopee! - half way) She takes 2 x Adacl+ 1 x Sunvit D3 daily and one Alendronic tablet per week to counter bone thinning as the results from her 2nd Dexa scan a few months in came back as osteopaenic. Even though she has found the 'one' that is kindest to her, she still hates the damn things and what they have done to her - BUT it is far better than risking the alternative. Especially seeing as her consultant said being ER, PR and HER2+ (triple pos) there is a 10% difference in her re-occurment risk with or without them :-( Her side effects are, gained around 7kg's in weight which won't budge, seized up joints first thing in the morning which ache a bit later in the day and into the evening, generally feeling like she has aged 20 years and Labyrinthitis (probably) but may be a separate issue. Oh, and global warming :-) There are booklets about each of these individual Hormone Inhibitor tablets halfway down this page listed under Hormonal Therapies / Aromatase Inhibitors. Sorry we can't be of more help with this one, seems it's just a case of plodding on until you find the best one for you. If you prefer Femara TELL your Oncologist (don't ask as it gives them the opportunity to say no) you want these, they aren't ones suffering the side effects and this comment of 'inactive fillers not affecting them' is absolute BS or they would all be the same for everyone. If they won't play ball get your gp to change your repeat to read Femara rather than just Letrozole - Most gp's are willing to do this as they are the ones dealing with your treatment baggage on a regular basis. Good luck with the ongoing battle, G n' J

Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Hi  Maria,  Sorry to see you joining us - It's a bit crowded here and although you would prefer not to have joined welcome aboard.  So you been given a grade 3, take it you had this figure your biopsy results. Have they given you a treatment plan as yet, or they still tailoring that to suit you ? The treatments can be varied but usually go in one of two directions. Surgery first which could be what they call a WLE (lumpectomy) where they remove the tumour with a healthy margin of tissue, or if it is in a difficult position or for other reasons you may actually need a mastectomy. Either of these although very scary to hear or read about are not as bad as you ever imagine, honestly... Then you could get chemo and radiotherapy.The other route is chemo first, then surgery, rads. A lot depends on type size position etc so you could get offered any combination of the above. Jackie was diagnosed grade 3 just over 2 years ago so we are well out of treatment and helping where we can - she had mastectomy, FEC + T chemo, Herceptin and rads. Know this is all a headspin at the moment but once you get a treatment plan in place you will feel a little calmer and more in control. I won't say much more as others here will want to say Hi and help you too. If you need any info there is a link to some Macmillan breast books under the cup cakes image below. Take care, George & Jackie

Just had a look and it seems you were on Carboplatin and Paclitaxel (Taxol) ? The platin and taxane based chemo drugs can do this :( Is this shedding mostly hands and feet or patches all over the place ? G n' J

It's correct they are biological antibodies so you would think OK regarding not causing chemo damage to your veins bit I haven't a scooby doo. Posts.Title: PICC line

Posts.Content: Hiya, It's a shame you didn't post about the symptoms you were getting earlier I'm sure most here would have advised you got this looked at straight away because a blood clot can be too risky to leave unchecked :-( If it is Lymphoedema there is some information and advise about it here. It's quite a big read so I wouldn't get stuck into it too much until you get it confirmed. There is more info under the info and support button at the top of this page. Hopefully if this is lymphoedema it will be short term, but some get lumbered with this being a long term problem, so fingers crossed for you. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Lymnphedema

Posts.Content: Hi sarahjj  Warm welcome to the Breast group, not that we like seeing new members joining this particular club. They automatically make an appointment for you if any biopsy is taken to get the results within 2 weeks and to not come alone. If your fears are confirmed as soon as you get the bad news you focus on the C word and just don't take anything else in, so an extra pair of ears can pick up on information you miss. Whatever they spotted on the ultrasound screen must have looked suspicious enough for them to have taken the biopsy, but it is early days and there are a lot of non-cancerous benign lumps like fibroids, calcification or a pre cancerous conditions which can show up - some benign fatty tumours can keep growing so this could mean surgery of some sort  :( None of us here have anything nice to say about waiting results this will be a very emotional time for you, we all hated the waiting results period - 2 weeks will seem like a lifetime :( You have replied to a quite old discussion here - If you have other questions or need some support at a worrying time, don't hesitate to create a New Discussion that way you know all the replies are for you :) As for how you get through the next 2 weeks without it getting to you - the best thing is to do things, go places or throw yourself into a hobby, anything that occupies your thoughts and kills the waiting time. Don't be a stranger, keep posting as you'll need the support, we're all here to help. Fingers crossed for those results, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Morning sarahjj  Please don't ever feel the need to say sorry around here - Days where you are having a wobble comes with the territory, and if the waiting time starts to get to you - Just post a message and grab some virtual hugs and reassurance :) Macmillan produce a booklet 'Understanding Breast Screening' (link) the section on getting biopsy results starts around page 25. Like nearly all of the Macmillan booklets you can use the above link to read it online or download and save it for future reference. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Hiya peachesxxx  Sorry to read you got your worries confirmed :( It can be scary when they get you started quickly - you tend to think it must be bad for them to offer you surgery so soon but it's usually just a case of a cancellation slot for theatre that needs filling. See you mentioned results of lymph nodes, so have they told you you will be having a sentinel node biopsy at the same time ?  That is something they usually carry out, so is standard surgery. It's good that it eliminates all the waiting around and worrying time but it can leave your head in a spin when the dust settles post surgery :-/ Fingers crossed you get to dodge the chemo bullet but you'll have to see how that pans out from the pathology report 10-14 days afterwards. If you need any info regarding surgery do reply, there's plenty of help on offer :) Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Results are back

Posts.Content: Hi maxinem2  If you are getting this from just 15 days in it may be your Docetaxel dosage is a tad too high for you - They always give the maximum dose from your bmi and for some it is too much. I would phone your breast care nurse, or better still your onco and let them know about both the foot pain and nails darkening. They may want to have a look and possibly reduce your dose by 20% for your next session but it's only just over a week away so if reducing will help you need to let them know sooner rather than leaving it any longer. The nails you may lose at some point but the foot pain definitely needs dealing with as this can get quite bad if not kept in check even leading to being so sore you are almost unable to walk :-/ Some units can offer cooling boots like the cold cap for those who get foot problems (gloves too) maybe this could also be an option ? There are several here who have had very painful feet who hopefully will reply and let you know what helped them. Just a quick note, friction can make this worse so for now try to avoid anything that causes foot friction like step excersies walking up hill - steps /  stairs on the balls of your feet (keep them flat) it's not unusual for this to affect hands too, so no unscrewing actions like bottle / jar lids and if you can get one of those undoing gizmo's arthritic folks use. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Tips for a black toenail

Posts.Content: Probably left overs from an Ikea flat pack Sorry I just couldn't help myself :) G n' J
Posts.Title: TAX - Sore Mouth - What to Eat?

Posts.Content: Hiya Maggie, Oh, it exists alright, it's just a lot of medical folks won't admit to it :-( There is a lot of info about 'The Fog' here at CRUK. It's not just the chemo, but those pesky hormone therapy tablets share the blame too - I think they sum it all up pretty damn good. G n' J
Posts.Title: Chemo fog

Posts.Content: Hiya, This has been a recent topic of several posts here so hopefully you will get several replies about this. Nail changes can happen towards the end of chemo, or as you have found anything up to 6 months afterwards. The main thing to keep a close eye on if your nails are lifting is skin breaks and the chances of an infection getting in - so please don't pull them off if they are hanging on by skin tags. Last thing you want is to risk lymphoedema from an infection (don't know how many lymph nodes you had removed)  If they are not only feeling sore but looking a bit inflamed do get them checked out by either your GP or breast care nurse. Until you get some other replies you could have a look here (link)  J lost all 20 of her nails in the end but this is a bit unusual, most if they get this chemo related nail problem only loose a few. It's mostly caused by Docetaxel / Taxotere but some other chemo drugs can cause this too. Hope this helps for now, oh! and welcome to the group btw. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Toenails and Nails

Posts.Content: Evening Blue, It's usual for them to stop HRT as soon as you are diagnosed with BC as some cancer cells are found to be ER/PR+ positive (oestrogen and progesterone) and if that is the case the hormones from the HRT could actually have been feeding the cells - You will get those results from your pathology report. If you are getting a lot of 'power surges' you can buy a 'Chillow' which is a cooling pillow. I think Amazon sells them for about £25 - Don't know if they are available on the high street chemists ? Maybe some of the other ladies here have found other ways of helping with those as well ? G n' J
Posts.Title: waiting and feeling a bit anxious today......

Posts.Content: Hi silvercloud  That is a new one :-/  You would have thought if they were any head lice in your hair the cold cap would have frozen / killed them so is it possible you have picked one up and had eggs laid within the last 11 days ? I definitely wouldn't used any chemical sprays etc without first contacting your onclology unit and getting more information as it could have an effect of your chemo or worsen side effects. Do give your unit a phone call before doing any treatment for this just as a precaution. G n' J
Posts.Title: Nits

Posts.Content: Hiya Karen, If they quoted only 1.5% I would have thought the chance of having another stroke to be higher than that. I don't want to sway you one way or the other but if it were me I would take my chances without the chemo and put my faith in the Radiotherapy and Letrozole. Letrozole is very good at starving ER+ cells of their food supply and is also used prior to surgery to actually shrink tumours down by quite a bit. Letrozole can be a bit tough on your joints though (there's always a sting in the tail) Only having one lymph node involved is good if there were a lot more it would be a harder choice to make. G n' J
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with W L E with one node positive

Posts.Content: Hiya, It is a bit of a grey area. For BC patients who have any type of lymph surgery (SNB or clearance) it mostly affects the arm, chest and/or shoulder on the affected side while the lymph fluid tries to find another route to flow way. That is why it can be more of a problem if you have a complete clearance. Just after surgery can be a confusing time figuring out it is it lymph fluid or seroma fluid from the cut tissue wounds. Lymphoedema can occur anytime post lymph surgery (even years) if you get an injury allowing infection into the affected side. That is why you have to be so careful about blood samples, cuts, scratches, insect bites etc on that side. The lymph system is massive I think there is an image in the first link Breast Cancer Care leaflet and covers the whole body - If I can I'll paste it in If you think of it like a map of major roads with vehicles on, when you get an accident it is localised in one area, but can cause bottlenecks and spread if nothing is done to help clear it. Thats is where specially trained Lymph drainage nurses can massage the fluid away you can also learn to do this yourself if lymphoedema is a problem ? Bit random, but it's the best way I could explain it :-) G n' J
Posts.Title: Lymnphedema

Posts.Content: Hi  Amy,  Have you any particular reason to think this may be breast cancer, relatives or friends who have had this in the past, or is it your mind running on overdrive and you Google'ing too much ? Have you had any arm/hand or other infections, or flu recently as the lymphs in your armpit are to trap infection bugs etc and just like the glands in your throat will swell and get a bit sore when they do. Could be a muscle / tendon strain, any number of things can cause this. Think worrying and fear of the unknown is only natural when you think the worst but please don't Google most of the information out there is either wrong, or way out of date. Stick with this Macmillan site, or breastcancercare.uk for reliable info from those who have it, or deal with this crap daily. As Emma said the only thing we are sure about is worrying won't alter the outcome of any tests and will only either make you a nervous wreck or depressed.  Assume it's an ultrasound scan the GP has you booked in at the breast clinic for (as opposed to a mammogram) ?  So at least you have done the right thing in getting it checked out early as many go into denial and leave it too long before seeking help. Keep in touch and don't hesitate to ask as many Q's as you like, fingers crossed your scan will be fine and you'll soon be telling us just that, or if your worst fears end up being confirmed either way, we're all here to help you. This is a very big club with some of the friendliest, helpful Breast Buddies there are  :-) Take care and good luck,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Worried to the Maximum!

Posts.Content: Morning PetticoatTwirler   Just wanted to send some 'Good Luck' wishes your way for your referral appointment today and for any results if samples are taken. Fingers tightly crossed for you, do let us know how you got on. G n' J
Posts.Title: Lump in breast - what to expect at breast clinic referral?

Posts.Content: Morning Jane, This can be a side effect of Letrozole but after all this time taking them and seeing no improvement after being off them for 3 weeks think you can count that out. Don't think of your referral as to a Bowel Cancer dept - It's planting worries where they may be no need - obviously they check for cancer too but there can be so many other causes for this problem. The colon is way down the list as usual sites for breast secondaries and very uncommon, so hang onto that thought. This could just as likely be Crohns, IBS, a bowel infection or slight ulceration in fact anything that speeds up the transit of waste so the fluid in it doesn't get time to be re-absorbed before it reaches the end of the line. Would be interesting to read if others have had this problem with Letrozole ? G n' J
Posts.Title: Side effects of letrozole

Posts.Content: Hiya, Whoever said tax doesn't have to taxing is an idiot :-/ Regarding taste issues - It usually goes one of two ways. Either you get a craving for bland food or you find the need to spice things up a tad to actually kick start your taste buds. Jackie went the latter and we ended up living on curries and chilli pasta bakes for what seemed like ages. Sometimes the old eating a bit of fresh pineapple or ginger nut biskwit trick just before you eat can help, but go easy on the pineapple if you have a sore mouth. Anything is worth a try ? Hope you get through this cra* time soon, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Rotting away

Posts.Content: Hi Sally  Londongal  Lovely to read you made it back home eventually and are on the mend. Thanks everso for the update - It's good for others to see that diep or other reconstructions are not always plain sailing and if you happen to be one of the unlucky ones who gets infection on either the reconstruction or donor site it can become a long drawn out road to recovery :( Please don't beat yourself up or regret anything, this was totally out of your hands. Fingers crossed they can work around any problems possibly using lipo later to give you a better shape and get you into a better place. Group hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Easter hugs

Posts.Content: Hi Wearymum, I think you are being very level headed about this Olympiad Trial. Talk about getting stuck between a rock and a hard place though. To benefit from the trial you have to be diagnosed BRCA 1/2 positive and have to go through the agony of informing your daughters of that scenario and the impact that may have for them - and if you aren't positive the trial wont be for you. Personally I wouldn't know which option to hope for :-/ Even if you are brca positive there is a 50% chance you daughters aren't which is something else for the wish list. You probably have already been given lots of info about the Olympiad trial but there is a webpage about it here at Cancer Research UK if you want to have a read. Best wishes for something good to come from this whatever the outcome. G n' J

Posts.Title: I could be wrong

Posts.Content: Morning Roundhouse1 Sorry to read your mum is very much glass half empty at the moment, this sounds very much like some form of depression - Has she suffered from that previously ?  Most feel a bit down for a few days post surgery as that can be a side effect of the annaesthesia but perk up once they get back home. As you say HER2+ BC isn't that rare of the 50K women in the UK diagnosed with BC yearly around 20% will be HER2+ so we are talking around 200 per week nationwide. That figure is why the newer targeted treatments for it were developed and they work very well. My wife was HER2+ and also left mastectomy back in May 2012 and apart from the odd ache still has no evidence of disease at her 6 year scan. This is very do'able although the treatment (usually chemo plus H&P) can be tough some days, they work and anything that stops this coming back elswhere in the future has got to be worth it long term. It isn't unusual for a few cells to be found in the nearest lymph nodes to the tumour as it is the nodes job to trap any stray cells should they come away but even if this is the case those few cells will be wiped out by the chemo and radiotherapy. I'm fairly sure most of the replies here will be very similar to ours both from those having treatment at the moment to the other ladies here who have been there, done that, come out of the treatment tunnel and living their new normal - Read or show them to your mum if only to try and get her to see this isn't the end of the world, just a crappy few months she has to get through to get her towards her 80th birthday :) Hope this is of some help, do get back to us, we're all here to help if we can but a lot of this means your mum will have to make the first move to find herself again or she will continue to drag you all down and the upshot of that will be family not visiting her to avoid the scenario altogether. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Help/Emotional support/what to do next / Brest Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi PetticoatTwirler   Warm welcome to the last place you expected to find yourself signing up to :-/ Just spotted your New To Site message but you would have only been pointed in this direction anyway, so I'll reply here  :) First off this is an emotional period of waiting for your clinic appointment then getting the results from that so try to distract yourself for a few weeks if at all possible, chuck yourself into something like a hobby, work etc anything that will help kill the time until you have some answers. There is also an Under 50's Breast Group here (link) as well - it isn't quite as active as this main group most under 50's join both - There are ladies here around the 30's age group. Being so young they will probably go more by the Ultrasound Scan images although you may also be given a mammogram but as your breast tissue will be a lot  more dense so they mamogram images are not quite so clear. If anything suspicious is seen they will no doubt use a hollow needle to take some biopsies for the pathology lab to check out. To help you get your head around the breast clinic scenario I have placed a link to a booklet Macmillan produces titled 'Understanding Breast Screening'  Just click / tap the cover image below to read and/or download. There are lots of various benign breast conditions so do hope for the best rather than fearing the worst. Hope this is of some help for now, no doubt you will soon get some welcoming messages from the other ladies here, unfortunately this is a busy place. Fingers tightly crossed for you, G n' J
Posts.Title: Lump in breast - what to expect at breast clinic referral?

Posts.Content: Hi terri f  Doubtful this is down to the scalp cooling. You get an ice cream headache at the time but unless you are a migraine sufferer and the cap brought an attack on it would be unusual for this to be the cause. A 7 day hangover from hell headache is very common for the first week or so with FEC or EC. J never cold capped and had this too. The cold cap for hair loss is a little like nail painting and nail loss. It definitely helps but if your genetic make up deems you to have chemo related hair or nail loss you may still get some of this,  only not so badly. G n' J

Posts.Title: Anyone had double mastectomy with reconstruction ??

Posts.Content: Hi secondtime,  A lot of those with seroma here have said before about being careful of infection from getting seromas drained. Think another problem is that the seroma fluid takes up and fills the space left behind after surgery and by having it drained it just as you say it fills up again because you have provided space again so it ends up being a viscious circle. It can be a slow process and a bit uncomfortable but if you can tolerate it for a longer period without getting it aspirated you may find it will eventually slow right down to a level where the fluid produced can be re absorbed back into your body until it just stops altogether. Any other members with thoughts on this and how you overcome it ? Hope it clams down a bit, take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Content: Hi Jeanette, FEC and T are the two most commonly used chemo therapies to treat breast cancer. FEC is actually three drugs given one after the other at the same session and T stands for Taxotere also known as Docetaxel. The chemo sessions are usually three weeks apart. G n' J

So T number 1 was last Monday and I am now beginning to feel like it is easing. The pains are fewer and not as strong although the aches remain along with the finger tip discomfort. 

I'd got used to how I was on FEC and knew which day I would start to feel a particular way it also felt more gradual. Because it was my first T I had no reference points as to what would happen when and how I would be. I have experienced no feelings of nausea with it and I suppose this gave me a false sense of security because when the effects did kick in it was sudden and hard. 

I've had 3 duvet days - with FEC I would have 1 maybe 2. I'm just going with the flow a day at a time and writing down how I am each day so that I know for the next session. 

We are all different and our pain thresholds are not the same so our perspectives will not match. I can see how T would be easier if you were really sick with FEC. 

Getting ready to tackle a new day and hobble about

Take joy in the simple things in life.

Posted by Roobieerants
21 Feb 2016 10:48 AM

Hello

I'm a week and a half along from my first Taxotere. I had three chemo sessions at FEC 100 and like you,  it was my fourth when I was switched to T. 

My FEC experience got progressively worse, the third took me much longer to recover from, having said this it was the psychological struggle I found hardest, my physical symptoms were pretty mild compared to many women's.

I was really anxious about changing as even though the final FEC had been tougher, at least I knew what to expect!

Surprisingly this first Taxotere has been much better for me. The nausea and lethargy of FEC are gone. Still feel tired but it's not as debilitating as the fatigue was on my body and my spirit!

The only other symptoms I have had are some lower backache, twinges and mild discomfort in my legs, toenail and finger nail pain and a sore tongue. (oh and of course the ongoing effects of bloating, indigestion and constipation brought on by an increase in steroids!!!)

The aches passed after a week, the tongue, which felt like I'd burnt my mouth and tongue with hot tea or something started to clear after a week too so I'm left now with the finger nail pain which to be honest only hurts if I catch them, the rest of the time it's more discomfort than pain.

At this point if I had to choose between Taxotere and FEC I'd choose Taxotere every time!.

I'v learned that in cancer treatment you can take nothing for granted however and so I'm assuming that like the FEC, each additional Taxotere infusion will build on the last and as such my fifth and sixth sessions may well bring more intense symptoms.

Ultimately, as many women have said on here-we each experience pain and discomfort differently and our vulnerable places, whether they be physical, psychological or both, are going to be pushed to the limits at times.

My only advice would be protect yourself, nurture yourself and take the preventative meds provided.

Rest, rest and lots of TLC.

Good luck. I will be thinking of you.

Roobieerants

Posts.Title: After Taxotere...

Posts.Content: Hi Mama55  Warm welcome to the group not that we like seeing quite so many new members :( There is a monthly chemo club here in the breast group as so many who have chemo at the same time - You can find Augusts Chemo Club here. Septembers will start Wednesday afternoon sometime. As it is coming to the end of the month there are quite a lot of pages of messages, please don't be put off by the number of side effect posts. There are a lot of people having chemo at this time and those who sail through chemo don't need to ask questions so you get a skewed view of it all.  There is a 'chemo aid' link in the first message about help with side effects and other helpful hints. Do you know which chemotherapy drugs your daughter is having ? Most here have FEC-T but there are other variations. Ginger Nut and Arrowroot biscuits can help with any taste / nausea issues and Paracetamol an hour before using the scalp cooling cap (ice cream headache) Some chemo units will supply hair conditioner, some don't so she may need to buy her own. There is quite a shopping list to help make this more do'able. There is some information about Scalp Cooling and Hairloss here. Hope this is of some help to start with,. I have a feeling your daughter will soon be wanting some help as this is a tough call to try solo. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Daughters 1st chemo

Posts.Content: Hi ranorton  J my better half was diagnosed HER2+ over 5 years ago (May 2012) and went through chemo and Herceptin.  The chemo period (18 weeks) were tough some days but only for about 5 days every session then the chemo fog clears and you feel more like yourself. When the chemo finishes and you carry on with just the Herceptin it is a lot more easier to cope and with very few side effects. You will have more good years, Herceptin is a game changer for HER2 :) Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: My test was funded!

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass  Lack of oestrogen can be a bugger to come to terms with, especially if you are younger (pre-menopause) when your oestrgoen suddenly gets switched off  - Oestrogen is one of the bodies feel good hormones and this is why you suffer with low mood without it :( Tamoxifen has been found to cause cognitive impairment similar to chemo brain as it works on stopping your ovaries from producing oestrogen. I assume when you mention 'was on' Tamoxifen you have now stopped taking that and been given Zoladex / Goserelin instead  - have you been switched to another Aromatse Inhibitor type hormone therapy tablet as well, or just stopped the tamoxifen ? It isn't so much of a problem for post meno ladies as the only oestrogen being produced is from the adrenal glands and a little from body fat cells as the ovaries have already shut up shop - although even this smaller amount of oestrogen loss is still noticeable :( Some people produce more oestogen than others so it is more noticeable when it gets shut off. You could have a chat with your Onco to see if there are any other alternative hormone therapies if you are nearer being classed as menopausal but to be honest they all make you feel cr*p but in differing ways. Sorry there isn't a magic remedy all you can do is try ways to minimise the issues they cause you, and if you can't ease the baggage decide what your recurrence risk % of not taking them is :( G n' J

Posts.Title: Hormone Therapies, Mood and Memory.....

Posts.Content: Hi Theresa28 It may be worth looking into the Exemestane (Aromasin) option as I think exemestane are steroidal based and Letrozole and Anastrozole are not, so may be better for you. All of these hormone inhibitor tablets have similar side effects to a greater or lesser extend because the side effects are more from the lack of oestrogen than from the tablets, but changing again may be the lesser of the 3 evils.  At least that way your ER+ worries are still covered. There are quite a few ladies here who have ended up taking Exemestane so hopefully will give you their experiences :) As for your sex life again - no oestrogen equals a big reduction of your bodies natural lubrication. A lot of the members in the cervical / vaginal groups get very similar problems after pelvic radiotherapy and the 2 products they mostly recommend are YES and SYLK. The Sylk webpage link also has a free offer section to get a freebie sample and I believe both products are paraben free. If you have a sympathetic GP you may even get this on prescription :) Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed triple negative starting Chemo 1st May

Posts.Content: Morning Rosiero, With HER2+ you will very likely be offered Herceptin but this is given after or alongside chemo - not on it's own. The only time this isn't offered is if you have any ongoing heart problems as it can affect heart chamber muscles by weakening them slightly. This booklet will give you some info about Herceptin. The most common chemo to be used alongside Hereptin is Docetaxel (every 3 weeks) or Taxol (weekly) but others are available depending on your oncologists choice. Some units now administer Herceptin as an injection, some still use the drip pump bag and cannula method. You could look up docetaxel and taxol using the cancer information button at the top of the page but they might offer you something else ? Jackie was HER2+ and was given 3 x FEC, then 3 x Docetaxel - the Herceptin was started with the first Docetaxel. Get back to us when you get your regime confirmed and we can post more info. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: What chemo

Posts.Content: Hiya Helen, J had this while taking Letrozole. It lasted around 2-3 weeks then it went, never to come back. GP said they weren't sure if it was vertigo or Labyrinthitis. Said she felt terrible laying in bed seemed like the room was spinning and when she walked she literally had to hang onto the walls to avoid going off at an angle. You could get it checked out by either your Onco, BCN or GP if it is Labyrinthitis they can do a head manouver that shifts the fluid in your ear to the correct canal which fixes it, but if it is vertigo and it doesn't ease off you may need meds to help. G n' J

Posts.Title: Sore veins post chemo

Posts.Content: Morning Shirl / Fiona, I think Positive1968's question about secondaries was meant for Mistymoley (Helen) in case it caused some confusion. Postive1968 - In case Mistymoley isn't around to clarify the secondaries thing,  I think what Helen was getting at is if you ask about having a bilateral mastectomy it obviously greatly reduces the chance of a getting a primary cancer in the 'good' breast at a later date, as it won't be there, but just because you have a double mastectomy it doesn't lessen the chances of getting secondaries in the future as secondaries nearly always appear somewhere else in the body. So no, having a mastectomy and reconstruction definitely does not increase your chances of getting secondaries. G n' J

Posts.Title: A bit of a ramble....and a thank you!

Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor, Don't you go talking up problems now.... If EC wants to kind to you don't tempt it to behave any other way :) You may be one of those who sail through chemo well, everyone is different and you may find it gradually gets a little worse (or maybe not) it's still early days as yet and it may take a couple more days to fully get into your system. If you do get an easy ride don't go thinking it's because it may not be working it has been known for some ladies to get away so lightly with side effects, they can continue working through chemo. Do keep taking any meds they gave you to keep on top of the nausea and drink plenty of fluids. Just see how it goes day by day and keep your fingers crossed. Keep in touch on how you are doing and if you need some advice just holler. Good luck with it, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Myshittit  There are going to be so'ooo many ladies here who wished they had thought of that as a user name :) Welcome to just about the busiest group going - which is good 'cause there is always someone going through the same rubbish at the same time to share tips n' stuff. There is a regular monthly chemo club too.. You can find July's here (link) There is a 'Chemo Tips' link in the first message you can check out. Notice you  said you started FEC 2 weeks ago - How is the head ? any sign of it getting sore pending hair loss ? You seem to be doing all the right things to ease the side effects bummer it isn't helping much.  You could go back to basics and try making a mouthwash from Bicarb of Soda and water to rinse with.  It may be down to the steroids wiping out your mouths good bacteria or could be an allergy issue from the chemo. Some find an anti-histamine like Piriton helps, you could ask your onco if this is ok - also next time you are having chemo take some frozen grapes to suck they can chill your mouth off and this seems to help. Don't think they would let you take in a tub of Haagen Dazs :) One of the most recommended hand/foot creams is Udderly Smooth (make sure you get the one with Urea though) Don't know offhand if you can get it from any high street chemist outlets but Amazon deffo does it. Sore bums not good, is that from going too often (chemo trots?) Warm welcome BTW, no doubt you'll be around for the long haul and we'll see you about the place. 26 is a crap age to get hit with the cancer brick :( No doubt the other lovely ladies here will come and say hi! and give you some tips as to what helped them :) Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: FEC side effect remedies needed please!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Lee, Don't know what stage / grade your were classed as or your age, but all this Chemo, Herceptin and hormone inhibitor tablets (given to ER+) post surgery is all about avoiding recurrence. Think the overriding fact here is the HER2+ part - see below - HER2-positive breast cancer is a type of breast cancer where the tumour cells carry much more of the HER2 protein than normal, healthy breast cells.  HER2 helps relay communication signals through the cell which tell it to divide.  It also prevents the cell from going through a process called 'apoptosis, where the cell commits suicide should things get out of control.  This combination of promoting cell division and preventing cell death contributes to the growth of HER2-positive tumours. Somewhere between 15-25% of all breast cancers are HER2-positive and these patients tend to be at a higher risk of recurrence following treatment.  Patients are tested to see if their tumour is HER2-positive or not prior to treatment so that the best treatment can be selected for them.  The drug Herceptin has revolutionised treatment for this type of breast cancer because it specifically targets the HER2 protein, effectively shutting off the signals telling the cells to grow.......... You can ask your oncologist to crunch the numbers using the NHS predict tool to give you a recurrence estimate with or without chemo and Herceptin. Everyone hates the thought of chemo but even if the risk of recurrence is 10% would you want to risk being one of those one in ten who it re-ocurrs for in a few of years time ? Because you are ER+ you will be given daily tablets for 5 maybe 10 years so adding chemo and Herceptin to the list will mean you have done everything you possibly can to avoid this coming back to bite you. I'm fairly sure NICE only allows Herceptin if used in conjunction with chemo. Hope this is given you some thought of questions to ask your onco team. Take care, G n' J

Warm welcome to the breast group, not that we like seeing new members to this particular club. You can ramble on, smash plates, have a good rant, anything goes here if it helps get the angst out. Like Karen says so much has changed with breast cancer treatment even within the last 4 years yet alone 10 - It now has a 90% recovery rate. Just about everyone says they feel every ache and twinge after they get the news it's mostly down to being so tensed up and stressy sleepless nights - the pain you felt beforehand from your shoulder is highly likely to be coincidental and nothing to do with this. Crying in the shower is a good way to get it out if it gets too much at times. Hope you get good results from all your scanxiety, this initial waiting results time is what everyone hated the most. As soon as you get a treatment plan put in place  it gives you something else to focus on. If you have any questions don't hesitate to ask, we're all here to help. Posts.Content: Morning Shirl / Fiona, I think Positive1968's question about secondaries was meant for Mistymoley (Helen) in case it caused some confusion. Postive1968 - In case Mistymoley isn't around to clarify the secondaries thing,  I think what Helen was getting at is if you ask about having a bilateral mastectomy it obviously greatly reduces the chance of a getting a primary cancer in the 'good' breast at a later date, as it won't be there, but just because you have a double mastectomy it doesn't lessen the chances of getting secondaries in the future as secondaries nearly always appear somewhere else in the body. So no, having a mastectomy and reconstruction definitely does not increase your chances of getting secondaries. G n' J
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Lindylou49  The Endocrine therapy (hormone inhibitor tablets) are for ER/PR+ positive. So either Tamoxifen if pre-meno, or Letrozole, Anastrozole or Exemestane if post-menopause.  ER is Oestrogen and PR is Progesterone. The scale is from 1 - 8 for both, which means the higher your number the better response you will get from the hormonal therapy. Those who are HER2+ positive have Herceptin a targeted biological therapy and also have to have chemotherapy too. There is more information about Hormonal Therapies here. Hope this is of some help - has chemo been mentioned or have you appeared to dodge that bullet ? Hugs, G n' J
