Posts.Title: Fear & Low Moods

Posts.Content: Hi berren  A YEAR!!! Was it your GP who told you this and did they realise this is a prior recommendation for the tablets you will be needing ? This isn't what NICE recommends for those having aromatase inhibitors like Exemestane, Letrozole or Anastrozole.... See Below, it's the very first item mentioned..... 1.10 Assessment and treatment of bone loss 1.10.1 Patients with early invasive breast cancer should have a baseline dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan to assess bone mineral density if they: are starting adjuvant aromatase inhibitor treatment have treatment-induced menopause are starting ovarian ablation/suppression therapy. 1.10.2 Do not offer a DEXA scan to patients with early invasive breast cancer who are receiving tamoxifen alone, regardless of pretreatment menopausal status. 1.10.3 Offer bisphosphonates to patients identified by algorithms 1 and 2 in 'Guidance for the management of breast cancer treatment-induced bone loss: a consensus position statement from a UK expert group' (2008)[12] (see appendix 2 of the full guideline). This is part of the cancer pathway not for just checking for osteopaenia and should be carried out to get baseline figures prior to starting the aromatase tablets so they can monitor any bone thinning. The reason that Tamoxifen users don't get a Dexa scan is that Tamoxifen doesn't cause bone thinning like the aromatase tablets. Personally I wouldn't take any supplements as yet as they will skew the Dexa scan results, wait a little while until you get this fob off delay sorted out - Do get back to whoever told you it would take a year and explain why you need one soon quoting NICE if you need to. Hope this helps a bit, G n' J

Posts.Title: re: How do I join September Chemo Group?

Posts.Content: Hiya MamaSm, Ditto what omg said - also if you feel any slight pain, heat or spot any reddening let the onco nurse know and they will take things a bit slower. If it is rushed (onco units can be very busy at times) or not diluted enough with the saline it can cause problems with your veins. They will probably keep asking you how you feel but in case your nurse isn't so 'switched on' keep an eye on how things are going. Morning appointments always seem to be a bit more casual than mid to late afternoon ones, so if you get a choice go for early. If they are running late it's the afternoon appt's that can get rushed through. If your first appt is later in the day, when you have finished and book the next session ask if you can have an earlier one if it suits you better or they will give you one around the same time everytime. They should be looking out for reactions to 'any' of the three drugs (assume you are having FEC) and because of this your first session it may take a little longer, which is a good thing. If they give you steroids try not to take one too late in the day or you will have a helluva problem getting to sleep - you don't want be known locally as the crazy 3am Dyson lady :-) oh, and they may make you want to graze all the time so keep plenty of low fat nibbles around..... or Choccy Hobnob's yum... Good luck with it, it's all very do'able even the tiredness, don't fight that - have nana naps if and when you want them. George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Mum has started chemo...

Posts.Content: Hiya, There are cases where chemoptherapy is very successful in shrinking tumours down to almost nothing. To the extent they insert titanium markers clips into the breast prior to chemo in case they have problems finding the tumours on subsequent scans. Chemotherapy will always have some impact on tumours the scale of any shrinkage will determine which surgery option is best for her as everyone has different results. But of course this will not be determined until after her sessions. She will be monitored during chemo to keep a check on any shrinkage. You mention 8 rounds of chemo - Do you know if this is the same chemo regime for all 8 sessions or could it be four sessions on one type of chemo then switching to a Taxane based chemotherapy drug for the other 4 ? If you could find out which chemo drugs are being offered there is extensive information about all chemo individual and combination regimes of drugs on this site we could refer you to. Regarding having children, this is a 'toughie'  They (or you) should look into this further. Get them to check out with their oncologist the chances of her chemotherapy regime making her infertile. Unfortunately this can be quite common and they may need to seek help with this regarding freezing eggs or embryo's for future use.  I believe embryo's seem to have a better prospect of being more viable after freezing than eggs but I'm uncertain of this as I'm not medically trained. You can find more info from this Macmillan booklet 'Fertility and Cancer Treatments for Women'  This can be saved when the page opens to maybe pass on to them as an attatchment ? As for her HER2 test coming back as 3 I would think that is to be taken as a positive if it had been 1 or 2 (borderline) it may have been worth checking again - You can read more about the Dako Herceptest here. There are so many younger women getting diagnosed lately this is because detection has greatly improved over recent years - I would very much doubt if BC had been diagnosed without very accurate pathology information to base it on. Having said that cancer is in itself an evil genius and mis-diagnosis can happen, mostly it is the other way around though, where someone gets a negative result which later turns out to be untrue and by then it is more advanced :( Personally I would have thought Canada to be 'way up there' on the expertise league table with great breast cancer surgeons and oncologists. If you haven't already it may be advisable to join a couple of Canada's more trusted breast cancer support sites to test the water regarding he best places for a second opinion - I have heard of, is it Sunnybrook in Toronto ?  but time to check all this out and getting second opinion appointments arranged may be wasting time they don't really have ? as treatment of any kind needs to start quite quickly. Hope this helps a bit, G n' J
Posts.Title: My apologies as I am not sure if my question crosses all groups

Posts.Content: Hi Iona, Please don't get all stressy about this - for the most part it's just standard hygiene nothing over the top. The time when you are more susceptible is during the middle week of 3 (days 7-15) Just to mention a few pitfalls but most are fairly obvious - Pets / Animals if you have or come into contact with either leave any cleaning up for others or wear  disposable latex gloves. During this week try to stay clear of places where you could pick up an infection. Other peoples snotty / sick children (it's almost impossible to avoid your own) doctors waiting rooms. Do the supermarket shop at a time the store is quieter. Making a good job of mouthwash and teeth/gum brushing as the steroids kill off all the good bacteria in your mouth which normally prevent oral thrush forming. Handwashing of course, but especially your own. By this I don't mean every 10 minutes :)  Hands are the most common way to infect yourself. There are a few food items to avoid during this week as well. No uncooked meats, or seafood and no live or pro-biotic yoghurts etc  There are plenty of alternatives you can have instead. Good point from Jannie about getting fast food to save the hassle of cooking etc.  Places like Fish and Chip shops, KFC and MaccyD should be fine but beware of places that can 'flash' fry meats like Chinese and Indian takeaways as it may not always be cooked through. Hope his helps, G n' J
Posts.Title: Risk of infection

Posts.Content: Morning Lorraine,  They only get a rough idea of type and grade from any biopsies. It's not until they get tissue results from WLE or Mastectomy the full picture emerges.  Nearly everyone gets their initial results 'tweaked' after histology. As for the B5b - It's a table they used when examining the cells to establish the amount and type of cell abnormality.  The B categories are as follows: B1 – normal B2 – benign B3 – uncertain malignant potential B4 – suspicious (further samples required) B5 – malignant. For B5, it should be noted whether this is B5a, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), or B5b, invasive carcinoma Although yours are at the top end of the spectrum, don't see this as too scary. Bear in mind the size was small, so caught early. Grade 2 is still better than 3 or 4 and it appears to be sort of borderline between 5a and 5b so although it has wiggled it's way out of the duct it cannot be by much and they must be sure they have got clear margins, or they would have had you back in to take some more tissue. Have you heard if any nodes on your SNB were affected, or if you are ER/PR or HER2 positive yet as this will further determine your treatment regime ? You may be told you need chemo, or with grade 2 you may be given the choice of chemo or not - different consultants have different views. You will be offered Herceptin if HER2+ which is only given with chemo. There may be exceptions, but I haven't read anyone here being given Herceptin without chemo. Maybe the above information will be forthcoming at your next consultation ? - it may be worth you making a note of any questions before then as you will never remember them at the time :-) PS - Keeker mentioned the Understanding Your Pathology booklet - so I just edited in the link. Hope this help a bit, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Slightly confused!

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy, All these many types scanners have their own specialist area uses. Not all hospitals have a PET scanner so you may have to travel to a larger unit. There is more info about what is involved with a PET scan here at CRUK Back to playing the waiting game eh :-( Sending you our best wishes for good luck with your scan and results, G n' J
Posts.Title: MRI-CT-PET Scans

Posts.Content: Hi  Wendi,  If it was a considered a major problem you would be given plenty of info about risk to others prior to being given chemo, so I wouldn't fret about it. I don't know of anyone mentioning on here about chemo risk to others ? Your body will break down and get rid of the chemo drugs within about 48 hours by natural process. So by that it means expelling "any" body fluids / solids may contain residue chemo. That's why everyone will recommend taking in lots of fluid just prior to and for the first few days of treatment to help flush it out. The important chemicals that do the work will already now be locked in to search and destroy  :-) Please do ask your onco team about this, they may suggest you avoid long contact with children during your treatment anyway as they will be a much bigger threat to "you" regarding picking up infections than you are to them when your white count is at its lowest ( middle week of three ) May not be so bad while the summer school holidays are ongoing with their germ breeding centres (classrooms) closed for 7 weeks, it's different if they are your own children at home as you all share germs and will have each others antibodies.   Hopefully, you won't need chemo,  but if you do we'll all help you through it.  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy - how dangerous?

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly57  From what flopsy has copied in from NICE it looks like the Metasin testing alone isn't that accurate, unless you has the combined Osna one as well :(  and if NICE doesn't recommend it how come you had it -  Was it carried out privately by any chance ? I can understand them wanting to check into this further if you got a false negative or the results are inconclusive but if they are saying you now need a clearance it means you must have at least one affected node from your SNB. If that IS the case you may want to ask about the POSNOC trial to really find out if you need a clearance or not as it's not a decision to be taken lightly. Do ask for a print out of what the results of infected nodes from the Metasin test actually were - I can't recall anyone else here mentioning Metasin so it doesn't seem to be used on a regular basis and there may be good reasons for that :-/ Don't be persuaded to have the clearance without knowing all the facts, if you do really need one, so be it - but you read so many messages here where after finding just a few snb cells a clearance finds no other nodes were involved - plus there's always radiotherapy as a back up. Hope you get some more background info from whoever told you this, was it the surgeon or an oncologist ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: This is all so random :( J's onco said we needed to book a DEXA scan prior to going onto Letrozole and to get this referral via our GP. GP said our local hospital didn't have a DEXA scan facility so she had one carried out as an nhs referral to a local private BMI unit. Appointment came though within 3 weeks. The costs of private dexa scans vary from as low as £70 to £180 but you should be able to have one via NHS outsourcing free. If you need to be taking these aromatase tablets it makes no sense at all to be on them for up to a whole year before a scan is done. They won't know how much your bones are being affected because they have no initial baseline figure to use as a guide :-/ It may be worthwhile seeing your GP and telling them your onco says you need a dexa scan and see if the GP can get one sorted for you earlier ? G n' J
Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: Hi  Wendi, Would be great if anyone in Maccyland has had any chemo contamination issues - Perhaps they could chip in with their views ?  We certainly have seen no posts about it and have been members a while. Regarding body fluids chemo contamination to others as long as you are careful for up to a week after a chemo session it'll be fine.  Obviously chemo can cause diarrhoea which would entail maybe double flushing the loo and wearing gloves to clean up any splashes. Nothing you wouldn't do cleanliness wise anyway  :-)  One area which may not be so obvious is mouth to mouth kissing and intercourse fluid exchange. Kissing won't be a problem as exchange of fluids is very minimal and even if you feel like intercourse ( doubtful ) they would probably advise using condoms as a barrier. These chemo drugs are now a lot more refined and targeted than they were even a few years back so are a lot less of a problem to others.   Only 2 more Herceptin to go and we'll be kicked out to face the future fully loaded and fighting fit  LOL It's been 14 months since diagnosis and the time has really flown by.  Your calendar gets so full up with appt's for scans, chemo, ecg's, bloods, etc your feet hardly touch the ground.  Have to agree with the Maccy Mantra - "It's all so Do-able".......  including the feel like crap duvet days. Take care and fingers crossed for good news in two days time, and yes we ALL agree the waiting is a killer............  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy - how dangerous?

Posts.Content: Afternoon Angela, Yes I'm afraid so, is the answer to both your questions :( This is a quote from Cancer Research UK (CRUK) taken from this page about Chemo Brain..... "They found that women taking anastrozole had more thought and memory problems than women taking tamoxifen"     See in particular the section sub titled 'Other Cancer Treatments' about half way down the page. The effects of taking any of these hormone inhibitor therapy tablets will cause some weight gain, that coupled with the fact you may not now be so energetically active adds to this. As for the post surgery bra's I agree, just ignore the 'young' model images and picture yourself wearing the bra illustrated instead.  I wouldn't have thought it is anything deliberate, it's just if you contacted a model agency asking for a 60 year old model for a post mastectomy bra shoot they wouldn't have anyone on their books to send you, just as you mentioned :) As long as you are healthy enough to get out of the house and meet up,  there are lots of groups out there where the young at heart can socialise or partake in hobby based activities or gentle exercise like swimming ect - Have you tried contacting any of the local charities to see what could be on offer that may interest you ? Hope this is of some help for you, best wishes, G n' J
Posts.Title: Anastraloze side effects and older ladies without family.

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly57  I had a look into posnoc and found it is a 10 year trial - hence no results as yet from phases I or II :( There are newsletters on the POSNOC website but have no idea if these would be of any value. If they found a tumour rather than just micro/macromets that would probably explain why the clearance is on the table. Posts.Content: Hi TSmith, Excuse me if I take the liberty of pasting in your under 50's message below our reply as it makes it easier for others to reply to without having to keep referring to the other group message :) I can only mention what is the standard courses of action in the UK although to may be very similar to Canada. In cases where chemo is given prior to surgery it is usually to see if the chemo can shrink the tumours down enough to offer a viable lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy. trying to save her from losing the whole breast. Also here in the UK they will not give you Herceptin (info link) for HER2+ without chemotherapy as it is nowhere near as effective used on it's own and because Herceptin (a targeted monoclonal antibody) is very expensive they need to ensure it is $ well spent. If you have any other questions, fire away, we're all here to help :)  Been a long while since I was in Ontario, take care, G n' J Original copied message from 'under 50's breast group below...... Posted by tsmith 2 Jan 2016 3:53 AM Hello to all, My heart goes out to all beautiful women [and men] who have been diagnosed with this dreadful disease however, I do trust one day we may all be free of it. Posting for my 30 year old, new diagnosed, sis in law to see if we can get some help to understand the treatment plan/pathology and opinions on best course. Some information to help. Living in Canada, Ontario. Infiltrating carcinoma cells shows: Positive staining for HER2(+3) -- have been told there is a drug to combat/cure this Dako Herceptest + 3 >10% -strong complete membranous staining (3+) is considered positive  for HER2 a. Breast (right at 2:00 o'clock), biopsy Invasive Ductal Carcinoma Comment: Sections show an invasive  ductal carcinoma, preliminary  intermediate grade.  There is a minor component of ductal carcinoma in situ, intermediate-high grade with comedonecrosis and microcalcification. Breast biomakers have been ordered and  will be reported  as an addendum. b.Breast (right at 10:00 o'clock), biopsy Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Preliminary  intermediate grade Comment: Breast biomakers have been ordered and  will be reported  as an addendum. c Axilla, (right) biospy Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Preliminary  intermediate grade no lymphoid tissue is seen Now, what I have been told from my sis in law and brother is that what has been currently planned is 8 rounds of chemo to see if the 2 tumors discovered [as well as the lymph nodes] will shrink followed by surgery if outcome is successful (what that exact surgery is, I am unclear from my conversation with them). Now, my thinking, with the limited information given, is that if this were me I would want surgery first and chemo second.  Now I have asked the question of what is the end goal of all this and please correct my ignorance here but if the end goal is to remove the breast then why not do this first, followed by chemo to kill off any residual.  I guess what I questioning at this point is the plan to tackle this.  I have seen what chemo does and I am willing to bet someone would give there left arm to have surgery rather then chemo [however having this choices are definitely positive].  I do know (and have been told) that the medical oncologists have been fighting with the surgical ones regarding differences of treatment plans on many cancers for years.  Please help shed more information on this and advise of any additional information we should be requesting before approving to this plan.  We will be meeting with the medical oncologist on Thursday and I do want to go with them to ask any questions that they may have forgotten/not thinking about [or just moral support). Also, since we are new to this disease, please provide, opinions, professionals around the world who I can email for second opinions or that are truely the best in the world who I can reach out too. Thank you so much to everyone who helps!!

Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy, and thanks Kate for bumping this as I thought I sent a reply yesterday but it seems to have evaporated :) They test everyones bloods for liver function by looking at several enzymes just before every chemo session to see how the liver has reacted and recovered from the last chemo before going ahead with the next in line. If some of your enzyme counts are 'out' they may either delay your next session by a week or so, or reduce the dosage slightly.  Any amount of chemo reduced (usually 20%) will not have any impact on it's effectiveness it just eases the side effects, stops your white count bottoming out so low and helps with liver recovery. It can also be used to help diagnose liver secondaries but if this is what they were looking for they certainly would have told you. Cancer Research uk (CRUK) have an info page about liver function tests, and by chance they also have a page about Milk Thistle and Liver cancer. There are promising trials with this but they advise against taking it during chemo as it may impact on some chemo drugs working fully. Fingers crossed 'this' reply works Mandy-Moo, take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Tabby Cat Lover, If you have the chance of Paclitaxel (Taxol) over Docetaxel - Go for it. It is the breast cancer chemo of choice for private clinics and with it being weekly much kinder to you than Docetaxel (Taxotere) regarding side effects. It's like being slapped with a velvet glove rather than a wet leather one :-)   It is still tough on cancer but being lighter doses your body will find it much more manageable than the NHS version of Mr.T There are a few ladies here who have had Paclitaxel hopefully you will get some more opinions. You can find some info about Paclitaxel / Taxol here. There is also this groups search results for Paclitaxel so you can read some of the older posts. Hope this helps, G n' J
Posts.Title: Paclitaxel

Posts.Content: Evening  Emma,  Don't know if we can help you out with dates / weeks as I think your treatment is different. Am I right in saying you having chemo, surgery then rads ? As Jackie was surgery, chemo then rads. From all her diary dates her rads were started 7 weeks from the date of her last Docetaxel and she had 15 mon-fri sessions, so her rads were about 6 months after surgery, but if you are having treatment the other way round I don't know how long the gap is between surgery and rads :-(   They will have to ensure you are capable of putting your hand/s behind your head and hold it for a few minutes while you have the rads so the more you persevere with post op excercises the more comfortable you will find that.  If you are having the chemo, surgery, rads route hopefully someone who has had that treatment regime will be able to give you more informative reply. Try not to fret about the Docetaxel,  what will be will be, and you may find it's nowhere as bad as your thoughts are telling you. Just be prepared for anything as it can lull you into a false sense of security for a few days, then on day 3 or 4 bite you in the bum. Then again maybe you'll be one who finds FEC worse, and sail through it reasonably well. Just remember to get plenty of fluids into you and you'll soon find out if you also need some pineapple, corsodyl and soft toothbrush for a yucky, sore mouth and as with the fec keep up all the tabs they give you. As a sore mouth and feeling wiped out some days and taste problems are the more common side effects, others not so common are tingly feeling or numbness in toes and fingers sometimes your feet or toes can feel hot and burning.  Keep your onco team informed of any problems as there is always something they can give you to help you through it, don't suffer in silence. As for the rads, they have you in a couple of weeks prior for assessment and planning where they talk you through it, all ask if you have any questions, then they put you in a gown and you lay on the table while they align the linear accelerator for the areas to be treated and give you some very small black dot tattoos this is for the LA alignment so they treat the exact same area everytime. These little tattoos are virtually painless. Ask if they supply cream for you to use, if not you will need a tub of E45 or any other unscented aqueous cream. A lot of hospitals allow either free parking for patients having rads, usually done by reclaiming your money back, or can be in the form of a voucher or pre paid card. Ask or look online at parking concessions where you are having your treatment about this as the daily parking can add up especially if you are kept waiting due to any delays. Here's a link to the Maccy External Beam Radiotherapy treatment info page. http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertreatment/Treatmenttypes/Radiotherapy/Beingtreated/Externalbeam.aspx Hope this helps a bit, try and enjoy whats left of the weekend,  George & Jackie.

Posts.Content: Hi Andi3xx  It's a yes from me  :) There have been very few ladies here who had problems with PICC lines compared to those that a line has helped greatly during chemo. Not only is it used to deliver the chemo, it's also used to take the many 'bloods' taken during the 18 weeks or so. The two problems you can get are getting an infection at the entry site, or a clot forming in the line and you being put on blood thinners to break it down but these are quite uncommon. Saves you from long term vein damage from the chemo drugs, and the time spent having your session shorter and easier. G n' J

Posts.Title: Mastectomy - Single or Double?

Posts.Content: Hi Tuppatea, I'm not medically trained but from what I can make out you friend is - Grade II (so grade2) ILC = Invasive Lobular Cancer that is 18mm in size and in the lower inner quarter of her left breast - the no LVI = there is no lymph vascular invasion which is why they say lymph normal so not found in the nodes (Axilla normal)  Stage equals size and grade equals the aggressiveness of the cancer cells to grow. The ER and PR are hormone receptors ER for Oestrogen taken from the American spelling (estrogen) and the PR being Progesterone the scale only goes up to 8 so her cancer being ER8 and PR8 is very hormone receptive for both. In layman's terms both oestrogen and progesterone hormones will be feeding the cancer cells. She will be placed on hormone inhibitor tablets for at least 5 years to wipe out her ER and PR, there are several types (tamoxifen, ansatrozole, letrozole, aromasin so which one will depend on if she is pre or post menopause and other diagnostic info. The HER2- negative means she may or may not be offered chemo mainly because of the grade, if she was HER2+ positive chemo and Herceptin would be a definite but with grade 2 and HER2- negative it is considered borderline and she may be given the choice of opting for chemo rather than being told, which is a tough decision to have to make :-/ The DCIS is ductal carcinoma in situ which is early breast cancer which is contained in one place (in situ) if this breaks out it is called invasive ductal - the reason they have mentioned this is because it is possible to have both ILC and DCIS at the same time - but it states NO DCIS so she has invasive lobular only. Don't fret about the invasive part, all cancer can be invasive all it means is it has the capacity to invade not that it already has.... I'm uncertain about the P1 10% part - I think this may be a cancer marker result ? There are several different ways a pathology result can be written up as each lab has their own way of testing and scoring. Hope this is of some use, if you have any other questions, fire away - We're all here to help. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: 22yo terrified of core biopsy - and, well, everything

Posts.Content: Hiya Lucy-B, You won't figure out how this will be for you until you know which chemo regime it is, as they each have differing common side effects. Even then you can never be sure because everyones body handles the drugs differently - The only common denominator is tiredness / fatigue. Some can cause nausea but they give you tablets to help counter this, some chemo drugs don't cause this nausea near as much but can cause joint / muscle aches instead :( Hairloss can start between days 10 to 22 from your first session but again some chemo drugs are more prone to cause this than others. Epirubicin is the biggest culprit for this and unfortunately is one of the more common breast cancer chemo drugs. If you are given this you can always try the Cold Cap to try and help to minimise hairloss - some use the cold cap with good success only losing up to about 40% of their hair but there is always some hairloss with Epirubicin and even with the cold cap it can look a bit patchy :( Sorry to be a bit vague but until Friday when you find out it will be all guesswork. G n' J
Posts.Title: Going to be starting chemo

Posts.Content: Hiya,  and welcome to the club no-one "wants" to join. Can't add much more to what Lynda has said - You'll meet a really great bunch of helpful friends here to help you through the highs and lows ( yes, there are some highs ) of kicking cancers butt. Jackie my wife has just finished 3 x FEC and 3 x Tax after left MX and Sentinel node check which luckily showed clear from 3 nodes taken. Herceptin for 12 months and Letrozole for 5 years. There will be times when you have to give in and accept that you'll need some "you time" if only to get some sleep, get relatives and friends involved in giving you a helping hand to get through it all.  Sometime it seems like one battle after another, then you see the light at the end of the tunnel and before you know it you start looking forward to getting your life back on track, albeit slowly.  Hopefully, fingers crossed your chemo journey will be almost hassle free, ( some are lucky ) but don't bank on it. The side effects can be many and complex with different effects for everyone.  Some get bad mouth ulcers others lose finger nails, sore joints etc. Be prepared for crap days and keep a close eye on your morning temp check as it can quickly jump up overnight to mid 37's and while your white cell count is low even a mild infection can get you a 4 day hospital stay being pumped full of antibiotics. You may get an easy ride from EC but not Taxel, or vice versa. That is why this forum is so brilliant everyone here has knowledge of whatever gets thrown your way and can help to guide you through it. Any probs or concerns - Ask away - Someone, somewhere will have the answers to help put your mind at ease. There are a whole shedload of booklets you can download on the macmillan website covering almost every topic of cancer and all the treatments if they're not available from your local oncolgy centre but nothing beats the forum  :-) Very best of luck on your journey. Hugs,  George & Jackie.

Posts.Title: Starting out......

Posts.Content: Hi millie63  Sorry to see you joining us here, hope you are recovering well from surgery without any complications ? The more normal'ish wait between surgery and the next stage of treatment is around 6-8 weeks could be a couple of weeks before or after that time frame - especially where chemo (depending on your Oncotype results) could be offered. Main reason being they have to make certain all healing issues are resolved to lessen the slightest chance of infection should chemo be needed. As chemo can lower your white cell count making infections easier to pick up and harder to fight off. You should get to hear something soon, keep your fingers crossed for a low Oncotype score but don't be too scared if chemo is recommended - It's your long term health and lowering the risk of recurrence that is the most important thing here. Don't be concerned about the time this is taking, surgery was your main treatment to remove any tumour/s nothing drastic is going to happen over a few weeks and you get a more personalised treatment plan, rather than the old standard over treatment of chucking everything including the kitchen sink at it. Any questions, fire away, we're all here to help where we can. The only silly question is the one that isn't asked :) Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi hairworries,  Quite right on the dif between Tamoxifen Pre and Letrozole for Post menopausal patients. This is from the Breast Cancer Care uk  site - When a woman has been through the menopause, oestrogen is mainly produced in body fat. Other hormones (androgens) are converted into oestrogen within fatty tissue by an enzyme known as aromatase. Letrozole works by stopping the conversion of androgens into oestrogen, reducing the amount of oestrogen circulating in the body. Letrozole cannot be used in pre-menopausal women (those who have not yet been through the menopause) because it’s ineffective if the ovaries are still making oestrogen. If there’s any doubt as to whether you have completely gone through the menopause or if your menopause has occurred during chemotherapy, your doctor will probably recommend tamoxifen and only switch you to letrozole after several years without a period. Letrozole reduces the amount of oestrogen in the body and lack of oestrogen over time can cause osteoporosis (thinning of the bone). Because of this, your specialist may want to check your bone density (strength and thickness) with a dexa scan before or shortly after you start taking letrozole. Your bone density may also need to be checked approximately every two years with a repeat scan while you are taking letrozole, but this will depend on the results from the initial scan or if your specialist has any concerns. To help keep your bones healthy you can increase your intake of calcium and vitamin D. Most people do this by taking a supplement, but you may also want to eat more foods rich in calcium, such as milk, cheese, yoghurt and cereals, and for vitamin D increasing the amount of oily fish and eggs you eat. Some people will find that letrozole causes the level of cholesterol in their blood to rise. You may wish to discuss this with your onco or GP particularly if you have a history of high cholesterol. Whatever works best for you is the right way for you to go, all we can do is put the information out there to help with informed choices :-) Best wishes, G n' J
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: Regarding the Biafine cream - It's available online from a company in the uk called blisslife co uk. With postage it works out around £25 for 400grams. There are also a few selling it on ebay,  but as with all the pirated medical stuff now out there you have to be careful that you'll be getting an original product. Wether it is of any benefit buying more expensive creams when generic aqueous is so cheap is entirely up to you. High street chemist prices for E45 is around £5 for a 350 gram tub and generic aqueous is around £3 for a 500 gram tub. Oh, and like Russ said, we lived on curries, chilli pasta bakes etc for about 2 or 3 months while J was on Docetaxel she could only taste strong flavours too. She said it made a change from cardboard and iron stews and polystyrene pies  :-)  You'll soon find out where your taste buds are going, just go with the flow... Mr Chemo at work on a cancer cell    G  n'  J
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy Advice

Posts.Content: Hi Tasha771  Welcome to the Breast Group - I'm assuming because you replied to this discussion you have been diagnosed with Phyllodes too or is yours a different type of breast cancer ? The way you are feeling is totally normal a lot of it is down to fear of the unknown and all the cancer horror stories you see in the media the recovery figure for bc is very high. While you are reading this just scroll up near the top of the page under the groups name and select the 'Join This Group' button. Then you will get email notifications of messages and replies in this group but will also be able to start your own discussion if you have any specific questions. Have you been told yet what your treatment plan is going to be ? Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Phyllodes/sarcoma

Posts.Content: Hi Karin  Karakeys  When you say large volume biopsy do you mean a biopsy containing actual tissue rather than fluid taken with a standard syringe ? There is more info about types of biopsy around page 8-10 in this BCC breast clinic booklet. Core biopsy is on page 9. You will feel a little sore for a couple of days afterwards but although the needle for the tissue sample used is hollow it isn't very large so please don't be expecting them to take large amounts of tissue at a time. You may well have one or two from the breast and another from the lymph node area. G n' J
Posts.Title: Hi im newly diagnosed with invasive breast cancer, scared and looking...

Posts.Content: Hi Ed, Ever noticed it's always the loudest chick that gets fed first ? It's time to bring out Mrs.P.Doff and just tell them how it really is..... Whoever you see, don't sit there and be Miss Nice, dig your heels in and tell them you want to go the iv route if only to see if it helps. It sometimes takes that much to get their attention!  If you find iv doesn't help that much then re-assess how you are coping with it - at least you tried. It can't be no big thing for them to switch you from jab to iv for a session or two to see how it goes. G n' J

Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: Hi Descat   Trying to figure out if you have a cat named Desmond or if you are Des and Cat as a couple :) As you mention only 2% of BC are Phyllodes and half of phyllodes are benign so you fell the wrong side of the lucky fence :( Don't know if this is the case for you but It is quite often found in those who have had a history of breast fibroids of which some can be pre-cancerous. The main reason there are so few phyllodes (current and ex patients) here is mostly down to it phyllodes only needing a quite short treatment regime. Nearly always surgery followed rads and you are sent on your way. Chemo is only usually offered if the phyllodes has broken through and is no longer contained (vascular invasion) and the 5 or 10 years of hormonal therapy is very rarely needed. Please don't feel disheartened by not finding someone else with Phyllodes - there are very many variations of breast cancer. I doubt if there are more than a handful here who are actually identical in their pathology. Not only are there around 5 more common types of BC there are variations within those as well like grade / stage, ER, PR HER2 Every BC patient here goes through the same physical and emotional turmoil of surgery and rads so in that respect nothing else is different, so don't feel you have to find someone in exactly the same boat when you are already settling in here :) btw - do check out the breast cancer groups monthly September Radiotherapy Discussion (link) for those having rads to help support each other during their sessions. Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Phyllodes/sarcoma

Posts.Content: Hi Maria, I remember you posting about you not getting much support from your own family quite a while back and it saddens me to read it seems like you and your husband have had to do this all on your own all this time :( It is tough hearing comments like that which will hurt you and make you feel worthless and you call these people 'family' (Shame on Them !!!)  :( You have got through the last 6 months or more without them supporting you (during probably the toughest thing you have ever had to face)  if your mum really feels this way it is time to let them get on with it and live your lives the way you want to without all the emotional baggage she is causing. Has you mum always been this bitter and cruel with you ? Do you think it's because you are the youngest and have always had to come last with everything including hugs.... Sounds to me like you are a caring, loving wife and mother, perhaps your mother resents the fact you are nothing like her and could have always been jealous of you for some reason ? There will come a time when your mum or one of your brothers needs some help and support - what goes around, comes around. Know it is a tough decision but I would look to the future without them being part of it - You don't need their petty ways making you feel so guilty about yourself. G n' J
Posts.Title: Extended family have turned their back on me

Posts.Content: Hiya MrsD, Sorry you have had to wait a while for a reply. Feeling sick before you even start is very normal - fear of the unknown, but if you get to see the chemo room you will find everyone at ease reading or using their iPads, listening to music etc it is in no way a stressy atmosphere, far from it. From what I can figure out this will be your first meeting with the chemo nurse ? So you will be told which chemotherapy drugs you will be given and how often - most commonly every three weeks. They may also measure and weigh you to work out the dosage according to drug calculations. It's just so they can give you the maximum dose that they feel you can deal with without overdoing it. They may also carry out an ECG to get your normal heart trace readings to give them base figures to compare any other future readings to. They may take blood samples too to check your liver can handle the chemo they are planning on using. Blood samples are taken a day or two before every session to make certain your liver is ready to deal with another dose. The chemo regime mostly offered is FEC-T but there are other regimes like AC or EC etc so pop back in and reply when you find out a bit more. If it is FEC-T you could get either first. If it's primary job is to shrink a tumour down so you can have a lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy it may be the T part first, but different oncologists go about things using their experience. Things to ask - If you have read on here about the cold cap and would like to try this ask about using that and if they actually have this facility, not all units do. Also ask if they allow anyone in to sit with you during your session, again most are ok with this but some units don't allow it and have a waiting area for whoever comes with you. If you have had problems with small veins and iv needles in the past mention this, they may offer you a PICC or Central iv line for chemo and bloods (if you are lucky) otherwise they will wait and see how your first session goes and take it from there. Ask if they supply an antiseptic mouthwash (chlorhexidine or similar) to ward off oral infections again most willingly hand it over others rely on you to buy your own at a high street chemists. Having said all that it may just be a quick chat about what chemo you are having when it is going to start, take a look at the chemo suite and come in a couple of days before your first session for all the above. Hopefully other members will reply with some ideas too, as by answering this it will 'bump' the post up the list. If I think of anything to add - I'll edit it in later. Hope this is of some help, G n' J
Posts.Title: Questions to ask.

Posts.Content: Hiya new2this, Welcome to our very active group even if none of us wanted to walk through the door. There are loads of us here at various stages of treatment and those who have completed treatment and have come out of the tunnel. It is odd that you can have a whole load of family and friends supporting you but still feel alone. So, yes, do post any questions or concerns you have, as we have all been there at some time or other. The conversations here can be very varied from teary, angry, funny and everything in between. If you need any questions answered or just want a chat, fire away. We're all here to help. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: does anybody talk here?

Posts.Content: Hi Chrissy,  I think a lot of these claims about food and drink are way over stated. Either to 'hype' the sale of a product, create media sales or just to stir the pot.  True a lot of the so called 'live' foods should be avoided during chemo when neutropeanic but as for dairy oestrogens causing cancer - Nothing has been proved. In fact Cancer Research uk (cruk) says this -  "Dairy products have been studied for their effect on breast cancer risk. Some recent studies have shown that women with a high intake of dairy products have a lower risk of breast cancer, but we need results from more studies before we can be sure about this. Dairy products are high in calcium, and several studies show a lower risk of breast cancer for women with high calcium intakes or calcium blood levels" Most of us especially as children consume a shed load of dairy from milk and milk shakes, milk based puddings like rice and custard, ice cream for those of us pre Thatcher who had milk at school every day. If it was a problem with oestrogens in cows milk I'm sure hardly any of us would have reached middle age yet alone the much higher average life expectancy we now have. Not only the UK and US, ALL cows milk comes from pregnant cows ? If anything there may be more in meat from animals fed on hormone supplemented feeds and from natural plant oestrogens ? Who knows, t's a battlefield with far too many if's and but's. Perhaps the China Syndrome is down to something else like not eating so much red meat having fish and chicken instead, or a higher soya and rice intake. Maybe being less affected by cancer is in their genetic makeup ? Until proper trials are carried out it's all guesswork. Perhaps the chinese detection rate is very poor so not as many get diagnosed ?  All I know is there are more people making a living from cancer, than there are dying from it. So just enjoy eating and drinking whatever takes your fancy, and if you are of the other side of the fence eating and drinking all the good stuff and supplements, also taking care in what you eat and drink in general that's ok too as long as you are happy with your choices. For me, life's too short for all the dietary hassle, denial and head scratching :-)  Just saying :-) Take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Lost my messages!!

Posts.Content: Evening KatieF  Warm welcome to the group, sorry to see you have to dance with the devil again after all this time :( If you are having a mastectomy it will probably be at least a few weeks before you start chemo as they like you nicely healed first to lower the risk of infections when your white cell count is lowered. At least it gives you lots of time to gather info and some tips to help you through your sessions. Don't know what chemo you may have had for your previous cancer and if that has any impact on the choice of chemo drugs you can be offered now but it they are offering you Herceptin you must have been found to be HER2+ positive, herceptin is nearly always coupled with chemo and may well be why they know prior to any surgery chemo will be needed. Have you got a surgery date yet or is this all still very recent - Just thinking it would be nice for you to get Christmas over before starting chemo as taste issues will take the edge of the all the food and celebrations :( There is a monthly 'Chemo Club' in the group where those having or have had chemo support each other during their sessions you could check out Novembers. Any questions simply ask, there is always someone here happy to help. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Hi Tabitha,  When you are expecting the worse you'll grab any results that are better eh  :-) Have they mentioned giving you a PICC line or port for your chemo and blood samples. If not ask about one, makes treatment so much easier for you, the chemo nurses and protects your veins, especially if you have small veins. Maccy has a port and central line info webpage if you want to check it out should be easy enough to find using the search box. Must admit we're impressed with your attitude to this, no sign of a rabbit in the headlights, just a Tabbi-Tiger stalking those bloody C cells. Do you know when you start FEC #1 ? They don't usually give you long to worry about it, if anything it's a rush getting all yourself sorted and ready to do battle.  Best wishes and good luck,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: results are in :)

Posts.Content: Morning Jackie, Have you any reason to feel this way ? Is this just a scheduled post treatment appointment, or one you have been referred to because of a problem ? If it's the usual post treatment chat, all that will be discussed is how you are feeling - any problems during treatment or ongoing issues you are still having. If everyone is happy they bid you farewell until your next review. If you are still having problems or side effects from any part of what you have been through, now is the time to ask questions about it ? I'm sure the only worry you will have is you won't get a cup of tea and biscuits out of them. Best wishes, G n' J
Posts.Title: Nevous

Posts.Content: Hi Pen, Does it hurt if you gently push onto your breastbone as costochondritis can affect this area's cartlilage and be painful where the ribs join the breastbone ? It could be scar tissue tightening up or possibly rads rib damage but that one is probably doubtful this long after rads... You are doing the right thing getting in contact with the Marsden to check this out, hopefully it is a side effect of previous treatment and nothing more. You may well be asked to go in for bloods and possibly a scan which would be scary but at least that way you will get some answers. It's a long shot but did you get any metal clips placed in the breast prior to the lumpectomy that were left in - assume you didn't have any chemo or you would have mentioned it ? You could do a group search for Costochondritis using the search box above to see if anyone ele has posted about it.... Do let us know what advice you get from Open Access as it may help others who get the same problem. Good luck with getting answers, G n' J
Posts.Title: Pain down side of ribs

Posts.Content: Hiya Fran, Sounds like she may dodge the chemo bullet then... Radiotherapy is nearly always given especially if she may not be having chemotherapy, as it's all about avoiding recurrence, hence also the 5 years possibly 10 of tablets (one a day) Radiotherapy is usually 15 sessions Mon-Fri daily for 3 weeks. 18mm in nearer 3/4 of an inch - same size as a 1p coin. You could have a read of this to help you get your head around the figures 'Understanding Your Pathology Report' (clickable link) produced by breast cancer care. Best wishes for her meeting on the 7th, G n' J
Posts.Title: friend just diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy-B,    Still can't tag you think the hyphen stops it :( Yes chemo is usually given in 21 day cycles. You have chemo on day one then every 21 days (3 weekly) Facing chemo is nearly always worse in your head that in reality, but you do get the odd tough duvet days. A lot of ladies have some cancer cells found in their nodes, these are mostly just a few cells rather than actual clusters or tumours. Don't suppose you know yet which chemo drugs regime you will be having ? The May Chemo Club has just gone live you can check it out clicking here. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Susie, I would wait and ask your oncologist which (if any) they are happy with you taking. This from Cancer Research is a good read  ---  and also this page A lot of the anti-oxident type vitamins can have an affect on the chemo and don't forget NO Grapefruit or Grapefruit juice at all while on chemo. An enzyme in it can stop the chemo from working or even have an opposite effect that can make your body react like it's getting an overdose of chemo with increased side effects......... Other citrus fruits are fine apart from marmalade (seville) oranges but who would want to eat those anyway :-) Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Phyllodes/sarcoma

Posts.Content: Hi Gypsylee  Welcome to the breast group - high five for wanting to be a great help to your friend at what must be a really tough time for her :( I'm not a 100% certain but I think subcutaneous mastectomy is med speak for what is called a nipple sparing mastectomy. Where the nipple isn't removed but all the breast tissue behind and within the breast skin itself  is removed. Her own breast skin and nipples are retained and these are used for the reconstruction.  Does this sound like what was explained to her, or don't you know much about it ? It may help you to join the BRCA Group (link) which we also have and ask this question there as this type of mastectomy would be more common for risk reducing BRCA patients. Hope this is of some help, someone here will have experience of this type and can advise you better. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi, Assume this particular trial is for those who are ER+ Positive but HER2- Negative ? I know when you check out any chemo drugs list of side effects they tend to list anything and everything and we all know you may only suffer a couple of these but with Abemaciclib / Verzenio (link) they do seem to be very much similar to chemo side effects; especially those mentioned in the 10% - 29% bracket and this is taken alongside the oestrogen busters so could be long term?   :( No wonder not many are signing up to this one :-/  Although the trial may use a lower dose ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Full Range of Breast Cancer Related Books To Read/Download

Posts.Content: Hi KatieF  We're mostly of the opinion that surgery removes the tumour and the follow on treatments like chemo, hormone inhibitor tablets (if ER+) and radiotherapy are back up's to help greatly reduce the chances of recurrence. With that in mind fingers crossed they aren't so cruel to start your chemo sessions before the holiday period :-/ You could ask your oncologist (when you meet them) if this is do'able - even with grade 3 nothing drastic is going to happen if chemo is delayed by a week or so. G n' J
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, Manx Healthcare are based in Warwick and are part of a pharmacy company called Dudley Taylor, so they may just buy in generic drugs and re-package them to pass on in their pharmacies. You may have got these because you live in that area ? The company isn't large enough to be a manufacturer so I would assume they could be made by any of the other generic drugs companies. If this is the business they are in, chances are they have bought and repackaged the cheapest ones they could get :( You could have a look at the blister package and see if it states the actual maker on that as chances are they buy them in already in the blister packs ? If you cant tell from any of the packaging who makes them you can phone them and ask who supplies their 'Manx' brand Letrozole their phone number is 01926  482511  I don't think they can actually withold this information to you as a patient prescribed them. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Hi silvercloud When Jackie was diagnosed HER2+ positive in May 2012 the oncologist went to great lengths to tell us if we had lived across the border in the next county Herceptin wouldn't have been offered as it was then still a postcode lottery drug due to cost :( At that time prior to Herceptin (one of the then new targeted biological therapies) HER2+ positive was 'up there' as among the worst types of BC to get and because HER2+ was considered aggressive with only a 75% chance of surviving more than 5 years and 4 x times more chance that it could reccur within those 5 years. Luckily NICE approved Herceptin for everyone and it is a real game changer as far as prognosis goes bringing it almost in line with recovery figures for other types of BC. With J's full diagnosis and crunching the numbers she was told without Herceptin her chances of recurrence within 5 years was 40% a scarily high figure which made the decision to have chemo and herceptin a no brainer. Unfortunately you have to have the chemo to get the Herceptin it just doesn't work as well without it and NICE won't fund Herceptin without certain types of chemo drugs being given, as per all the original trial results. In a way it is good they found you to be HER2+ as it means there is excellent treatment for it, just a bit of a shock when you were hoping to avoid the chemo and you get tripped up - as you say that tough decision has been taken out of your hands. It just goes to show how much these new targeted biological therapies have improved the outcome for so many in such a short time, even over the last few years :) Four years on the only thing holding J back now is that pesky Letrozole but if it keeps the devil away from your door, so be it :( You can do this, hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Shopping list for chemo - am I missing anything?

Posts.Content: Hi, I think some chemo nurses tell people not to take paracetamol as paracetamol can lower your temp so if you have paracetamol in your system when you take your temp you may get a false lower reading masking the onset of an infection starting when your white count is low. Most people take their temp first thing in the morning before taking any tablets to counter this effect, but in your case it may well have something to do with you being allergic to penicillin ? I think you should ask someone else there about taking paracetamol mentioning your allergy and see if you get a different answer ? It may be just a comment she makes to everyone which is ok for her, she's not the one with the thumping skull ache for a couple of days. G n' J
Posts.Title: Shopping list for chemo - am I missing anything?

Posts.Content: Hi  Cat,  My assessment was 3 weeks prior to starting my 15 x sunbed sessions. This was at Addenbrookes other treatment centres may vary slightly. It may be worth you giving your dept a ring and asking them. Addy's have 6 linear accelerators - sunbed rayguns :-)  So they have a lot of options. At the assessment with a radiologist and assistant they'll ask you loads of Q's about your general health, if you have any problems keeping your hand behind your head for 10 - 15 mins as they require this to treat armpits lymph area and will answer Q's on anything you have concerns about. They really put my mind at ease before giving me a half gown to wear before taking me to an LA room where I lay whilst they made various adjustments to my position and then aligned the machine up and made 3 small black tattoo marks. They are used to line the machine up to when you start your treatment, so they don't have to keep measuring every visit. So be careful you don't wash them too hard when showering etc as they did tend to get smaller prior to treatment. A couple of images are taken to ensure the area being treated doesn't include any heart or lung tissue ( with mine they said it only just clipped the very top of my left lung ) The rays are directed in at angles so they sort of skim the area ( in at the side and out through the chest and vice versa ) so they don't actually go wholly right through you.  So treatment is just kept to the area it's needed in. Get a good supply of unperfumed aqueous cream in to use once treatment starts. Honestly a lot of people have major worries about radiotherapy apart from the accumulative tiredness and daily travel it was a walk in the park........ It'll be over before you know it :-) One thing that you may need to double check on is seeing as your rads will be daily they may clash with any other onco or dr's appointments you have already booked, if so these will need juggling a bit. Best  wishes,  Jackie and George

Posts.Title: What a difference

Posts.Content: Hi Bevdin, Not trying to confuse you even more, but the answer to both questions is yes. They take biopsies when they find something that doesn't look like normal breast tissue on the ultrasound screen and need to know more about it's make up from examining the sample/s under a microscope in a pathology lab. This will determine if this is a benign lump / cyst / fibroid or calcification or if the sample does indeed contain breast cancer cells. Some (very few - one stop shops) can let you know the same day, more often you have to go back a week later for the results so I would take someone with you anyway. Not only will it give you a 'friend' to chat with to help take your mind off it a little but another pair of eyes and ears always helps in case you miss something. The scan operator won't be able to diagnose anything but you can ask them questions about approximate size, it's position (if it appears to be in one area or scattered) etc This may help 'Understanding Breast Screening' knowing a little in advance what may happen. Take care and good luck, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hiya Kimmy, No fretting on the Groshong, it goes nowhere near the arm veins. Enters the chest and is tunnelled up to your neck than down into a large vein near your heart. Jackie had a Groshong fitted for 15 months and apart from the weekly flush had no problems with it at all. There is more info about Central iv lines inc Groshong here. Click the button on the page named  'Read The Details'  Hickman and Groshong are similar it's just that the Groshong has an inbuilt valve. Take care, you'll be fine honest, G n' J

Posts.Title: Taxotere and Cyclophosamide (TC)

Posts.Content: Hi  Jackie, Assume they explained it's easier to check for any reactions if they start these 24 hours apart. Together on the same day would muddy the waters. You don't say which chemo drug regime you will be on, but if it is Docetaxel and you get no immediate reactions they may be given after each other but on the "same day" next time around. If you could post the chemo treatment schedule they are giving you we'll be able to answer any Q's better as each has their own varied side effects. i.e FEC-T or T and Herceptin then FEC ? Have you already had any surgery ?   To be honest you won't know how chemo will affect you until you are a few days into it, some get hardly any ill effects apart from extreme tiredness and achey muscles and joints, the unlucky ones will get a rougher ride. It's a very individual thing and although a lot of the side effects are more common everyone's experience will be different. Unfortunately some days you do feel like sh*t, but not many are really bad. Although it will seem a long time to be having chemo, the time soon goes and before you realise it you are having your last one and looking forward to a brighter future. Hope this helps, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Morning Suze,  Steep learning curve at the start isn't it ? and so hard to figure anything out with the diagnosis fog still in your head. What decisions do you need help with ? is it whether to have chemo..... Chemo is great for shrinking tumours down which in some cases can make the difference between a lumpectomy (WLE) or mastectomy - It also acts as insurance agains re-occurance as it 'treats' the whole body so if any cells have escaped they get found and zapped. It's tough, but as others here will tell you do'able. No doubt you have loads of questions, so fire away - We're all here to help and there's loads of us around at various stages of treatment. So there is always a few at exactly the same stage to share notes and tips with. Won't say welcome as none of us really wants to be here, but it's great place for friendly advice, support if and when you need it but most of all trying to make the rocky road walk a bit smoother. Take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Content: Hi Suze, Sorry didn't realise you already had the WLE - It pains me to think they ask if you would like chemo :-/  Instead of just saying you'll need this, making that decision is always fraught with worries. I know one thing and a lot here (who have gone through chemo) would probably agree if you were one of a 100 women in a room and you knew that 7 of you won't be around in less than ten years I wouldn't want to take the chance that one of them could be me.... Eeek!!  Now that is scary....just for sake of 18 weeks of FEC. As for winter children and colds etc out of the three weeks between sessions you are only at risk of infection for about 5 days between days 7 and 12'ish. Know it all sounds very scary especially as you probably don't know anyone who has had chemo before, we've all seen the horror stories in soaps and in documentaries but it really isn't as bad as they portray it and those 18 weeks soon get ticked off the calendar. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Hi ... and help please!!

Posts.Content: Hiya Bailey, Warm welcome to just about the busiest group here. TC combination of chemo is a bit different to what is usually handed out so there may only be a few of the lovely ladies here who have had that combination - It's nearly always FEC-T (FEC is 3 sep chemo drugs) The C you are being offered is the C part of the fec  coupled with the T The C is for Cyclophosphamide and the T is for Taxotere also know as Docetaxel. There is an information page you can read clicking here about TC to give you something to browse until you get some other replies. There is also an August Chemo Club here where everyone having chemo helps each other along with advice and support. If you click the above august chemo club link it contains some chemo aids info in the first post on the page. Realise you are scheduled for Sept but the club is run every month, so you won't miss out. If you could reply with any other questions you may have about chemo (or anything else) do ask, there's no such thing as a silly question here. Is this chemo prior to surgery or have you already had surgery ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Chloe, If you or anyone else is interested in NICE Breast Cancer guidelines you can read the Early and Locally Advanced Breast Cancer: Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines here.  Covering every stage from seeing your GP and getting a breast clinic referral to post treatment 'Follow Up' Original is dated 2009 but obviously is updated regularly as and when required. Certainly makes interesting reading, even if a tad 'techie' in places :) These two sections regarding Hot Flushes etc while on Aromatase Inhibitors (but not Tamoxifen) caught my eye as there has been a lot of posts here recently about menopausal side effects......................................................... 1.13.12 The selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitor antidepressants paroxetine[14] and fluoxetine[14] may be offered to women with breast cancer for relieving menopausal symptoms, particularly hot flushes, but not to those taking tamoxifen. 1.13.13 Clonidine, venlafaxine[14] and gabapentin[14] should only be offered to treat hot flushes in women with breast cancer after they have been fully informed of the significant side effects. G n' J

Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Bat, HER2+ is a gene fault but isn't one that is hereditary like BRCA so it isn't passed down. What is HER2 ? Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is a gene that creates HER2 proteins. HER2 proteins act as receptors on breast cells and promote breast cell growth. Every woman has HER2 in her breast cells. In a healthy breast cell, HER2 is responsible for repairing the cell and growing more cells. If the HER2 gene mutates, it causes an uncontrolled increase in HER2 protein. This causes cells to grow and divide out of control, which may lead to cancer. Which is why HER2+ is considered 'aggressive' About one in every five (20 percent) of breast cancer cases, HER2 genes don’t function correctly. HER2-positive breast cancer is not inherited from a parent. Instead, it’s considered a somatic genetic mutation. Somatic gene mutations occur after conception. Having a close relative with HER2-positive breast cancer does not increase your risk for breast cancer or HER2-positive breast cancer. Treatments that specifically target HER2 are very effective. These treatments are so effective that the prognosis for HER2-positive breast cancer is actually quite good. Treatments include: Trastuzumab (Herceptin) Lapatinib (Tykerb) Pertuzumab (Perjeta) Ado-trastuzumab emtansine (Kadcyla) So it is a gene fault caused by a gene that 'switches' at sometime after conception not a parental gene fault that is passed down through families. With a 1 in 5 chance of any breast cancer patient having this her2 gene fault it's purely coincidental if this occurs in a mother / daughter or sister / auntie scenario. Hope this helps, G n' J
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: Hiya Vonnie, There are so many different combinations of supplements and therapies out there, coupled with the fact that everyone handles chemo drugs differently it is far easier for them to blanket ban all of them for the duration of chemo as it would be impossible to check every one against all the (100 +) chemo drugs. Some supplements are under normal circumstances fairly harmless (even helpful)  others not so and can either cause the chemo to be not as effective or increase the side effects. Ooh bugger! Cellulitis that can take a while to sort out :-( It can be caused by something really random too.  Here's a bit of info from Lymphoedema Org. If you select the consensus link at the bottom it brings up a good but bit techy read all about anti-biotics and ongoing treatments Clarithromycin is mentioned a few times. What is cellulitis? Cellulitis is a sudden, non contagious infection of the skin, characterised by redness, swelling and heat, accompanied by pain and tenderness. People with lymphoedema are particularly susceptible to cellulitis because the lymphatic system is damaged or overloaded and does not function adequately to fight infection.    What causes cellulitis? The infection may enter via a break in the skin, such as a scratch or insect bite or through a pre-existing wound or ulcer, or through an area of skin inflammation, e.g. athlete’s foot, eczema or dermatitis. However, it may not be possible to identify the cause and an attack may arise without warning.    How can I recognise cellulitis? The patient often feels unwell, as if ‘flu is starting. Symptoms can include fever, shivers, muscular aches and pains, headache, nausea, vomiting etc. The swollen area usually develops a rash or becomes red, hot and tender to the touch. Swelling may dramatically increase and pain may occur in the swollen area, or the armpit, with lymphoedema of the arm, or groin with lymphoedema of the leg.    What should I do if I develop cellulitis? Contact your doctor immediately as you will need antibiotic treatment. Treatment of cellulitis in lymphoedema is very important, not only because the sufferer may become very ill, but because lymph drainage routes risk being damaged further, in which case, the swelling may worsen and permanent skin changes, e.g. thickening, may result. This does not help the long-term management of the condition.    For information on the type of antibiotics used in the treatment of cellulitis in lymphoedema, see the Cellulitis Consensus Document (in pdf format).   Lets hope that when your cellulitis is cleared up it stays cleared up and doesn't re-visit you. At least now you know the signs. You could get a med-alert bracelet for this should you feel it necessary ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi, I think some chemo nurses tell people not to take paracetamol as paracetamol can lower your temp so if you have paracetamol in your system when you take your temp you may get a false lower reading masking the onset of an infection starting when your white count is low. Most people take their temp first thing in the morning before taking any tablets to counter this effect, but in your case it may well have something to do with you being allergic to penicillin ? I think you should ask someone else there about taking paracetamol mentioning your allergy and see if you get a different answer ? It may be just a comment she makes to everyone which is ok for her, she's not the one with the thumping skull ache for a couple of days. G n' J

Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Nanks   Unfortunately if you only had radiotherapy the answer is probably yes :( Up to the menopause most of your oestrogen is produced by the ovaries - post menopause oestrogen is still produced by the body in the adrenal glands and from body fat cells, - being ER+ you still need protection from this risk. Your onco will know your ER score (8 is the highest figure) which means strongly receptive only between you can you figure out which will be best way for you long term. Carrying on with the Tamoxifen or switching to aromtase inhibitor type tablets like letrozole, anastrozole or exemestane. The AI type tablets can cause bone aches and thinning which can lead to osteopaenia - so they are all a bit rubbish really. If you had chemo as a whole body treatment chances are your recurrence risk would be low enough to not have the tablets and take your chances but if you didn't have chemo the tablets are the only thing acting on your whole body. Radiotherapy is only a 'localised' treatment. Unfortunately recurrence doesn't always come back in the breast. The other breast, bone, lung, liver are also areas that can be affected :( I would phone your oncologist for an appt to work out your risks. G n' J

Tamoxifen may be the better one for you, no one really knows until an alternative is tried for a couple of months. A lot of ladies have switched for whatever reasons and all that happened was they swapped one lot of side effects for another :( There is a lot more information about hormone therapies here (link) it is an American cancer site but they go into far more detail explaining things.

Posts.Title: Brittle nails

Posts.Content: Hi mummylove, Sorry to read your mum is feeling a bit down. It is normal to have dips in mood and it doesn't take much to tip you over the edge. Did your mum have chemo before her surgery or is she not having chemo ? As this can also affect the emotions, as can any hormone inhibitor tablets like Letrozole, Anastrozole or tamoxifen etc ? Sounds like what you mum is going through is similar to post traumatic stress. Although happy to be free of cancer, she looks down and hates what is has done to her 'young' body :-(  When you say her reconstruction feels 'alien' did she have a type of recon that used skin / tissue from her tummy or back as this can feel strange as it is not breast tissue ? It is possible that she has had the reconstruction with an implant of some sort and this is stretching her tissue if it is still very painful she should contact her breast care nurse and get it checked over in case of minor infection or other problems caused by the surgery. A lot of nerves are cut during recon and it can take ages for these to repair themselves and get anything like some normal feeling back, that coupled with any scar tissue is enough to make anyone less than impressed with the outcome, but it does get better, it just takes a long time. No doubt you will get some supportive replies from other ladies here who have had recon surgery. Just being there for her will be a great comfort, so don't beat yourself up and feeling guilty that you could do more this all takes time and although she probably hasn't yet realised it is time she now has - if she hadn't had it checked out as soon as she did this could have been so much worse. Take care, your'e both doing great!  G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Birty, Are you taking on loads of fluids (2 litres a day) ? As eating all the 'right stuff' (fibre/roughage etc) will just sit there and can make matters worse if it hasn't got enough fluid to absorb and allow easier transit through the plumbing. Assume you are eating plenty of fresh fruit etc as well ? There are plenty of different loosening meds hopefully you will get some replies regarding what worked best for other ladies here, as it is a very common problem. Good luck, G n' J
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Teresa, OK the Picc line or any central iv line is a constant reminder of what you are going through and can get in the way at times but the benefits far outweigh the inconvenience as you will soon see. All your bloods can be taken from it and your delicate veins will be protected from 'burn' damage or collapsing altogether post chemo. Everyone should be given a line of some sort, you see far too many posts here from those who have long term vein pain and circulation problems which could be so easily avoided. Why their use varies from one health authority area to another is anyone's guess (probably cash related) Very few have problems with ports and lines although it does happen occasionally. Takes around 30 - 40 minutes to fit and it aches for around 36 hours until it settles down but makes having chemo quicker and a lot less hassle than being constantly stabbed with needles while they try to find a good vein for the cannula :) Best wishes, G n' J

Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Morning Jonesy, Sorry to see you joining the club no-one wants to be a member of and hearing about your mum. Unfortunately if the signs are "to a doctor" fairly obvious they are usually correct. I would like to think they would never diagnose cancer of any sort without being confident they were correct. Some more obscure symptoms like slightly inverted nipple or small hard to find lumps they usually refer to confirm, which your gp will do now anyway. Fingers crossed on further investigation there may be better news ahead, but do be prepared for bad news which will seem ten times worse if you are in denial. You are both now about to get a two weeks ride on the emotional roller coaster of getting appointments for scans, biopsies and results from those before you will know anything for absolute certainty. You will find this waiting time very scary as your minds go into overdrive with worry. After this diagnosis stage a treatment plan is put in place it all happens very quickly Try not to Google anything. A lot of the information out there is either way out of date or wrong. Stick with reputable uk websites like Macmillan and breastcancercare.uk Please do keep in contact with us here whatever news you get, it's a magical place full of wonderful ladies. There is another group you may find useful if your worst fears are confirmed this is the relative/carer group just click on the green text link to have a look at the topics covered. Take care, George & Jackie
