Posts.Title: It's our anniversary today

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona, I can't give you an reply based on experience either as J only had the sentinel node biopsy during MX but from what I can make out it all depends on whether the infected nodes contain just a few cells or if there are clusters ? I had a look around NICE and the only info I found on axillary clearance pathway was this 1.4 Surgery to the axilla Invasive breast cancer 1.4.1 Minimal surgery, rather than lymph node clearance, should be performed to stage the axilla for patients with early invasive breast cancer and no evidence of lymph node involvement on ultrasound or a negative ultrasound-guided needle biopsy. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is the preferred technique. 1.4.2 SLNB should only be performed by a team that is validated in the use of the technique, as identified in the New Start training programme[6]. 1.4.3 Perform SLNB using the dual technique with isotope and blue dye. 1.4.4 Breast units should audit their axillary recurrence rates. Ductal carcinoma in situ 1.4.5 Do not perform SLNB routinely in patients with a preoperative diagnosis of DCIS who are having breast conserving surgery, unless they are considered to be at a high risk of invasive disease[7]. 1.4.6 Offer SLNB to all patients who are having a mastectomy for DCIS. Evaluation and management of a positive sentinel lymph node 1.4.7 Offer further axillary treatment to patients with early invasive breast cancer who: have macrometastases or micrometastases shown in a sentinel lymph node have a preoperative ultrasound-guided needle biopsy with histologically proven metastatic cancer. The preferred technique is axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) because it gives additional staging information. 1.4.8 Do not offer further axillary treatment to patients found to have only isolated tumour cells in their sentinel lymph nodes. These patients should be regarded as lymph node-negative.

Posts.Title: A Bell To Ring

Posts.Content: Have to totally agree with what "okdokyayintheend" says and that is exactly how you will feel - okay doky in the end...... whatever results you get on Friday good news or your worst fears confirmed. The waiting results stage can crush you if you let it get to you. We're certain the medics have no idea how bad the waiting 10 days to 2 weeks or more can affect you mentally. It's worse than the treatment, we found at least when it was confirmed we knew what was now coming and could prepare for all the treatment. Hopefully It will be a cyst, or a growing but benign tumour, maybe blocked milk ducts, or calcification... Unfortunately no amount of worrying is going to alter the outcome of your tests. We all hope you get away with it and never have to come back after telling us it was "all clear"  but do take someone with you Friday because if your worst fears are confirmed as soon as you hear the C word your brain go into overdrive, tears will flow and your ears will stop hearing, you won't take much in after that so another set of ears and a someone to hug is a good thing. From then on your feet don't get chance to touch the ground so you don't get time to worry as you go through a constant cycle of hospital visits for more tests, treatment etc There are loads of us here 5, 10, 15 years and longer well past treatment. Breast cancer has one of the highest rates of success now and is no longer the "doom and gloom" it was even a few years ago. My wife works with a woman who had a breast off 18 years ago with no sign of any re-occurance.That was in the days when doctors wore pointy hats and sang voodoo chants in hospitals, the way they cure it has come a very long way since then :-) Chin up Linds, what will be will be, fingers crossed for you. Meanwhile do anything and go anywhere that helps kill the waiting time and takes your mind off it all. Easier said than done we know but it would ease your worries. Take care and best wishes,  George & Jackie

Posts.Title: I'm back n worried

Posts.Content: Morning D, It is do'able with some juggling around. Jackie packed in work (also Letrozole related) after being on them for just over a year. Found she could no longer do the job she loved which was carer in a residential nursing home because of all the stairs, corridor walking and manual handling involved. She even struggled with the phased return so things weren't looking good from the onset but stuck at it getting up to 16hrs a week until the letrozole gradually took it's toll on her joints ect. What savings we had did take a big hit while we figured it all out but now things are great :) Things you could take into consideration are - How long before your husband retires and his current earnings level ? and is he willing to share his stash (unlike the husband who slammed his wallet shut) "Whatever happened to what's mine is yours"  :( Would you be entitled to Pension Credit (also paid before retirement age) which would also gain you access to other benefits like Council Tax reductions etc.  Find out more from Gov UK DWP or AGE.UK website. You could probably get the £200 Winter fuel allowance too. Make sure any credit cards, loans etc are paid off first so you aren't giving money away through interest payments. After we went through all this. I got all my tax back since the start of the tax year and pay zero tax. get monthly Pension Credit payments and our council  tax was halved. Obviously each case is different and the questions can seem never ending but it pays to not be put off. So many people are entitled but either don't realise this, or are put off by all the form filling, sending off bank statements, payslips etc.  We got all this even after they took into consideration my quite good ex company pension which I'm taking as a monthly part pension payment until I get the full whack when I officially retire - this seemed to make no difference regarding income ? Must admit though I did go part time when J was diagnosed so at 20 hours per week my pay is a lot lower now. If I had been still working full time we would have got none of this. Strange thing is we ended up better off with my reduced hours than we would have been if I was still working full time :) Pension Credit option was a good choice as a starting point as all the questions are asked over the phone (no forms to fill in) There may be alternative illness related benefits you could claim if you don't qualify for any of those mentioned. Best thing is to ring the free phone 0808 808 0000 support line and speak to the financial dept, they are brilliant :) In your life's routine, you just don't realise how much money you waste on non essential 'stuff' until you trim back. What is unexpected and even better is that going without said 'stuff' isn't even missed. i.e - We downsized the car from an automatic petrol estate to a smaller diesel runaround - result almost no car tax, twice as many miles to a smaller tankfull, cheaper insurance which is saving us at least £100 per month :-0  Oh, and we don't visit Ikea so much now as the larger stuff won't fit in LOL Our verdict on taking early retirement = Best move we ever made :) Hope you can get your head around it all and successfully take the plunge, G n' J
Posts.Title: Retiring but scared...

Posts.Content: Hi Blackrabbit, The scalp pain is caused by the weight of your hair 'pulling' on the follicles. If you get your hair cut really short it will bring almost instant relief and the slight residual pain will go over a day or two. It also helps emotionally too as you only lose the fuzz rather than your long hair. It can be a bit painful getting it cut at this late stage so get whoever does it to be gentle with it :-) If most has already gone it may take a few days for the pain to go as it's been 'pulled' at for around a week now :-( It is a bit of a shock but once the hair is gone it slips way down the list of priorities - Do try to see a kick cancer in the ar*e lady in the mirror looking back at you, and not a cancer victim. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hiya Blackrabbit, We're all happy to whenever we can and there are loads of us here so there is always someone going through the same issues at the same time. You can split the group into two halves those recently diagnosed and riding the Runaway Mine Cart and those who have been there, done that and wondering what the hell just happened :-) You'll always get honest friendly replies around here no matter what you post. Anything goes from questions, worries, being tearful, having a good rant (better here than at home) and most of all trying to do this with a sense of humour. You can do this, you are stronger than you ever realised :-) G n' J
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Afternoon Heidi, Welcome to the group... Congratulations on getting through the chemo, hope it wasn't too tough on you - was it to shrink the tumour down? Whoa!!! Stop those thoughts right now - it is a few cells they have found not tumours..... It is the lymph nodes job to trap dodgy cells whether they are from flu, mumps or cancer..... So be reassured they have done their job and put these on hold and stopped them from going elsewhere. There are lots of ladies here who have had full node removal surgery (axilla clearance) so as you can see it is quite common - and they can advise you about clearance surgery. Obviously everyone would prefer clear nodes but it isn't uncommon to have some nodes affected with cells - a month or so after your clearance surgery you will no doubt have radiotherapy sessions to the breast and armpit area as well. This is all insurance against any recurrence. Are you ER+ positive or ER- negative, by the way ? There are no guarantees against recurrence, but that is not just you , that applies to everyone here. Be assured that BC has a 90% recovery rate, so don't worry about the future,  look forward to it. Take care G n' J (class of 2012)

Posts.Content: Hi Ludo  Pleased to see you getting those pathology results :) If you don't meet the criteria for Oncotype-DX under the NHS but are seriously thinking about going privately for more personal prognosis and/or peace of mind I could throw a couple of curved balls into the mix... You could try this NHS Predict Tool for free - or an alternative to the Oncotype-DX test is Endopredict which can be carried out at selected UK sites ?  The predict tool is not personalised and based on averages but will give you % figures over 5 / 10 years with or without 3rd genertion chemo regime - it is free meaning you could use the Oncotype test cash for a post surgery late winter holiday instead. I assume you are ER+ and/or PR+ positive so will be on tablets long term as a back up ? and has radiotherapy been mentioned or offered ?   I don't think many here would put themselves through 18 weeks of chemo (with the risk of some long term side effects) for a 1% or 2% decreased risk of recurrence. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Kar44 TBH, I have no idea if ER/PR status is taken into account with staging within the UK.  Know in America they 'tweaked' the way data is complied but they use the same TNM Grade Staging System (CRUK link) as we do in the UK. In the UK we use the Allred scoring scale for ER and PR (Zero to Eight) which is why the scores can be written as ER8  /  PR4 etc This may be a quesion for one of the Macmillan Nurses - You can find them here in the Ask a Nurse area. It isn't unusual to be given a higher grade from say 1 to 2 from any post surgery tissue pathology results but I don't think this is the reason for your question :) Perhaps it is just that in the US insurance companies need all this extra information as their drugs / meds have to be paid for ? If you do ask a nurse it can take a couple of days for them to reply; what er/pr status scores were you given ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: breast cancer concern, inverted nipped , GP says comeback in 3 mo...

Posts.Content: Hi Nanks   Thickening of the womb lining and other gyne issues can be side effects of Tamoxifen. If they are wanting you to resume Tamoxifen in a few weeks I'm assuming they didn't remove your ovaries with the hysterectomy ? There are alternatives to Tamoxifen but they are used mostly for those who are post menopause whose ovaries have stopped producing oestrogen.  It is possible to switch off the ovaries to stop producing oestrogen by using drugs like Zoladex you could possibly have one of the other types of tablet then, but tbh they all come with side effects of one sort or another :( You need to have a chat with your oncologist about any options available but now you have had the hysterectomy you would think you no longer have the the main problem area. What other back up treatments to help avoid the risk of recurrence have you had - chemo, radiotherapy etc ? G n' J

Posts.Title: feeling hopeful

Posts.Content: Sorry to see you got hit with hospital Always Baking bet you got a good ear bashing  LOL Lets hope everyone here on Docetaxel/Taxotere learns from your experience (especially if you aren't having the white cell boosting jabs) 37.5C is the magic number - if your temp reaches this or is erratic or even unusually low ring the unit and get yourself checked over.... Cannot state this enough it may be a blip and you can come straight back home wasting only an hour, but it could be an infection that will floor you :( If your neutrophils are low you have no immunity......... Most of these infections you catch from yourself like oral thrush and other yeast infections, UTI's, bacterial infections (some of which can be serious) with a healthy white count they normally get easily wiped out early on. Know it's a pain in the ar*e having to go to the unit but that is so much better than an emergency 4 day minimum 7 day possible inpatient stay on iv anti-biotics. The average neutrophil count it between 2.0 and 7.5  (2,000 - 7,500) so you can see a count of 0.1 is about as low as you can get :(  This equates to - A general guide is: slightly low neutrophils (1.0–2.0) – little change in your risk of infection (1,000 - 2,000) low neutrophils (0.5–1.0) – slightly higher risk of infection  (500 - 1,000) very low neutrophils (0.2–0.5) – infections common  (200 - 500) extremely low neutrophils (up to 0.2) – infections very likely.  If you have a neutrophil count of 0.1 means only 100 neutrophils for every mL of blood  - Like expecting to put out a fire with a teaspoon of water :( I doubt if they will add a top-up session you could ask next Thursday, if nothing else the reduction will definitely help with any side effects and peripheral neuropathy risks :) Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Oh Boy ! Fell At The First Taxotere Hurdle !!

Posts.Content: Hi Rosalyn,  It could well be a one off unfortunate episode. They can reduce the dosage by 10% or even 20% if they feel you cannot cope with the side effects. What they more probably will do is give you medication to avoid your white cells bottoming out to such a low level for the next two sessions. I would give them a phone to ask about (what if) it happens again to hear what their reply is. Jackie had a 5 day stay after her first Docetaxel because of really rampant oral thrush when very neutropenic she was given a choice and opted for a 10% reduction and apart from the 'normal' side effects the other two sessions were fine.  You are on the downhill run now, god knows it is tough, but you don't know how strong you actually are until you have to be - Group hugs..... Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Update No.2 After Visit To One Stop Cancer Shop For Check for 2nd...

Posts.Content: Hi Julie / Jdperry I would phone them and ask as there is a lot of out of date misinformation about massage spreading cancer cells around that a lot of spas don't 'do' massages rather than reading up to date information about this. If they are in the 'no, sorry' brigade and won't refund, you could get it exchanged for a different therapy in advance ? Macmillan and Cancer Research UK both say there is no evidence to support or disprove the idea that spa-ing with cancer is dangerous. This dilemma has historically led spas to err on the side of caution and refuse to treat those who are not yet through a five-year remission period. In fact some hospitals offer massage as a complimentary therapy but private spas are too worried about legal action  G n' J

Just so the other ladies here can reply if they are having the same and it gives us a guide to what effects you will be having at any particular days of your cycle. Posts.Title: Chemo symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi Sue  Su12345  Sorry to read the reality is starting to sink in, the cancer angst had to come out sometime - Cr@p isn't it  :( Chemotherapy is the one treatment option everyone hopes to avoid and it's hard to say so early on if you will dodge that bullet or not. Most of the info regarding the need for chemo comes from the surgery tissue pathology report and it's quite uncommon to get a positive answer one way or the other beforehand. Unless you are offered chemotherapy prior to surgery to shrink any tumours down first - which sometimes happens, but mostly for hopefully changing what would be a mastectomy into a lumpectomy. Two main types of breast cancer which practically guarantees chemo is if you are classed as Triple Negative (which is why Fiona needed chemo) or what they term HER2+ positive.  For other types the decision is based on lymph node involvement, grade/stage and several other factors. There are chemo risk assessment tests to give you the % of recurrence with or without chemotherapy but again you will need to know your pathology report information to see if you meet the criteria for the tests.  If your surgeon thinks you will only need surgery and radiotherapy, that is good but please be aware things can change post surgery when all the results are in. That is why chemo probably wasn't mentioned at the time.  Don't worry about that for now, it's no good fretting about something you may not need. As they say cross that bridge if and when you come to it. Hope your sons elbow isn't too bad, what month is the wedding planned for btw ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Jump123  Some of the ladies here have managed to get hold of R1 and R2 (link) a reasonably new specific radiotherapy gel product with very good success and minimal burning issues, and is made by a company that specializes in burns bandaging. It is available in the UK on prescription but for some reason or other some GP's don't yet know about it, so don't prescribe it and radiotherapy departments are slow to accept it is better than the cheap creams they offer you :( Some have purchased it online from the company  (around £41 for 3 X weekly treatment packs of both R1 & R2) There is also a 6 week pack containing both R1 and R2. The NHS prescribing / order numbers are mentioned on the link above. G n' J
Posts.Title: Question I have post to Ask a Radiotherapist

Posts.Content: Morning purplediva  If I remember rightly they advise you use a liberal coating of R1 after treatment and leave it on for a minimum of 20 minutes before gently removing the residue, then continuing with the R2 - So you only need it for that for 20+ minutes period after each session, continuing with only the R2 at weekends. This means if you are a larger lady you may need to use two packs of R1 at a time.  Don't forget with the R2 to use it for up to two weeks after your sessions as the rads keep working for that period. Any you have left over can be offered to anyone who would like them - as they are not a prescription only medicine (POM) and can be purchased over the counter if your GP won't prescribe them :) I do recall someone else here who gave her leftover sachets to another member who wanted to try it. There is an R1/R2 frequently asked questions page here. G n' J EDIT - If only I realised there was another page and Lynn had replied I could have saved all that early morning typing  LOL

Posts.Title: Dietary advice

Posts.Content: Morning Barb, Sounds like your oncologist got his/her diploma from the Katie Hopkins Charm School :-) For some reason chemo works better for TNBC than for the more common types BC so take that to help turn a negative into a positive. As you know TNBC can be tough on the nerves regarding recurrence and you will have to be vigilant, not enough to worry yourself sick over it, but just do keep listening to your own body and if in doubt about any twinges - get them checked out. The CA125 Helen mentioned is a marker for ovarian cancer which could be significant if your have the faulty BRCA gene ? - The markers mostly looked for with breast cancer  are........  CA 15.3 and CA 27.29, for monitoring treatment; these should be used along with the patient's health history, a physical examination, and diagnostic imaging tests, such as an x-ray, computed tomography (CT) scan, and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). CEA, (carcinoembryonic antigen) for monitoring treatment; this test should be used along with the patient's health history, a physical examination, and diagnostic imaging tests. So these will be what they are looking for in 'bloods' depending on how often you have to have them for monitoring purposes. There may well be a secret, or open facebook groups for Triple Neg which may be worth looking into if you are 'into' fb ?  Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Has treatment worked fears?!

Posts.Content: Hi phoenixmoon  Don't know how long it was between chemo and your mother getting her eyes checked but they do recommend waiting at least 4 months after chemo as some of the eyesight changes caused during chemo can partially return to normal during that time. If your mum has low income (probably at 70) and has limited savings she could be eligible for part cost towards glasses in the form of an NHS  voucher. There is more information about that here (link) there are also some forms like HC1 or HC11 and there is some information about the voucher values here. As expected they don't make applying for these as simple as they could be - If you have any queries relating to to this do please use the free phone 0808 808 0000 support line (Mon - Fri  9am to 8pm) and ask to speak to a Macmillan benefits advisor to help you through the red tape. Hope this is of some help, it's about time chemotherapy was recognised as something which can change eyesight to make this process far more straightforward :( Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Hope???

Posts.Content: Hi earwig o  As Jess has mentioned a lot of folks confuse stage and grade and the way it is explained in tech speak isn't always helpful :( In a nutshell Grade is how fast the cells multiply (aggressiveness) The link provided by Jess explains this very well. Stage used to be considered just the size but that has now vastly updated - I have placed the newer breast cancer staging info below. Staging of breast cancer_tcm9-302934.pdf Hope this helps a bit, G n' J

Tough isn't it especially if you are used to being really active :-( Don't let cancer make you a prisoner (it's a word - not a sentence) You only have to be careful of infections during the middle week of three when your white count is low. Posts.Title: Starting chemo!!

Posts.Content: Hi Hayley,  A PET scan is usually the most accurate an MRI scan image can be blurred slightly by any slight body movement including breathing. Which is actually the best for this purpose to be honest I couldn't say - That would be a question to ask someone in radiology. None of these scans however will pick up any individual cells only clusters - a PET scan can determine if any cancer is 'living' or already treated dead tissue. There is some info about PET scans here at CRUK which may help if you compare that with MRI and CT scan information at the same site. PET scanners are very expensive so not many hospitals have one and the cost of a pet scan privately would be quite high. Unfortunately no one will ever say you are 'clear' as once diagnosed nothing is ever guaranteed the best you would get is NED (no evidence of disease) at the time of checking. Hope this is of some help - George & Jackie
Posts.Title: DCIS, IDC, Mastectomy, No Rads, No Chemo, Tamoxifen.

Posts.Content: Morning Brittany8 I'm hoping this reply shows up as quite a few are appearing as grey lines with no text visible, which the tech guys are trying to fix. There is a shedload of Benign Breast Conditions (info link) that can cause lumps from fibroids, cysts, calcification etc but this coupled with finding yourself affected by the PALB2 mutation is bound to be a worry for you :-/ Although a CBC with differentials is a comprehensive test unless any of the marker(s) count figures are a lot higher than normal this on it's own doesn't really count for much in a diagnostic way. They can fluctuate and several other factors can raise these slightly. Markers in 'bloods' are mostly used for monitoring how well a particular treatment is working on a cancer to indicate if a dosage needs raising or a different treatment regime is required. I don't know enough about PALB2 to know if there is a specific marker they look for, but the 3 common breast cancer markers are tests for CEA, CA 15-3, and CA 27.29    These as mentioned above are mostly used for monitoring and not a 'given' for a diagnosis. Do you know from your 'bloods' sheet which if any markers were checked for  ? Take Care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Been a while again but on 6th and final chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, It is normal to have a DEXA bone density scan prior to starting any of the AI (aromatase Inhibitor) tablets Letrozole, Anastrozole or Exemestane as these can cause bone thinning leading to osteopaenia over a long period.  These AI's are usually offered towards the end of treatment, I think because you have been placed on these to shrink things down early on into your diagnosis it has thrown them off track somewhere along the line. Jackie's oncologist referred her to her GP to get the DEXA scan carried out - So this is something an Oncologist would arrange as standard but the surgeon may not have even realised this needed to be arranged ? I would phone your GP and explain that you have been placed on Letrozole and need to have a DEXA bone density scan - and see what they say. Your GP may need to speak with your surgeon to confirm this but you deffo should have one as you may well be on these tablets for 5 years and need a baseline figure to compare against bone density figures again later on. It may be another couple of weeks before you can have the scan but your bone density won't have been affected too much in that time frame.  J had her 2nd dexa scan after being on Letrozole for 6 months. There is more info about DEXA scans here - They only take around 40 minutes. Hope this has helped a bit, take care, G n' J

You just have to drag yourself up and do stuff on the good days (luckily there are more good than bad) just don't overdo it and hit 'the wall' the next day. What you are feeling is totally normal.... For the tough days there are duvets on sofa's and DVD's :-) On the first page of Aug / Sept chemo clubs there is a link to chemo aids that have been gathered over the months from members here which can help you through some of the side effects. Posts.Content: Hi Lynn,  Jackie was grade 3 (DCIS) had 3 nodes removed as a Sentinel Node check at the same time as (but first, before) her mastectomy. If they had been cancerous they would have done a 'clearance' while she was still in theatre but luckily hers were free of cells. Not all hospitals can carry out these checks while the patient is still 'under' so can be called back a week or so later to have the rest removed if needed. From what we have read on here, quite a few have to go back for node clearance. Have you had a HER2 result yet - or will you have to wait for that test from histology post surgery ? Posts.Title: Lymph Node Sentinel Test

Posts.Content: Hi Sinead, Is there any particular reason why you said a definite no to chemo. Know it is everyone's personal choice but did you ask about your chances of recurrence with or without the use of chemotherapy ? If you have an appointment due soon ask them to put your pathology results into something like the 'Predict Tool' (link) so you get a better understanding of the % chances of recurrence with or without chemotherapy being used. Don't know if you qualify for the 'Chemo or no Chemo' Oncotype-DX test without knowing your grade and other details from pathology results, if you have them is there any chance you could type them into a reply, if they didn't give you a copy. Do please ask them for a copy for your own future reference - you need to know your full diagnosis to make informed decisions about further treatments without putting yourself at risk later in life. Hopefully your aren't classed as HER2+ positive and was offered chemo because of this but still said no ? Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: isolated cells in nodes

Posts.Content: Hi Sinead, You should deffo ask them about the Predict test at the very least. It looks very much like you would qualify for the Oncotype-DX test too if you are ER+ positive and grade 2 with no lymph node involvement. As long as you are HER2- negative as well, you tick all the boxes for the Oncotype test which is the better one of the two. Predict is just that a prediction but the Oncotype test actually tests your own tissue (they use some from the surgery) but the results can take a month to six weeks to come through with that test. Everyone would love to dodge chemo, it can be damn tough some days and of course the hair loss is a bonus (not) However the hair comes back and chemo can help you make it through to enjoy being a grandparent in the future too :) If you manage to get a test of some sort done and the figures show you would only benefit having chemo by a couple of percent over 10 years or so it makes saying 'no thanks' easier but if it comes back higher you might want to try all the meds you can to avoid all this happening again sometime ? Not trying to worry you in the slightest but I would like to think at least you had been given all the information you needed by your team to make this decision one way or the other. G n' J

Those that have already had chemo know the score, but those newly diagnosed and facing the unknown can have the pants scared off them :( There is also this briefer info page at Cancer Research UK (CRUK) note: both links are for docetaxel only - fec isn't even mentioned. Posts.Title: Annual Check up

Posts.Content: Tamoxifen doesn't have as much impact regarding bone thinning but is known to cause joint pain. Do you know what 'brand' of Tamoxifen you are taking ? As with a lot of these tablets although the drug it contains is the same it is the fillers and coatings used can cause problems and there are around 6 dif makes / types now. If you are any other brand than those made by Nolvadex who were the original maker of these try and get your GP to switch your prescription over to Nolvadex so you can try these for a couple of months to see if they help as there seems less people mentioning joint pain if taking this make. There was a discussion about this last autumn you can read clicking here. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Sinead, Assume this info is from your pathology results ?  A lot of ladies get isolated cells in the lymph nodes if single cells this means they haven't divided so are not increasing in size. It's usually only if these cells are in clusters or invasive they will remove more lymph nodes. Have you been offered chemo and radiotherapy later on (or hormone therapy tablets if you are ER+ or PR+ positive) as a back up insurance to avoid recurrence ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) Aches & Pains!!

Posts.Content: Hi Crystal Kitty, Unfortunately this happens quite a lot. It's the risk you take with a WLE as they try to take as small amount of tissue as possible (hopefully getting it all) to avoid disfiguring the breast too much. From what we have seen here around one in four have to have more tissue taken to ensure clear margins.  It is a knock back but just one of many that gets chucked at you during the course of all the treatments given. Have even seen some cases where after two more tries to get clear margins they end up suggesting a mastectomy :-( Do you know how many nodes they took for the SNB sample and did they mention how many more they are going to remove ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Curvy, The Tax is mostly how Docetaxel (Taxotere) is referred to it is the T part of FEC-T you usually get given 3 sessions of FEC then 3 of T, but Tax could also mean Taxol also known as Paclitaxel. They are basically the same but Taxol is given in lower doses weekly and Docetaxel is given every 3 weeks. So if yours is going to be 3 weekly it will be the Docetaxel. Hope this helps, if you need more info just holler there are info pages on Macmillan covering ALL the chemo drugs if you want to have a read ? G n' J

Posts.Title: immune system

Posts.Content: Hiya, Yes, herceptin can affect your immune system and it also takes around 6 months to clear your system but it does not have the more severe impact chemo can have. The more common symptoms are gradual weakening of the heart muscles which can cause lower pressure of blood ejection between heart chambers - This is why you have regular Muga Scans runny nose and slight cold symptoms. There is some info on Cancer Research UK about Herceptin here and also the PIL patient information leaflet from Roche here. Do you know if you are having Herceptin via sub-cut injection or the bag, pump and cannula method ? Please don't read too much into the huge list of side effects although some do have reactions to herceptin - Jackie had 18 x Herceptin and apart from the 24 hour headache and a runny sometimes minor nose bleeds all was well. G n' J

Posts.Title: last chemo,

Posts.Content: Hi LongDrive According to cancer research uk regarding Soursop / Graviola Quote - "Overall, there is no evidence to show that graviola works as a cure for cancer. In laboratory studies, graviola extracts can kill some types of liver and breast cancer cells that are resistant to particular chemotherapy drugs. But there haven’t been any studies in humans. So we don't know whether it can work as a cancer treatment or not.  Many sites on the internet advertise and promote graviola capsules as a cancer cure but none of them are supported by any reputable scientific cancer organisations. We do not support the use of graviola to treat cancer. Our advice is to be very cautious about believing information or paying for any type of alternative cancer therapy on the internet" Further Soursop info at Sloan Kettering. G n' J

Posts.Title: AI's for up to 15 yrs

Posts.Content: Morning Lynn,  Seems like over the next few days would be a good time to make a list of questions to ask on Monday. Like if they would remove any extra nodes if needed at the same time, or would it def mean a separate operation ? What types of chemo regime drugs are they going to give you ? How long would you have to wait for results about margins and ask about your HER2 status, if you are HER2 + you may be given Herceptin as you can be on this for a year. It is possible to be negative for ER and PR but still HER2+ You seem to have a great attitude to all this even if you are concerned about it all. Lets face it, who isn't at the start :-(    One step at a time is def the way to go, once they start the treatment roller coaster ride your life seems to revolve around hospital appts and you don't get much time to think or worry about it Big 'High Five' for the weight loss,  recon later could be a way of making use of some excess skin and free you of it without having to go private - Suppose that could be seen as a bonus :-/  Know you say about that would be at least 10 months or a year away but that time soon goes. Most of us old hands look back and wonder how a whole year of your life could disappear like that  :-)   Been two years for us now but only seems like 6 months ago (it's just weird)   Take care,  (group hugs)  G n' J

Posts.Title: There's light at the end of the tunnel, ladies...

Posts.Content: Brilliant message Karen, High Five for bringing this topic up - It's something which has been bothering me of late too. A few ground rules about chemo in general and switching to T.... Reactions are very, very rare, thanks mostly to the steroids given. People only post messages when they have a problem leading to a very biased negative opinion. You get everyone's snapshot of all the side effects but individually most only get a couple to deal with. Don't keep secrets, if you do get an issue tell your onco, and ask about it here - most can be easily helped with meds. Most doses are the maximum you can handle, if it seems too much it can be reduced by 20% and still be as effective. Look in the mirror and see the beautiful feisty woman doing all she can to get through this and not a cancer victim. Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Anybody heard or used the Oncotype Dx test for deciding treatment...

Posts.Content: Hi Chiara,  Welcome to the club no one really wants to be in. Have the utmost respect for you asking here so you can help your mum. Good news is that the ductal part means it's probably DCIS = ductal carcinoma in situ - the in situ part means in one place, so it has been found early and hasn't spread - maybe a few cancer cells will be found in any lymph nodes they remove for checking (known as a SNB Sentinel node biopsy which is standard practice. This is usually done when they perform either a lumpectomy or mastectomy but can be carried out as a separate op to aid diagnosis. Jackie my wife was also grade 3 DCIS (dcis is always stage zero which is good) but for her being classed as ER and HER2 positive still meant Mastectomy, 6 x chemo sessions and radiotherapy so although this sounds grim most of the treatment is to stop any re-occurance later on. Once any surgery is completed the tumour will be gone. Your mum won't get a full diagnosis until they have got results from any tissue samples post surgery. Please understand because it has been found early and contained the treatment is still fairly full on, so she may need, surgery, chemo and radiotherapy. Realise this may sound very scary at the moment - it is tough but do'able as most here will tell you. Here is a link to the booklet 'Understanding Ductal Carcinoma In Situ' which may help you get your head around what it's all about. Hopefully you can get mum involved here too later when she or you needs more specific info about any treatment regime they put in place. Hope this helps for now, no doubt you have a head full of questions, so fire away.... We're all here to help. Take care,George & Jackie.

If you start getting sore you could ask your GP for something like Flamazine but everyone handles rads differently so don't go stocking up on stuff you may not need. Packet of wet wipes will help underarm as they don't really like you using deoderants and anti perspirants are a definite no, no. G n' J

Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: Morning Breast Buddies, Pinch, Punch, First of the Month... Katie, don't know if you came across this BCC booklet during your research but it's a good read so I'll stick the link in anyway 'Reducing The Risk of Lymphoedema' don't get too fretful about this only a few people get full blown long term LD after lymph surgery most will have a little fluid build up but some of this will be seroma (fluid from the surgical cutting) rather than lymph fluid. A lot of people confuse the two. Seroma is short term fluid build up which eases as the scalpel cuts heal and is mostly why the drains are put in. Lymph fluid build up can last longer, and if severe and painful can have to be aspirated out a few times before it settles down. Problem is with LD it can come on anytime (even after a year later) after surgery especially if you have had a full clearance so you have to be aware of injuring to that side. Luvvin' these threads at the mo, reminds us old hands of all the battles fought through and the dreams and promises we place as targets at the end of treatment - Anything that helps has to be a good thing :-) A lovely warm July day would nice for today Br'rr!  - G n' J

This will also give you a lot more information and options on your profile page and you can also then use the site fully and create and add friends as you settle in who you can personally message later on these do not appear on the website so is good for exchanging personal info like email addresses etc. If you see an interesting post and wish to get more info from the poster, just click their 'green text' name and it will open up their profile page and you can find their other posts clicking their 'Activity' button and read their status. Most items in posts with green text are clickable links. Three weeks for radiotherapy is the norm, just take it one step at a time - if you have any questions or concerns about your lumpectomy, just join and holler. They are a great bunch here who all go the extra mile to help with friendly advice and support. Hope this helps, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Start of treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Poppy58  They can of course use the CT scan to rule cancer out in other areas but that isn't the main use for this prior to chemo. The main type of scanners used looking for cancer spread are MRI or Nuclear Bone Scans - You will more than likely be offered some form of chemo regime because of the affected lymph nodes you had. Which is fairly standard practice for what they call lymphovascular invasion. Although post surgery means the cancer has been removed the aim of the chemo and other follow on treatments like Rads etc are to vastly reduce the risk of recurrence in the future. Happy to hear you are well on the mend :)  Just the upcoming mystery tour to get your head around :-/ G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Vicki, Tamoxifen and any of the other oestrogen hormone inhibitor tablets will have this effect - It could also be a touch of post treatment depression like post traumatic stress. If you have lower levels of oestrogen you are probably not producing so much serotonin the feel good hormone either which can make you feel a bit down. It may be a case of allowing a bit longer for your body to adjust to the new hormone levels. If it continues to be a problem and you don't want to take anti depressants the only other option may be to see if your onco can give you an alternative tablet. Only problem with that is it may well have the same effect and you end up with other side effects too :-( Hope you find your smile soon, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Ali, Sorry to say there isn't much you can do to stop this but It may be helpful to use a moisturiser (emollient) which contains an antibacterial agent - for example, Dermol cream or lotion or Emulsiderm this will improve the condition of the skin and soothe it. It may help the folliculitis to clear more quickly and reduce the risk of it becoming worse. You can use one of the Dermol emollients as a soap substitute until the area has cleared also Oilatum Plus bath additive. For localised areas of in grown hair, an antibiotic cream like Fucidin may be easier to use. Have also read on here that aloe vera can help sooth sore skin - if the hairs have formed 'heads' you could pierce these and tease the hair out, as these boil type bumps can get quite large if the hair coils up under the skin and is not treated, do be careful of infections though. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Frankie  /  Frankies_Ducky If you are definitely HER2- Negative and also ER/PR- Negative - This is what is termed as Triple Negative - Around one in six with breast cancer are found to be TN and is mostly found in the under 50's. You are right about the meds as treatments like Herceptin and the 5-10 years of hormone inhibitor tablets are used for those who are + positive.  The standard treatments for TNBC are Chemo, surgery and radiotherapy. If chemo is given before surgery this is called neoadjuvant, surgery then chemo is called adjuvant. Sometimes patients only find out they are TN from the pathology test results after surgery. There is a Triple Negative Breast Group you could also join but it isn't as active as this group and most of the TN ladies are in this group too. If you are curious about Triple Negative BC you can find out more clicking the link. Regarding your needle phobia; was anything mentioned to you about having a PICC iv line or Port fitted for your chemo and blood tests etc ? If these daily injections are during the middle week, they sound more like a type of G-CSF injection to help build up your white blood cell count ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi  Deidre,  This seems like a step up from just tingling or pins and needles. Sounds like you may have a touch of what they call peripheral neuropathy which is basically a bit of nerve damage. Yet another side effect of chemo which mostly affects toes and fingers. Sometimes it goes the other way and everything feels warm or hot. Definitely phone your onco dr or nurse tomorrow morning as they may want to see you and check it out. Don't get alarmed, it's just that neuropathy is something they advise you inform them of asap. The after effects of chemo can take a good month or two to recover from after treatment. Posts.Title: Coping

Posts.Content: Hi Poppy  / Poppy58  Nice early morning reply, but then 30 years of shift work will do that to you :) There are two tests for HER2 which are IHC and FISH They carry out the IHC test first and this is marked out of 3 This is usually written up as   HER2- +  or  HER2+++  the plus sign being the score (1 or 3) 1 is HER2- negative  3 is HER2+ positive, but if the results come back at ++2 (inconclusive) they use the other FISH test which is either neg or pos with no middle ground to confirm it one way or the other.  If you had been HER2+ they would be offering you a year of Herceptin and possibly Perjeta on top of chemo, so you'll get away with that part at least. The CT scan is standard if they are going to be offering you chemo, they use it to check for any unknown surprises to the health of your other organs: Liver, Kidneys Heart etc - in case they need to use an alternative chemo regime to compensate for an issue. I'm assuming by 'and then drug treatment' you mean tablets for being ER+ positive ?  Any other Q's, just holler, there is always someone around :) Hope you are recovering well from surgery and keeping up with those pesky exercises... Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: how u all doin ?

Posts.Content: Evening, Sorry to read about your recon problems. There can be noticeable skin creasing or wrinkling over the implant. It’s most common in people who are slim and have saline implants. It’s usually less obvious when wearing a bra. If it becomes very noticeable the implant may need to be replaced. Were you originally diagnosed with IBC (Inflammatory Breast Cancer) or another type ? Another question - has this orange peel appearance only come on during radiotherapy or has it appeared since surgery but before rads ? One side effect of rads is the build up of lymphatic fluid under the skin which can cause dimpling and / or this orange peel look. Think personally I would ring your breast nurse (BCN) to get this 'orange peel' checked out now to see what they suggest, if it is a rads side effect It should go down slowly within a few weeks of finishing rads but do get it looked at before then. Hope this helps, take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Help please has anyone got breast concavities / valley type scars...

Posts.Content: Evening Porffor, Sorry to see you joining us here. Yes, you are most certainly posting in the right place :-) There is quite a bit of reading material about microcalcifications we can let you browse over to work out what questions you may want to ask. Just don't forget to take the list with you :-) First off you mentioned the scoring system - you may mean Bi-Rads - so basically this is what that is - BIRADS Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System score. Indicator of radiologists opinion of the absence or likelihood of breast cancer. On a scale of 1 to 6 (1 being negative 2 definitely benign 3 probably benign (6 month follow up) 4 reasonable chance of being malignant biopsy recommended 5 High probability of being malignant take action 6 Known to be malignant after biopsy confirmation. BCC has a booklet about Microcalcifications which you can read clicking the green text link, there is also a Macmillan info page about this which you can find here. Hope this is of some help. Let us know how you get on ? Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications - what should I be asking?

Posts.Content: Hiya, It is unlikely to be the Herceptin but we all know about expecting the unexpected... I haven't read anything in the group about Herceptin being the cause of hair loss. What ER/PR+ hormone inhibitor tablets have they put you on? as these can cause hair thinning (some more than others) but I'm surprised to read you have the same scalp pain as well. What are the other two drugs you are having with the Herceptin ? When your hair grew back was it very fine like baby hair or the more coarse type, as the fine hair can come out as it is replaced by the more normal hair you had prior to chemo. Eye lashes and / or eyebrows can be the very last to come back and can take ages. G n' J
Posts.Title: Hair started falling out again!

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey, You would be better off contacting your breast care nurse about a sleeve as they have to be "fitted" properly to get the size correct. Maybe she can put you in touch with a local Lymph nurse who can help if she isn't experienced in this area. You can just buy them online but seeing as you'll be in flight for a long haul you want to get it right. There are printed sleeves available now if you don't like the look of the skin tone ones. There is a Macmillan info page on Lymphoedema Control just click the link to read about sleeves. Don't get confused between Lymphoedema and Seroma though, they are different. Seroma is usually fluid build up from breast surgery and the latter from lymph damage or removal. Have you had many lymph nodes removed ? Hope this helps, G n' J

Posts.Title: Post Surgery Seroma Problems - Advice Please...

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy  / Winky49  Similar to other replies J's GP ordered the Dexa Scan and also got the results through a few weeks later. If you were given very little info about Dexa Scans they are performed when going onto Letrozole / Anastrozole long term as these can over time cause bone thinning. If and when you get your score this is how to work ot the T and Z figures................................ The difference between your measurement and that of a young healthy adult is known as a T score, and the difference between your measurement and that of someone of the same age is known as a Z score. T scores as follows: above -1 SD is normal between -1 and -2.5 SD is defined as mildly reduced bone mineral density (BMD) compared to peak bone mass (PBM) classed as osteopaenia. at or below -2.5 SD is defined as osteoporosis If your Z score is below -2, your bone density is lower than it should be for someone of your age. G n' J

Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Hi Stoksie,  Long time no see. Were you not given a DEXA bone scan before you were put on the Letrozole ? They usually do to give them base bone density figures to check to see if your osteopeania is getting worse the longer you stay on the Letrozole. As you had osteo problems before you would have thought this was a no brainer  :-(  I would definitely take this up with your gp don't suffer in silence it won't get any better if you keep it to yourself.  I'm not medically trained but there are two types of bone scan that I know of. The 15 minute Dexa scan and the much more informative bone scan performed by the nuclear medicine radiology dept which can take up to 4 hours where you are injected with an isotope wait a few hours while it gets into your bones and they use a gamma camera (similar type of thing as a Muga scan) if you ever had those for Hercepin treatment. If you have already had dexa scans maybe it's time to go for the bigger picture at the nuclear radiology dept ? Cancer research has an info page on this here http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/cancer-help/about-cancer/tests/bone-scan So, yes by all means get yourself a scan. Jackie was given a borderline osteopeanic diagnosis after her second Dexa scan after being on Letrozole for 6 months and is taking Adcal (calcium tablets) Sunvit tablets and takes one Alendrolic acid tablet a week to help with this.  You can search the Maccy site just type in Dexa  There are bound to be some posts as we recall having mentioned it before in replies to others suffering with this. Take care Stoksie and let us know how you get on. George & Jackie

Posts.Content: Hiya Yvonne,  You sound a bit more chilled out, that's great......  Don't worry about the radiotherapy yet it's the daily travelling more than anything which is tiring although the radiotherapy is progressively tiring in itself it just combines to make you feel a bit whacked out. More'so at the end - do you know how many sessions you will have ? As for the operation if it's a lumpectomy also known as WLE (wide local excision) depending on how much tissue they take you may have drains in for any fluid to escape from sometimes they will send you home with one still in place for a week or so before it is removed. This is to help avoid any seroma (fluid build up) under the skin which can be a bit sore when you are healing. After that the tissue removed will be looked at to check if they got it all and adjust any grade or stage results. They use this info to fine tune your treatment. Are they taking any lymph nodes as a sample - 'sentinel node biopsy' with dye (SNB) at the same time during the op ? if so they will check these too - so you'll probably have a little wait to get the results from that. Best wishes Yvonne, it'll be nowhere near as bad as your imagination is telling you. You'll be fine, George & Jackie

Posts.Content: Evening Tracey, Sorry to see you joining us. Sounds very much like Seroma which is quite common after an LD flap recon. If it gets really uncomfortable and getting you down it can be syringed out but in some cases it just makes space for more fluid to be produced. It can take quite a long time to be re-absorbed reducing the pressure you think it will never go away. I would contact either your breast nurse, consultant or GP inform them of your problems and see what they can do to help with pain relief apart from aspirating it don't think there is much they can do about the fluid build up. Be honest with them don't pussyfoot about if it's agony tell them how bad it is. You know what medical folk are like if they tell you something is going to be uncomfortable it means it's gonna hurt like hell. You have to spell it out in black and white or they just don't get it. A lot here have mentioned previously they find some comfort from using those V shaped pillows. Maybe some replies from anyone who have also suffered seroma after reconstruction can advise ? Hope you get some relief soon, it sounds awful. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Rach1969  This is nearly always 3 sessions of FEC (3 different drugs given one after the other on the same day) followed by 3 sessions of the T part which is Taxotere aka Docetaxel - but can sometimes be T first then FEC Whatever day your first session is the others will be on the same day 3 weeks apart. There can be a weeks delay at times if your blood count or liver enzymes are low you will be given a week for them to recover - it isn't written in stone so don't plan anything specific too far in advance. Take it week by week. The E part of FEC will make your pee pink for 24 hours or so afterwards, so don't go thinking this is blood. You will also be given anti-nausea tablets and probably steroids to help with any reactions to have on the day and bring home - Do take these even if you feel you don't need them, as it's easier to keep on top of any issues rather than actually being sick then trying to keep the tablets down. Assume you have seen the July Chemo Club discussion on the breast group you could get involved with for advice, answers and support ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Heels' skin is peeling off during docetaxol (FEC-T)

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline, So after the agonising waiting initial results stage, you are now finding once your treatment starts your feet won't touch the ground for a while now. The extra tissue taken on your WLE is what they call 'a clear margin' and is supposed to be a margin of cancer cell free tissue around the lump unfortunately sometimes after it's been examined in pathology they find it doesn't have clear margins they have you in to take another nibble. The reason they have taken you off HRT is because if it turns out your tumour is ER or PR positive (oestrogen and progesterone and quite a few are) this means the hormones in your tablets would be feeding the cancer cells. You won't get this info until about a week after your WLE and the results come back from histology. Which is also when you will get any stage / grade and HER2 - or + diagnosis. These are the results they tailor your further treatment regime to. You would be surprised at the number of ladies here who have been diagnosed with cancer after being on HRT - nothing proved but seems too much of a coincidence ? :-( We were a bit more fortunate that you re IVF our daughter was born in 1989 after three attempts and a miscarriage. No NHS funding or 'free' goes at all for it way back then seemed like were both just working to live and pay for ivf treatment. Still It was only money :-/ we got lucky and that is the main thing. Chocolate is the answer to most problems :-) Best wishes, G n' J

Posts.Title: Risk of infection?

Posts.Content: Hiya Honey Bea, PN five years on does seem like a long time back for this to be getting worse now ? Know if you get left with some residual PN you can get stuck with it on a more permanent basis but not heard of it getting worse this far down the line.  There is a thing called Motor Neuropathy which is a type of PN that affects muscles and movements. Is this something you have had for a while since chemo or quite recently started ? I would get yourself to you GP, explain in full the range of all your 'tics' and get some bloods and/or other tests done to see if they can point to a cause. Twitching and involuntary movements happen to everyone at times but it's usually a 'one off' and doesn't happen that often - if this is getting more common it needs looking into as it could be a symptom of lots of other conditions from a particular vitamin deficiency to tourette's tics, diabetes, parkinson's etc Good luck in getting through the GP's firewall receptionist for a quick appointment. G n' J

Posts.Title: party

Posts.Content: Hi  Kiaracat, You are doing the right thing by trying to sort this out now as your savings do take quite a hit when either partner is out of work for any length of time. Surprising how quickly they evaporate when you are dipping into them on a weekly basis and with winter heating bills and Christmas on the horizon they can be an account zapper. Nice to hear your husbands new employers were so sympathetic ( bloody shi*s ) but it's an employers market and with so'ooo many applying for every vacancy they can afford to be very picky as to who gets the post. I dropped down to part time when Jackie was off work for 9 months and although she got SSP for 28 weeks it was still a juggling act but we made it through unscathed. In fact it was a great eye opener for both of us as we found we were wasting a fair chunk of our earnings. We both stopped smoking, cancelled some monthly subscriptions  and  non essential outgoings and since then we now both only work part time and we have so much free time for ourselves now to enjoy the simple things like afternoon walks with the dog, pub lunches etc. Sure beats the hell out of the 40+ hours a week work merry go round. Can you and your husband "wing it" to get jobseekers allowance by saying you ARE actively looking for work but at the present time it would have to be part time employment ( after all it doesn't state it has to be full time work ) surely actively looking for work means any work ? Don't be fobbed off by the benefits system you have to be on the ball or they'll try to do you out of every penny you may be entitled to unless you get someone sympathetic the other side of the desk. A lot of people do not realise that if you have, or have had a diagnosis of cancer you are covered by the DDA disability act, now named the Equality Act so that label so that can open a few doors you may have to be persistent to get anywhere though.  Do phone the maccy financial folks, they helped us out and guided us through the benefits minefield when we needed it, they know all the in's and out's of finding out what you are entitled to  Hugs and Best Wishes,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction and redundancy

Posts.Content: Hi Stephjc  They aren't saying don't have Chinese or Indian meals, it's the types of food that are flash fried and steamed rice that can be the problem areas. Meat or seafood that may not be cooked all the way through and warm, cooked rice that could be left long enough for bugs to form in it. If you are happy with your local take away and have no worries about the quality of their dishes, great but to be sure the best options are the Chinese or Indian ready meals from supermarkets because they have to be cooked and packaged to the same very high safe and consistent food standards as frozen ready meals. You go through so much cr*p you are more than entitled to a meal you can actually taste, so don't deny yourself, just be careful :)

Posts.Title: anyone out there diagnosed with tubular cancer?

Posts.Content: Hiya, As long as your temp stays on track just see how this cough behaves over 24 hour period. There are a few winter bugs going around so keeping an eye on your temps is a good thing. If it is a dry cough it could be a side effect of the Cyclophosphamide part of FEC as this can affect your lung tissue a bit. Lung tissue can get thicker and less flexible making it harder for you to breathe. If this cough doesn't clear up over the next day or so (or develop into a cold) or If you find that you start getting breathless when you do any exercise, walking uphill or going upstairs let your onco team know about it so they can check you out - If it is Cyclophosphamide causing this they may change it to something else. Hopefully it will only be a 24 hour thing. Maybe others ladies here have had similar issues with FEC, luckily Jackie got away without any coughing issues from it. G n' J

Posts.Title: party

Posts.Content: Sorry have to agree with MM - Had a look on breastcancercare uk and cancer research uk and these snippets are from their info pages. G n' J If your child has chickenpox, try to keep them away from public areas to avoid contact with people who have not had it, especially people who are at risk of serious problems, such as newborn babies, pregnant women and anyone with a weakened immune system (for example, people having cancer treatment or taking steroid tablets)............................ There are many types of white blood cells which make up the total white cell count. Their main function is to help your body to fight infection. If your white cell count is low (usually 7 to 14 days after the chemotherapy) you may become prone to infections and take longer to recover from them. In general, these arise from bacteria within our own bodies, and it is not necessary to avoid crowded places or isolate yourself from others. However, we advise you to keep away from people with serious infections, such as chicken pox................................ Stay away from people who you know have an infection such as a cold, the flu, measles or chicken pox. If you haven’t had chicken pox yourself and you come into contact with someone with chickenpox or shingles, please contact the unit for advice.................. Varicella zoster is the same virus that causes chicken pox. It can cause very serious and sometimes fatal infections, such as pneumonia, in people with cancer. The virus also causes a painful condition called shingles. You can only get shingles if you have had chicken pox in the past. This is because after you've had chicken pox the virus does not fully go away. It lies inactive in the body, but can become active again if the immune system is weak. This is why people can get shingles after chemotherapy treatment............ Keep away from people who have chicken pox or shingles if you have never had these illnesses. They could make you very ill. If you do come into contact with someone who has them tell your doctor or nurse straight away............................
Posts.Title: Risk of infection?

Posts.Content: Hi young mum of two  A slightly raised CEA level will trigger a witch hunt which is a good thing - Look at it as ruling stuff out rather than confirming anything nasty.  Normal levels are considered zero to 3  (5 if you smoke)  CEA levels can rise into the many hundreds, even thousands so in the grand scheme of things 15 doesn't look too bad, but there must still be a reason for it :-/ Some non cancerous conditions which can raise CEA levels are - Peptic ulcers, inflammatory bowel disease, pancreatitis, hypothyroidism, diabetes etc  So it's possible they will check for these too. Do you have any other symptoms that could be associated with those conditions ? Good to see your CA15.3 levels are normal - Hope you get good results from your CT scan. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi,  CMF may be a better option as they replace the Epirubicin (the E part of FEC) with Methotrexate. There is more info about CMF here and Info about FEC here. The individual chemo drugs mentioned on the info pages are clickable. There is also a booklet titled 'Coping With Hair Loss' which explains a little about the 'cold cap' Most here would agree that once chemo starts the importance of hair loss slips down the league table of concerns but if you are wanting to keep you hair the cold cap may help. Everyone is different and what works for some doesn't always work for someone else. There may be a few here who have had CMF but it is not a commonly used combination. Posts.Title: CMF OR FEC WITH A COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hi hairworries,  Had to reply to your last post as we're a tad concerned for your train of thoughts on treatment. There is a line between Complimentary therapy and Alternative therapy. We're hoping you meant the former. Sometimes the words are used together but they mean totally different things. Complimentary is fine but NONE of the alternative therapies have been tested and proven as effective. Please don't think you can beat this with just alternative treatments too many have tried before you and lost the battle. Those few who have survived probably would have survived anyway. There is a lot of information about complimentary and alternative at cancer reseach uk (cruk) Just be aware of dubious claims - 'There are a lot more people making a living from cancer than there are dying from it' G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Pat,  It's unfortunate you have got some blisters it sometimes happens towards the end of your Rad sessions or up to a week or so afterwards depends on how delicate your skin type is. Try to protect them as best as you can while the new skin grows underneath. If they do break and weep it can be quite painful (just like sunburn blisters do) If this happens get in touch with your onco or rad team or even your GP and depending on how it looks, they may give you a course of anti bio's in case of any infection getting in the open sore areas. Just keep up with the cream and try to be gentle with it and keep an eye on them for weeping. Hope it heals up soon, sounds a bit ouchy, G n' J

Posts.Title: not sure were i should be

Posts.Content: Hi Year 4 teacher  Depending on what pathology results you get from the breast or node tissue you may not need chemo. The affected node you had may have only had a few cells within it, not a cluster or tumour and as the other node was clear feels it is better left rather than having more removed and finding those also clear. Until then and depending on what results you get if you are ER+ oestrogen positive but HER2- negative some tissue may be sent off for the Oncotype-DX test to get a score out of 100 to find out if chemo would be of any substantial long term benefit. If you are found to be HER2+ positive you will definitely be getting chemo and Herceptin. If you do have chemotherapy recommended the sessions usually take 18 weeks in total (6 x 3 weekly) but you can usually add two weeks to this if your chemo gets delayed for a week a couple of times.  Radiotherapy is mostly started around 4 - 6 weeks post chemo so you are talking about a ball park figure of 5 possibly 6 months. Either way the radiotherapy or chemo will given to eliminate any risk however small to your nodes as best as possible. Most here will tell you it is harder to recover from a node clearance than a mastectomy or WLE (lumpectomy) and remember if you are ER/PR+ positive you will also be placed on hormone inhibitor tablets for 5 possibly 10 years as another back up treatment. Good luck with your margins Friday, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Hiya, I think all oncologists would veto any herbals during chemo, herceptin and to a certain extent radiotherapy there are just so many variations of compounds within the products they simply cannot test them all against adverse reactions etc. Post treatment unless you are ER/PR+ positive I would have thought it possible to take some to ease any side effects or get back to where you were prior to treatment.  Do still check any out though because you need to now be a bit more aware of what you are taking especially those which can mimic ER/PR hormones, or alter the effectiveness of hormone inhibitor meds. The Milk Thistle info page is here and the main alphabetical herbal index page is this one. Which is great because you can flick through all the ingredients in a product. G n' J

Assume you didn't go the cold cap route ?If you have longish hair it may start to actually hurt your scalp in a few days time. If you have already had it cut to a shorter style it may not be so bad as it is the weight of hair 'pulling' on the follicles that causes the discomfort. If it gets quite bad you could see your GP as there are meds that can be prescribed as well like Meloxicam (a non-steroidal anti inflammatory drug) or Amitriptyline - you could look any of these up at EMC here. Posts.Content: Hi Fireopal  I think this question would better answered by someone with more medical experience using the 'Ask a Nurse' area (link) as there is a lot of misinformation regarding all the various types of massage. Some massage therapy can be helpful as a complimentary treatment but some types are not advised like deep massage and I'm unsure if ultrasonic massage is classed under this term ? There is actually a specialist cancer treatment available which can kill certain cancer cells called 'HIFU' (high intensity focused ultrasound) which is ultrasonic based. Posts.Content: Morning Lou, Long time no see, hope you are well ? Hair re growth varies a lot depending on the type of hair you had - for some it comes back quicker than for others. It is common for it to be really slow to start with but after a month to six weeks it should be growing around half an inch per month. This rate can be slower if you are taking any hormone tablets though and also whether you had FEC then T or the other way around can have a bearing on this ? For some reason it seems to grow back quicker if you were FEC then T. How long, or should that be short is your hair at the moment ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Mastectomy tomorrow, 9-9-15

Posts.Content: Hiya Fluff99  So lets get this straight - You had a lymph node clearance on Friday and you have gone back to work for some normality ?  That's not normal  :) Blimey, are you trying to get on the Queen's new years honours list  LOL The only thing that is normal is the way you are feeling - You may feel fine physically (lucky you after a clearance) but you will be suffering post trauma stress from your surgeries. It's not so much depression but the effects are very similar, and no doubt all the guilt you are piling onto yourself about being a burden won't be helping to get your head back in a good place. In the old days after surgery you had a period called "convalescence" a word not used much now, but is as important now as it was back then.  A time to heal both the body and mind after a trauma or surgery something too easily ignored in this fast paced modern life of ours. So stop impersonating the Duracell bunny and take some time out for yourself - "you are worth it"..... as they say. Loads'a hugs and a Fluffy Drum Roll , G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Tiggy, This may be fluid retention (oedema) can be a side effect of the steroids given during chemo. Keep an eye on them because if the skin gets stretched too tight it can make walking or anything that expands the calf / ankle muscles quite painful. If it gets bad enough for you to need to see your GP and get Furosemide or something similar for it, just don't take them last thing at night or you will be in and out of bed all night going for a pee. If left it will go down on it's own but can take quite a while. Hope it doesn't get too bad, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Leg Calves Increasing in Size After Chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi Felen, TC chemo regime (Docetexel & Cyclophos) can be a bit harsh - are you due to have 4 sessions or 6 ?  Unfortunately you do find yourself becoming a baggage handler - Taking meds for the side effects caused by the side effects meds syndrome :(  The list you rattled off is fairly standard for Docetaxel... The one you haven't mentioned is mouth ulcers so hopefully you are getting away with that one, as it can really take the edge off your appetite... There is another member here who has had TC anncg hopefully she will spot this and get back to you about how she found her TC sessions - There may be others too, but I haven't had enough coffee to think straight yet :) As for the guilt thing, I assume you mean you feel guilty that your husband is having to help you ?  If so, please don't do that to yourself, there's no shame in needing support going through this rubbish and he is probably only to happy to help and can work for hours on just one hug  LOL   It's one of the few times fella's can actually show they really care. Tell yourself Mrs.Independent will be back shortly but for now accept all the help you can lay your hands on, it all helps lighten the load :) Welcome to the group by the way, you'll be glad you joined, it's a great place to be at a tough time. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hiya Karen, Lovely to hear from you :) Don't now if Davina mentioned we were chatting last night or if you noticed our conversation yourself but please don't feel you have to say sorry. It's great she is up for helping her mum, unfortunately I didn't realise who her mum was until she mentioned your name and her age. I noticed her  membership still seems to be useable and I sent her a link so she could get 'chatting' on the Rip-Rap website forum. I don't know if you mentioned to her she is under age so I don't know if she has seen that message so I'll copy that in here so you can pass it on if she missed it or let her read the original message (either or)  :) Copied text -  Davina, You can post an introductory message to rip rap from this link  www.riprap.org.uk/.../new-topic.asp     You just have to select a member name (not your own) and follow the instructions. There is one message there from someone whose mum has breast cancer too. Bless her, she was probably too scared and angsty while you were going through treatment - In her eyes she could have even had thoughts of losing you and that must have been a terribly emotional time for her as well as you. Is Davina your oldest by any chance ? Now she can see you have been through the survival course those worries have left her and she wants to be there for you. Sorry to read the booster was a step too far and you got rad burns don't know how long ago you finished your sessions but the worst should be over 2-3 weeks afterwards, so hang on in there and count the days off. You are so right, cancer does change you as a person - for the better mostly. Teaches to enjoy the simple pleasures you used to take for granted, who your friends really are, not giving a shi* about other peoples 'petty' problems, being more assertive and no longer take the crap you used to :) Can't believe you have just about finished ? Looking back it doesn't seem that long ago we spotted Karen the rabbit in the headlights joining us here  LOL Don't be a stranger we love to read how you are getting on and you are now fully qualified to help out the 'newbies'  :) Loads'a Christmas Hugs Karen (and Davina)  G n' J

Posts.Title: Estriol Cream

Posts.Content: Hi QuiltyRosie, Thickening is a known side effect of Tamoxifen but it doesn't affect everyone and in those it does affect it can thicken more quickly for some than it does for others. The results from the TVU may not be detailed enough to make an accurate diagnosis, if so you may also be referred for an MRI or CT scan to double check everything. As you have only been on them for just over 18 months it is likely to get worse if you have to take these for another 3 years plus so even if the results hopefully come though clear they may offer you a hysterectomy anyway.  Whether they would do this and keep you on Tamoxifen or possibly change you onto one of the Aromatse Inhibitors type tablets is something you could ask when you get your results. You could join and post this question to the Womb Group NOT saying this because it could be that, it's just that the ladies there can give you more experienced advice about TVU results and follow ups, lining thickening (how thick 12mm is by comparison) and any other symptoms like bleeding etc. Hope this is of some help, there may be other members of the breast group who have had similar problems with Tamoxifen and thickening and what that involved. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Coping with chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Rhonda, The amount you are getting does seem too be way more than most, unfortunately halting oestrogen production either surgically or with Zoladex / Gosrelin to get off Tamoxifen is only part of the problem. This is called Ovarian Ablation (link) under Information and support ? Although pre menopause your ovaries produce most of the oestrogen it is also produced by your adrenal glands and body fat cells so you will still be producing some oestrogen which will still need tablets to control. There are some who have Zoladex and are switched to an aromatase inhibitor like Letrozole ot Anastrozole which may help with easing all these hot flashes but these AI's in turn may also cause joint / bone aches so you just end up swapping one lot of side effects for others :( Just putting a few options out there for you to consider and ask your onco about until you get more replies to help you gather enough info for a decision. G n' J
