Posts.Title: Hair & cold cap

Posts.Content: Hi Fleet, Sorry to see you joining us here and reading about your husband and his Tamoxifen baggage :-( Oestrogen is one of the feel good hormones so as it gets reduced it can be a bit mood changing. Is your husband on any other medication besides Tamoxifen ? as in males around 20% of the oestrogen is produced by the testicles and there are other drugs out there that control this better ? If you click this link it takes you to the Hormonal Therapies Treatment for Breast Cancer  in Men information page where you can read about oestrogen production in men. There is also this page about Possible Hormonal Treatment Side Effects in Men (link) Depression post treatment is also fairly common, it's like a type of post traumatic stress disorder and there may well be other problems he is coping with like male breast cancer and surgery for it is quite rare and he may feel really strange in himself about this, also drug treatments may have affected the way he now feels about himself ? Hope this is of some help. No doubt you have other questions too, so once you have settled in here just ask, we're all here to help. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen side effects depression

Posts.Content: Hiya Pmcd, No reason why you couldn't start the ball rolling now if after a bit of thought you would like to go for it. A couple of ladies here had their recon over 2 years later. In a lot of cases they actually prefer you to get rads out of the way before doing reconstructions as the rads can affect the tissue by causing some tightness and possibly a little shrinkage. There's this Macmillan booklet 'Understanding Breast Reconstruction' (link) you can read and also download for future reference. There is quite a range of different types, some where they use back or tummy tissue you may not be suitable for if you are a bit on the slim side. Be aware it does contain post surgery images but it wouldn't be very informative without them :) There is also a Mac info page here which  may have different topics about it. If you are a larger lady they may require you to lose a little weight first it depends on the surgeon and annethetist. There may be several reason why some don't get a recon. Could be they can't face further surgery, were small breasted before and are happy with their look - being uneven can be a pain if you are left with one big boob but they can also reduce the size of number 2 to match the recon breast, as they only usually recon up to a C cup ? as the weight 'pulls' on the stitches and can cause other problems. I'll butt out now and let others bombard you too  LOL Good luck gathering all the info and making the right decision for you.  G n' J
Posts.Title: Reconstruction advice and info please.....

Posts.Content: Morning Tansi  Just got the 'tag' email from Lynn's message - So sorry to read about your mum. It is tough when a loved one is too frail to get the more affective treatments like surgery or chemo but targetted radiotherapy is a good option in these cases. Do you think her breathlessness could be tied in with anything else going on like COPD, pleural fluid issue or sarcoidosis as well as having some chest node involvement ?  Unless the swollen nodes are pressing on her trachea you would think any enlarged nodes would have to be fairly large to put enough pressure on her lungs/diaphragm to cause breathlessness. Is your mum just 'top' breathing (not using bottom half of lungs) or having problems breathing alltogether ? You could ask her oncologist to go through all their findings with you to get the full picture and what her radiotherapy course would entail; maybe ask if you can record it on your phone so you don't miss anything mentioned ? Find with a lot of these professionals unless you ask specific questions they tend to not tell you everything :( Most cancer cells are spread through lympho vascular invasion. If in the lymph system they can be 'caught' by the nodes which stops them reaching other organs, if vascular they can find their way to the liver, lungs, bone or brain - Chemotherapy as a whole body treatment would normally be on the table if this is the case but it is too tough a regime for those who are frail :( Hope you find some answers and your mum has a successful outcome from the rads. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Dentist

Posts.Content: Hiya  MamaSm,  Think not enough information is given about nailcare during chemo it's about time a leaflet was produced to highlight these issues. By the time you realise you have a problem you are too far into your sessions to do anything about it :-( Yes, by all means varnish is fine Just make sure you get some Acetone free varnish remover from Boots, or any other high street chemist as the solvent used is a lot less harsh. Don't be tempted to use stick on nails as the adhesive can get into any places where your own nail may have lifted and become a site for infection and they may actually take your own nail with it if you try to remove them. You may end up losing some nails anyway, but you will have almost fully formed but thinner new nails underneath. Hopefully you will get some more replies about nail varnish types and care - as Jackie lost all 20 of hers because we knew nothing about this nail problem at the time. Found this on the Australian Breast Cancer Network About Nails and Chemo  it's a good read but a bit too late. May be of use to others reading this and about to start chemo though. Take care, G  n' J
Posts.Title: Fingernails turning black

Posts.Content: Hi Peartree, Driving 50 miles only one week after breast surgery is a bit much too soon - They recommend not driving for at least 2 pref 3 weeks post breast surgery. Was the seat belt over your operation side as well ? Right hand side surgery will cause seat belt pressure problems and left side surgery will stretch everything with gear changes handbrake etc. That and having both hands on the steering wheel for at least an hour will stretch the tendons in your armpits. I would see if it eases over the weekend but if this is really painful get it looked at and some some better pain relief until it lessens. As long as it doesn't feel hot and/or look inflamed (sign of infection) a bit of rest should help. If you were a right handed breast girl you could get one of those small shaped cushions to slip between your seatbelt and chest to take the pressure off. G n' J

Posts.Title: Zoladex and Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Nina, You have certainly been through the mill Nina :-( There are lots of things this could be besides a cancerous tumour, but having 'previous' you will be very wary of anything suspicious now, that's only natural. Jackie has just got her 3 year review scan letter and it does bring back all the emotions of when first diagnosed, so how you are feeling is totally normal. Several types of lump which will show up on an ultrasound are benign fatty tumours, calcification, fibroids and others non cancerous conditions. Chances are you could rule a cyst out as these are mostly fluid filled and would probably have be noticed during the biopsy. You would be very unlucky to get another primary so do hope for the best, rather than fearing the worst. It is a long time until next Thursday and for you will seen like an eternity but do try to keep your head occupied with other things to think about, chuck yourself into a hobby, visiting friends and family even window shopping - anything to help take your mind off it and makes the days pass until you get your results. We'll all keep our fingers crossed you are just visiting us here for a week or so, but do keep posting as you sound like you do need some positive thoughts from us all to help you through the coming week. Take care and sending our wishes for the best of luck for your results. G n' J

Posts.Title: I've only gone and done it !!

Posts.Content: See a lot posts mentioning  'Don't Google Anything' cancer related. We have used the term often to new members. Main reasons are a lot of the information out there is either out of date, misleading or downright wrong !!!     Others try by any means possible to separate you from your cash. Cancer Research has just posted a page of the 10 most popular cancer myths - either from a causes point of view or concerns about  alternative treatments. When diagnosis takes people to a dark place, patients may actively try and seek out alternative therapies as a last resort, often contradicting their tried and tested modern treatments. Some even poisoning themselves in the process. Items covered range from superfoods, sugar intake, miracle cures etc If you are interested you can find it here - http://scienceblog.cancerresearchuk.org/2014/03/24/dont-believe-the-hype-10-persistent-cancer-myths-debunked/ Stay safe out there, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Why You Shouldn't Google - 10 Cancer Myths Debunked

Posts.Content: Morning  Paul,  Yeah, What the Lucky Black Cat said.....  We all have crossed fingers for you mate. You may not get the full picture today, it may well mean a bit more nail biting for the full results but at least hopefully you'll find out if they want to take things further or if you got away with it. 'GOOD LUCK'  Paul, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: thank yuo to evertone

Posts.Content: Hiya, It is nearly always the lack of oestrogen caused by either the menopause itself and/or the hormone inhibitor tablets (whatever type they are) that are to blame. Oestrogen is also a 'feel good' hormone which is why you can also feel down or teary at times but oestrogen also controls other glands within the body so can throw the whole thing out of synch. During the menopause for most women this decrease is gradual, but many experts believe when estrogen falls, the hypothalamus is adversely affected. As the hypothalamus regulates your body temperature, the decrease in oestrogen causes the brain to detect too much body heat. As a natural reaction to this the brain releases hormones to help lower body heat, causing a patient’s heart rate to rise and blood vessels to dilate in order to allow more blood to flow through and dissipate the heat. The increased blood flow causes the body to produce its natural cooling method- sweat. This series of events is what creates that heated, sweaty feeling that can be so inconvenient for sufferers. Having medication to halt oestrogen production stops this process being gradual and plunges you straight into low levels so you don't get chance to adapt to the changes over an extended period of time. You could ask about the hypothalamus aspect - if this is related there may be meds to counteract this effect but it is a complicated area ?
Posts.Title: Too Many Hot Flushes

Posts.Content: Hi BeautyBeau15  Passing on the cold cap option and facing hair loss can be a bit traumatic and there are a few things you can consider. When hair loss starts the scalp can get quite sore - the too tight ponytail feeling can be a sign this is starting to occur ? Then is probably the best time to go for a shorter style like a pixie cut as it isn't so traumatic losing shorter hair. Deciding on when to take off the rest is more individual depending on appearence. If you leave this first cut too late for some the scalp can become so sore having it cut can be quite painful. The scalp pain is a lot less with shorter hair as there is less weight pulling on the follicles so you may not get this. Another option if you anyone has longish, undyed hair is to contact the Little Princess Trust and donate your hair to this worthwhile charity who make wigs for children with hairloss due to cancer treatments. Hope this is of some help, G n' J
Posts.Title: Coming to terms with hair loss.

Posts.Content: Hi YorkA, Try not to be too downhearted about your lymph node results, it's lovely if you get to hear they are clear but chances are what they have found is just a few cells, not actual tumours. Obviously it does mean a bit extra surgery to remove them but they have to go to clear you of these stragglers. Lymph nodes are like your bodies fishing nets catching germs and infectious cells to trap them and mobilise your anti bodies to attack them. That is why your neck glands swell up with things like mumps and flu.  Nodes also stop cells from traveling elsewhere in the lymph system as the last thing you want is these cells floating around where they can settle in other areas like liver, lungs etc. Yes, it is hard especially at the start when everything is unknown and seems to take forever to get the answers you need regarding a full diagnosis and finding out what your treatment plan will entail. I was going to say happy new year but yours has started a bit c*ap, so we'll just say focus on something special to do in the summertime when you will feel more like you have reached your goals. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: reigning in the fear

Posts.Content: Hi Paula  /  PGT64  The funny mouth, taste and fatigue are fairly standard but I would definitely mention the other effects you are having as the E part (Epirubicin) can affect the heart and from what you mention this could be circulation or blood pressure related. Would be worth giving them a ring, they may want you in to check you over which is hassle, but better than doing nothing and continuing to feel rough. G n' J

Posts.Title: Edinburgh group

Posts.Content: Evening YorkA, It certainly does come as a shock and as you are finding once they confirm your fears it lets all the 'what if's loose to scare the pants off you :( Welcome to the group btw, you'll get to love it here. Best place around for friendly info, support and being able to rant when needed :) Don't know what would have been worse, keeping you waiting a few more days before telling you so as to not put a dampener on your Christmas or the extra days terrible waiting results time. Lets grab the postives and there are plenty so please try to stop all these 'don't want to leave them' worries. Grade 2 and ER+ so it's been found fairly early and being ER+ they will place you on long term tablets nearer the end of treatment for that.  J was grade 3 ductal in May 2012 (getting on for 4 years now) so this is do'able for around 90% of those diagnosed these days and the other 10% are those who are elderly, have other health problems or have been diagnosed really late with advanced BC. There are lots of members here who have finished treatment so can help you by answering any questions you may have (probably loads ?) Do ask away, were all here to help. Do you know as yet if you will be having surgery soon ? as when you are diagnosed things tend to happen quite quickly and that can make you feel a bit out of control.... Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: reigning in the fear

Posts.Content: Think the problem is some take the 'don't google' comment too literally. It's fairly obvious you are going to get up to date, valid and reliable info from places like cancer research uk, Maccyland breastcancercare uk nhs etc and complete BS from websites selling alternative remedies and weird and wonderful treatments - some of the youtube videos are very informative like manual lymph fluid massage - others are posted to get a reaction, so yes you do have to trust your intelligence. The problem lies with those first diagnosed whose heads are in a fog, and can be led to believe almost anything because logic has gone on holiday and those who are terminal and therefore very vulnerable seeking the 'cure' Like we always say, "There are more people making a living from cancer, than there are dying from it" So Just be safe out there,  G n' J
Posts.Title: Why You Shouldn't Google - 10 Cancer Myths Debunked

Posts.Content: Hi PGT64  The effects of chemo can be accumulative - It's like you haven't quite got over one session then they hit you again :( If you are gradually struggling do mention this to your Onco, there may be something they can add to your bag of smarties to take, or could even possibly reduce the dose of your chemo by 10% When you say 'awful' what are the main effects you are suffering from as there are no doubt ladies here who have had the same and can offer you some tips that may help.. There is a monthly chemo club here too where those having chemo support each other you could take a look at ? You can find the August Chemo Club here. Hope this helps, take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne, Remember when you were a kid and you grazed your knee you got clear'ish fluid appear with a bit of blood in it to help it heal over..... ?  Same sort of thing really only there's more of it. The fluid forms inside and after they stitch you up it has nowhere to go - rather than have it expand like a blister causing pressure they put drains in to allow it to get out. So after reading highland mum's reply seems not everyone gets them. You'll be fine, bit of discomfort but great after they take them out a few days afterwards. Best wishes, G n' J

Posts.Title: What is the prognosis for inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: Well, after what seems like ages ( last May ) Jackie returned to work last night. Only half shifts to start with as it entails lots of corridor walking and climbing those dreaded stairways. Was great for her to meet up with her colleagues and tend patients again. She got chatting to a nurse who started there while she was off sick fighting the "beast" and to her surprise she mentioned  "I know what you have been through, I had grade 3 BC SEVENTEEN years ago"  She had right mx, sentinel nodes, chemo etc and has never looked back. Now, if that isn't inspiration that this bugger is so do-able, hide my underwear and call me Ben Dover. She came home to lasagne and lemon meringue - perfect way to end another hurdle being jumped. Nine months ago this point seemed so far away, it was a long tunnel and Jackie got derailed quite a few times on the way, but reached the end eventually. To anyone mid way, or just starting their on ride the Chemostar Express. Hang on tight and be aware of the bumpy bits and before you know it you are back in the sunlight, squinting, a bit wobbly, liking the new you that is emerging and feeling so much better.The glass that was half full, has been topped up. Now all she has to do is avoid getting shoved back in that queue for another ride in the future. Very best of luck to you all, and a huge high five for Annie's Angels,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Turning Corners and a Bit of Inspiration :-)

Posts.Content: Hiya  Kay, Jackie finished her chemo mid Oct  3 x FEC / 3 x T. She soon got some peach fuzz sprouting but it was very slow growing to start with. Now it's just under an inch and nearly long enough for a pixie cut. Came back same colour and still straight :-)  She never wanted to get a wig from the start either just bought a couple of wooly hats and some sparkly bits to smarten them up to wear when the chemo chills were worst. Gotta love the scrub hats idea, you can get some great random prints on those - Magic Roundabout would be apt  :-) It's been a hard 9 months for our daughter too, as she is 200 miles away at uni doing an adult nursing degree (BN) All she wanted was to be back home.  It was so hard trying to convince her all was well and she needs to stay put. Gotta mention the youtube video you replied to shuey about. If it's the same one we saw it sums chemo up perfectly. I found it easier to find if you add the word cancer to the wildest ride on earth search as it came up with loads otherwise. So true to life video about one ladies battle and recovery with a brilliant soundtrack. Certainly makes you feel an affinity with her. I may get a maccy slap for this, but here's the link anyway.... Is it the same one ?. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vD9K3PqGE9k Cheers,  George n' Jackie

Posts.Content: Hi Morecombe, No wonder you are confused - They are two totally different forms of BC ? Do definitely ask on the phone tomorrow as you need to know for sure, and perhaps a member of their staff needs to go to specsavers..... or at least should take a bit more time and care.... Posts.Title: which diagnosis is right ?

Posts.Content: Hi Lelly, So sorry to read about your twin. Of course you are more than welcome here, it's just about the busiest group here (there are loads of us) and we're all here to help each other through this. A lumpectomy is sometimes written here as WLE (wide local excision) so if you see that written anywhere it refers to the same op your sister is having. The surgeons tend to take the minimum they can without being too drastic in altering the breast shape, downside to that is one in five get recalled for a little more to be removed to obtain what they term as 'clear margins' to ensure all of it is removed. This information along with a fuller diagnosis is obtained from the removed tissue via the pathology lab about a week after surgery. So if it's info you need you can try this booklet first Breast Surgery and Recovery to give you some idea as to how your sis will be. You may also find this of help with the emotional side of all this When Someone Close To You Has Cancer - just click the green text links. You must have ahead full of questions, so if you need to know anything in particular, fire away. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Am I allowed to join - or would you prefer this group to be just patients...

Posts.Content: Hiya, Pleased to see you hopped over the fence and came to join us - Warm welcome to the group, there are loads of us here. Apart from the 2 weeks to get to see your GP most here had the same time scale. 4 -6 weeks weeks of emotional agony, days seem to last forever until you find out the score :( You will find now they take brakes off and your feet hardly get chance to touch the ground Have you got a date for your surgery yet ?  It doesn't usually take long to fit you in for theatre and there will be another angsty 10 day waiting period after that while your tissue results from pathology come through. Don't fret too much about the surgery with lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy (WLE & SNB) most are home the next day if you are early morning on 'the list' may even be same day.  If you were wondering a SNB is where they inject a tracer dye and remove the nearest 2 or 3 lymph nodes to the tumour to check to see if any cells have got trapped there. Best wishes, G n' J   =  if you click the 'green' name dreamthief you can read our profile :)

Posts.Title: Pros and cons of bilateral mastectomy/reduction

Posts.Content: Hi Ivyivy At least you have time to get a few things together prior to starting your chemo roller coaster ride. The main items to get hold of are something for both constipation and diarrhoea as one can quickly turn to the other :-/ A digital thermometer (doesn't have to be a really expensive one) We used a cheapo from Asda which we found accurate enough. A packet of Ginger Nut and Arrowroot biscuits they both help in different ways - Ginger Nuts help with taste issues and Arrowroot with nausea or queasiness.  Generic brands of Paracetamol and Ibuprofen because if needed you can alternate between the two at 2 hourly intervals instead of just 4 hourly with paracetamol only. Supermarket multi buys of various bottled flavoured waters (still or fizzy) as you need at least 2 litres of fluid daily while on chemo as Tea / Coffee may taste awful... Soft (baby) toothbrush in case your gums get sore and some Chlorhexidine antibacterial mouthwash - Lloyds, Superdrug and Boots all sell their own brand at a round £3 a bottle to help avert oral thrush. Tin of Pineapple Chunks which you can open and put in the fridge in case you need to sooth a gunky mouth. Do get back to us when you find which Chemo Cocktail you will be having,. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Preparation for chemo and herceptin

Posts.Content: Hiya, As you are asking for experiences, I'm hoping you get loads of replies from those that are on any of these hormonal therapy tablets but just to cover the basics - If pre menopause they give you Tamoxifen because it works better on halting the ovaries producing oestrogen than the AI (aromatase inhibitor) types. Post menopause with the ovaries shutdown you will be given the AI's. There can be variations and crossovers though. Like if you are approaching the meno you can be placed on Tamoxifen for a couple of years then they change you onto the AI's - or if you can't get on with the AI's they can switch you back to Tamoxifen. There is more info on this Maccy page about Hormonal Therapies. G n' J
Posts.Title: Tablets

Posts.Content: YODA says,  On the Dark Side - A Little More Knowledge Lights Our Way  :) I actually look a little like him some mornings too  LOL........... Letrozole long term is considered the slightly better of the AI's but I don't think one isn't necessarily chosen over another because of this. An oncologist may have a preference but I get the impression within the menopause consideration these are interchangeable to counter side effects. Breast Cancer Org in the USA have this Hormonal Therapy Side Effects Comparison Chart you can check out which makes very interesting reading. As for the Italian Job - As a registered drug Femara®  It would have to be exactly of the same compounds wherever it was made ? but don't quote me on that :)  They may have been shipped into Italy in bulk and repackaged by Novartis Italy ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Veritas, Never good getting a review, takes you right back to a time you would rather forget :-( Perhaps if they used the same machine to detect testicular cancer the machines would be re-designed..... It really is about time they were all scrapped and it was all carried out using ultrasound. Jackie just passed her 3 year review but unfortunately it was a just over a weeks wait for the postman to deliver the letter and I admit it is a tough wait :-( I think it's a case of no news is good news as I'm sure if something is found it would be a phone call with an appt to come back in. The odd twinge you are feeling is probably scar tissue so try not to worry about this. Good luck, hope you don't get messed about too much this time around. G n' J
Posts.Title: Year on mammogram coming up

Posts.Content: Hi volvox167  Losing your hair is especially hard when you have persevered with scalp cooling and are one of the unlucky ones who it isn't successful for :( It makes such a change to your appearance even some folks who have know you for years don't recognise you at first. It is quite probable those at the quiz night didn't notice as a lot of wigs look far more natural compared to the coypu hats the NHS used to hand out :) Please don't feel ugly, and definitely don't see the lady looking back at you in the mirror as a victim when in reality she is a strong woman doing what she needs to do to climb her personal six peaks challenge - 2 down 4 to go ? Don't take your eyes off the prize Churchill :) Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: thank yuo to evertone

Posts.Content: Hi Bedy, As the other lovely ladies have mentioned. There are a lot of members here taking these various types / brands of hormone therapy tablets and you see a snapshot of everyone's problems, so it all gets magnified out of proportion. The drug companies don't exactly help by including a massive list of common and not so common side effects but that doesn't mean you will get them all  - Thankfully..... If you do get placed on one of the generic brands and it doesn't agree with you, get your pharmacy to switch you to another brand and see what differences you feel. It only usually takes a few swaps to find one that is better for you. Pharmacists can change brands of the same drug without having to go through your GP, that is why some never seem to get the same brand on a regular basis. You will only need to go the GP route if you want to change your prescription from one drug to another like Letrozole to Anastrozole etc, from any generic to a specific brand that you prefer entered in the system as your repeat. Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Sue  /  sue62  Sorry to see you are one of the few who has had PICC Line clotting problems :( You can check out the difference between Hickman Central iv Lines and Ports using the links. You can ask about either one you prefer but in a lot of cases it all depends on who at the hospital is signed off to carry out the installing procedure. Someone who  fits PICC Lines may not be allowed to fit Hickmans/Groshong lines or Ports. In a larger hospital this isn't usually a problem but in a more local unit you may only get offered what they can fit ? In our local unit they had someone specifically come round every Wednesday from Addenbrooke's to actually fit them. Hope this is of some help, you could ask which options were preferred by the ladies here ? I haven't got any 'Big Girls' pants but you can borrow these :) Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Bra donations

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, Pleased to read your infection / lack of healing seems to be at last turning a corner. Bummer about the Herceptin but 7 sessions is better than none. There was an original trial (PHARE) with Herceptin being given for 6 months instead of 12 did show there only seemed to be a 2% difference in recurrence between 6 and 12 months.  The much newer and larger 'Persophone Trial' results are due in sometime this year but if the first set of figures are anything to go by it may end up with Herceptin only being given for 6 months as standard anyway. Of course 6 months equates to 9 sessions so you are still 2 short of that figure. There are other Monoclonal Antibody type drugs - Drugs that specifically block HER2 to stop the growth of cancer cells are called HER2-targeted therapies. Examples of these drugs include trastuzumab (Herceptin), lapatinib (Tykerb), pertuzumab (Perjeta), and ado-trastuzumab emtansine (Kadcyla), commonly referred to as T-DM1. How many of these partly contain Herceptin in their make up I have no idea. Kadcyla (T-DM1) contains Herceptin but NICE stopped that one because of it's hefty price. I think some of the others are for HER2+ secondary cancers (mets) so they may not be available either but it gives you a few names to check out and ask about ? Good luck, G n' J
Posts.Title: Efficacy of Herceptin

Posts.Content: If you happen like grapefruit, do be careful with grapefruit or grapefruit juice and your meds..... They are recently finding a lot more contradictions with meds to the extent you often see 'Avoid Grapefruit with this Medication' printed on the prescription label. It contains an enzyme that weakens or strengthens some drugs. Including common drugs like some types of chemotherapy, steroids, statins etc If in doubt, do check it is OK to have grapefruit with your drugs regime. There is more information about this and the types of drugs that flag up alerts here at CRUK. G n' J

Posts.Title: Multivitamins

Posts.Content: Hi Loving the Sunshine, Sounds like you are what they term Perimenopausal. This mostly starts between 46 and 50 and is when your oesteogen and egg production slows down for a few years prior to the menopause and will have nothing to do with spread etc.  Some cancer types have night sweats as a symptom but breast cancer isn't one of them. Do you know if you are ER/PR+ positve as this will mean tablets for 5 years after your chemo and can have a similar same effect. G n' J
Posts.Title: awaiting chemotherapy treatment but might sweats have returned!

Posts.Content: Hi ks1966  I'm not a resilient lady (stop sniggering you lot) but I am married to one  :) Most ladies get switched from Tamoxifen to one of the AI's (aromatase inhibitors) like Letrozole or Anastrozole once the blood test confirms they are now post menopausal. Main reason for this is most of the oestogen which was produced by the ovaries have shut down so there is more of a need to stop oestrogen being produced from other areas like the adrenal glands and fatty tissue etc. You can read more about this clicking this link. Has your girlfriend been offered a Dexa Bone Density Scan ? As long term AI's can cause some bone thinning and a dexa scan will give base bone density levels to find if she would benefit from any bone strengthening meds to help avoid osteopaenia later. J finished her 5 years on Letrozole about 6 months back - so if you have any more questions about these, just holler :) If she hasn't it may be worth asking her oncologist or GP to arrange a Dexa - they are minor scans and only take around 20 mins. Hope this is of some help, G n' J
Posts.Title: Tamoxafin Letrozole

Posts.Content: Hiya Mandz1001  If you have had no treatment yet but facing surgery next week this sounds like it could be a stress related reaction - perhaps partly due to chemical changes within the body caused by the fight or flight reflex ? Our daughter got very stressed out just before her driving test (not like a burning reaction though) and her GP told her to get some Bach Rescue Remedy from the chemist. I wouldn't normally recommend herbals but this stuff seemed to actually help her. Think it was around £8 - £10 If you can calm yourself down a tad and reduce your stress levels perhaps this rection will ease off, if not maybe this Bach is worth a try  ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi chloecat45  I think they were referring to Kisqali aka Ribociclib. Think this is primarily for Pre Menopausal patients who are ER+ Positive and HER2- Negative to treat Advanced or Metastatic breast cancer, but there may be other types this can help with ? BUT - They may also be referring to Perjeta / Pertuzamab which also isn't freely availabe in Scotland yet, although south of the border in England is used in conjunction with Herceptin as the newer regime for HER2+ positive BC (TCHP) Hope this helps with any research :)   G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, As far as I know it is just a blood test but the results can take quite a few weeks to come back. You can read more about the test and common questions clicking this link. Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: Hi lindylooloo  I wouldn't be surprised if this was something like that... Assuming you are post meno so no oestrgoen from your ovaries but oestrogen is still produced by the adrenal glands and from body fat cells. Which will be why you were placed on them originally - so this may be starting to kick in a little after coming off the tablets. You could use the free phone 0808 808 0000 support line number and have a chat with one of the Macmillan cancer nurses about this as they will have more experience of this than I do and may have a helpful solution to it. Jackie still has just over a year on Letrozole so has this to come :( There aren't many around here who are 5 years on from treatment as most gradually stop posting after a few years - once they have gotten used to the 'new normal' There may be several who have stopped taking them early though, so fingers crossed you'll get more replies. Take care, G n' J

There's no such thing as a big fuss where your health is concerned, only being in a boat on a river in Egypt (De-Nile) You keep the appointment and we'll all keep our fingers crossed for you. G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning Ivyivy, Warm welcome to the busiest group here, although sorry to read you have recurrence :( There is a regular monthly chemo club within the group. You can check out the June Chemo Club clicking the coloured text link. There's also a 'chemo tips' link in the very first message which should answer a few questions - Just don't be put off by all the side effects mentioned, they can be so varied, but most only have a couple of the more common effects. Is your chemo going to be FEC or EC followed by Docetaxel and Herceptin ? Fingers crossed the chemo is kind to you, G n' J

Posts.Title: I think I am a NEDdy

Posts.Content: Hi Funda, 1)  FEC-T is three x 3 weekly sessions of FEC followed by three x 3 weekly sessions of T (taxotere) 2)  ACT Would probably be AC chemo followed by T (taxotere) 3) ? but the 12 x weekly one would be Taxol also known as Paclitaxel which is a milder weekly dose of the similar 3 weekly Taxotere/Docetaxel. You can find these listed on the Mac chemo page here. Some like Taxol / Paclitaxel will be listed under individual drugs in the left hand menu. It would help if you could find out the other chemo drug names that are going to be in option 3. This could determine if this is the easier option regarding side effects ? Hope this helps a bit, G n' J
Posts.Title: Different chemo regime options - any advice?

Posts.Content: Hi Angel, I think this means the cells are different shapes and sizes so not uniform. Which could mean the cells look more like ducal carcinoma but is lobular ? Have no idea any further than this - So it's question to ask the surgeon and oncologist what this means in regard to your treatments. Hope this is of some help, G n' J
Posts.Title: my invasive lobular carinoma tested positive for being pleomorphic...

Posts.Content: Morning Angel, I need another sip of coffee to get my head around the maths.... Er' Lobular accounts for around 10 - 15% of all breast cancers and Pleomorphic forms are around 15% of those - So we're talking around 1 in every 400 of all those with breast cancer which is not so much rare as uncommon. Over 4,000 women are diagnosed with BC in the UK every month to give you an idea about this. Don't let this get you fretting though all it means is probably a couple of tweaks to the standard breast cancer treatment to allow for this, as all treatment and chemo regimes are specifically tailored to the patient. Don't forget to take pen and paper with you to write down any answers to your question list and try to have someone with you as 4 ears are better than two in case you miss something. Easily done as you latch onto some comment and forget what else is being said. How are you feeling post surgery, recovering well or any problems ? Oh! and yes, everyone absolutely hates the waiting times - in a lot of cases it seems worse than the treatment :-( Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: my invasive lobular carinoma tested positive for being pleomorphic...

Posts.Content: Hiya, It really is about time these therapy centres read up on massage regarding cancer patients rather than just blanket banning it without a get out of jail free card from a medic. For the most part it's all about their own liability insurance and the risk of being taken to court and publicity :-( As far as breast cancer patients go as long as the therapists stay clear or any arm that may have had lymph surgery on (unless qualified for lymph massage too) it isn't a problem. The text below was taken from the Complimentary Therapies booklet  from BCC. It has been said that people who have had cancer should not have massage because of the risk of moving cancer cells from one part of the body to another. This is not true, although it is important to tell your massage therapist about your breast cancer history. If you have had surgery to the lymph glands under your arm, it is best to avoid having deep tissue massage to that arm unless your therapist has also been trained in a specialist type of massage known as manual lymphatic drainage. G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning  Dianne,  Perfectly normal to have these feelings, your brain has learned to be on high alert for anything that doesn't "feel quite right" and lets you know by reminding you that you have a sword hanging over your head. It takes you back to the early days worrying period of time when you were waiting for scan/biopsy/histology results. When you get to feel like this, grab a friend or family member and do something a little special, or go somewhere nice, even if it's just a yak in a coffee shop just to take your mind off it, anything to stop your smile turning upside down  :-) As our sub text says - Today is a gift. Take Care Dianne, and best wishes,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: living in fear while in remission

Posts.Content: Aw''www,  Gaw'schhh, you gone and made us feel very humble now  LOL Seriously, we know a lot here once treatment is over and folks are in touch with their "new you" they wander off never to come back and be reminded of darker times in their lives, and very best of good luck them for their futures, but several of us ol' timers from the class of 2011/12 and earlier who have been there, done that and put on so much weight the T shirt no longer fits :-) hang around to help others out at what is probably the most scary time in their lives especially when first diagnosed and joined us at Maccyworld will see and hear things that they would rather not, but are are in need of lots of info and reassurance. Phew, that was a long sentence..... There are quite a few of us that just feel pointing new members in the right direction to get the best help for their situation within this vast site , reporting scam/dubious posts to admin and offering info, a helping hand or a shoulder is the very least we can do after owing Macmillan so'ooo much for the help they gave us early on and all through treatment. We have to tread a fine line between not sugar coating stuff, but not scaring the crap out of people too but hey, we're ALL in this together trying to top up each others glasses. This place is amazing and the inner strength of those who come here always inspires us. Enjoy what is left of the weekend, we'll soon get the chance to say good riddance to 2013 a year some would rather forget.....  Hugs, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: 5th chemo

Posts.Content: Hi benimar As I read you are HER2+ Positive, this is definitely a tricky one to come to a decision on :-/ HER2+ receptor cells tend to grow quicker than her2- negative cancers and NICE states you have to have the chemo to get the very effective Herceptin / Perjeta targeted therapies to lower the risk recurrence or even secondaries in the future. I would have a chat with your oncologist to see what the minimal ammount of chemo you would safely need (allowing to compensate for your other issues) to qualify for the HER2+ therapies - or at least ask them to put your data through the NHS Predict Tool to see what % of benefit chemo etc would give you over a 5 and 10 year period. Do ask them outright for an honest prognosis as you need as much info as possible to make an educated decision. Am I right in thinking achalasia is an oesophagus problem ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Mrs B, It can take a couple of weeks to start getting fully into your system and depending on how the side effects kick in can get gradually worse over a period of weeks then stabilise. Posts.Title: Letrezole

Posts.Content: Hiya marshinthesun, Welcome to our not so little place on the web - There are quite a few of us kicking around here so there's always someone around :-) So Invasive Lobular - only around 10% of breast cancers are ILBC  the triple positive is more or less the same as being triple positive for the other types so your treatment won't vary much from the 'norm' If you didn't know triple means ER/PR+ (oestrogen and progesterone) positive and also HER2+ which will mean Herceptin as a treatment as well. Not that anything is normal with treatment :-)  OK 20 questions time.... Have you had any surgery yet or are you having the chemo first and what type of chemo have they got you on and are you having the 3 weekly sessions or the weekly ones ? What part of the lobular bit are you trying to get your head around ? This What is Lobular info may help a bit (link) but if you ask specific questions we'll all chip in and sort your curiosity out. You mention the Mayo Clinic, are you in the US of A or elsewhere ? Hope the chemo isn't being too hard on you, take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Getting back to "normal"

Posts.Content: Hi Jessie,  Wanted to reply earlier but what with the site upgrade and a few hiccups followed by a brief power cut we made it eventually. Jackie was grade 3 (May 2012) Left Mastectomy, 6 x chemo, 18 x herceptin, 15 x rads and still on 5 years worth of Letrozole. Don't get too involved with stats and figures everyone is different all you need to realise is the survivability for breast cancer is around 90% - They will chuck everything you need tailored to your diagnosis to prevent any re-occurance at you. Does it mention of your path report if you are ER+ and / or HER2+ positive or do you not know that as yet ? If ER+ you will get the 5 years of tablets - if HER2+ you will be given Herceptin too. This may help you get your head around your results 'Understanding Your Pathology Report' just click the link. If you have any unanswered questions, fire away, we're all here to help. Take care and best wishes recovering from surgery, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: A Year On

Posts.Content: Hi annie, I daresay you mean well but even DCIS can be a real bugger. There is no 'better' cancer to get, they are all cr@p be it TN, Inflammatory, HER2, BRCA related and all the other many variations. Those with DCIS that are triple positive (HER2+ ER/PR+) face mastectomy, 6 or 8 x chemo a year of Herceptin, then radiotherapy and to top it all off, 5 or 10 years of hormone tablets that make you feel you are aged 80 :( Prior to Herceptin HER2+ in any type of BC was up there as just about the most aggressive and fastest growing type to get lumbered with and prognosis was really poor. That is why there was hell to pay when NICE wasn't going to license Herceptin for use within the NHS (the original postcode lottery drug) We're all in this together and a lot of members here appreciate the information Chloecat provides about her personal experiences from doing it 'her way'  -  Indeed some members have found nuggets of info that provides help easing some treatment side effects in a complimentary direction. No one here (including Chloecat) would ever say this is the way to go but it's great she is willing to share her unconventional approach.  Who knows in the near future maybe we may all be taking some of these compounds as a standard treatment for this evil disease ? Just sayin'  G n' J
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Lilythepig  You don't have to call a halt to eating out - Just be aware of what you can safely eat and where. The list Julia has pointed out to you offers safer alternatives to risky foods. Chinese and Indian restaurants or any other menu items that are 'flash fried' or meat / fish / seafood not thoroughly cooked through is a risk too far.  No blue or undercooked steaks, sushi etc as you say basically a preggers diet :) Supermarket Chinese / Indian food you buy to cook and eat at home are fine as they are produced and pre-cooked to far higher standards - as are chain store KFC, MaccyD type meals. Whether you will actually taste it is another kettle of fish :-/ Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hiya Heidi, 8 sessions of chemo means your body has been well battered for a sustained period and it also wipes out quite a few good cells while doing it's work. Things will slowly improved week by week but it can take a while to build yourself back up. Unfortunately it takes longer than everyone hoped for. Think it is the aches, twinges and general fatigue that are the worst to deal with but it does get better and you'll soon find you are able to do more and enjoy the hols. It's tough enough keeping the little 'uns entertained for 6 weeks plus when healthy, don't beat yourself up about it you are doing all this so there will be many more summer holidays to share :-) Take care and best wishes for supermum, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi isingbass, As you can see the biggest concerns are what your job entails and how physical it is, how your skin reacts to the accumulative effects after the first week or so and how much daily hassle it is to get to and from your appointment. For us it was 40 miles away, so a round trip of 80 miles daily (400 per week) parking etc - so by the time we left the house it was around 3 hours before we got back home. As long as your employer is aware that although you could be fine the first week or two it may more of a problem for you weeks 3 - 5 if you do start getting sore G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic  The main difference is that Exemestane is steroid based where Anastrozole and Letrozole aren't. BCC has this leaflet about it - bcc46_exemestane_2016_web.pdf G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi  Jo, Anyway you can twist their arm and get a line fitted. Assuming you are not getting Herceptin seeing as you didn't mention it which would help with that also. A line is so'ooo much easier, not only for the fluids going in, but for any bloods taken too. Only downside is it has to be flushed once a week to stop it getting blocked. Jackie got hers fitted after it took them ages to get the 1st lot of chemo in.  I'm surprised they didn't fit one after you mentioned it the 2nd time. Might be a more positive outcome if you phone and ask your Onco Dr instead of the nurses. Worth a try ?  Hope this helps and very best of luck,  George & jackie.
Posts.Title: collapsing veins in chemo arm!

Posts.Content: Hi Shirls,  Picc lines or the hickman / groshong central iv lines are brilliant.  If you get the chance of having one go for it.  A little discomfort for a couple of days will out weigh easily the vein hassle you get from chemo through a cannula. Sessions are quicker too. Jackie had a Groshong line in for around 15 months (chemo and herceptin) no problems whatsoever with it. They used hers for taking bloods too as an added bonus. There is some info here about PICC lines and a video - Central lines are listed on the left and side if you wish to check and compare. Adding to what Moll mentioned - the onco sister trained me to flush the line weekly to save us coming in to the unit. For obvious reasons it has to be carried out under sterile practice. G  n' J
Posts.Title: picc lines

Posts.Content: Hello Pat, No doubt you will hopefully get some replies from the good ladies here who have also had calcifications. Until then we can shed a bit of light on them. They are usually benign harmless calcium salt specs, but (you knew there was going to be a but didn't you) if when they look at the pattern of these specs and see anything unusual they will check them out further as they can become pre-cancerous so they are doing the right thing by getting a biopsy. There is an info page on the Breastcancercare uk web site just click the green text link to get some idea of what they are. Don't feel alarmed by this, it's just they want to keep you waiting even longer, as if one week waiting wasn't enough eh  :-( Hope this helps for now, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Docetaxel - please tell me it gets better??

Posts.Content: What a lot of us knew all along has been confirmed - It's official Chemo Brain isn't all in your mind..... Cancer Research UK (CRUK) has recently updated their web page about Chemo Brain with further information about it. Just hit the link to have a read. Thought it would be a great opportunity to have a laugh about all this too, so I'll start the ball rolling. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ When Jackie was starting her chemo she had a Groshong iv line fitted as she was also having 18 x Herceptin. The sister in the onco unit asked if we wanted to avoid coming into town weekly (a 25 mile round trip) she would show me how to flush the line etc. Great, I can do this........ My chance to step up to the plate and actually do something useful. I got on so well first time at the unit under supervision, but it was a different matter first time at home............. It had been drummed into me exactly how to go about this and to keep everything very sterile. Opened a syringe pack and it flipped out of the packet across the room and our cat ran after it, so had to open another  (Not a good start) Went to fill the second syringe from the saline bottle and managed to get most of it running down my arm and dripping from my elbow and used two full bottles to get about 20 mil in the syringe. They must have known me so well as we seemed to have several of everything  :-) Ended up shutting the cat out of the room as he found the dangling iv line too much of a temptation. Then I found they latex gloves they gave me fitted a five year old perfectly, they were so small it was like I had webbed fingers and then one split. Right, all packs now opened and gloved up, lets get on with this..... How did that nurse unfold those little alcohol wipes wearing latex gloves so easily, Gr'rrr. Grasping the other empty syringe I undid the cap from the line and proceeded to withdraw a little blood first to clear the line before flushing. That went ok, Ooops a little blood comes out the end and misses the bib altogether, good shot on the cream jumper though. By this time we are laughing so much we didn't care anymore. After using about half a roll of steritape most of it attached to my gloves I managed to get enough on Jackie to hold the line in place. It was a sharp learning curve but after a few flushes I got quite proficient at it, but we still crack up when we talk about my 1st time. Which just goes to show it's not only those having chemo that suffer from chemo brain LOL G n' J

Posts.Content: Hello Meeralax, Welcome to the Breast Group, a great place to be at a tough time. What you are feeling is very normal, it's a combination of your bodies reaction to the all battering it has had and the uneasy feeling that you still feel rough even though your treatments are nearly over. It can take good 6 - 12 months for you to recover and clear the residue chemo from your system. You mention your feet feel numb, are your fingers OK or are they suffering from numbness, pins and needles a bit as well ? This sounds like a touch of Peripheral Neuropathy which is nerve damage and is mostly but not always from either Taxotere / Docetaxel or Taxol / Paclitaxel Have you taken this up with anyone (GP or Onco) as you can get meds that ease it..... Please try not to feel lonely, you are definitely not alone, at a guess well over half of the ladies here get moments like this even when surrounded by family and friends. It's like no one can really understand what you have been through and how you now feel. How are the Rads going for you - any problems arising from those ?  This far into your rads 23 sessions will no doubt be making you feel tired too, what with that and all the daily traveling which won't be helping. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Hello Newbie Here

Posts.Content: Hi KitKaty,  A central iv line or PICC is the best way to protect your small lower arm and hand veins from accidental chemo damage - The chemo drugs are very powerful and if not mixed / diluted enough or pushed through too quickly it can lead to leaking into surrounding tissues and can leave your veins permanently hardened and resembling twiglets a quite painful condition. It is not something that occurs very often but it does happen,  so It makes sense to try and avoid this risk if you can. I think having veins like that for the rest of my life would be more freaky. There is a lot more information here about chemo delivery at the cancer research uk website. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Not_half  or G'day! Thanks for bumping this Lesley as it brought it to my attention Some can lose a few nails due to chemo but it isn't one of the more common side effcts apart from nail ridges, colouration changes etc. However my wife lost ALL 20 of her nails over an 8 week period - This started happening about 2 months after her last Docetaxel and was a bit of a surprise.  If we had been forewarned we could have saved them all and made a Voodoo Necklace to sell on eBay  lol They did turn up in some odd places too - surviving a washing machine cycle hiding in a sock - in the bath or bed... Good news is that when her nails lifted there was a new but thinner nail already formed underneath so she didn't actually go nailess. I'm assuming these grew during the 3 month post tax period? Are you still having chemo ? as this may mean you may not have the new nail layer underneath. Most here who don't taped their loose nails with stuff like steri-strip plaster to avoid getting them caught or snagging on clothing or bedding  etc. If you are still on chemo last thing you want is an open wound on your fingers. Hopefully some of the other ladies here can advise what they did to help with piano key fingernails :-/ Take Care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Internal Mammary Nodes - can they be removed ?

Posts.Content: Hi Marie,  They really should standardise all the hormone inhibitor tablets. Letrozole, Tamoxifen, Arimidex etc they all seem to have the same problems with the fillers (added compounds to dilute the drug for slower release or many other reasons) They are not allowed to make them exactly the same as the original because of patents - all they need by law is to contain the correct dosage of letrozole drug per tablet in them  - same goes for all the other anti hormone tabs.  This also explains why some are dif shapes and colours. They mustn't look exactly like the originals  - it's a minefield :-( Problem is everyone reacts differently. A brand that suits someone else may not suit you and vice versa. It's really a case of making notes about which ones you take and how you 'feel' after you have been on them a couple of weeks. Then after a while when you have tried several dif makes you see a pattern emerging. Then is the time to make a choice and ask your pharmacy to just get those ones for you. It's not easy as there can be six or more generic companies making these tablets after the original makers license runs out. Coupled with the fact the original makes usually tend to be more expensive than the other brands making them cheaper to supply. They are cheaper because these generic tablets don't need testing as the original was, and they have no research and trials to pay for up front. The original makers name for Letrozole is Femara, you can still get it, but it is now the most expensive so unless it states Femara on your repeat prescription you can be supplied with any make which is called Letrozole. A lot of gp's and others may try to tell you they are all the same, but those taking them know this simply isn't true. Sorry it's a pet hate of ours, almost turned into a rant  LOL Take care, hope you find one that's suitable, G n' J

Posts.Title: let down again

Posts.Content: Hi  Grapevine,  Sounds to us like a bad case of chemo anxiety, fear of any / all the side effects you feel you may encounter in a few days time. Try not to stress, easier said than done we know, but no amount of fretting will alter the outcome and only make you feel worse. You just have to go with it. It probably won't be too long before you catch up on your sleep as you'll feel so wiped out you won't be able to fight it and you can crash out having sofa snuggle sessions. Maybe you'll be one of the lucky ones who sail through it, everyone is different after all........ Write a brief daily chemo diary noting any s/e's and temp variations, how you are feeling and if you encounter anything that causes you sickness, stress or pain inform your onco unit and get some help, They wouldn't want you to suffer in silence so please don't  :-)   There are remedies for the side effects so claim them as soon as you feel you need help.  The diary can also be a good comparison point for future treatments but you soon get used to what to expect and all the chemo sessions get ticked off so quickly once you start. We're at the far end of treatment, and don't post here as much as we used to. Jackie has just 3 more sessions of 18 herceptin and her line can come out and has been back at work for  4 months. Loving the new normal and even her Labradoodle curly hair which was poker straight before. Do keep us up to date with how you are progressing, we'll all guide you through this and try to keep a smile on your face.  Take care,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Not sleeping

Posts.Content: Hi Ann51   FEC is well know for giving you an almost instant headache which over 12-24 hours can become the hangover from hell  :( Apart from keeping yourself well hydrated which does help a bit, as you have found tablets that usually relieve headaches don't seem to touch this. For most this does ease off after a few days but can leave you with fuzzy head for around a week.  If you are one of the unfortunate souls who suffered from headaches or migraine prior to BC no doubt the FEC may make it may feel worse than what you were used to ? If it is of any help you can alternate with Paracetamol and something like Ibuprofen so you can take tablets 2 hourly - as long as the other tablets don't contain any paracetamol to avoid overdosing on it. G n' J

Any particular reason for thinking this could be Phyllodes as there are quite a few other benign breast conditions this could be instead ? Like Carolyn said this feeling of being disconnected is very common and a very natural state of mind, you probably went through something very similar with your original diagnosis too - Almost like you are looking in on someone else's problem. Posts.Content: Hi Pat, A lot of ladies have had very good results from hormonal therapy shrinking tumours down. Whether this was because of Anastrozole or Letrozole I'm unsure. I know Heather77 who has just had surgery was taking Letrozole for a year prior to surgery and her post surgery pathology results were excellent. The newest published comparison (2011) between Anastrozole and Letrozole I found was carried out by the Edinburgh Breast Unit, Western General Hospital which you can read here. It is by it's very nature a bit 'techie' as it is aimed at other medical folks, but you should be able to read between the lines and gain some info. As to why some choose one over the other I haven't any idea - I assume it is based on all the info they have on your age, diagnosis and medical history etc. If you are ER/PR+ positive and the tablets are cutting off a cancer food food supply that has to be a good thing and outweigh the side effects ? Hope this is of some help, G n' J

Posts.Title: Time off work

Posts.Content: Morning Comper,  I think you are stressing too much over them using this 'Invasive' word. Nearly all breast cancers are invasive - it certainly doesn't mean it has invaded all over the place within you personally. It just means it has grown through the duct or milk lobule wall that it started in and it only has to reach a size of around 5mm to do that. As for analysing every ache and pain you have to learn to control that as you will be doing this for the rest of your life now. Once diagnosed we are so worried about re-occurance that first fear never goes away so for your own sanity you have to think what the heck, what will be will be and get on with it, or life becomes a misery. What are those lyrics from Disney's Frozen Let It Go - It's funny how some distance, makes everything seem small. And the fears that once controlled me, can't get to me at all It's time to see what I can do, to test the limits and break through. No right, no wrong, no rules for me. I'm free! In a few months you will be free too. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Confused about type of chemotherapy for Breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Shepherdess  Sorry to see you have no replies as yet - There must be others here with a needle phobia ? I don't know if this is of any help at all but you would be having needles for the pre med before either surgery and you probably had a core biopsy needle used to diagnose you at the breast clinic ? A similar hollow needle is used to place the titanium marker so would be nothing worse than you already had.  Opting for a mastectomy instead of a WLE (lumpectomy) seems a bit of a drastic step to feel forced into :-/ I do hope someone else with a fear of needles replies to you with options they found helped with this dilemma.  Maybe hypnotherapy or something that slowly gets you to accepting and overcoming this fear. First of all you need to make it very clear to your medical team that you are not just a bit afraid of needles, but that they scare the crap out of you. They should take you seriously and totally numb the area first, maybe take a stress ball or something similar with you and concentrate on squeezing the life out of that rather than thinking about what is happening ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Scared of needles

Posts.Content: Morning Mvi2017  Sorry to read you are going through all this stress and worry so soon after having your baby :( Everyone here will agree; at first this is like, they must be talking about someone else, this can't be me :-/ Inflammatory is fairly uncommon (only around 5% of breast cancers)  so although you have joined the correct group you will find it isn't as active as this one, so do please join this main breast group as well because although inflammatory is fast-tracked the treatments are basically the same - although not in the most common order - Inflammatory patients are usually given chemo prior to surgery. The symptoms for Inflammatory Breast Cancer (info page link) can be quite different to other breast cancers which can include skin taking on an orange peel appearance, dimpling,  pinkness, feeling hot, nipple discharge etc Know it is hard but if you do feel the need to use Dr Google please stick with reputable sites like Macmillan, BreastCancerCare and Cancer Research UK (CRUK) as a lot of the info out there is well outdated and worryingly misleading :( Fingers crossed for tomorrow's results, take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Have to admit she has our appreciation for the message she is trying to put across. If you feel the time is right and you want to go the recon route, you read through all the different methods of recon (if given the choice) and go for the type of recon which you feel is best for you without any idea of what the final outcome can look like. Imagine a lot of us don't actually realise how much damage and scarring to other areas will follow the surgery. Another point is the huge amount of people who "unfriended" her after she posted the images. Posts.Title: help - what to do if i get a cold during chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi hayleycm  Warm welcome to the Mac Community, not a club anyone ever expected to join :( Sometimes the HER2 testing part of the pathology can take 3 weeks or so to come through - Do you know if any tissue was also sent off for an Oncotype test as this can add another 1-2 weeks to that as well ? The upside of this prolonged wait means at least you should be well healed before any other treatments (if needed) are offered. Posts.Content: Hi Andrea, Looks like you got a shedload of replies - nice eh :-)  Macmillan has an age limit of 16 and unfortunately the groups for younger members are child cancer related from a parent of child patient aspect, so basically are for adults. There is a brilliant uk website for children who have a parent diagnosed though called RipRap. It has been vetted by the Cancer Research UK (CRUK) charity and is recommended by them in cases just like this.  Do check it out and see if you feel it may be suitable for your children as they may feel the need to mix and chat with their own age groups about their worries and concerns. Mouseover or click the coloured 'beans' at riprap to check out their areas. Hope this is of help. Seems a lot of your Q's have been sorted, but if you need any specific info just holler. We're only a mouse click away and we're all here to help. Take care, George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: New Person!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Saranghae, What are the chemotherapy drugs you mum has been given up to now - FEC by any chance ? You mention she may be going onto a weekly chemo regime and yes Taxol also known as Paclitaxel is the most common breast cancer chemo that is given weekly. It has half the potency of Docetaxel (which is given every 3 weeks) but being weekly is just as efficient at doing the job but is kinder in regards to side effects as it carries lower toxicity - so 9 weeks of Taxol is the equivalent of 3 x 3 weekly Docetaxel which is the standard dosage in the UK (usually following 3 x FEC) The surgery aspect depends on the amount of shrinkage from the chemo. If the results keep coming back good they will carry on and she will probably have the complete course. If it looks like they chemo has gone as far as it can with shrinkage they will operate and she may have to continue to finish the chemo course after surgery It doesn't really matter which way round this is carried out as long as the way they go about it is best for her. Her tumour being ulcerated will benefit from the chemo first as it will zap any cells that may escape from the tumour. There is some info about Taxol here.... Hope this is of some help, it must be really tough for you being so far away from your mum. If you have any other questions do reply, we're all here to help. Take care and good luck to your mum with her continuing chemo. G n' J

Noticed you haven't actually joined the group yet, so if you wish to you can find the 'Join' button under the groups title. The 4 or 5 figure they gave you isn't a cancer grade as such, as that only goes up to 3 but sounds more like the grade the breast screening technicians give to what they see and find. From 0 to 5 and is called a BIRADS Score. A score of 4 or 5 is classed as suspicious and will trigger biopsies. Have you been given a date for the biopsy results yet ? Good Luck, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne, Don't fret about it, it was said a bit tongue in cheek. But Jackie and a lot of other ladies on these type of tablets do have a few twinges first thing in the morning but they do ease quite quickly once you get mobile. As for your Dexa Scan (click link for more info) - The first one is to get 'base figures' they will check it again after you have been on them a few months to compare figures. If your bones show a lowering of their density it's then you will be given the bone strengthening tablets. Jackie takes one Alendronic Acid tablet a week and Adcal+ and Vit-D3 daily. The scan only takes 30 - 40 minutes. G n' J

Posts.Content: Evening OMG, That is so good to hear after you last message seems it's working it's way out of your system now little by little. Don't go overdoing anything it's early days and don't forget week two is low white count week so try and stay clear of anywhere you may be at risk of picking up bugs. No kids birthday parties, school visits, be wary of doctors waiting rooms etc, and if you need to, shop when the stores are quieter like early morning. Don't become a prisoner though get out into the sunshine if you feel up to it. It's only for a week - come week three you'll feel ready to take on the world, well, not quite but ready for round two. Take care OMG, nice to hear you are feeling a bit better, George & Jackie

Posts.Content: Hi Vonnie, You certainly are getting a rough ride from this TC cocktail :-( Various eyesight problems are a known side effect of some chemo drugs inc TC - It is probably tied in with chemo affecting the nerves rather than your eyes, same as with your feet and toes. This is called Peripheral Neuropathy This can be tingling and / or numbness but in some cases it can lead to feeling painful like burns and can even blister so do keep an eye on them. Friction tends to make this worse things like step exercises, walking uphill, or stairs so try to keep the pressure off whenever you can. It can also affect your hands so be careful with the friction thing again especially with simple tasks like unscrewing bottle caps or jar lids etc. Sounds like a duvet afternoon on the sofa may be on the cards today. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Avi, Yes, totally normal, if anything taste issues can be worse on the Docetaxel part :-( Easting a little fresh pineapple or a ginger nut biscuit or drinking a little ginger beer prior to eating can wake up your taste buds a bit but if your mouth starts getting sore (possibility of mouth ulcers) don't use the pineapple. Some people at this stage go one of two ways - Finding spicy well flavoured foods are the only ones they can actually taste the flavours in, or those who can only manage bland tasting food. Another thing which can help with a furry mouth is a rinse with bicarbonate of soda. There is more info about eating / taste problems you can read by clicking here 'Eating Problems and Cancer' No doubt you will get plenty of replies as this is such a common problem. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hiya SOD (That looks so wrong) er' Dawn, Keytruda is the trade name, the drug name is Pembrolizumab made by Merck. It was originally trialled and used to treat melanoma. Now they are trialling it for some Head & Neck and Lung cancers and also those who are TNBC (triple negative) and it is the first trial of a Monoclonal Antibody drug that works like Herceptin for those that are HER2- Negative. Part of the trial arm is also for those who are HER+ positive but whose cancer has spread despite having Herceptin. I think but am not certain but I think it's for those who are diagnosed as 'advanced' but that could be adbvanced head &neck and lung patients. It would well be worth checking out what the criteria is for those who Triple Neg. So could be very good news on the horizon for TNBC'ers. There is a bit of info here about it. I'll have a browse around later and see if I can find any trials that are UK based. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: New Keytruda cancer seeking Immune boosting drug

Posts.Content: Hi Tiggy62  You are certainly not alone with this. Nearly everyone really underestimates the hours they can handle on a phased return :( Especially in a demanding nursing / caring role as most of the shifts are long hours. A lot of employers in health care seem to be unwilling to accommodate short hour shifts as it messes their rotas up and if your phased return is trying one long shift per week it takes you the other 6 days to recover from it :( Another issue which rears it's head is post cancer treatment you tend to lose confidence in picking up where you left off, where you easily made correct snap decisions you now really have to think about things more. It's as if you no longer trust yourself regarding your abilities. Even stuff you took for granted like drug calculations and administering can seem a nightmare to get back into ? Rather than trying to muddle through and feeling even worse about yourself, do tell them you need more time to get back into the swing of things and get a more realistic phased return put in place. 2 weeks is nowhere near enough time to build on, you would need more like 3 maybe 4 months of gradual increase. You have been through a heck of a lot and post chemo it can take a year for all the good cells that got wiped out to get back to near normal levels. You say 9 months off but in reality you probably didn't finish your chemo sessions until what, late March time ? You can do this, just ease yourself into it slowly. Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Advice for radiotherapy burns

Posts.Content: Hi Karen / Warrior k, Welcome to the breast group - a great place at a tough time. Looks like you will be here for the long haul, the lovely ladies here will make you feel welcome and you can all support and help each other and even share a few smiles along the way. Having all your lymph nodes removed is more painful than just having a few removed as a sample and as you are probably finding more sore than the breast surgery too. There can be a lot of nodes as well - everyone has a different number. It can be as few as 8 but some ladies have over 30.... Obviously the more they need to remove the bigger the surgery wound. Don't know what pain relief they have given you but if it doesn't seem to be doing much do try and get some better ones as the annaesthetic fades off it may get a little worse before it starts getting better, a few days after surgery you may get a little teary too, not only because of what you have been through, it is also an annaesthetic side effect. It's a bummer they found cells in your nodes but in a lot of cases there are. It's the lymph nodes job to trap these to stop them going elsewhere in your body, so in that respect they have done their job. It's early days as yet but I assume you have been given a leaflet with the post breast surgery exercises in ? As for the chemo it is usually 6 sessions, sometimes 8 spaced 3 weeks apart - so we're talking around 20 weeks in total. Sounds a long time but it's surprising how quickly the sessions get ticked off. The most common chemo regime is called FEC-T which is 3 or 4 sessions of each. Mostly it's FEC (fec is 3 separate drugs) first then T which is Taxotere (also known as Docetaxel) but not always in that order. Don't be too alarmed at some of the posts here about chemo, no doubt about it, it's tough at times because it has a tough job to do, but you do get a good week every session. Some find it harder than others as it treats everyone differently. Looks like you got another tough 2 weeks thinking time before you get the surgery results ;-( Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Birty, Bums, Sorry to read Mr T has introduced you to his friend 'pain'  -  Day 4 puts it right on schedule as it takes a little longer to get into your system compared to FEC It's weird how some have more joint / bone pain with T than others - I have read posts here in the past where one lady even had to get up and down stairs on her bum 'cause her legs / hips ached so much, while others seem to more or less get away with it :-/ Phone your your onco unit and get some better pain relief to tie you over until this stage passes - It is recommended you don't take co-codamol for more than 4 days or so as they can become addictive ? You could try ibuprofen and paracetamol as you can alternate between these and take one dose every 2 hours instead of 4 hourly. There is better pain relief out there, so try to get some help - I'm sure there are a few lovely ladies here who can tell you what they took to ease this when things got tough. Hope it eases soon but don't suffer in silence Birty.  G n' J

Posts.Content: Purina Diet  :) I have a Bearded Collie and picked up a large bag of Purina at Tesco's. While queuing at the check out a woman behind me asked if I had a dog. On impulse, I told her that no, I was starting The Purina Diet again, although I probably shouldn't because I ended up in hospital last time, but that I had lost 30 pounds before I woke up in an intensive care ward with tubes coming out of most of my orifices and IVs in both arms. I told her that it was essentially a perfect diet and that the way that it works is to load your pockets with Purina nuggets and simply eat one or two every time you feel hungry and that the food is nutritionally complete so I was going to try it again. Horrified, she asked if I 'd ended up in the hospital because the dog food poisoned me. I told her no; it was because I stepped off the kerb to sniff a Labrador's arse and got hit by a car. G n' J
