Posts.Content: Hi JakeB, Welcome aboard the chemo express mystery tour :-/ Couple of things first off, if you haven't already do select the join this group button for the Breast Group so if you need to you can post a new discussion (the button for that doesn't appear until you actually join the group)  At the top of this page you will see 'Add To Favourites' - select that and this chemo club discussion will be added to the Favourite's tab on your profile page to make it easier to find next time you are here. If you 'hit' the number 1 at the bottom of the page it will take you to the first post and there is a link to Chemo Aids which you can read to help you with any side effects. FEC is mostly associated with feeling nauseous. When you have your first session you will be given anti sickness meds....Take them even if you feel ok, because it's easier to keep on top of it if they are in your system. If you hold back and are actually sick you won't know if you brought the tablets up or not :-(   It's recommended you drink 2 litres of fluid a day to help flush it through your kidneys and recover quicker. You may find you go off hot drinks (which may taste weird or even awful) but there are plenty of alternatives. Are you using the 'cold cap' to try and preserve some of your hair, or not bothering ? Keep posting if you have any questions, as there's not much time for us to get some answers in for you by tomorrow... Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, Congrats to your son for his results, hopefully they should help him get into the uni of his choice :-) You mention PICC line, please don't have any fear of these if one is offered 'go for it' the inconvenience far outweighs the risk of getting chemo damaged veins and they also use them for all the 'bloods' that get taken. They are fitted in around 30 minutes using a local so you barley feel it and it's a tad uncomfortable for a day or two rather than painful. A couple of ladies here have had problems with them but most find them well worth it. You can read more about them using this link.... Regarding the T part of chemo - You white count can bottom out more with T than FEC. Some health authority area units give G-CSF injections as standard to build up your white count but you do still have to monitor your temp a couple of times a day (including first thing in the morning prior to taking any paracetamol) to get a more accurate reading. If your temp goes above 37.5 they ask you to phone the unit, to come in and get an infection check and possibly give you anti-biotics. G n' J
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Maria  / Maria 712  Pleased to read after all your normal pre surgery nerves it doesn't seem to be as bad as you were expecting. How it pans out from here is that the removed tissue goes to pathology and they double check there is a margin of healthy tissue around it. This ensures it has all been removed. In some cases if margins are not clear or too tight to call they have you back in and take a little more tissue. This news can knock you back a bit if they find this but it is soon sorted out. It will takes about a week to get this information from the lab, they may also check it for hormone receptor status if they haven't mentioned ER positive or negative or HER2 to you yet. Once you get told you have clear margins that means all the tumour is gone. All other follow up treatment like chemo, herceptin (if needed) radiotherapy and any hormone inhibitor tablets you may be offered is all added insurance to minimise any recurrence at a later date.  This stage is classed as NED no evidence of disease - That is as good as it gets because they simply cannot find single cells anywhere in the body at a cellular level but chemo should zap those if any exist, this is less likely seeing you say your nodes were clear :) 18 chemo sessions seems a lot, so I think you need clarification on this, you will get that information from the oncologist. The standard dose for Herceptin is 18 sessions and this is given with chemo so perhaps this is what they mean ? As soon as you hear you have clear margins, you can rest assured the tumour has definitely gone :) Good luck with your recovery and getting news of clear margins - Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Ar1ene  Recovery from breast surgery depends on the extent surgery you had - assume apart from the WLE you also had a sentinal node biopsy where a couple of the nearest lymph nodes are also removed ? Most here will say no driving for 3 weeks and no hoovering and keeping ironing down to a minimum especially if the side operated on is your dominant arm/hand and seat belt hassle if this was right side wle. Posts.Content: Hiya margym, It's common practice at most radiotherapy planning appt's. There is more info about it all here. Don't have any worries about the tattoo part, they are very small dots. Assume you will be going onto Letrozole, Anastrozole or something similar for 5 years then ? Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: radiotherapy planning appt

Posts.Content: Morning Carrie, Telling close family about your diagnosis is a toughie, but it will help you to share as this will lift the burden you have been keeping mostly to yourself for a while. To have a read of some advice regarding telling adults you can check out page 19 in this Talking About Cancer booklet (link). Telling your girls will be the worst, do if possible tell them all together. Firstly it saves you having to repeat everything and the natural teary session again but it saves anyone from feeling left out and wondering why they got told last ? Do check out Talking To Children and Teenagers  see page 4 (teens start on page 20) for some info about how you may need to be cautious with info regarding your 15 year old it's a hormonal angsty time at best without the bombshell you are about to drop. Luckily she has her older sisters to help her as well. They will pick up on how you break the news so if possible try to do this in a calm way or you could frighten them into thinking they are going to lose you if you appear really frightened about it all. Be prepared if you can by having some info written down in case they ask questions, if it's something you can't answer yet ask you team or post here depending on how much you have been told so far. If you are going to be given chemo ask if your chemo unit has scalp cooling facilities (not all do) this can save some of your hair - it is a bit hit or miss - works well for some but not everyone benefits from it as any of these drugs used affect people differently. Good luck with informing everyone, keep plenty of tissues handy but most of all although you may be scared witless try to keep everyone positive - remember over 90% with BC kick cancer where it hurts and gets through all this. You got grade 1 on your side, even if this gets upgraded to a 2 after closer inspection, know it's not much consolation but this could have been so much worse. Take care, don't envy you, we all found this part emotional. G n' J
Posts.Title: Telling the parents tomorrow??

Posts.Content: Hiya, Did you ever have a DEXA bone density scan before starting the Letrozole or Anastrozole ? as these can cause bone thinning and osteopaenia - If you haven't had one get a dexa scan referral from your GP to check this out. Switching from Letrozole to Anastrozole can help but mostly you end up just swapping one lot of side effects for another set :-( If you have already had one this problem may need some help with as 5 years is a long time to be on these pesky tablets. J is nearly 3 years into Letrozole and also has to take Adcal+ Vit D3 and Alendronic Acid to help with the joint pains. There has been replies here about K2 and chelated magnesium helping so hopefully you will get some replies about those. Another good point raised by Rain Forest is the make of your tablets. There are around half a dozen companies making these and it could be another 'brand' will be kinder to you. The drug is the same it's the different fillers which can cause issues. If you let us know which brand you are taking other ladies here can reply mentioning which ones suited them better, or if they had similar problems with the same make. G n' J

Posts.Title: Triple Negative Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Morning Karen  Lacomtekp  This should sort it out ? Triple positive: positive for oestrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and HER2 Triple negative: not positive for oestrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and HER2 Probable treatment for Triple Positive = surgery, chemo, herceptin, radiotherapy and 5-10 years of hormone inhibitor tablets. Probable treatment for Triple Negative = Chemo, surgery, radiotherapy and crossed fingers for 5 years. These two were considered the nasty types to get for recurrence risks - Herceptin has changed that greatly for those who are HER2+ This race is on now for a targeted biological therapy for those who are triple negative and could be promising for TN. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Joyce, The tablets they usually hand out for bone thinning are Adcal-D3 which is calcium based with vitamin D3 and it's more common to get the chewable type rather than a tablet. Let us know what you end up with. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Kismet, Letrozole can cause a higher heart rate and / or palpitations in around 1 in a 100 patients - So it is a known side effect albeit not one of the more common ones. Are you still also taking the med's for speeding up your heart rate, or have you now stopped taking those ? Just wondering is there is some combined reaction going on between them. Otherwise you can probably put it down to the Letrozole. As long as you aren't getting breathlessness with it as that could be a symptom of a blood clot and would definitely need checking out asap. I assume you have a normally lowish heart rate from previously having an athletic lifestyle ? Nearest I get to that is eating 'runner' beans  :) Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: problems getting on forum?

Posts.Content: Hi pearldrops  Sorry to read someone had to pay for this to be fitted under the NHS :( A lot depends on the health authority area - they all seem to have different criteria for the delivery of chemotherapy drugs. Some offer nothing and use the cannula in the back of the hand or lower arm method - other ways include a PICC line which is fitted in the upper arm, an iv line like Groshong or Hickman that is fitted in the upper chest and a Port o' Cath which is mostly fitted in the upper chest but below and covered by the skin. You can read more about these methods clicking this link. It is a shame because if she had asked at the pre-chemo appointment (depending on how they usually administer chemo) she may have been able to have the more common PICC line fitted for free but if she actually asked for the Port and it is something they don't normally do they will of couse offer this as a private procedure :( Maybe this wasn't explained very well to them at the time but as mentioned it may be worth the family involved taking it up with their hospitals PALS (patients advice and liaison service) to at least get an explanation. Hope this is of some help, G n' J

It only lasts a few days and then clears so you just have to get through this stage :-( Take care, and good luck with any side effects. G n' J

Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Cgs54  There are two tests they can use to determine HER2. If the first test is borderline or inconclusive they use the other test to double check, so the status can change because of this. It wouldn't hurt as Jo says to ask them to clarify this for you. If you 'were' triple positive I assume you are still ER/PR+ positive so the TN Group wouldn't be for you in that case. You will be placed onto hormone Inhibitor tablets for 5 - 10 years. NICE states to be given Herceptin you have to have it in conjunction with chemotherapy so if you no longer need the Herceptin this is why you may not need chemo either. They may have said 3% over 5 years but did they give you the predicted figure for 10 years also ? So this is something else to ask the oncologist about when you meet them, oncologists also cover radiotherapy so this could be your next step ? The oncologist may also ask if you want chemotherapy anyway to help avoid recurrence so be prepared for this scenario if your results are boderline for needing chemo or not. Hope this is of some help, good luck with your post op recovery, and keep up with the post surgery exercises they help at the rads stage. Take  care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Anyone here on Megace? (Megestrol Acetate)

Posts.Content: Hi Petrina,  If they told you they are cysts they must be fairly certain that is just what they are or they would have carried out a biopsy on them or at least looked more closely. It is very unusual for ovarian cysts (which are very common) to be cancerous. You can read more about them here. Obviously you now need to get these double checked for your own peace of mind as some can get quite large. If they are only smallish, you may just be monitored for now. As for the side effects of the Tamoxifen, all these hormone inhibitor tablets are tough going. Oestrogen is a feel good hormone and it takes a while to adjust to not having it flowing through you like it did previously hence the mood swings etc. It may be worth you trying a different brand of Tamoxifen as there are several different makes and some find a particular brand easier to cope with and stick with those. If you reply stating which 'brand' you are taking hopefully other ladies here can comment on which brands they have tried and which ones worked better for them ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Mastectomy tomorrow, trying to research reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Gang,  This is a work in progress, bound to have missed loads  :-) If you notice any that are not included or are wrong flag 'em up and I'll edit it, cheers... Good point Litlegem, I'll put in the link for the bcc glossary too as it covers medical terms as well. http://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/breast-cancer-information/glossary Here ya go............  G n' J AI - aromatase inhibitors ADH - Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia-no apparent involvement of surgical margins. ALH - Atypical Lobular Hyperlasia - cells in the lobules that look different from normal cells, but aren't cancer and more cells than there should be. AND - axillary node dissection AWS - Axillary Web Syndrome; associated with Cording as a result of surgery/rads.    B9 (Not Cancer) BC- Breast Cancer Bi-Lat (bilateral, Mastectomy of both breast) BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System score. Indicator of the radiologist's opinion of the absence or likelihood of breast cancer. BMX - Bilateral Mastectomy CMF (Cyclophosphamide Methotrexate Fluorouraci) - chemo combo regimen of breast cancer chemotherapy that combines three anti-cancer agents CT scan - computerized topography,  DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma In Situ) DIEP - deep inferior epigastric perforator: autologous (own tissue) transfer. A refined version of the TRAM flap Dx (Diagnosis) ER (Estrogen Receptive USA spelling) Oestrogen receptor positive+ or negative- FEC (flourouracil/epirubicin/cyclophosphamide) -  chemo combo HER2 + or -, whether your tumor reacts to the HER2 protein or not HT (Anti-hormone Therapy) HRT (Hormone Replacement Therapy) IBC (Inflamatory Breast Cancer) IDC (Invasive Ductal Carcinoma) ILC (Invasive Lobular Carcinoma) IV Line - Hickman or Groshong intravenous tunnelled catheter for administering chemo and taking bloods because of poor veins LCIS (Lobular Carcinoma In Situ) LD flap - Latissimus Dorsi Flap LE - Lymphedema LNC - Lymph node clearance Lump (Lumpectomy) Mets  - (Metastasis) MLD - manual lymph drainage MX - Mastectomy NAC or NSM - nipple sparing mastectomy performed with preservation of the nipple-areolar complex (NAC). NED (No evidence of Disease) Omph (or Ooph) ~ Ovary removal ONC ~ Oncologist PBM - prophylactic bilateral mastectomy PET-CT scan - a combination of PET and CT which superimposes the active cells that ‘light up' on the bodily structures so that the radiologist is reading a single image. PICC - peripherally inserted central catheter.  Used for chemo, it is sometimes known as an "arm port".  PR (Progesterone Receptive)  progesterone receptor positive+ or negative- RADS - Radiation; Radiotherapy Rad Onc (RO) - Radiation oncologist SNB - sentinel node biopsy TAC - Different to Tax - TAC is Docetaxel and Doxorubicn (also known as Adriamycin) and Cyclophosphamide TAX  Taxotere also known as Docetaxel TCH - taxotere, carboplatin, herceptin TE - temporary expanders or tissue expanders TN (Triple Negative) In regards to negative status for ER/PR and Her2 status TRAM flap - Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap

Posts.Content: Hi PinkSparkle  Sorry to see you back here with these worries :( Inflammatory is quite uncommon and there can be other symptoms besides an itchy red patch, but you are doing the right thing getting this checked out - Once bitten, twice shy as they say....... There is an extensive reliable information page about Inflammatory Breast Cancer here you could have a look through the symptoms. Hopefully it will ease your worries and not add to them :-/ How you get through the next few weeks waiting any results is a tougher answer to give. Saying don't worry is easier said than done the only thing I can suggest is to chuck yourself into a hobby or take on a project that will need some concentration to help take your mind off it all. If you find this is causing you sleepless nights you could get a short course of mild sleeping tablets like Kalms if you would rather not go back to the GP - or you may be able to get in to see your own GP ? Just out of curiosity does the steroid cream seem to be helping, or having no effect ? No doubt this has taken you right back to your original diagnosis waiting time emotions - Fingers crossed you get better news this time around. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Going crazy - inflammatory breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi Daisy, Yes, you are correct in that US scans aren't the best for checking lymph nodes. They can see which ones are swollen but not really which position in the 'lymph drain chain' they are although they will know which one the sample was removed from by position recording on the biopsy scanner but this in itself will have no real relation to where along the line it is. With a SNB check a blue dye and a low dose radioactive tracer is injected near to the tumour and the flow is monitored. They use this to find which nodes take up the tracer. The nearest 2 or 3 nodes are those removed for testing. This is nearly always done at the time of breast surgery very rarely on it's own. So they may well wait until surgery before carrying out the snb check. In larger hospitals they can carry out the check while the patient is in theatre and if needed remove all in one go. If not the patient gets recalled and the removal if needed is carried out around a week later. Which can be tough undergoing two ops only a week or so apart. You can read more about SNB here. They can find the sentinel nodes either by tracking the isotope or looking for the blue dye. G n' J

Posts.Title: 3D Tattoos

Posts.Content: Hiya, Where it says HER2 does it have a minus -  or plus + sign next to it because HER2 on it's own isn't actually telling you anything ? The ER8 means it is Oestrogen fed hence you needing the Tamoxifen to stop your oestrogen feeding any cells. The score of 8 is as high as the scale goes as far as I know. Grade 2 at 10mm is fairly good (well it could have been a lot worse anyway) and don't read too much into the invasive part as all breast cancers are or in the case of DCIS can become invasive. If after surgery you are upgraded to a 3 (which sometimes happens) and / or if it turns out you are HER2+ positive this is where the chemo comes in. Just have to keep your fingers crossed on that one. Good luck for your appointment Tuesday, and have a think over the weekend and make a note of any questions you may want to ask. G n' J
Posts.Title: understanding letter received by GP

Posts.Content: Hi Rosiero,  Being HER2+ you will most probably be given Herceptin, these are mostly 18 sessions at three weekly intervals (one year) given either via an iv line through a cannula or the newer way is by subcutaneous injection but not all units are trained up to do this as yet. NICE only allows Herceptin to be used in conjunction with chemotherapy so this will undoubtably mean chemo too. You will have to confirm with your oncology team about this. The ER+ (oestrogen receptive) meaning after any other treatment including radiotherapy if you need that will be followed by five possibly ten years of oestrogen hormone inhibitor tablets. These could be Tamoxifen or Letrozole depending on if you are pre or post menopause. Treatment can be started as early as within one month post surgery providing you already know you don't have to go back for more surgery to get clear margins from the first lumpectomy.  This is how it was for Jackie who had a left mastectomy but was grade 3 ER/PR+ and HER2+ so could possibly be very similar treatment regime for you. When do you find out what they have planned for you ? G n' J
Posts.Title: Treatment after surgery

Posts.Content: Hiya, The blue dye they use is a radio-nucleoid tracer posh techie name that means it is slightly radioactive so they can monitor where it flows / drains to after it is injected. It not only shows them blood flow in and around the cyst, tumour or whatever, it also shows if fluid from the lump is trying to reach or has reached the lymph nodes. From what they see determines how much of the lump they need to remove and hopefully get clear margins and also a guide to how many lymph nodes need removing to check out. This tissue goes to histology and it's them who figure out what it is grade / stage etc and if they need to get you in to take a bit more if it's found they didn't get clear margins and also check any lymph nodes for dodgy cells. The lymph node check is probably what is known as a SNB read about that here. Sentinel Node Biospy. They usually take around 4 (the nearest ones to the lump) - you can have up to thirty lymph nodes each side. Enjoy the weekend and try not to stress too much, G n' J

Posts.Title: Top tips for TAC treatment?

Posts.Content: Morning Daisy,  Sorry to read this is all still a bit up in the air at present but if you turn this on it's head it may help with what is going to happen next. If a patient gets surgery first and there is any lymph involvement they will perform a clearance to find out how many are actually affected and how far along the chain of nodes it has progressed. There can be up to 30 axilla nodes in some cases even more so without a full check it is difficult to say how many could be affected. Big question is what nodes did they FNA sample to establish they were positive. If they were close to the tumour it may be they have not travelled any further, if they were from distant nodes (doubtful as they usually check the nearest ones first) it could be more involved. In your mums case with chemo coming first reason being to shrink down or at the very least halt the growth her team will keep a close eye on her through chemo to check her tumours response to it and as it is a whole body treatment any lymphs affected will also get treated and checked. It all hinges on how she responds to the chemo as to the next move. Some are lucky enough to have massive shrinkage allowing a Lumpectomy (WLE) instead of mastectomy in either case they will probably carry out a SNB (sentinel node check) during surgery. If however at the half way stage she hasn't respond as well as everyone had hoped for, they may well perform surgery then (probably mastectomy and full axilla clearance ?) and continue with chemo and radiotherapy afterwards ? Have they mentioned which chemo regime they want to try her on as yet ? Sorry this hasn't really answered your question, it's very much a wait and watch situation. Might be a good idea to raise these questions with her team when you next meet them. If that seems a long way off, phone and get some information and questions answered. Take care and good luck for your mum with her prognosis. George & Jackie

Posts.Title: lymph node biopsy clear

Posts.Content: Hi littleone31 Some find T easier than FEC depends really on how easier a ride you had with it. Those who have constant nausea find there is rarely any issue with sickness on T but are caught out by how different the effects are by comparison. Taxotere /  Docetaxel gives you a 3 day honeymoon period so sort of lulls you in then you wake up on day 4 feeling achey like when you have flu but this seems to affect both muscles and joints - Oral Thrush is also quite common with T as well   T can also reduce your white blood count more than FEC so do make sure you keep a regular check on your temp and contact the onco unit if it ever reaches the magic 37.5C figure in case you have picked up an infection. Do get involved with the July Chemo Club (link)  if you get any problems or have questions about it all - Most have already been there, done that and are happy to help. Please don't be put off by the huge list of side effects connected with T, most only are affected by three or so and there is always something you can take to ease these. Main thing is to not keep secrets; if you have an issue with anything, share it or nothing will change  G n' J

Posts.Content: Hiya,  Back again  :-)   Our local Macmillan / Onco centre used to stipulate a spike of 38 but reduced it to 37.5 before phoning as it bought them a little more time to treat any infections. Because of your probs with antibio's do be careful regarding your temp as Jackie was admitted two weeks after her 1st FEC because of something as simple as oral thrush which quickly spiralled out of control her temp was 36.6 at night but had jumped to 37.8 by the morning. It meant a 4 day stay as an inpatient on antibio iv drips and tablets. When we phoned the unit and when they said come in straight away we panicked a bit, so it's ( not trying to worry you unduly here ) something they take very seriously when your white count is low while they find out what the cause of the infection is. Lots of us here have had to be admitted at some time, they reduced her chemo dose by 20% so it didn't knock out all her white cells next time around. BTW - It may take a couple of days to get the tabs out of your system so don't expect an instant feel good factor :-) Take care,  G  n'  J

Posts.Title: Hair started to fall out

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly, Know all this chemo malarky is pants and having an easier ride can make it seem a very long ride when you still feel fit enough to stay in control but there is a very good reason why the sessions are spaced out to this length like they are...... Chemo isn't just used to shrink tumours down, it is the main defence to smash any straggler cells that could be floating around elsewhere in the body. Most patients are unfortunately never told why chemo goes on for such an extended period - I just hope by putting this in here it doesn't cause anyone any concerns ? Chemotherapy drugs kill cancer cells by attacking cells that are in the process of doubling to form two new cells. But not all the cells in a cancer will be dividing at the same time. Normal cells go into a long rest period between divisions. Cancer cells do too, although the rest period may be much shorter.  Giving chemotherapy in a series of treatments helps to catch as many cells dividing as possible and so kill them. Hopefully, cells that were resting when you had your first treatment (so didn't die) will be active when you have your next and so will be more likely to die. Multiply this by your number of sessions (usually six) and you can see why missing more than one session could mean you miss out. But it is unlikely that any cancer treatment will kill every single cancer cell in the body. Doctors try to reduce the numbers of cancer cells so much that the remaining cells will be killed off by the body's own defences. Or the cells may just die off naturally. That is why other complimentary treatments are offered too like Radiotherapy, possibly Herceptin (her2+)  Hormone Inhibitor tablets etc. This also partly explains why Triple Neg ladies are at a slightly higher risk as they will only get the surgery, chemo and rads :-( Hope this helps you understand why it drags on for so long but is a proven way of zapping the nasties. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Side effects from Tamoxifen after nearly a year

Posts.Content: Morning poolm4n, Well you have come to the right place to help ease your fears a bit. Yes, there is another fella who had a double mastectomy his member name is Russ-H his last post was about a month ago, so he is still around but doesn't post so often now. If you put his member name with the hyphen into the search this site box above his link should come up. Strangely enough Russ was same age as you (53) when diagnosed, but you haven't been yet and hopefully you won't be. Would be great to find it was just a cyst or benign lump but if your fears are confirmed understand BC is one of the most treatable types to have. You are at the moment what many would call the worst stage - Playing the waiting tests and results stage. It can really mess with your head if you let it. Know it's hard, but you have to try and find things to do, or places to go to take your mind off it all. Don't google random websites stick with reputable places like Macmillan, cancer research uk and breastcancercare uk  there is a lot of misleading very old information out there and treatment has come on leaps and bounds in even the last couple of years. If it is BC ? with your family having 'history' ask your GP about getting a BRCA-1/2 test done, it can take a month or two, so it pays to ask early on if you want one carried out. Reason for mentioning it is that if you do have gene issues it can be passed down to any children but if you are confirmed brca2 it can carry a higher risk of prostate cancer in a similar way to women with brca can have ovary problems. Not trying to worry you even more, just letting you know :-/ There is a Macmillan booklet 'Understanding Breast Cancer in Men' I've put the link in so you can read up on the testing / diagnosing sections- don't bother reading any further in as none of it may end up applying to you - nice thought, that one :-) Here's another link to BRCA1/2 in Men if that may also help you figure out whether to get the test done later on. Hope this helps a bit, very best of good luck waiting results. George & Jackie
Posts.Title: breast cancer in men

Posts.Content: Hi Hilary  /  Dormouse  We are just off out but wanted to pass this on first; until you get some replies from those with experience of brca testing. It is the Royal Marsden BRCA 1/2 Beginners Guide. brca_0.pdf G n' J
Posts.Title: BRCA gene question

Posts.Content: Hi jessbell  Something isn't right here :( 8 - 10 weeks is not an urgent appointment.... An urgent referral has to be no longer than 2 weeks between seeing your GP and getting a breast clinic appointment. These are government directives backed up by NICE - See this NICE link. Especially as you have family links. Either the GP hasn't put this through as urgent or they have and it has been wrongly listed at the clinic, I would contact the GP concerned to check it was put through as urgent and get them to sort it out for you, or phone the clinic back to see what your GP's information stated ? I really feel for you, this is tough enough without being messed about like this :( G n' J
Posts.Title: 8 - 10 week for breast clinic appointment

Posts.Content: Morning Scaredgirl34  Hope your weekend wasn't too stressy after getting some reassuring replies from the lovely ladies here ? My wife was diagnosed ER/PR+ and HER2+ positive in May had all the treatments offered and has come out the other side. I say May but this was way back in 2012 - she had the No Evidence of Disease news at her 5 year review around Easter time and is about to finish her 5 years of Letrozole - Yey!!! I won't kid you there are the odd crap duvet days ahead but mostly it is do'able and as your chemo sessions get ticked off you will find the times goes quite quickly. That far back there wasn't Pertuzamub / Perjeta then either (apart from trials) so if anything the treatment for HER2+ has improved yet again in those 5 years :) Remember you are like a Tea-Bag.... The more they dunk you in hot water the stronger you will get :)) You can do this; and get your 'new normal' life back. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: ER+ and HER2+

Posts.Content: Hi  Chodgy,  Suppose it depends on what your job entails. Have you already had chemo or are you due for it later on ? Jackie felt she could have gone back to work a bit earlier but seeing as she works with some pt's who have mrsa and the ever present risk or norovirus etc her Dr kept her off. She has only just returned on half shifts ( which they were fine with ) after being off work since late May. Other areas like working in schools or other places where bugs are more likely to be present will def be a risk whilst on chemo, same with any type of post op manual work, but if you are just on hormone tabs or herceptin could be do-able if you feel up to it. Finances can be a problem, it's a large drop from a salary to stat sick pay and any annual leave will soon evaporate. If you can manage on SSP for a while have a word with your Dr and get a few more weeks off to fully recover. You know your own situation best go for what you need - but be sure you put your health first eh  :-)    Good luck  George & Jackie.

Posts.Content: Hi rrrosec  I don't know how low this is for you (Hypotension) compared to your average readings but it is worth getting checked out in case it is treatment related. Could be one of many things, low red cell count (anaemia) - cancer meds making your blood pressure medication stronger. You may need a reduction of dosage with your BP tabs or possibly a blood transfusion to top up your red cells. ? You don't want this low reading for too long in case you pass out and hurt yourself. Posts.Title: Experts Needed

Posts.Content: Hi Operahappy, I usually have a quick look at the breast groups overnight posts first thing in the morning as I start work at 6am :( Jackie finished her chemo (FEC-T) around November 2012 and still has slightly numb big toes the rest eased off within 12 months post chemo - so it can take a while.... As long as it doesn't start getting painful and feeling like a burning sensation or blistering as these are signs of PPE (Palmar Plantar Erythrodysesthesia) more commonly called hand and foot syndrome. To help avoid this try to avoid friction to the hands and feet like tight grip used when unscrewing bottle / jar tops etc and stepping type exercises or hill walking which puts friction on the soles of your feet (normal walking is fine) If you want more information about it you could Google CIPN (chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy) or Hand and Foot Syndrome, but only view trusted cancer websites for up to date facts. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Carol, There are quite a few ladies here who were never offered a PICC or any other type of iv line and have posted about problems with badly aching arm veins from chemo and a sore hand from all the needles for bloods and cannulas. If you are being offered a PICC hug the person offering one and say 'YES PLEASE' !!! Only takes around 30 mins or so to fit using a 'local' bit of discomfort for around 24-36 hours while it settles and gives you 18 weeks of freedom from all the other chemo hassles. There are few who have had a slight infection at the picc entry site but this is uncommon. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hiya, Not really especially as you have now finished your chemo. Anything that could have helped with this is preventative and done at the time - It's a case of it's in there and what will be will be. Some chemo units have cooling gloves and bootees that work in a similar way to the cold cap but this is fairly new technology and not many units have them as yet. J had PN affecting her feet and hands post T they gradually recovered but it took quite a while. Both her big toes are still a bit numb and her chemo ended around Oct 2012 :( I would mention it though as they may be able to tell you exactly what they think it is (PN or not) and have some advice about making things easier to cope with.  G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning, Just a quick reply before I shoot off to work :-( Neoadjuvant (before surgery) therapy makes no difference to recurrence risk (compared to adjuvant therapy). It is used to change the timing of other treatments and can change surgical options. Sometimes, neoadjuvant therapy can shrink a tumor enough so that lumpectomy plus radiation therapy becomes an option to mastectomy. Mostly it depends on the size and or position and type of the tumour, patients age (wle rather than mastectomy) and several other factors. G n' J

Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: Morning dragonlady, It can take a while for things to settle down when you first take any of these hormone inhibitor tablets (around 4-6 weeks) but even after that you may still get similar side effects. It may be a combination of starting Tamoxifen on top of all the treatments you have already been through that has pushed you into fatigue rather than just feeling tired :-( Sometimes the make of tamoxifen you are given just doesn't suit you, there are several 'brands' so a different one may be better for you. Can you mention which make you are taking at the moment to see if anyone else has had similar problems with it and found a brand which they found better  ? There is more advice about tiredness and fatigue here, you could also ask your GP about a blood test to see if you are a bit anaemic or lacking in some vitamin or other ? Maybe it's your bodies way of telling you you need to stay in third gear for a while longer to let your body recover some more - so many here hit that 'wall' trying to do too much too soon ? Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen for 10 days & shattered

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy d  Long time no see (or should that be read) Tinnitus and other ear / balance problems are not listed as a common side effects of hormone inhibitor tablets but should be. There are loads of messages on breast cancer forums from those seeking advice about it - whether it's tinnitus, vertigo etc It's good you are being referred for an MRI to hopefully rule out anything nasty but from what I have read the chances are this is Anastrozole related are quite high. If this does seem to be anastaozole related maybe switching to another type of Ai like letrozole or exemestane would fix it, but would then possibly give you different side effects :( You can check out a whole shedload of posts about Tinnitus (183) at BreastCancer.Org in their 'Hormonal Therapy During and After' discussion page. Don't know if you have had an MRI before but the are a bit claustrophobic and very noisy. Great to read apart from the tinnitus you are getting on well with your 'new normal' Has your brand of anastrozole changed and could that be a reason this has now started or is it something you have always mildly suffered with on and off but now seems more permanent ? Hope you get some more messages from friends you met here last year :) I'm having hassle getting the link to work - To read them you will need to copy / paste all the below text into your web browser... https://community.breastcancer.org/posts/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&search_builder[keyword]=tinnitus&search_builder[author]=&search_builder[source]=forum_78&search_builder[date_range]=&commit=Search Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Unilateral TInnitus and worried 18 months on .

Posts.Content: Hiya Claire,  It's only a matter of time before this whole body fatigue thing kicks in. You take a fair battering as you constantly switch from one lot of treatment to another and your body doesn't get time to fully recover from any of them. The tiredness thing will carry on for a good 2 - 3 weeks after rads too - only thing you can do is rest when your body tells you it's had enough and during times when you feel a bit brighter go for a short walk if only window shopping round the stores or maybe to a park or somewhere a bit more peaceful and serene if you prefer. As long as you get a little exercise to stop you seizing up all together. If it seems to be gradually getting worse have a word with your GP about getting a blood test done to see if you are a tad anaemic especially if you are not eating healthily because of treatment. You know what's coming next don'cha 'Coping With Fatigue'  yes a Maccy booklet I'm afraid - LOL Well it's there if you want to check it out :)  Don't expect too much of yourself for a while it may only take a few minutes getting zapped but it stays working within you 24/7 Get the rads out the way and then set your alarm clock for quarter past Spring and you'll be fine. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Paclitaxel - TAXOL

Posts.Content: Hi Von, Nearly all of our usual drinks fell by the wayside too. Ended up mostly drinking those fruit flavoured still or fizzy waters you can multi-buy in the supermarket. The only hot drink J could get any flavour from was Galaxy drinking chocolate. As for food it mostly goes one of two ways - Some prefer bland food like porridge, toast, crackers, baked potato meals, milky puddings etc and the other half find they now prefer spicy foods to enjoy any flavour at all. We lived on curries, chilli bakes and saucy pasta based dishes for around six months. Sometimes you can play the small portion on a small plate trick so the look of a piled up plateful of food doesn't put you off. As long as you are having a mix of fresh fruit and veg and eating little but often you'll be fine. It just takes a bit of experimenting to find what you prefer. You could try looking here for some ideas and recipes. Take care, G n' J

It could be poor circulation but If it is Peripheral Neuropathy (info link) from the 'T' you never know in advance if it is going to be mild or more troublesome :-/ G n' J
Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: Hiya Stoatie, Just read your status update and as you said you now know the news from your consultant. It's nowhere near as bad as you are imagining. Just another hurdle to jump. Having two nodes affected from three means the lymph nodes were doing their job which is to trap infectious cells and stop them from going elsewhere within your body - We have read here of ladies with far more nodes affected than that (15 maybe more) who have gone on and kicked cancers ar*e so please don't see this as a death sentence - far from it. BC has a 90% recovery rate. Ok so they now recommend chemo, but you may have been offered this anyway depending on what the histology results were. Things often change when the surgery tissue samples have been looked at and well over half of ladies get put on chemo as insurance to help stop any re-occurance. Please reply with any questions or concerns you have, you certainly sound very shell shocked and we all want to help you through this. Group Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Pain following LD reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi hedgewitch  There are a few ladies here who had Letrozole given to shrink tumours down prior to surgery instead of the more common chemo b4 surgery route.  It takes longer but is very effective. Heather77 took Letrozole for a year prior to surgery and Chloecat45 is taking Anastrozole (very similar drug) as her only treatment so yes, they work :) Other cancer types also found to be ER+ positive (of which there are several) can also be treated with Letrozole type drugs or Tamoxifen if pre meno. Letrozole is considered the better one long term but all AI's (aromatase inhibitors) have these bone/joint aches as a side effect. The Herceptin can also cause aches in legs, knees etc so perhaps you are getting a double whammy at the moment :( Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Letrozole shrinks tumours other than primary breast tumour.

Posts.Content: Hi, I posted this into another discussion and thought it may be of use here as well :) BCC booklet "Understanding Your Pathology Report" Just click this link. 7384.bcc161_understanding_your_pathology_2016_web.pdf G n' J
Posts.Title: pathology report

Posts.Content: Hi jojo1969  Is this appt for a pre-chemo assessment visit rather than you actually having chemo ? If so you may be given your HER2 results and confirmation of which chemotherapy drugs you will be given. They will weigh and measure you as the dosage levels are calculated by your BMI. If you haven't one as yet you could be given a CT scan and/or ECG heart trace. These are just to confirm you are fit enough for chemo and there are no surprises like finding you only have one kidney or any other organ damage etc. Probably a blood test to get base levels of things like red and white cell counts liver enzyme levels, although this may be carried out a day or two before your first session. This is where you could ask about using scalp cooling (cold cap) if you fancy trying that option to save some of your hair and you can also ask if they fit a PICC line or some form of intravenous line for administering chemo and taking blood tests. Some health authority area do this as standard, some don't. If you get offered one seriously think about accepting it, they make sessions far more do'able :) G n' J
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi Phaedra  I wouldn't let the 10% reduction cause you any concern whatsoever :) The dose rate is worked out from your BMI - that is why they weigh and measure you prior to chemo; and the figure is the maximum you can handle according to your bmi figure. A lot of patients find this level a tad too high but either don't mention how tough they are finding it, or don't even realise a dose reduction is do'able. There are quite a few who have their chemo dosage reduced and the most common figure is a reduction of 20% J is HER2+ and had her last Docetaxel lowered by 20% five years ago, so reducing is a known way of helping you through this. Oh, and do ask your consultant  to    speak    more   slowly   so  you   can   understand   what   they   are   saying  :)) Hope the 10% takes the edge off the side effects, G n' J
Posts.Title: Reduced dose of chemo

Posts.Content: Hi  Chris,  Re - DCIS, the Ductal part means it's found in the milk ducts and the "in situ" means it is localised in this place, it doesn't travel so is non invasive. It is common this type localised doesn't need chemo, if they are certain they have got it all with clear margins, but other factors may mean that chemo is also used. Was the first lumpectomy not for dcis then ? In Jackie's case her BC was DCIS 8m/m just behind the nipple, but it was also found to be HER2 hormone receptor positive so this meant she had to be given Herceptin but in order to get Herceptin she also had to have Docetaxel chemo but she is ER+ (oestrogen receptor ) positive as well. So for her she got the full monty mastectomy, FEC then Docetaxel chemo, Herceptin and radiotherapy.   A receptor is basically like an on / off switch which switches on the cancer cell growth if the hormone it it positive for is found in cells in your bloodstream  i.e. oestrogen or progesterone etc. The oncology drugs given target these receptors and either switches them off permanently, or by reducing your hormone level stops the cancer cells from developing further and in a lot of cases actually shrinking them by cutting blocking off it's receptors or starving it. Yours were found at a very early stage so that is great, have you had any info yet regarding the HER hormone receptor status yet or they just told you about being ER+ ? This will determine more than anything how your treatment plan will work out. We are 14 months past diagnosis / surgery now with only 2 Herceptin to go and continuation of her 5 years worth of Letrozole. They are not unduly worried about BC occuring in her other breast but obviously keep a close on things with regular mammograms and scans. Assume your sentinel nodes check must have been given the "all clear" ? They are a great bunch on here,  best thing we ever did was joining up to Maccyland  :-)  Keep us informed as to where you go from here, as for the train ride bit,  well expect to be derailed a couple of times along the way, but it's all so do'able and the time soon goes. Kindest Wishes and very good luck,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed..

Posts.Content: Usually the way, Tamox pre menopause Letrozole / arimidex post men.... They all mop up oestrogen which is why after a while you may get some joint pain and osteoporosis type symptoms. If you get any problems with the Tamox ask then if a change is possible and see it is better for you. You news so far keeps getting better, lymph nodes job is to collect any infectious cells so of they are clear,  jobs a good 'un - As for the odd stray cell, they'll never tell you you are clear,  just nothing found. The fact that your sentinel node check was clear is excellent.... If you were HER2 pos I reckon they would have told you but it's always worth asking, - If you don't ask you don't get eh  :-) Same with everything else including treatment, don't suffer at all, there are always antidotes to side effects.  As you have found out you get better information from onco team than surgeons, the work they do is brilliant but they live on a dif planet to the rest of us. Makes you wonder if the oestrogen in your HRT acted like a trigger for the ER+ receptor ? Anyone else on the list had HRT and thought the same thing  ?  G  n'  J
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed..

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine,  It's a case of trying what makes you can get hold of to see which ones suit you best, as everybody is different and what works for one may not work for another. Femara are supposedly the best as they were the original brand before Letrozole became unlicensed and could be made by other companies. Jackie was given two months of Femara by the onco unit, however when she picked up her repeat from our local pharmacy she was given Teva brand and these increased her joint pain and caused a few other issues. After trying two other types her GP altered her repeat from Letrozole to Femara so these are the only ones she gets now. These suit her but all letrozole will cause bone / joint pain to a certain extent, it's because of the lack of oestrogen which causes bone thinning and osteopaenia problems. If this is still a problem you can get NSAID's (non steroidal anti inflammatory drugs) to ease the joint pains and Adcal+ and vitamin D3 to add calcium which helps with the bone thinning. Have you had Muga scans to check your bone density ? Hope this helps a bit, G n' J
Posts.Title: Letrozole V Femara

Posts.Title: critical illness insurance

Posts.Content: Evening Maggie, This is a toughie to get your head around as there is so much involved as with any treatment plan - a lot more stats are gathered than the info given if you ask for your path report. They could have given you chemo first to shrink them but the chances are with two multi focal you would have had to go back after a WLE and either had a lot more removed to get clear margins or the given mastectomy anyway. I reckon they gave you the mastectomy first so they could check the tissue for HER2 and gather more info from the tumours to work out the best treatment plan for you. Jackie had just one 8mm tumour behind and attached to the nipple and was given an MX before chemo. No option to try and shrink it and we never questioned that decision at the time or now. Think you just accept that given the information they have obtained and using their expertise and experience you trust they make the right choice of treatment on your behalf. It may seem drastic but I think most would rather have the kitchen sink thrown at it knowing everything possible was being done to avoid any re-occurance than leaving a chink in the armour that comes back and bites you at a later date. The EC over FEC chemo plan could be down to a number of things. Oncologists preference, some medical reason why Fluorouracil wouldn't have been suitable for you. It could be they wanted to give you higher doses of E and C so adding the Fluorouracil would have been too much for you. EC or FEC for that matter can affect the heart more than Docetaxel, that is why Herceptin isn't given at the same time as either of those. Only after those chemos or in conjunction with Docetaxel. So maybe the EC regime you were on was to protect your heart for some reason. There maybe even some stats which are unknown to you that played a role in the decision only way to find out for certain would be to contact your onco and ask for the reasons behind it. Sorry it's a bit of a long non answer, just a few suggestions, but hope it helps in some way. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning Ro, I was going to reply to this yesterday but didn't want to rain on your party. Welcome to Mr.T's  'How to make your joints and bones age 20 years overnight' club :-( Jackie always called Docetaxel FEC's ugly sister. If the pain gets really bad you can alternate paracetamol and any other non paracetamol containing tablets like Ibuprofen so you take something every two hours if that doesn't ease it ask for some better pain relief and also ask about the chances of having the dosage reduced by 20% for your other sessions - if it is mostly bearable just try to work through it day by day if you can. The lack of sleep at first is mostly down to the steroids and the aches disturbing your sleep don't worry about that you'll soon be crashing on the sofa by around 2pm (or earlier)  Do please use any mouthwash you have - even if you don't feel you need it at the moment because if you do start getting a sore mouth it will be too late to stop it getting a little worse. The steroids kill off the good bacteria in your mouth and throat which normally keeps your mouth healthy. Mouth ulcers and oral thrush are what you are trying to avoid. This docetaxel can really knock the stuffing out of you so dig deep and hang tough and it will pass day by day. Plan a little special treat for yourself as a reward during the week (days 14 - 21) before your next session when almost overnight it will feel like a brick wall has been lifted off you. Hope you feel a little better this morning but it's probably a bit early for that yet. We feel your hit by a truck pain Ro - G n' J

Posts.Title: Lymph node removal and under arm nerve

Posts.Content: Morning  Trudi, Sorry to see another new member of the club no-one wants to join.  Right first off, take a few deep breaths and slow yourself down a tad. You are understandably worried and wanting answers to so'ooo many questions you'll blow a fuse at this rate  :-)    Sounds to us like you haven't had much time to soak up all the results info as yet and are still in shock. So, after reading your messages, lets see if we can figure this out. Are you going to get TAC or FEC ? before your mastectomy, then Tax with Herceptin after the op ? Bit confused here as to which one they are giving you first, could you clarify please ? They can all effect you in different ways. Did they mention wether it's DCIS or Lobular as we have no idea about FE2 ? The lumps under your arm are probably the lymph glands reacting to the cancer. Were those biopsies taken from just under your arm or the breast ( maybe both )  ? Sorry to be shooting so many Q's at you but it gives us a better chance to help you if we know a bit more about it  :-) I'll paste a couple of links in that may help you get your head around it all,  there is so'oo much to try and get your head around at the start, it's hard trying to take it all in. Meanwhile, take one day at a time, walk don't run, you have come to the right place and will find loads of friends here who have been there, done that and will guide you and others new members who will share their treatment with you. For info on TAC or FEC (combo chemo's ) note make sure you know which one these they are giving you, because TAC is different to Tax - which is short for Taxotere / Docetaxel and just to confuse things even further there is also the FEC you mention  :-) The first link is for TAC (combo chemo ) http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertreatment/Treatmenttypes/Chemotherapy/Combinationregimen/TAC.aspx For info on just Taxotere  http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertreatment/Treatmenttypes/Chemotherapy/Individualdrugs/Docetaxel.aspx Understanding your results booklet - http://www2.breastcancercare.org.uk/sites/default/files/bcc161_understanding_your_pathology_report.pdf This link is for FEC (combo chemo ) http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertreatment/Treatmenttypes/Chemotherapy/Combinationregimen/FEC.aspx Take care,  George & Jackie.
Posts.Title: FEC-T chemothrapy

Posts.Content: Hi Aneesa1   A lot of people associate grade with size but although that is taken into consideration it's not the whole picture. It's also about how aggressive the cells appear. J's tumour was only 8mm and she had no lymph involvement but was also classed as grade 3 we were told that was because of the HER2+ positive finding bumping up the ladder from a grade 2. Although hearing a grade 3 is more aggressive can be a bit scary, the Herceptin this finding qualifies you for is a game changing treatment for HER2+ cancers. Your wig lady was bang out of order - Totally agree with Londonlass's comment. What she could have told you is that Herceptin is brilliant at avoiding HER2+ becoming a secondary cancer later on, but I'm wondering if she even knows the difference between secondary and recurrence :-? I remember reading a comment on here years ago saying when you get a cancer diagnosis there were 2 types of friends - Drains and Radiators. Those who mentally drain you, and those who radiate warmth and keep you cosy. "Ditch the drains, and surround yourself with Radiators" Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning KitKaty,  (again) feels like I'm stalking you this morning LOL Holland and Barrett did have Manuka Honey included in there penny sale promotion. Do check it's still on offer though as manuka isn't cheap. Don't want any checkout embarrassment  :-) The number on the jar equals the strength - higher the number the more expensive. The background for Manuka is the bees (NZ) feed off the manuka bush which has antiseptic properties and it is used to treat stuff like mrsa and the nhs also uses medical grade manuka dressings to aid wound recovery. It's supposedly good for dabbing on cold sores too. G n' J

Posts.Content: Posting on behalf of shazlo who is seeking anybody who is taking part or has experience of the Pallet Trial using Palbociclib and Letrozole before surgery.  The trial has 4 arms using combinations of the above and runs for for 14 weeks. CRUK Pallet Trial info page can be found here. It is important anyone having Palbociclib doesn't eat Grapefruit or drink the juice nor have St Johns Wort as like many other medications these contain an enzyme which strongly affects the dosage strength and side effects :( Hope this is of some help, G n' J
Posts.Title: Pallet Trial - Palbociclib and Letrozole Before Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi shazlo  Shame you weren't suitable for the trial criteria but Letrozole is good for shrinking tumours down; albeit a bit slow. The info link above will be of use for anyone else querying the trial. Stopping HRT and starting Letrozole will make your body feel like it is dealing with a double whammy as you are not only losing the hrt hormones, the letrozole will stop you producing Oestrogen. So do be prepared for some menopausal symptoms to kick in at some time - hot flashes and some bone/joint aches  :(  Have you had a Dexa Bone Density scan yet - You should have one if you are on Letrozole long term as they can cause bone thinning ? If you start getting issues do post a new discussion to the breast group there are plenty of ladies on Letrozole who can offer you some advice about easing any of the side effects. You should get some idea on how they will be affecting you after 2-4 weeks as they get into your system. There are also a few here who have been placed on letrozole to shrink tumours prior to surgery too (neo-adjuvant hormone therapy) Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Pallet Trial - Palbociclib and Letrozole Before Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Sazig  Warm welcome to the Breast Group - sorry to read you and your mum are getting these worries, but it's good your mum went to get this looked into rather than just leaving it. Calcifications themselves are fairly common and are mostly benign, however if these calcifications form a cluster it could be a sign of it being a pre-cancerous condition which will need further tests to get a conclusive answer - Hence the biopsy and scans etc, especially with the added symptom of a lymph node being enlarged, which mostly only happens when something upsets them like when they swell up if you get flu or mumps. There is more information about Calcification here (link) you can read through. Fingers crossed for good results from the barrage of tests she is having, do keep asking questions here, you probably have loads. Take care and good luck, G n' J

Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Cheri, Not long got home from work so couldn't reply earlier. This finger and/or toe pain from Docetaxel affects some people more than others and if you are getting this now it could be that your dosage levels have been set a tad too high - In cases like this it is important you give your Onco unit a ring and explain what is going on and they may well reduce your others sessions by 20% or could change you to the milder weekly Paclitaxel version of Tax type chemo or replace the Taxane type chemo for something else.  PN needs taking seriously and keeping an eye on as the pain can get worse before it gets better. Especially if your hands or feet start feeling hot and burning like pain as this can lead to Palmar Plantar (hand and foot syndrome) which really is debilitating as the skin can get blistered and crack open. Normally it takes a while for signs of this particular side effect to appear (can even happen post chemo) as it takes a while to travel along to the end of the long nerves in your legs and arms. Obviously this has happened a lot quicker in your case :( Unfortunately unless your unit has the new type 'cooling gloves and / or boots' similar to the cold cap if you are prone to this there isn't anything they can actually give you to stop this happening apart from what's mentioned above. Do have a read of this Macmillan info page on Peripheral Neuropathy (it's an vastly updated version of the old one mentioned in the previous reply) As for the rash, this is quite common and some have found an anti-histamine like Piriton helps but do mention this as well because they may be able to supply you with something better to help clear it up. Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Sore fingers and toes after docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi Diamondmum  Be careful what you wish for - Docetaxel usually gives you a 3-4 day honeymoon period while it gets into your system. Hopefully it will be kind to you, but don't be surprised if you gradually feel a bit rougher during the day or overnight :-/ Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Jane, Peripheral Neuropathy unfortunately comes in many flavours very minor nerve damage can be slight numbness and pins and needles but it can get so painful you can hardly walk and climbing hills and stairs are like a form of torture. Use the link to read more about what you can do to help with this, and you are correct Docetaxel and other chemo types are the biggest culprit for this. At least see your GP or onco unit and get some NSAID's - Non steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as nothing much else will help with nerve damage pain.  Please keep a close eye on your hands and feet as the skin could become blistered or broken and feel like they are burning - Which is a type of PN called Palmar Plantar or hand and foot syndrome. Jackie didn't get the PN pain but did lose all 20 nails over a period of 3 months post Tax. You can get some cream to help which is the same stuff dairy farmers use on cattle teets to avoid cracking and mastitis called Udder Cream, you can get it from Amazon but also from country stores and may even be able to get it through your GP on prescription. Hope this helps, suffering with this is awful :-( G n' J
Posts.Title: Sore fingers and toes after docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hiya Yvonne, It could be you picked this up if your immune system was a bit low, but this flu bug that is going around is a new different strain to the one the jab is meant for. Both myself and Jackie picked this up a few days after Christmas and it really floored us both. Hang on in there and just take stuff to ease the effects. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi AntsNest  You could try Quinnine rich tonic type drinks from the supermarket like the Fever Tree brand ? It could also be caused by a Magnesium and/or Potassium deficiency. Posts.Content: Hiya Ali, They don't use a line for the nucleide used for a Muga Scan anyway - soz... If you not had one before they are a doddle really. Jackie had a Groshong line in but they said lines can't be used. Maybe it's because of the radioactivity ? They can if trained take the blood from your line, but it never goes back in that way, it has to be a vein. They are radiologists not medical folks... They take a little blood, you go for a coffee, come back in half an hour during which time they have mixed your blood with the 'glow in the dark' stuff and they inject it back into you and then it's 20 mins on the scanner. Is this tied in with having Herceptin or they checking to see if chemo has affected your heart ? This Muga leaflet is from Derby Hosp. G n' J

Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi  Gillie,  Like Russ says around day 10 you should def start to feel a bit livelier. Some folks liver are not so efficient at processing the chemo tho', so may take a few days longer. Thats why they take bloods a few days before each session - to check liver enzymes etc and your daily temp checks help you to see if it's going Pete Tong. As a rule of thumb it's sort of - Week 1 makes you feel like crap - Week 2 you can catch any type of crap and - Week 3 you are feeling better just in time to accept the next lot of crap.  Ok it's not all that bad, just be cautious but not overly so during the 2nd week. Snotty schoolkids and dr's waiting rooms are germ factories. Normal personal hygiene to be considered as "you" are the biggest threat to yourself as we all carry loads of bugs around with us too. Remember cancer is a word, not a sentence, so don't let it make you a prisoner.  Cheer's to another chemo date box ticked off.  Hugs, G  n'  J

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda, Hope you are doing OK ? Can't give you an experienced reply regarding Tamoxifen as J is on Letrozole so I'll leave that to those who are also taking it. Can give you a little background info though :-) The original registered make of Tamoxifen and probably the most expensive is Nolvadex (astra zeneca) all the other brands are generic so although they contain the same drug the fillers used to make up the balance and the tablet coating (e-numbers for colouring etc) may be different and it is these that can cause some issues as well as the drug itself. The more common 'brands' in the uk are - Arrow,  Bayer,  Mylan,  Orion,  Novartis,  Merck,  Sandoz,  Schering,  Teva and  Wokhardt. You may get lucky and find the first one suits you, but if it does cause random problems you may have to get them to switch a few brands around until you find the best one for you :-( Hopefully you will get lots more replies with recommendations and can find which brands 'seem to be better'  I think the general consensus is if Tamoxifen causes you night sweats or other overnight problems taking it in the morning could be a better option ? but I'm uncertain about this..... ? Like all these treatments some get through with few problems - fingers crossed that is you :-) Tamoxifen (BCC booklet link) Group Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Taking Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Gdpt Sorry to see you joining us here and reading about your mum :( This will be a rather brief reply as we are off out in a little while but I just wanted to reassure you that although what they call multi focal tumours sounds worrying and will probably need a mastectomy rather than a lumpectomy this is still very do'able. J, my better half was diagnosed way back in May 2012 and also has a left mastectomy followed by chemo and radiotherapy, the treatments work and she is still classed as having no evidence of disease. No doubt you will get a more detailed report from the biopsies and also tissue pathology examination post surgery but the recovery rate from breast cancer is very high (over 90%) contrary to what you see and read in the media. Try not to let the stress at this emotional time upset you and affect your pregancy, this is rarely as bad as it all first seems. Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky  /  SpicedTea  It's not a question easily answered because you never have any clues about how bad or mild it could become beforehand. Some get neuropathy pain during chemo and the dose can be tweaked to a lower level to minimise it, like yours was, or help it from getting worse. This can also ease right off when chemo is completed over an 8 week period. Others find they don't start getting neuropathy pain until the chemo has already ended (can be 3-6 months later) others don't get any at all - it's all very individual. For an unlucky few they suffer some permanent residual chemo induced neuropathy and there are several ladies here who are a couple of years post chemo who still have slightly numb feet / toes - fingers / hands :( I'm afraid it's a case of carry on with your reduced dose and hope for the best, or take the risk of not having the remaining 2 x Paclitaxel - How many Paclitaxel have you already had ? G n' J

Posts.Title: advice on telling my children

Posts.Content: Morning JJ, As Helen mentioned it is quite common to be moved up a stage after the tissue is examined in the pathology unit as they get a much better view of it compared to the small biopsy samples. Sorry to read you have been called back for more tissue to be taken, did you get any results regarding your sentinel nodes being clear ? because if some are affected they may remove some more of those as well :-( If you haven't been given much information about triple negative you can read about it here at BCC. A CT scan check is common practice before starting chemo to see if there are any previously unfound problems which the chemo may have an affect on (heart, liver, kidneys etc) There is a Triple Negative Breast Group but because TNBC isn't that common (around 15%) the group is not very active but you could have a look at the posts and replies there. I don't want to add further worries to you but a lot of TNBC ladies end up with a mastectomy because there is a slightly higher possibility of recurrence over the first 3 years with TN. Both you and they will want to do all they can to try and avoid this. TN mostly responds very well to chemo. There are quite a few triple negative ladies here, hopefully some will reply to this to help advise you. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Gutted bad news

Posts.Content: Hi Iona, Well done for having the courage to inform them, that is probably the toughest part of 'talking' about it you will face. Trying to tell younger children without scaring them whilst keeping it honest is a tricky balancing act. They do need to know as children pick up on stuff around them and not knowing what is going on can get them believing all sorts of weird ideas - especially the younger ones. Have to agree with Julia 'Mummy's Lump is certainly way overdue for an update - If anyone knows of a better BC booklet for younger children please post some info about it. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: advice on telling my children

Posts.Content: Hi Jean, Sorry to see you joining this club, won't say welcome as none of us really wants to be here. It's terrible to be put in this position when you know so little about what it's all about and what the future may hold. They all seem to think you know a much about it all as they do. Seen quite a few very similar posts recently and it is a tough choice. They can enter your diagnosis results into a "predict tool' and give you percentages of recurrance which with a stage 2 and no lymph involvement is usually fairly low % The problem is if you declined chemotherapy and went with rads only you will probably spend the rest of your life wondering if you did enough to avoid it coming back at sometime or whether you should have chucked everything including the kitchen sink at it knowing you did everything you could to give you the best possible outcome. Most would say go for it and accept the chemo too, but it is your choice - having chemo can be a tough 4 months and even the thought of saying yes to that is scary but it is do'able. It all depends on the type of person you are, minimum treatment and a quicker recovery time now and risk it later, or accept everything going and still have no solid guarantees just the security of  'I did all I could' Don't envy you with this head game but good luck with whatever you decide is best for you. George & Jackie

Posts.Title: A smile to start today.

Posts.Content: Hiya Sim, This Tamoxifen / Rads question has been popping up more recently. Seems from results of some recent published tests carried out in the USA Radiotherapy appears to be more effective if any stray cancer cells are active, Tamoxifen can make them a bit docile as it is cutting off a big part of their food supply (oestrogen) but most of this is speculation at the moment. Where the problem is is that some oncologists now follow this view and delay Tamoxifen and / or other hormone inhibitor tablets until after radiotherapy just in case this is proven through trials. Other oncologists are prepared to wait until all the evidence is in and will still get you on the tablets soon as possible. Result there is a variation in treatment depending on who your onco is and their views on this ? I may be wrong but that's what I can gather from it all, G n' J
Posts.Title: New member to the group

Posts.Content: Hiya Sims, Welcome to the Breast Group.  Your'e a bit late, what kept you :-) Congrats on getting through your chemo relatively unscathed. With your ER & PR score at 8's they may well keep you on the Zoladex as well as introducing the Tamoxifen - So you must still be pre-menopausal ? Quite a few nodes are found to carry micromets - depending on the size they will either remoove more or all nodes to check the lot, or if minor they will leave them and use chemo and rads to zap them. I think Micromets are classed as anything from 0.2 to under 2mm over that they become classed as macromets. They are basically talking about groups of cells rather than actual tumours - hence node negative (it's a bit of a grey area)  The H&E part is Hematoxylin which stains cell nuclei blue/black and Eosin stains protein and cell cytoplasm deep pink. When used together, hematoxylin and eosin is termed ‘H&E.’ With micromets they sometimes give a more concentrated (boost) of rads or concentrate more on the axilla area than they would if the nodes were clear. Another way is to give an axilla 'boost' dose on the last day of rads - Has anything been mentioned about this to you ? I'm sat tapping away thinking I'm preaching to the already converted here  LOL You mention loads more questions, so fire away. We're all here to help :-) Any other ladies here had micromets and could chip in ? Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi invisible me / Yvonne, What is it about the HER2+ that is getting your worries coming out of the closet ?  The concern about needing to go through chemo to get the Herceptin or have you been using Dr Google and found old information about how bad HER2+ was considered for recurrence risks prior to Herceptin being discovered and used to treat it. Can't really comment about the Herceptin injections as back in 2012 when Jackie had her 18 x Herceptin it was given like chemo using a bag and pump through a line. Herceptin can weaken the heart muscles but this is very closely monitored using regular Muga scans and this happens you get given a short treatment break allowing recovery if this occurs. 4 years on and still no evidence of disease, I would say Herceptin is a major game changer. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: Hi Windmill68  Don't know how long this week has lasted for you but yes, a week of this waiting time has passed - get the holiday weekend over and Wednesday will soon be here. No doubt you will start to get more apprehensive as Weds gets closer, that is only natural. Biopsies may be taken which although these don't hurt much at the time can ache for a few days afterwards. Although at the breast unit they don't usually tell you much on the day, unless it's a one stop shop - some position the ultrasound screen so you can see what is going on, others can place it where you can't make much out. You can pick up on things facial expressions the way they speak to you and how they put 'stuff' over. Just don't read too much into this as they may be having a bad/busy day or just passing wind :) Hope your cold clears up quickly, G n' J
Posts.Title: New, just been referred for fast track tests after finding lump

Posts.Content: Morning gumpo  Warm welcome to the breast group, let's hope after Friday you find yours is a short stay. Re the thickening thing - Not all breast cancers are lumps in which case thickening can be a symptom but don't read too much into that on it's own ? A lot of women have breasts that aren't an even, soft, spongy texture all over, so if you find things are firmer in one area more than normal, or more firm in one side compared to the other it is worth getting this checked out.  What to look out for are when things feel or look different to how they normally are for you.  That is why regular 'cop-a-feel' (breast and underarm tail) sessions with soapy hands in the shower are important, so you get to know what feels normal and can notice any changes sooner. Good luck with your results, G n' J
Posts.Title: New, just been referred for fast track tests after finding lump

Posts.Content: Hi DebsT, There are a couple of ladies on EC - It is almost the same as FEC but without the F part - dropping the F part seems to becoming more standard. You can check out February's Chemo Club where those having chemo this month support each other with tips and a chat. If you look for messages from either Fundamentals or Mistia they are both on EC at the moment. Just a quick couple of tips. Take the anti-sickness meds whether you feel nauseous or not, it's easier to keep on top of that way and drink plenty of fluids (2 litres a day)  The E part (which is red) will make your pee pink for 24 hours or so, so don't go thinking this is blood in your urine. Take care, G n' J
