Posts.Title: Full Range of Breast Cancer Related Books To Read or Download

Posts.Content: Hi Skopje, Compared to chemo, radiotherapy is a lot easier to deal with. The biggest hassle is feeling a bit tired mostly due to the daily travelling. The rads keep working for up to two weeks after your sessions end and it can feel a bit like light sunburn but nothing too bad. It is very uncommon for anyone to get long term side effects from rads, just use plenty of the cream they should give you, if they don't supply any you may have to buy a tub but it's not expensive. You can get some info from having a read of this 'Radiotherapy For Primary Breast Cancer' (link) which covers the assessment appointment too where you get to ask any questions and see what goes on. You also get some very tiny black dot tattoo's which they use to line the machine up with each session so you don't have to be messed about being aligned every time. What fears do you have about radiotherapy  ? Hope this is of some help, Rads are so do'able, honestly :-) Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Still awake..& radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Windmill68  There are couple of ways that can help get through this rubbish waiting period... Find something you like that takes concentration and also kills time - maybe a hobby, or a tablet / phone game ? Another is to just allow yourself 30 minutes stress period once or twice a day and those are the only time you are allowed to worry. When the clock runs out you say 'that's it' time to move on :) If you are tempted to see Dr Google just use sites like Macmillan, BreastCancerCare and Cancer Research UK (CRUK) It's a long time until the 31st - keep posting here, asking / chatting about anything or nothing, we're all here to help. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: New, just been referred for fast track tests after finding lump

Posts.Content: Morning Windmill68  I just happened to be reading this section when your message popped up. Welcome to the Mac Community, although it probably the last place you thought you would be signing up to :( You are entering a very stressy and emotional time - everyone hated the waiting results period it seems to drag on forever. You get the 2 weeks between GP and breast clinic then another (in most cases) 10-14 days wait for results from any mammogram /and/or ultrasound scans or biopsies if taken :( It is going to be hard carrying on as normal without your savvy pair noticing something not being right ? They will pick on 'stuff' so have a reason handy if needed - if you feel a bit teary at times the shower is a good place to get soap in your eyes... You are right about keeping quiet for now, at least until you know for sure what this is and what is happening as questions will be asked if you bring this up and you as yet don't even have any answers yourself. Fingers crossed whatever this is it is benign, benign may still require surgery as they grow as well, however if your fears are confirmed treatment can and does start quite soon after the results are back (within a month normally) Noticed you actually joined this very active group (good move) we're a friendly bunch who will help support you - hopefully yours will be a short stay. Meanwhile you could have a look at this booklet Understanding Breast Screening. Just click the cover to read online or download. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: New, just been referred for fast track tests after finding lump

Posts.Content: Hi Mira Mirabo  They recommend you don't use anything that is either too hot or cold during breast rads. This list of precautions is taken from the Sloan Kettering US website. Avoid irritating your skin in the area being treated Wear loose-fitting cotton clothing and undergarments in the area being treated. Avoid tight clothing that will rub up against your skin, including underwire bras for women. Use only the moisturizers, creams, or lotions that you have discussed with your radiation oncologist or nurse. Don’t use makeup, perfumes, powders, or aftershave in the area being treated. Don’t put tape on your treated skin If your skin is itchy, don’t scratch it. Apply moisturizer. Ask your nurse for recommendations on how to relieve the itching. Don’t shave in the area that’s being treated. If you must shave, use only an electric razor. Stop if your skin becomes irritated. Don’t let your treated skin come into contact with extreme hot or cold temperatures. This includes hot tubs, water bottles, heating pads, and ice packs. If you don’t have any skin reactions during your treatment, you can swim in a chlorinated pool. However, be sure to rinse off the chlorine right after getting out of the pool. Avoid tanning or burning your skin during treatment and for the rest of your life. If you’re going to be in the sun, use a PABA-free sunblock with an SPF of 30 or higher. Also, wear loose-fitting clothing that covers you as much as possible. Hope this is of some help, G n' J

Posts.Title: Hair Re-growth

Posts.Content: Hi Mini11  One question you should ask (especially if you are one who has finding a vein hassle having bloods taken) is if they fit a PICC line or Port-a-Cath  prior to chemotherapy - Has this been mentioned to you ? Some health authority areas do this as standard others only fit one if the chemo nurses have problems at your first session, but by then you will have already had one session and any vein damage (if you are going to be prone to it) will have already started. These stay in all the way through your sessions but PICC's do need a 5 minute flush weekly to avoid them getting blocked with congealed blood. I think the Port versions have a monthly flush  but uncertain as J had a Groshong iv line in her chest. They only take around 30-40 mins to fit under a local and save loads of needles, eliminates the risk of chemo leak and makes the sessions quicker which is a bonus. Very few have issues from a line of some sort; they are also used for the many blood samples taken during the 18 weeks or so. There is extensive info about ways to give chemo here (link) You could ask about scalp cooling if you want to try minimising hair loss (although you could still lose 50%) and if so which system they use as not all have the Paxman cooling systems. Sure you will get more tips on what to ask. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Questions to ask oncologist tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Morecombe, There is a very active chemo discussion titled May Chemo Club (link) here. The link will send you to the first page but it already has lots of posts. It has carried on from the April Thread so some have already had a couple of sessions and can offer friendly advise and tips. Inflammatory is a quite rare (only around 4%) and as Helen says the treatment can differ slightly. IBC will always mean chemo before surgery but a lot of the ladies here also have that to shrink tumours down first. Surgery should follow on within 4 weeks of chemo finishing and Radiotherapy within 4 weeks of having surgery because IBC is classed as fast growing and mostly there is no tumour (lump) which can make detecting this type taking longer to diagnose. Did you read the 'IBC-What Is It ?' post in the IBC group ? there is a 'secret' facebook group if you are into FB ?  There is also this booklet about IBC from breastcancercare.uk if you haven't been given a copy. Hope this helps you settle in a bit, facing chemo can see a bit scary, but your first session is always more scary in your head than in reality. Are you having the FEC part first, or the T (Taxotere aka Docetexel part first ? Just wanted to add, don't know if you have heard of this but there is a 'Cold Cap' you can wear during chemo which can save some hair but unless it is a very good fit most suffer some hair loss. There is more information about Scalp Cooling here. It is a bit hit and miss, for some it works well others either give up because of all the hassle or would rather be without than be patchy. It also adds a fair bit of time to each session Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Kinesio Taping - request for information

Posts.Content: Morning Maria 712  Chemo Club, here ya go. Bicarb Mouthwash... You can find the powder in the baking aisle. Every 3 hours during the day, mix together: 1 cup warm water, 1/4 teaspoon baking soda, and 1/8 teaspoon salt. Take small sips and swish them around in your mouth. If your throat is rough too you can gargle with it but it may be oral thrush so get this checked out. We're so good to you LOL G n' J
Posts.Title: Preparing for chemo

Posts.Content: Hi BrainSquashed, Is this related to the post surgery puckering you had or did that ease off ?  You can get tissue damage (hardening and/or shrinkage) from radiotherapy but this mostly affects reconstructed breasts. Don't know if this is anywhere near the area where your tumour was removed from but it may be scar tissue forming and affecting the nipple nerves and also from the armpit if you had any lymph nodes removed. Either way I would contact your breast care nurse and get it all checked out, they may arrange to ultrasound scan you to see if it is scar tissue, but you need to get some answers to this to ease any worries. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Post radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona, Welcome to the group, a great place to find at a tough time. Sorry to read you are having another anxious waiting results session for your pathology report, it really is a tough time :( There are several Triple Neg ladies here who will no doubt say Hi! as soon as they read your message. How long past surgery are you, it sounds quite recent - If you have any questions regarding recovery or healing worries, do ask, the help here is amazing. It isn't unusual to have some cells found in the lymph nodes it is the most likely place they get trapped and this is supposed to happen, so at least your lymph nodes did their job containing them. How are your boys taking the news and have you told them a little about what is happening but waiting until you know more about it yourself or tried being more open about it all to your older son ? As for the chemo it depends on which chemo regime they place you on as there are several differing options. For the most part they are at 3 weekly intervals and can be 6 (in some cases 8) cycles - so it does tend to go on for a while - and has it's ups and downs but is do'able. BTW - You can find the November Chemo Club Helen mentioned clicking the green text link. Don't get alarmed by some of the posts, as everyone gets a different ride and most only ask questions when they have a problem that needs advice so it can seem a bit unnerving. Take care and good luck with healing well and getting those results. G n' J

Posts.Title: Full Range of Breast Cancer Related Books To Read or Download

Posts.Content: Hi scotland13  There is quite a list here you can pick through. Some are more of more value than others. Personally I would go for a mouthwash that contains Chlorhexidine J was given some by the onco unit,  soft toothbrush, digital thermometer (to check if your temp goes up to 37.5) , something for Constipation and Diarrhoea as you could get either and one can quickly turn to the other. Ginger Nut and Arrowroot biscuits to help with any nausea and taste issues and if you haven't got a PICC line fitted one of those microwaveable lavender wheat wraps (Tesco or Amazon etc) to help with any vein aches. Hope this helps, G n' J
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Evening Nicky  /  SpicedTea  After having 10 Paclitaxel following on from the all the other chemo drugs - Personally If this was me, I would be very sorely tempted to forego the last 2..... Having said that the decision must obviously be entirely yours, so please don't be swayed by my thoughts about this. It's how you feel in yourself and if the risk of neuropathy getting worse over the next few weeks is the deciding factor. Please don't feel you have to apologize for feeling down, you have been through a lot of various long term chemo drugs no wonder you have the odd 'falling to bits' days. You have to call it as you see it Nicky :) Hugs, G n' J xx

Posts.Content: Hiya Heather, Pleased to hear your long overdue surgery is now behind you and fingers crossed you don't need a re-visit because of margins :-( You body has been though a long ordeal and you have apprehensively been waiting for this for ages so it was a big event for you. The main reason you are feeling a bit down is a common side effect of the anneasethic is that it makes you feel a bit depressed for a few days as it works it's way out of your system. Take it steady for a while and let it all settle down. Keep posting if you get and problems - There are plenty of ladies here with experience of flap reconstruction that can help you with advice. Good luck and hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Quadrantectomy plus LD Flap

Posts.Content: Hiya, A lot of ladies find hair regrowth starts again when they get onto the T part - So this is probably how it will be now. Whether changing from Taxotere to Taxol will alter this usual pattern I'm uncertain but it probably won't and your wife will find the hair keeps growing. The new hair may be very fine and may start becoming curly as it gets longer but is quite slow growing. The lady garden and other hair will also start coming through. Some find the facial fluff a bit alarming but that doesn't mean they are turning into 'Chewbacca'  it usually falls out after a couple of weeks. The weekly chemo is Taxol also known as Paclitaxel and is a lower dose version of the 3 weekly Taxotere / Docetaxel and the side effects from this are the same as for docetaxel, but are usually a lot more do'able. It is the E (epirubicin / red) part of EC which is the hair zapper and some chemo drugs are worse for hair loss than others. Nice to see that for you two the end of chemo is in sight. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Hair loss or otherwise on Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi Heather, You will get these odd pangs and twitches now and again at the start it is the nerves cut through during surgery trying to repair themselves. Another thing which may feel a bit strange is it will take time for the tissue used to 'learn' it isn't back tissue anymore if that makes sense ?  The body is a weird and wonderful thing.... As for the stockings I have no idea... I only wear them when I hoover. Cue music, 'I want to break free'  ♪♫•*¨*•.¸¸♪♫•*¨*•.¸¸♪♫•* Sorry, too much information :-) Best wishes for a speedy hassle free recovery Heather, G n' J

Posts.Title: Chemotherapy on Tuesday

Posts.Content: Hi Jump123  This is something you need to contact the Radiology department about - so first off find out where the rads unit you will be having your radiotherapy is at and give them a ring - Perhaps they could offer you an appointment  well in advance to chat about the risks of keloid scarring from the radiotherapy and what they could do to minimize this ? I'm uncertain if this is the same type of treatment but it seems radiotherapy is actually used to treat keloid scars, so hopefully this won't be a much of a problem as you are thinking. I would definitely check this out in advance and get informed answers to your keloid risk questions though. When you have enough information about the risks you can make an informed decision. At least you have plenty of time to gather some facts together. I'm assuming you are having chemo before surgery so you will be having a lumpectomy (WLE) and not a mastectomy ?  I'm just wondering about the risk of keloid scars from the surgery ? Hope this is of some help, G n' J
Posts.Title: Really struggling

Posts.Content: Hiya, This hair loss malarky is really random - You get FEC or EC etc and lose head hair and the lady garden etc - but mostly get to keep you eyebrows, lashes and nasal hair which then get finished off by Taxotere / Docetaxel. Why on earth if Tax is strong enough to get rid of the more deep rooted 'other' hair does your head hair then decide to start growing back as soon as you go onto it........ ?  G n' J
Posts.Title: Hair Re-growth

Posts.Content: Hi  Mumbly,  Welcome to the club no-one wants to join. We can understand your chemo concerns and worries, but all it takes is for a few rogue cells to by pass the lymph system and they could show up elsewhere later in lungs, bone, liver etc. No chemo treatments are the same, some suffer several side effects, some get an easier ride. Think of chemo as an insurance on you and your families future. I'd prefer to have those cells jumped on by chemo and obliterated, rather relying on localised radiotherapy and hormone tabs to fend it off.  I hope you get a reply or two about saying no and explaining why that route was chosen, but I think a vast majority would advise you to take the bull by the horns and kick C's arse. It can be scary, but once treatment starts the time goes so quickly and your soon out the other end a bit wobbly and bruised but looking towards a brighter future knowing you did all you could to stay safe. Hope this helps,  George and Jackie.
Posts.Title: Chemo yes/no

Posts.Content: Hi Lottie8  The Muga scan or ECG cut off figure for Herceptin is 50%  Most peoples normal average is only between 65-70 so it doesn't take much for it to gradually dip. J had a two week break from Herceptin around number 8 as her LVEF (lower ventricular ejection faction) went down to 51% after the break it was back up to 55% and stayed around that figure for the rest of her sessions; although she did miss out on the last one as she had by then gone over her 12 month time frame (NICE only license it for 12 months unless it is being given for secondaries) Well done you for getting through all 12 Taxol, no mean feat in itself. You are bound to feel a bit rubbish for a while as it can take a few months to recover from, so please accept this as normal. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi, There is more info about Grapefruit here at Cancer Research uk (CRUK) It may not be the same for all types of chemo, so if you are a grapefruit lover do ask your onco team if it is suitable to have with the type of chemotherapy drugs you are having. From what  I can make out Grapefruit or the juice can either reduce the way chemo works, or make it stronger, so increasing the side effects. G n' J

Posts.Title: Positive news

Posts.Content: Afternoon Rily, Sorry for the late reply but I have just finished work (really early start) so missed your post last night. So pleased to read you convinced your daughter to get a GP appt. You don't need us to tell you this is the start of an agonising waiting results period for all of you. A lot of breast lumps (even growing ones) turn out to be benign fatty tumours or cysts, hopefully this will be the case for your daughter too. Fingers crossed and hope for the best. Heaven forbid this is isolating enough without trying to cope while being deaf as well :-( If you haven't found it already Macmillan has the 'Understanding Your Breast Clinic Appointment' booklet which covers everything from mammogram screening results and further tests if required. This one from Breast Cancer Care deals mostly with those referred to a breast unit from a GP appointment, so may be more appropriate. Don't fret about being a fella here, these lovely ladies have tolerated me for nearly three years now. If you need any more advice or support, or have some unanswered questions just holler. This is a very active group and there is always someone around to reply. Best wishes for some good luck, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Daughter

Posts.Content: Hi Pennyred, Regarding your palm skin peeling - Do please let you onco team know about this, you may get something similar going on with your feet later too (as it takes a bit longer to reach down that far) and makes walking painful. This is probably from the F (Fluorouracil) part of FEC. Macmillan lists it as a side effect of  Fluorouracil you can read about it here. Considering you have only had one session with more to follow last thing you want is for this to get worse :-( It's best to get this checked out as it could be the start of what they call Hand and Foot Syndrome (palmar plantar) which can get really painful. Click the green text link to read more about it. Hope this helps, let us know how you get on. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Sore mouth,sore scalp, sorely in need of advice, please!

Posts.Content: Hi Baxter2010   A quite common side effect of steroids are mood swings / changes - So yes, it probably is down to those. There are several different steroids that can be given so maybe a change would help. I would give your Onco a ring and explain they seem to be giving you anger issues and see what they can offer you to help with this and change your meds for other sessions so you don't suffer this next time around. Which steroids have they got you on at the moment ? G n' J

Posts.Title: Awaiting results of biopsy

Posts.Content: Morning Ruby Rose I bet Johnathan Ross loves your name..... 50 to 52 is around the cut off point for stopping Herceptin when the heart is healthy, so considering you have a murmer it is the safest course to follow - the risk of permanent heart damage is far too great; even 6 sessions of herceptin is far better than none. J was so knocked about by her treatment she tried going back to work on a staged return but found it was still too much both mentally and physically so finished working at 59 She did have some anti-side effect tablets to counter the Letrozole aches (Meloxicam and Amytriptyline) and has weaned herself off these since finishing her 5 years on them. Having a tube of Smarties weekly is a pain but if it helps lower the risk of recurrence it is a small price to pay. Re Pills: Don't know if you are taking a daily Letrozole or Anastrozole (ER+?) but if you are you should have had a Dexa Bone Density Scan carried out. Good luck with the dentist today, G n' J
Posts.Title: Risendronate

Posts.Content: Hi KitKaty,  Regarding the ER and PR scores - the figures quoted are a percentage out of 8 - 8 meaning 100% and nought meaning zero. The system looks at what percentage of cells test positive for hormone er and pr receptors, along with how well the receptors show up after staining (this is called “intensity”). This information is then combined to score the sample on a scale from 0 to 8. The higher the score, the more receptors were found and the easier they were to see in the sample. A higher number doesn't mean anything sinister, it's just the higher the number the more benefit you should get from Tamoxifen, Letrozole or Arimidex etc.   Which are the 5  / 10 year tablets they can put you on at the end of main treatment. G n' J
Posts.Title: Another newbi

Posts.Content: Hi  Mumbly,  FEC are the 3 chemo drugs Fluorouracil, Epirubicin and Cyclophosphamide. You will often see ref's here to FEC-T the T is for Docetaxel and is another commonly used breast cancer chemo drug.  Some chemo regimes are just FEC some a combo of both (FEC-T) They are usually given three weeks apart. Sometimes given before surgery to shrink tumours, or after to clean up any random cells that may have got missed.  For more info you can check them out here. http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertreatment/Treatmenttypes/Chemotherapy/Combinationregimen/FEC-T.aspx Don't read too much into it for now, until you find out what regime they will have planned for you some of it may not apply. There is a long list of possible side effects at the bottom of the page, again don't let this sway you either, obviously from reading posts on here you will find out what the more common ones are and how we all coped with them. As for the 92/100 figures thrown at you they could mean anything ? When given a diagnosis your brain goes into overdrive and you don't always grasp what they are telling you and all the info gets a bid muddled. I can tell you Jackie ( my wife ) works with a nurse who was given chemo for breast cancer SEVENTEEN years ago with no problems since and there is a very high % of those in remission for five, even ten years plus and treatment has come a very long way in that time, more'so over the last few years.   Make a note of any questions you need answers to before you go to the demistifyng chemo session and it will help if you can take someone with you, as four ears will pick up more info than two  :-)  Hope this helps, and good luck whatever path you choose, George & Jackie.

Posts.Title: Little things - just need to say it

Posts.Content: Hi ShadesofDawn I found this info on testing for HER2 - It reads like if the IHC comes back borderline they then use the FISH test. Which says no her2 gene amplification - perhaps this means you are considered to be HER2- negative but I would phone them and ask them to clarify this as it is a bit technical ? G n' J IHC test (ImmunoHistoChemistry): The ImmunoHistoChemistry test finds out if there is too much HER2 protein in the cancer cells. The results of the IHC test can be: 0 (negative), 1+ (also negative), 2+ (borderline), or 3+ (positive — HER2 protein overexpression). FISH test (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization): The Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization test finds out if there are too many copies of the HER2 gene in the cancer cells. The results of the FISH test can be positive (HER2 gene amplification) or negative (no HER2 gene amplification).

Posts.Content: Hi knicnic  Knowing your mum is being checked out so soon after losing your poor dad is a tough situation to be in :( If your fears are confirmed your mum's breast cancer would have to be top end worst case scenario (found very advanced with secondaries and too poorly for treatment) which is highly unlikely, for this to be anywhere near as scary as what you all went through with your dad. The prognosis for breast cancer has never been better with very high recovery rates. OK the treatments can be tough at times but they work well.  There are a lot of ladies here many years post treatment and still classed as no evidence of disease. If you are wondering what to expect you could read through this Breast Clinic Appointment guide (download link) from BCC. Fingers crossed for something benign, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Breast lump over 50

Posts.Content: Hi Evie-on  Know you have only been a member for a short while, warm welcome to the group btw :) but have you seen / read any of the chemo tips in the June Chemo Club discussion. As mentioned though this will be a cross section of everyone's side effects and people only post a message when they need advice or information so you do tend to get a one sided view of it all. The list of side effects is huge as they tend to include everything from headache to global warming fact is 2 or 3 are more common and any of the others it's a bit like an UN-lucky dip. The trick with chemo is to not keep any secrets - You don't get a medal for suffering in silence :) if you do get any issues tell your Onco unit or breast care nurse - Oh, and post about it in the chemo club discussion too, so you get advice, support and info about easing side effects. The nerves will creep in as you feel it's all a bit out of control and are putting yourself into unknown territory.  Have you had a PICC line or port put in for your chemo or just having it done with a cannula at first ? Fingers crossed for a hassle free day tomorrow, take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy-B, I wouldn't read to much into either as they are all worked out on averages. Try to remember that the scoring does not take into account individual diagnoses and treatments or the newer treatments being introduced (as it takes ages to update these prediction tools) most have a major cobweb issue :( The newer Predict Tool V2 doesn't even mention radiotherapy for instance :(  Which you would think plays a big part in reducing recurrence risk ?    Also your surgeon may not have had all the oncology information to input fully. There are just so'ooo many variables between individual patients even within those who have exactly the same type of breast cancer. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Loolyboo  It will seem scary having a 6 week wait between surgery and chemo starting but you are having the chemo to qualify for getting the Herceptin for your HER2+ - as herceptin is not given on it's own. From reading your profile page about your pathology report after surgery your cancer has been removed - all the other treatments are to avoid recurrence, so at the moment you haven't got cancer, it has been removed :) Please don't fret about this - know you really just want to get on with it, but enjoy your extended recovery period to build yourself back up to fitness before they start attacking you with needles. Posts.Title: survivor

Posts.Content: Hiya Jane, Although everyone would like to hear that their nodes are clear, it fairly common for some cells to be found in the nearest lymph nodes. It's the nodes job to trap anything dodgy like flu, mumps and other bugs etc that is why they swell up when you are poorly. It is far better for any random cells to be found 'trapped' there than for them to have found their way through the lymph system. As you have found Dr. Google isn't your friend at a time like this a lot of the info out there is either well outdated or misleading wrong and a lot of other sites trying to separate you from your cash on random cancer cures (yeah right, like they are gonna work - not) This is a step learning curve but take it a couple of days at a time so you don't overload your head with what if's over the next week.  One of our favourite sayings is 'Don't miss today's sunshine worrying about tomorrow's rain. So'ooo true, total waste of time overthinking stuff until you need to. At the start you beat yourself up so much with worries until you get to the stage where you realise what you are doing to yourself and you turn from a timid mouse into a feisty cat  :-) Oh! and you'll need some of these to keep you going until the 13th. G n' J
Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: Hi calador  Femara is Letrozole, but to clarify that, Femara® is the original registered make of Letrozole. All the others that are just called letrozole are generic brands that were made by other pharma companies when the Novartis (the femara parent company's) license ran out after they had recovered all their research and development cash back. The price difference is massive - Femara is around £85 per month but the generics can be as little as £15 per month meaning GP's are very reluctant to issue prescriptions for the original Femara :( The main side effects besides the more common menopausal symptoms with all of these oestrogen inhibitor tablets could bone / joint aches.  Before starting Letrozole you should be given a Dexa Bone Density Scan; if you haven't been offered one ask your GP about getting one as letrozole and anastrozole can cause some bone thinning long term ? Hope this helps, G n' J
Posts.Title: Hormonal treatment differences

Posts.Content: Hi Steph1684  Warm welcome to the breast group. Great to read you got through it, 28 is a crap age to get lumbered with BC :( Post treatment if you periods return you should always assume you could get pregnant, so this is a good question but for the ladies here to give a better reply could you let us know what treatment you had and if that included chemo, and if so which chemo drugs were used ? as some have a greater impact than others -  Also were you placed on Tamoxifen ? I'm thinking if you were ER+ that could limit your contraception choices ? As any of these treatments could affect your fertility to a greater or lesser extent post treatment.  Even if your periods have returned your ability to conceive could be affected as quality of the eggs you have may be compromised :( Take care, G n' J

We won't need any anti sickness tabs until their date runs out in 2017  - In fact half our medicine drawer is full of leftover onco stuff from line flushing to mouthwash etc.....  Time for a sort out I think :-) Group Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: Hi, Have to hold my hand up and apologise as I have used that phrase before as well. I can see it's not of much comfort if you feel you could be one of the 10% but percentages are just averages and we are all individuals - problem with that is percentages don't take individuals into consideration :( By the law of averages J should have had a lumpectomy and possibly rads only with her comparatively tiny 8mm DCIS with no node involvement - it was a bit of a shock when the surgeon said because of the position (small breasted and right behind the nipple) it has to be a mastectomy - then 2 weeks later along came Path-Man to ruin the party with their findings. ER+ PR+ also the nasty HER2+  Totaling 15 months of treatment followed by 5 years of Letrozole tablets - How little we knew what that left nipple slightly inverting was going to lead to :( At least there was treatment for this and for that we are thankful if it helps keep this away but no one ever really knows. All we have to go on are 5 year guesstimates and hope that the HER2+ part of this doesn't lead to secondaries at some time. Think we're all in leaky boats, bailing it out for the future unfortunately some have smaller buckets than others :( Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Post radiotherapy -Dehydration, waking at night etc.

Posts.Content: Hiya, What your oncologist told you isn't strictly correct maybe you would have got a better answer from someone in radiology. J had her rads in Oct 2012 and her marks soon faded (within a year) and have have totally gone... so being permanent didn't happen -  unless they were heavy handed with the ink perhaps yours will too over time. They are only meant to be very small 1mm dots, like a small freckle ? A few Rads units now offer 'invisible' fluorescent tattoos, only visible under UV light. This came about because of problems occurring with conventional marks on dark skinned patients. Sounds such a good idea to me I think everyone should given these as standard practice :-) Try to see yours as a badge of survivorship rather than of being a cancer victim. If they are larger or more obvious than you would like perhaps a gp referral to a dermatologist could offer a removal solution - If you go this route be picky though, you could end up with a worse removal mark than what the 'dot' is :-? G n' J

Posts.Title: 5th chemo don ......1 to go..... yay

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane, Hadn't heard from you for a while, see why now (surgery) This tingling feeling sounds like it could be a touch of Peripheral Neuropathy from the docetaxel, or maybe nerve damage from surgery. It can take quite a while after chemo to travel down the long nerves in arms and legs before you get any effects in fingers and toes from it (are your toes ok ?)  It could also be slight nerve damage from having lymph removal surgery seeing as it's the same side although there was only one taken they still have to sever a lot of nerves you to get at it. Maybe leave it another couple of days to see if it eases as the nerves heal and knit back together more. You say it is worse operation side, so assume you have some in the other hand ? Don't think you would have it on both sides if it was lymph nerve damage ? but I'm not medically trained so wouldn't feel safe confirming that.... As for the seroma it can take quite a while to re-absorb the fluid it you are producing lots. They can use a long needle to drain some away to ease the discomfort but they don't really like doing this as it can be a cause of infection and will probably refill with fluid by making space for it anyway. If it gets really uncomfortable or starts getting painful seek further help with it as the internal pressure can put a strain on any internal stitches. Take care Lizane, and good luck with your recovery, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Numb/Tingly Fingertips after surgery, is this normal?

Posts.Content: Morning Lizane, It's possible you weren't offered rads because your lymph nodes were negative and grade 2 but by all means do ask why they feel you don't need referring for radiotherapy if only to reassure you. Jackie was grade 3 and node negative but was given 15 rad sessions which apart from the daily travel inconvenience were a doddle compared to chemo, so maybe you are borderline for needing them ? If you would feel happier in yourself knowing you had thrown everything at it ask if you can have rads, they can only say no, unless for some medical reason they feel you would be at risk from rads. Like if the area to be treated was very close to either heart or lungs and couldn't be screened out from the radiation beams. They may say "why, do you think you need them" putting the ball in your court, so give it some thought in case they offer you the choice. http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertypes/BreastDCIS/TreatingDCIS/Radiotherapy.aspx You would be given the Tamoxifen whether you have the rads or not, so unfortunately you won't get away with that - It's a case of as well as, not instead of :-( Keep writing those questions down for today, take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Could we give some hope to people like me please?

Posts.Content: Hi catsrme Warm welcome to the club no one expected or ever wanted to join :( I would hang fire until you get you get the full biopsy details from the pathology lab on the 31st as treatments can change depending on the type of breast cancer they find (there are around 6 common types) Around 65% have surgery first but for the other 35% chemotherapy can be the first line of treatment to not only to shrink the tumour down but to start killing the tumour cells straight away if they have any concerns it could possibly spread as chemo is a whole body treatment. J my better half had surgery first within 2 weeks of her breast cancer diagnosis biopsy results came through and the rest of her treatments were tailored to her BC type from the surgery tissue lab results but having to wait another few weeks would make very little or no difference to the risk of this having spread further. Don't fret over whatever size it is, it may well still be contained to one area and certainly don't worry about this being something you may have caused - that is rarely the case. Looks like your message got cut short; was there something else you wanted ask ?  "What I really want to know" ?? Assume you are just over the border from us in Norfolk then ? Good Luck Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Surgery waiting time

Posts.Content: Morning Ruby Rose Got the notification from Leolady about Risedronate (35mg) and as you seem to have found out there are very few possible side effects from it. J my better half was taking Alendronic Acid (Fosamax) which is very similar (one tablet per week) for 5 years with no problems whatsoever. These are both bone strengthening drugs, usually taken if you are a slightly osteopaenic and taking something like Letrozole, Anastrozole etc. Only comment I would make is the oncologist put her on Alendronic Acid as the bone density benefits were better with that than from Risedronate, so it may be worth asking yours about the difference to you ? Whilst taking them she was also taking Adcal+ chews (one twice a day) the + means they have added vitamin D3. The only thing you have to be really careful with is to ensure you take Risedronate with plenty of water (at least half a pint) and you must remain upright (standing or seated) for at least 30 minutes aftwerwards or the drug can damage your oesophagus. These type of meds can be a bit unsuitable for anyone with reflux or oesophagus problems that can cause them not to reach the stomach within half an hour as the tablet coating disolves after that time. So that probably explains the omeprazole to lower your stomach acid. Her Alendronic tabs were 70mg - do you know if the Risedronate you will be taking are 35mg ? How bad is your PN ? J still has slightly numb big toes 6 years on. Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Dogs (man's best friends)

Posts.Content: Hi Jane, Welcome to the group. What they don't tell you in their 'shock tactics' adverts is that breast cancer has a 90% recovery rate and of the other 10% some will have underlying health issues that means they cannot have some of the treatments or are have their cancers found at a very advanced state. In the UK there are an unbelievable 55,000 women diagnosed with BC every year (over a thousand per week) just to put this into perspective. If you can share six months of your life with us, honestly, we can all help get you through this. Best wishes for good results on the 13th. No doubt you have gone through every very scary scenario in your head - are your main worries whether you will need chemo or not ? Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: Happy Christmas Yvonne - Great to see you getting into the christmas spirit. Have a lovely family day you have had a tough year hun. Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Just like to see A Merry Christmas

Posts.Content: Hiya Mandy-Moo, That was a hard slap in the face getting diagnosed yourself so soon after losing your dear mum :-(    It has to be the fact you helped your mum and know it can be a tough path to tread so you have a good idea of how any treatments will affect you and that has given you a great attitude to deal with this. As long as you realise this is you, you are not your mum BC treatment has a very high % of success compared to most other cancers inc lung.  Everyone else around you will only know the horror stories about terminal cases as seen in tv soaps and the media that unless they have had personal dealings with cancer in their own families never get to hear about the very high percentage that beat this crap disease and go on to live almost normal lives afterwards. So you get the sorrowful looks and the head nods now and later when you are mid treatment you will get 'you look well'  and 'you are being so brave'  which, yes you are but you have no choice - you just don't want to hear it from everyone you meet :-) This is a great place full to bursting with members who will go the extra mile with you and give you friendly advice, support and helpful tips on every stage of your treatments. There is always someone at exactly the same treatment stage as you to share the journey with, many become firm friends. Do you know your HER2 status from pathology yet ? If you are HER2+ you will probably be given Herceptin as well but that is a pussycat, so don't fret about it if you get that drug chucked at you as well. See you also joined the under 50's group - that's ok you can read posts from other younger women diagnosed but that group isn't very active compared to this one, so if you need info in a hurry this is the one to post to first.   A few rules... Don't google stuff most of the info out there is either way out of date, or misleadingly wrong. Stick with reliable uk sites like Macmillan and breastcancer care uk - don't ever feel you have to apologise for letting off steam here if you get down days and there is no such thing as a silly question  :-) Won't say welcome to the club as no one really wants to be here :-/ Take care Mandy, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Is how I am feeling normal?

Posts.Content: Hi Islanikita, Welcome to the breast group, sound like you are having a tough time after your surgery, it can all get a bit relentless :( Do you intend having a reconstruction at some time ? As they can reduce your other breast down to near enough match with the reconstruction. They tend not to carry out large cup reconstructions as the weight creates healing and recovery issues. Balance after a mastectomy is always a big problem for larger ladies. A lot of ladies take this option, it isn't perfect but it is better than spending the rest of your life this way. As for your underwired bras, you can always 'nick' the fabric and remove the wire from your surgery side cup for now if it helps. The full prothesis can also be a problem as it is so much heavier than the softies. Has anything been mentioned to you about a reconstruction yet ? Take care, G n' J Islanikita
Posts.Title: Made to feel like a freak because I am larger breasted

Posts.Content: Hi Dindu  It's good your wife was referred for biopsies as there is an uncommon type of Pagets that can mimic Melanoma so there may be a connection. Also If the symptoms are dry, scaly skin around the nipple It can very often mistaken by GP's initially as eczema too. The usual time frame for biopsy results is 10-14 days which everyone here hates with a passion - that two week waiting results time can be emotionally crushing :( You just have to hope for the best, rather than fearing the worst and try to get through this period with your sanity intact.  Feeling painful for a few days afterwards is the norm but this does ease off after a while. Depending on how deep they were taken from as the breast and nipple area has lots of nerves and is very sensitive. Having the ultrasound come back clear is a good sign but not wanting to dash your hopes, there are quite a few ladies here that were diagnosed with BC who also had nothing confirmed from mammogram or ultrasound, unfortunately it's not an exact science. Keep posting messages and asking any questions you have, it will let us help you get through the next week or two. Fingers crossed all is well, a lay-by stop here is so much better than being in it for the long haul. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Padgets desease

Posts.Content: Hi Julie,  Sorry to see you joining us here, there are a couple of other ladies in the breast group who live in Spain Patricia34 and Mo66 who are both near Torrevieja (mo hasn't posted for a month) so may not be reading posts here now there may be other members in Spain too. About your nails - Are you on a Tax type chemo (Docetaxel, Taxol, Taxotere ?) they are the main ones that affect nails. The blue / purple colour may turn to black and you may lose some of your nails but will soon have new ones underneath. You can read more about it here. Know it is a page from the Australian Breast Cancer Network but it's the best page for chemo nail information. Don't think it will be a heart / circulation problem but you could show them your nails and ask next time you are there. You got good advice about drinking plenty of fluids it helps flush the chemo through your kidneys and liver and gets the residue out of your system quicker which can help ease some of the side effects. Hope this helps, if you have other questions just ask, we are all here to help each other. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: finger nails and chemo

Posts.Content: Evening Dindu  It is about you too you are facing this as a couple and in some ways it can be harder for the bystander as you feel a bit guilty you can do nothing to fix this or take it away. The feeling everything is starting to get a bit out of control ? There's no manual as all couples are different your wife may want to know all the in's and out's but could just as easily not want to talk about it at all and just wants it all to go away. Don't go overthinking this and getting way ahead of yourselves reconstruction may not be needed with a lumpectomy if it comes to that. Just deal with this in bite size pieces one week at a time (one day at a time if easier) - It's so easy to get all consumed by this and waste a lot of time reading up about treatments that may not be needed. Breast Cancer Care produce a booklet "In It Together" which you might find helpful. Just click the title, this can also be saved if you would like to refer back to it. The booklet assumes a breast cancer diagnosis is confirmed but this isn't actually you two yet, and hopefully won't be so just take in the emotional 'being there' section and reach / cross the other bridges if needed. I'm pretty sure a lot of the lovely ladies here will reply mentioning what they would like from their husband as this tough time, so I'll leave that to them :) G n' J
Posts.Title: Padgets desease

Posts.Content: Hi Cocopops1  Welcome to the Mac community and the breast group. Your blood test saying your Gamma GGT is slightly high which could be caused by many different things. It doesn't necessarily mean damage from spread to the liver in the way you are thinking. Some of the other things which could cause this to raise slightly are having previously damaged your liver (car accident etc) smoking, drinking alcohol, and use of many prescription and non-prescription drugs including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), lipid-lowering drugs (statins), antibiotics, histamine blockers (used to treat excess stomach acid production), antifungal agents, anticonvulsants (seizure control medications), antidepressants can all affect the gamma ggt level. You are right though, as soon as you hear the word cancer all the scary what if's come out of the cupboard to put your mind into overdrive and it's hard to ignore them until you get some answers about what the heck is going on. Fingers crossed your results will mean you having a short stay here - however if this is cancer there are loads of us here to help you so you don't feel so alone. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Scary times ahead

Posts.Content: Hi Mlanders, You won't find out what treatment regime they have worked out for you until you get your pathology results from the surgery tissue Friday. This is where they fine tune and tailor your treatment plan. Also you will find out if you are ER+ positive (oestrogen) and more importantly as far as chemo goes your HER2 status. If you are HER2+ you will need Herceptin and this is always given in conjunction with chemotherapy. You can read more about his here 'Understanding Your Pathology Report' The section about ER and HER2 starts on page 12. Do you know what type of breast cancer you were diagnosed with (Ductal DCIS, Lobular, Invasive etc) as this may also have a bearing on chemo being offered. I have no idea what your job entails but I think returning to work so soon may be expecting a bit too much. Have you spoken to them about a phased return, if not do wait until you find out more Friday . Always expect the unexpected as it is not unusual for them to upgrade from 2 up to a 3 because they have a lot more tissue to examine and the biopsy may not have been taken from the most aggressive area. Keeping our fingers crossed for you, good luck Friday. G n' J

Best wishes for good news regarding treatment some are more do'able than others but we're all here to help whatever your team puts your way. If you have any questions or just need a hug and a soft shoulder or a rant to get it out your system here rather than at home, just holler this is such a busy group there is always someone around. Can you get back to us with a little more info ?  If this is from nerve damage it does heal and disappear after a couple of weeks :) Hope you are finding the post surgery exercises manageable. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Op done and now home

Posts.Content: Hi Grogg, Have you tried having any late afternoon and evening drinks that won't over hydrate you ? Tea is thought to contain more caffeine than coffee unless you like your coffee really strong (caffeine is a diuretic) so if you need a tea time hot drink it may be better to have a coffee rather than tea, better still a glass of milk cold or warm in the evening instead of water based drink may help you not wanting to get up so often for a pee ? If you aren't taking any diuretics but think you may be feeling thirsty too often it may be worth having a quick diabetes test next time you are at your GP's as constant thirst can be a diabetes symptom it can also be a sign of hyperthyroidism ? G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning Broken-Emi  /  Emily Hope you feel a little better this morning after a bit of an emotional release - Information overload when it's already a steep learning curve will easily push you over the edge when you get to find out all you may be facing :( Just concentrate on getting enough info in advance to do this one week at a time, it's so much easier to deal with in bite size chunks. You can do this - You are a lot stronger than you ever realised. It just takes a while to get your head into a better place. One thing I will add - If you get offered a PICC line or Portacath - Grab it with a smile... They are great. If you don't get an offer ask if they can fit one, they make chemo so'ooo much easier to deal with. You are not broken, you are just having a wobble.... Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Padgets desease

Posts.Content: Morning Irish Girl, It's a bummer when this happens. They will try to find out if it was the FEC that has caused a loss of heart function (chamber muscle strength) or it may even be a problem you have always had but until now has never been found ? Jackie had 4 Herceptin sessions and her heart function dropped below their base level and they cancelled it for that period and she missed one session - Three weeks later her heart function had recovered enough to continue with Herceptin and she had no other delays until she finished the 18 session course. Hopefully it's just a blip and you will get given the Herceptin when things improve, but if this is a problem not caused by cancer treatment it may be your heart just isn't strong enough to handle the side effects - They certainly won't risk it causing any permanent damage which can happen in some cases :-( There is a bit of info about Herceptin and heart issues here. (link) Fingers crossed it all sorts itself out and you will be started on it before too long. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Content: Morning Ann156 Yup, Doxorubicin aka Adriamycin is on the hit list as being able to do that to you as well. So you are HER2+ then; so was J 6 years ago, treatments for her2+ have changed even over that timeframe and they were good back then when Herceptin was introduced it was a game changer for her2+ BC.  It is more like walking a full marathon than running a sprint but it works. Posts.Content: Hi Godblessdiva  This can be a tricky one to navigate if they don't just offer you the reports and images on disc, usually there is an add on charge for this service :( Under the data protection act you are entitled to your reports but some have riders that won't release information without the permission of your referring doctor ? Posts.Title: Scan reports

Posts.Content: Evening Ann156 Sorry to read about your nails - is your chemo one of the taxanes like Docetaxel or Paclitaxel ? or something else. As there several types which can cause this. For some painting your nails black or using a black base coat for another darker colour on top like purple etc can help as it reduces the UV light reaction some people get.  This is usually done before starting chemo so may be a little late for you but could help if you have more sessions to follow. If you do decide to paint your nails get hold of some Acetone Free remover as it won't dry the skin out so much. It could lead to nail loss if the nail bed is badly affected but this my not happen until a new nail has formed underneath and they sort of delaminate. Mac has an info page about Skin and Nailcare (link) while on treatment you can read through, but do keep a lookout for the October Chemo Discussion in the Breast Group you joined and ask about this problem there too. If they do start lifting you can keep them in place with steristrip to avoid snagging them on clothing etc - J lost all 20 of hers over a 4 month period post Docetaxel, but it is very uncommon to loose all of them; but if you are prone to this keep a check on your toenails as well :-/ Hope this is of some help, take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: emotions I really didn't expect

Posts.Content: Hi I'm sort of sitting on the fence with this a tad :) There are some good 'complimentary' aids to cancer treatment side effects out there - providing your oncologist checks them against any meds you are taking for contradictions but, and it's a big but - it's the unknown additives in these compounds that cannot be vouched for because they vary between brands. Very much like when you get generic versions of hormone inhibitor tablets (don't get me started on those)  :-/ The biggest stumbling block is complimentary vs alternative. To my mind alternative is the last resort when all the conventional treatments and meds have been tried and for whatever reason not worked.  It's certainly (in my view) something you should not be looking into at the start of treatment or when newly diagnosed. Chemotherapy can sound very scary and taking a few herbal remedies can seem a much easier alternative - No one surely would recommend using any alternative therapies at this stage ? If you are already 'into' the Supplements / Herbal lifestyle way of thinking this probably comes as second nature but there are a lot of members who haven't the patience or time to wade through all the tech talk about these different compounds to weigh up what could be beneficial - yet alone have the finances to pay out what, £60 maybe much more every month for them when getting by with a cancer induced lower income is their main priority. We are all different and have differing views of all this all you can do is what feels right for you! Personally I view a lot of this like Jehovah's ringing our doorbell, I don't agree with their views but it's their life to lead however they want to - I just don't want or need converting thanks :) Now where did I put that cup of tea and chocolate Hobnob....  G n' J

Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: Hi Gaynor, Sorry to read that the cold cap hasn't been as successful for you. Unfortunately like all these treatments be it chemotherapy drugs, hormone inhibitor tablets etc, everyone get affected differently by them. Some can sail through one sort of chemo relatively side effect free only be hit by a truck with the second set and vice-versa. The soreness you are feeling is tied in with the hair loss. A lot of members here just prior to losing hair mention a pulling feeling like when you were a child and having a 'too tight' ponytail in ? There is no way to tell if you will lose more hair or if it will stabilise but if it gets to the 'what a mess - I can't be dealing with this' stage and you decide to lose it, clipper it short, don't shave it because if you 'nick' your scalp it can become a site for infection to get in. You would be surprised the number of folks who get wigs and then only wear them a couple of times and go the bandanna / hat route. Have you got a wig cap liner for your head, if not they one is worth getting as wigs can make you head a bit hot / sweaty and itchy. J never even bothered getting a wig, she bought some bandannas but mostly went 'commando' which is quite apt really because you not only look like one, as far as cancer is concerned you are giving it such a pasting.... No matter what happens with your hair at the end of the day as long as when you look in the mirror you see a warrior looking back at you and not a victim, you'll be fine. Any hair lost will grow back so although you may feel your hair defined you it does tend to slip down your list of priorities quite rapidly as you progress through chemo. It's great later when is does 'peach' back through though :-) How many TC are you having in total ? Do check out and join in with  the August Chemo Club Discussion. G n' J
Posts.Title: Hair Loss

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa, Regarding you asking about Tax - It's a bit confusing. Tax mentioned here is usually Taxotere also known as Docetaxel - However there is also a chemo drug named Taxol also known as Paclitaxel which can also be used for breast cancer which is sometimes wrongly called Tax The main differences are Taxotere is given at 3 weekly intervals mostly by the NHS where Taxol is given in smaller doses weekly mostly by those getting private treatment through BUPA etc Sometimes you will get Taxol through the nhs but because the nhs saves money by only having one session every three weeks and Taxotere is a bit cheaper than Taxol. The side effects with Taxol are usually not so severe because of the smaller more do'able doses. You will see it written here as FEC-T which is the most common chemo regime for BC.  FEC is 3 dif drugs given at the same time then you switch to T (taxotere) both are mostly 3 or 4 sessions of each given at 3 weekly intervals. If you want to have a read of the Maccy info pages just click the green text links below. T = Taxotere (Docetaxel) T = Taxol (Paclitaxel) FEC = combination chemo ( 3 drugs) The EC you see mentioned on this thread is FEC but without the F part which is Fluorouracil 5FU  Some oncologists are now not including the F part as it can affect the heart and side effects from EC are more manageable. Hope this helps, G n' J

Posts.Title: Quick question.

Posts.Content: Hi Jenson, Regarding admin deleting messages or editing out links - Don't take it personally as anything that doesn't come with a 100% cast iron guarantee of being legitimate and safe would suffer the same fate. Macmillan cannot take any chances as there are many really vulnerable members here who may think Macmillan is actually promoting 'whatever substance' is being linked to - there are so many scammers out there willing to sell anything of dubious quality to anyone. At the moment it's a bit like where they replace carbon dioxide in beer with helium (guaranteed to stop drunk people arguing / fighting) but it's not been proved legally safe to drink :) There are loads of really promising trials going ahead using cannabinoids at the present time but like everything else it takes forever to get new meds tested and licensed.  It took around 6 years to get the cannabis derived meds Sativex (for MS) and Epidiolex (for epilepsy) through all the regulations. It would help if the government took it on through the NHS/NICE and produced a list of cannabis oil makes that were known to be consistent quality, safe and legal to purchase in the UK, but until then unfortunately it's still too much of a grey area. At least that would stop all the dodgy stuff being sold. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4  There have been several ladies here with 12cm lumps that were probably smaller than 38JJ and they missed feeling theirs so it is easily done and not worthy of a guilt trip.They went through treatment and came out the other side and you will too. 5cm is only just larger than a golf ball which compared to a JJ boob would be hard to find ? Only in very, very rare exceptional circumstances is no treatment at all offered - The chances of them saying this to you is is near to nil as you could possibly get. In the grand scheme of things tumour size doesn't count for much regarding prognosis - some ovarian tumours can be the size of footballs :( You will feel aches and pains, some as you mention from the biopsy - Others from you being all tensed up and probably subconsciously moving around in a more protective way which is causing you to use different muscles, lack of sleep etc - it all adds up to Jojo with no Mojo. You need to do something that causes you to concentrate and kills time for the next week - there are several 'puter games that can do that along the lines of Candy Crush etc You're doing fine, just be kinder to yourself, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi, Unfortunately the comment 'There are more people making a living from cancer than there are dying from it' has never been more true. A lot of natural products are in the process of being tested at this very moment  in the same way as Yew was many years ago and where the Taxane based chemotherapy drugs originated but any refined drugs are a long way from the natural versions you can buy over the counter. It's the research and development and all the trialling that has to be done before licensing and marketing which hikes the final price up :( I'm not saying there isn't a very high added mark up and all the big pharma companies are guilty of profiteering on a grand scale, but if they didn't carry out all the R&D work who would ? Cancer Research has a 10 Cancer Myths De-bunked page which has a lot of information regarding topics from superstition to superfoods which is a good read. G n' J

Posts.Title: Quick question.

Posts.Content: Hi juliet 65  Must admit if you are definitely HER2+ positive and having Herceptin unless NICE have revised their pathway for herceptin this does seem weird ? According to NICE Herceptin is only licensed to be given in conjunction with any of the Taxane type chemo drugs (Taxol/Taxotere) when treating HER2+ breast cancer. Which is more commonly FEC or EC sessions first then switching to Taxotere or Taxol for the Herceptin. I was always under the impression that because both the Epirubicin and Herceptin can cause damage to the heart muscle, so regarding FEC or EC they are not given together (double whammy) I'd suggest you ask your oncologist on Monday for clarification, or get in touch with your Onco unit or BCN today to double check that they have got you down for having Herceptin ? and will be getting changed to T after 3 sessions of EC or if they are following a different regime. Hope you get this clarified - Know it's April Fools day, but this is not the time for larking about :) Take care, G n' J

Hugs to you and Sharne, G n' J
Posts.Title: Chemo done!

Posts.Content: Hi, We had 4 cats and a dog who were with us all through Jackie's chemotherapy (18 weeks) and as long as you are careful especially during the middle (low immune system) week and take all the necessary precautions as mentioned the benefits outweigh the risks. Main things to take on board are definitely no cleaning up puddles and mishaps, avoiding any licking making sure the puppy is inoculated, wormed and healthy prior to you getting it home, regular washing of hands if pets are handled. Care against scratches and those sharp puppy teeth. No need to really wrap yourself up in cotton wool and not leave the house for 18 weeks you just can't live like that, and have to use a bit of common sense - most of any infections that are picked up during the middle week are from yourself.... rather than from other people - as we carry loads of bugs around with us that normally are no problem for our immune system. You could also go for a docile breed type rather than the hypo breeds that bound around and fly about like a dawg possessed :-) Biggest problem is that a lot of days during chemo you just haven't got the energy to drag yourself out of the house for walkie's, but on the days you are feeling a bit brighter a stroll in the fresh air is great. Those cra* days are the days it will be someone else getting the joys of dog walking. Just don't forget when you feel you have walked far enough, you have to turn around and walk all the way back again :-/ Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Silly Question??

Posts.Content: Thanks for the 'Heads Up' Marg.  Looks like a well thought out programme - There is more info about it here. G n' J
Posts.Title: beating breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Shellie, Welcome to a great place to be at a tough time. Have you actually been diagnosed with BC after seeing nothing on the scans or are you being checked out and are worried in case you are diagnosed with this although nothing is visible ? In answer to your question, yes! quite a few ladies here have been diagnosed after having nothing visible in the way of lumps. In the same way as lots who have had lumps or other signs have found them to be cysts, areas of calcification or any of the other many non-cancerous breast problems. Not all types of breast cancer appear as a lump and there are also other symptoms that can appear before any lumps form, like a nipple starting to invert or pucker, breast skin texture looking different, discharge or bleeding from nipple, breast looking inflamed (red and feeling hot) besides aches and twinges which could be put down to monthly hormone changes but may be an initial sign of something more sinister. Younger women's breast tissue is also lot more dense so that can cause problems with getting a good mammogram image. Do get back to us with a little more info as to what problems you have or where you are at the diagnosis stage so we can give you some support and info. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Invisible lumps??

Posts.Content: Hi Shellie, Hoping the ladies here will reply to you today with their views on this..... I would be a bit concerned too :-/ If they could feel something but not 'see' it why didn't they try to biopsy them or send you for an MRI scan ? Whether these lumps painful or not (some are and some aren't) sometimes any pain increase or decrease can follow your monthly cycle if the lumps are hormone related - perhaps this is why they want to let you keep an eye on it for a few weeks to see if anything changes. Have you noticed any changes during your cycle or do these lumps always feel the same throughout the 28 days ? Sometimes lobular type breast cancer isn't 'seen' on ultrasound either. Personally I wouldn't let this lie for too long if at all, you need answers - I don't want to worry you but if something doesn't feel right then something must be wrong, hopefully something minor but it needs looking into further not dismissing. Do look out for more replies to your message during the day as I'm certain you will get several with other members views on this. If it was me I would make it really clear you are not happy with the wait and watch approach it is wrong that you have these lumps and nothing is going to be done to find out what they are as a matter of urgency :(   Especially as you have a family history of BC and OC - Did your consultant know about your family history, if not he / she needs making aware of this and put you forward for further checks. How on earth they expect you to lead a worry free normal family life when you have this scary unanswered question is beyond me. Oh, and don't let them play the you are too young card either, there are cases of women in their late twenties diagnosed with BC which unfortunately seems to be on the increase. Do have a read about breast lumps here, it explains what any lump(s) could be. Maybe something will seem similar to what you may have. I'm trying so hard to not alarm you but do chase this up again to find out exactly what this is, for your own peace of mind. G n' J

Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over

Posts.Content: Hi Leona, Just got back home from work.... 'er, I also go for what Julia said :) CT can be used to monitor existing tumours to check how effective chemo is working but isn't generally used initially to actually find cancer cells. There is a condition known as Paget's disease which affects the nipple and is mostly benign but can be cancerous you can check that out clicking here and paget's can also be found in those with BC. The sooner you get some action leading to answers the better I think. So, you are a Maths geek ? You are going to hate these.... "Hired an odd-job man to do 8 jobs for me. When I got back, he'd only done jobs 1,3,5, and 7" Last night I dreamed that I was weightless! I was like, 0mg Sorry, it had to be said  LOL Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Invisible lumps??

Posts.Content: Hi  JJsailor  Pleased to read you are back home - 7 weeks in hospital is a tough call :( Thank you for highlighting the pitfalls - It's nice to think you can regain some of your former body shape back by taking up the offer of reconstruction, but when things go wrong, they can go really wrong and become a long term nightmare scenario to have to cope with. Because the flap types use your own tissue they are basically a double operation for each breast.  It is a surprisingly higher number than you would first think who seem to get recovery issues too, with either the reconstruction site, or the donor tissue site. Now you are back at home, in your own bed getting a better nights sleep than in a noisy hospital ward hopefully your recovery will speed up a tad. Gentle hugs JJ, you certainly have been to hell and back :( G n' J
Posts.Title: Back from hospital after DIEP

Posts.Content: Hi Emily, The steroids are mostly (although not entirely) to counter any feelings of nausea which isn't anywhere near so much of a problem with Docetaxel as with FEC or EC. You could have a chat with your Onco about this and also see if they are willing to try you on a minimal steroid dosage, or lower your Docetaxel dosage by 20% so you need a lot lower dose of steroids.Lowering it by 20% won't be detrimental to it's effectiveness. You could ask about being given weekly Paclitaxel also known as Taxol, which is very similar to Docetaxel but in smaller weekly doses therefore a lot less of a problem with side effects ? Paclitaxel could possibly be do'able without the steroids at all ?  I'm not medically trained so you will have to seek their advice on this but from the sounds of your previous problems anything has to be better than going through that again :-/ There are options so do get some answers to help you get through this. Take care, G n' J Edit - Good point about the anaphylactic shock Julia, thanks for adding that...
Posts.Title: Psychotic reaction to chemo steroids

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, I'm hoping nobody pours scorn either - There is no need for any of that around here :) As long as whoever wants to try complimentary items has checked they will have no contradictions with the meds they are on and have researched them well enough to find out if they are safe in the dosages they will be taking, that's good enough in my book and nobody has the right to say otherwise. If there are obvious dangers the poster may not know about, by all means advise but that's as far as arm twisting should go. Everyone goes through so much angst dealing with cancer and the side effects of treatment, if you can find something that helps with this then why should anyone criticise that - it's your body after all :)  and there is a lot to be said for quality over quantity post cancer treatment. I think a lot of the worrying issues are when members start talking about alternative as opposed to complimentary. There are those who feel alternative is the best way to go, but if you are a firm believer in conventional medicine it is really scary to read someone may forego this in the hope that some obscure natural remedy may cure them. I must admit I've never checked a turkeys tail to see if mushrooms grew there  LOL G n' J
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: Morning  Kathy,  Are you are worried because you don't really know why they are not offering you any other treatment, or worried because you are "not" getting it ? Either way you have to ask specific questions to medical staff. They don't "get it" if you just hint at something you need info about. So to clear that one up I think the first Q should be why have they decided you don't need any other treatment and if you don't understand any parts of their answer tell them. Some of these medical folks spend so much time talking "tech speak" amongst themselves they find it hard putting info into plain english that we can understand :-)   You could ask about what the next step is regarding monitoring you, how long before your next check up and will it just be a mammogram or ultrasound scan. If you think you may need some info for future reference maybe for getting travel/medical insurance, or just for "you" in case as time goes by you forget some details etc ask to have a printout of all your diagnosis and treatments. I guess you are not going to be taking any of the (5 year) hormone tablets either then ? So if that is the case you won't need to worry about Dexa bone scans for osteopenia, but if you are on these, then do ask about that side of it too. If you feel brave enough you could ask about chances of re-occurance over any given time span. Coming to the end of your treatment can make you feel a bit abandoned and forgotten about especially if you have practically lived your life around doctor and hospital appointments for what seems like ages. Perfectly normal and this isn't the case - it's just that now in their eyes you are cancer free and cured........... Now that IS worth celebrating. Maybe you'll get a few more answers before your appt today adding anything I may have missed, especially regarding the ld recon as Jackie never had this. Take care,  George & Jackie

Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: Is this the long agonising wait for your Oncotype results to see if you need chemo or not ? You can bet the Christmas period added a bit of time to keep you on tenterhooks for a bit longer too :( Can't speed things up but we can send you a huge {HUG} and keep our fingers tightly crossed for you getting some news very soon. Good luck, G n' J
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: Hi JJ, In a few words, so typical and totally normal. You spend what seems ages fretting while waiting the scan and biopsy results - you get surgery and in your head you know the cancer has been removed and after the anaesthetic wears off you feel great  about this. Then it dawns on you you only know half the story and the worries start simmering again while you wait for the pathology results. It's not a case of panicking for nothing, it's more like it doesn't matter how much you panic it won't change the results, so the panicking needs telling to 'sod off' while you concentrate on recovering from surgery :-) You can have a read of this 'Understanding Your Pathology Report' before Wednesday and see if it raises any questions you may want to ask about further treatments they may offer you ? Have you been told anything as yet - type of bc etc Do reply if you have other concerns, the only silly questions are the ones not asked... Just noticed your other reply, the shooting pains you describe sound very much like any nerves cut during surgery trying to repair themselves. This can feel like sharp twinges, stabs, even little electric shocks - some have even mentioned it feeling like it's wet from hot or cold water too ? Take care, and good luck with your results. G n' J
Posts.Title: Is it normal to feel so low, tired and achy?

Posts.Content: Hi BB, Sorry to see another new member joining the club no one wanted to be in - Welcome to our self help haven it's a very active and friendly place. About your question 'how deep' is a tough one to answer because the very nature of SNLB is that the sentinel node is regarded as the nearest one but this usually found with the tracer dye so could be in towards the breast or in the armpit. Surgery to the armpit could be quite deep, depending on how far they had to 'go in' to reach it. Keep up with the painkillers, ask if you can use some with and without paracetamol in if that is ok, you can alternate taking some every two hourly - this may also be pain from any cut nerves repairing themselves as well and sometimes these 'pangs' can feel really weird. Hope this is of some help, G n' J
