Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information

Posts.Content: Hi Caitlin  /  Caitlin59  Chemo Brain or Chemo Fog as it's sometimes called is a mild form of cognitive impairment that affects some who have chemotherapy or hormone inhibitor treatment like Tamoxifen etc. The figures for those affected range between 15% and 50% and the severity of it varies from person to person a lot too. for the most part it can be amusing as long as you don't let it get you down. There is more information about it here at CRUK (cancer research uk) This sort of sums it up nicely... G n' J
Posts.Title: One year on and 1st mamograme

Posts.Content: Hi Year 4 teacher  Sorry to read you are getting multiple post surgery healing issues and your results are dragging on a tad :( In reality 2nd of May is only 5 days away, but if you are to be having chemotherapy, this may not be started until 10 - 14 days after that appointment.  Hopefully during that time you will have fully healed because they won't want to start chemo until all signs of possible infection have gone.   Last thing they will want to risk is the chance you still having a slight infection and the chemo wiping out your white cells leaving you with no immune system in place to combat the infection. When your white count is low, it is surprisingly easy for something you would normally simply shrug off to take hold and floor you. Try to make the most of this 'free' time to build yourself up in prep for the chemo and buying some valuable extra healing time. Everyone would much prefer to just get on with it and get treatment started, but it's much better for you long term if you are as fit as possible before you start down that particular road :) Fingers crossed for the 2nd, hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Throwing up

Posts.Content: Hola Julie  :-)   Try and work the times out so you try not to take the steroids after 4pm if you can as the later you take it the more chance there is you will have trouble getting to sleep. They can also make you want to nibble snacks all the time.  They are always given with chemo along with the anti sickness tablets they do help with the side effects a bit so keep taking them even if you feel fine.   If your new cycle is Taxotere (docetaxel)  you will get a 3 or 4 day honeymoon period where you think 'this is ok' - then you wake up and could feel like you have been hit by a truck during the night (some get away with it) just letting you know in case it happens. Affects your bones and joints and coupled with fatigue you can feel like you aged 20 years overnight for a few days - If this happens you will start to feel a bit better by around day 9 or 10. Don't be surprised if you need a longer siesta time. It may help if you get some mouthwash with Chlorhexidine in if not from the hospital get some Corsodyl from a pharmacy because mouth ulcers and oral thrush is quite common with Tax. If this happens and your sense of taste goes weird try a bit of pineapple or a ginger nut biscuit before you eat. Feeling like Des O'Conner is fine - Just don't start singing like him  LOL Dos San Miguel por fa'vour, - Chink, Cheers   Take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie, We both went the same route as Heather and found it so much easier to quit using e-cigs than by using gum, patches or tablets which for both of us were a waste of time and money. If you find you are really struggling give the e-cigs that take tobacco flavoured fluid a trial period to get you through the first month or so. We were both long time smokers and it has been nearly 3 years for us - we have never looked back and it must be saving us loads of ca$h too :-) There is this Macmillan booklet 'Giving Up Smoking' if you need some encouragement. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Smiffy2512  Like Helen mentions once you get your biopsy results if your fears about breast cancer are confirmed your treatment plan kicks in and your feet usually don't touch the ground. After being diagnosed from the biopsy Jackie (my better half) had surgery (mastectomy) 10 days later - It was originally going to be 2 weeks but they had a surgery cancellation and phoned to ask if she was OK to come in a few days sooner. J then started her chemotherapy sessions 4 weeks post op. If you have enough cash stashed away for private surgery - Hang onto it,  go with the NHS and use the money you saved to treat yourself to a post treatment holiday - 'cause you will deserve one.... It will give you something to aim for as a reward for all you have been through :) Good Luck with your results, hugs, G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi Poppylisa  Know about that scenario - You tell people who want to know, then you end up feeling like you are supporting them when it should be the other way round   :) Bummer about the late diagnosis, why the heck doctors just assume because you are younger it can't be cancer is beyond me :( There was another lady who we mentioned joining the secondary group to earlier today who also has BC secondaries to hip and spine her member name is cazwaz   Think she joined so maybe you will see her posting there at some time. Fingers crossed for the rest of your FEC, hugs to you and your little ones, G n' J
Posts.Title: bit of a ramble starting to wobble!

Posts.Content: Hi JJ, You have certainly had an emotional year so far, please don't beat yourself up over any of this. It's very unfortunate you were in hospital when your sister in law was so poorly but maybe you will have better memories of her because of this. It won't stop your feelings of guilt about being unable to visit, but with palliative care and strong pain relief she may well have not even realised you were there :-( When you are over this, you can do stuff with her children to help ease their loss. Grade 2 ductal is usually borderline for chemo. ER- negative means you will not need the 5 years worth of hormone inhibitor tablets, but you will probably be given radiotherapy later. So this means your further treatment all hinges on if you are HER2 positive or negative ? If you are HER2+ positive you will be offered/given Herceptin. This is licensed by NICE to only be used in conjunction with chemo, it is never given on it's own. You aren't a complete mess, you just need to give yourself some time to accept all the very emotional things that are going on around you. The tears are helping with this, it certainly is a lot better than trying to be strong (whatever that means) bottling it all up and having a major meltdown later. Take care JJ, you can so do this (Hugs)  G n' J

Posts.Title: Parabens, etc

Posts.Content: Hiya,  Well, it's a good thing because they now know what hormones the cancer is feeding off so they can use tablets and/or Herceptin to stop production and mop up those hormones they also block the receptors in the cancer cells so the hormone that feeds it cannot lock on - So they DIE... Good eh ? Maccy info page with some links for more hormone treatment can be found here. http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertypes/Breast/Symptomsdiagnosis/HormoneandHER2receptors/HormoneandHER2receptors.aspx Downside of this is all the baggage that comes with taking the tablets :-(  G  n' J

Posts.Title: Operation

Posts.Content: Hiya, 'Early' can mean several things like finding it within 4 months of a previous clear mammogram or while looking for something else unrelated, but in the true sense of their wording for BC it would be DCIS or LCIS (ductal or lobular in situ) it doesn't become classed as invasive while it is contained (in situ)  Early can also refer to finding a pre-cancerous condition. Unless tissue samples from the path lab upgrades them these are at first classed as grade zero. Where the cells 'break out through the wall where it was contained  it then becomes invasive, sounds harsh but may only mean a few cells have settled in areas close to the original cluster - terms like like vascular invasion or some cells found trapped in the nearest lymph nodes. Early can also be used where the tumour size is small, but as we all know even small tumours can be found to be a higher grade 2 or 3, so this is a bit of a misconception. it is a very grey area and 'early' is a loosely used term (even by us here) and personally I don't think it counts for much.  Jackie was DCIS (grade zero remember ?) with a fairly small 8mm tumour just behind the nipple. Post surgery pathology confirmed it was in fact Grade 3 ER+  &  PR+  and also HER2+ so she had MX, 6 x chemo, 18 x  Herceptin and 15 x rads - So DCIS doesn't count for much until the final results are in :( Think I've just muddied the water a bit,  G n' J

Posts.Title: An exciting day!

Posts.Content: Hi jules66  There is this interesting Cancer Research UK (CRUK) information page about Nail and Skin problems from cancer treatments. Although brittle nails aren't listed as a common side effect from Tamoxifen hair thinning is and hair and nails are made from the same stuff so if it affects hair chances are it can effect nails too :( There are loads of messages here and in Breast Cancer Care forums about brittle nails and Tamoxifen so there must be something in it. Jackie lost all 20 of her nails but that was definitely down to chemo and is currently 4 years into Letrozole so we have no real experience of Tamoxifen. It could be your nails were affected by the chemo and the tamoxifen is stopping them fully recovering ? Hopefully the lovely ladies here can advise you on loads of various nail moisturising / strengthening treatments that will help. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Nails breaking and coming away from Nail bed

Posts.Content: Hi 58Petals, Welcome to the BC Group. A great place to be at a tough time! OK, think you need that big worry of yours putting to rest. The recovery rate for breast cancer is currently around 90% and that includes up to grade 3 so seeing as yours is stage 1 this means it has been found early enough to not have grown to a significant size. Have they given you any indication as to what type of breast cancer this is, or is it too early to say ? If they were really concerned about you they would have suggested a mastectomy and not a lumpectomy and possibly chemo prior to surgery - so although you are still in shock this could have been so much worse. The node removal may well just be a 3 or 4 node sampling to check rather than a full removal, unless they have definitely told you this. Won't spend too much time replying as no doubt you will get lots of other replies as this is a very active, friendly place. The pains everywhere you are feeling is more than likely because you are all tensed up and worried sick more than anything sinister - It happens to all of us at the very beginning. Where it is all new and very scary.... So sorry to read about your husband, hope he is well post surgery. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday...

Posts.Content: Morning Scared10  Everyone hopes to find they have clear nodes or minimal nodes affected sorry to read you had eight found to contain cancer cells :( It is the nodes job to trap these cells so they have done their job with 8 out of 24 that figure could have been so much worse though and the CT scan you are having is something everyone has prior to starting chemo, as for the bone scan do try to look at this as they are checking you over to rule spread out rather than the alternative. Chemotherapy can start quite soon post surgery so be prepared for things to happen fairly quickly. Don't know if you know anything about ER (oestrogen) but being ER7+ you will also be given hormone inhibitor tablets at some time between chemo and rads - these are taken for 5 or even 10 years and offer good protection against the risk of  recurrence. There is a very active monthly chemo club within the main breast group you can check out just do a group search for August Chemo Club. Hope this is of some help at a scary time. Fingers tightly crossed for those results, hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: FEC T allergic reaction

Posts.Content: Hi Sunshine22  Welcome to out not so little breast group, it's a busy place and there are loads of us here. Either like yourself newly diagnosed and fearful of the unknown or finished treatment and helping others with friendly support advice and a few laughs to help lighten the load. The way you are feeling is totally normal for the first few weeks you are mostly in the dark and have to many 'what if' worries this all changes when you know exactly what you will be dealing with as it allows you to concentrate on the next step to kicking cancer where it hurts. A couple of things that can help you for now is click the button at the top of the page that says 'Join This Group'  that way you not only get email notifications for all the messages posted, you will see a New Discussion button appear so you can start your own discussion asking any specific questions you may have knowing all the replies will be specifically for you :) Another good point to remember is making good use of the 'Save This To My Favourites' option in the discussion tools section. All favourites you select will be saved under the 'Favourites' tab on your profile page so you can easily find them again. Hopefully the rib and back aches will be down to you tensing up with the stress and worry of all this and no doubt more than a few disturbed nights sleep too. Very best wishes for some good news when you go for your results next week, do join the group and keep posting whenever you need some reassurance or questions answered, we're all here to help. Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: bit of a ramble starting to wobble!

Posts.Content: Hi Poppylisa  Welcome to the group - a great place to be when times are tough :( I was going to ask if that was a typo but seeing as you actually typed 'stage four' can we ask where your secondary is, as there will be other members with the same who can get back to you with more experienced replies. Pleased to read you seem to be managing the side effects of the FEC well, nothing worse than feeling nauseous all the time :( There is also a Secondary Breast Group for those with stage four but it is a fair bit less active than this one, it's there if you get curious and want to join that group as well, to check posts from others with similar secondaries out. You are right being wary of unreliable websites for info that is well out of date or worryingly misleading. Most of us stick to Macmillan, Breast cancer care and Cancer Research for more accurate info. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: bit of a ramble starting to wobble!

Posts.Content: Hi Welshie007  Sorry to see you are getting the all so common 7 day hangover from hell. You haven't (spelt woefully wrong) or cocodamol  :) Being prescribed co-codamol is good as you should get advice rather than just buying them on a regular basis over the counter and not bothering to read the patient info leaflet. Chances are the prescribed ones may have a higher Codeine content though.  Co-codamol is available in different doses. They all contain 500mg of paracetamol (the same as one regular paracetamol tablet or capsule) but the dose of codeine varies and can be 8mg, 15mg or 30 mg. If you are on one of the higher doses try not to take them for too long if possible (4 to 5 days) as codeine is a mild opiate and you can become addicted to them. There is an increased risk of constipation with the 30mg ones too so keep the fluid intake up if they are the ones you have :) G n' J

Posts.Title: Anyone for Cabbage (Radiation related)

Posts.Content: Hi Nicola  nicolaangie66  Warm welcome to the group, not that we like seeing so many new members to this particular club :( Hope you are recovering well from your surgery. Your consultant may also have explained that post surgery the cancer had been removed and everything else is follow on insurance to try and eliminate as best as possible risk of recurrence at a later date ? Being strongly ER/PR+ positive this will mean long term (at least 5 years) of hormone therapy tablets (one a day) to reduce the oestrogen in your body so if any cancer cells have escaped from the surgery sites this will cut off their food supply. If you are pre menopause this may well be Tamoxifen - post menopause it is usually Letrozole or Anastrozole. The newish POSNOC trial is quite good (several of the ladies here have had it) It can save you being over-treated like having all your lymph nodes removed when the risk is very low and may be unwarranted, or being placed onto chemotherapy when the need of this 'for you' is low.  So only those who would benefit the most get these treatments (and their side effects) rather than giving it to everyone if needed or not. For instance it's not really worth putting yourself through 18 weeks of chemo if it will only reduce your recurrence risk by 1%  Having said that chemo could be less of a problem than a full axillary clearance. If it is recommeded you have one or the other, caught between a rock and a hard place comes to mind :-/ It is better for you if you can avoid un-needed treatments because they all come with risks like lymphoedema if your nodes are removed and some longer term chemo side effects. If you want to read up on POSNOC just click this link :) Don't know if the Bisothingy's are biological therapies, or bi-phosphonates ?  LOL Hope this helps a bit, look forward to seeing you about the place :)  No such thing as a silly question here, if you need answers just holler, we're all here to help. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??

Posts.Content: Hi Pinkshoe, This is probably a question to ask your Onco about. The hormone inhibitor tablets can be started at any time, sometimes even before surgery to help shrink things. It is common to start these up to 6 weeks after any chemo has finished (don't know if you had chemo prior to surgery) If you haven't had chemo it may be that you having to use that Vac-Pac has shoved things back a few weeks but I'm not aware of any reasons why you can't start the hormone therapy before rads ? The usual practice is to start after rads so you need to find out if you need to be put onto them now or if they are starting you after rads. Even if you have a date for your rads this will add another 3 weeks to the waiting time which is pushing the time without them. It may be that the Onco doesn't realise your rads are delayed (they should, but you never know) cross department information between surgeon, rads and onco can get lost. So do give onco a ring and get some answers rather than worry about this pause in your treatment schedule. G n' J

Posts.Content: Hi CARDBOND  They may phone you to give you an appointment date and time for your results which is usually confirmed by letter, but mostly it's just waiting for the appointment letter - they very rarely give any information at all out over the phone (good or bad) in most cases those who phone you are ancillary clinic staff who are not qualified to pass on any medical information. All these results whether positive or negative will always be told face to face as they will want to explain the results in full detail. Be those about a cyst, calcification, firbroid or if cancer cells were found. In ladies who have denser breast tissue the mammogram images aren't so clear, that is why they follow up with an ultrasound and/or biopsy so you don't slip through the net. The waiting is agony isn't it :-/ Sending some Good Luck Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Thank you to everyone who offered support last night when I really...

Posts.Content: Hiya Mr T, Your'e gonna have to start using your christian name - Everytime I see Mr T I keep thinking it's a post about the chemo drug Taxotere 'as it's commonly known as mr t here'  :-) Did they tell you both which chemo drugs your partner will be having (FEC-T) perhaps ? Regarding recon - It's a very personal choice. Some can't be bothered with all the hassle of more surgery after a long treatment regime especially if surgery is performed before chemo and recon surgery is planned possibly up to a year later. Mostly they use chemo before surgery to reduce tumour size to enable a lumpectomy instead of mastectomy, but if they have told you a mastectomy is on the cards, they must have their reasons for discounting a lumpectomy from the start. With chemo prior to surgery at least the recon can be performed at the same time but this may mean any radiotherapy required has to wait until the recon has fully healed as rads can interfere with recon tissue. There are also many different types of recon some may be suitable for your partner, some not - especially those requiring tissue used from elsewhere in the body like tummy or back. Most here who have had a recon after a few months coming to terms with it find they are pleased with the results, some unfortunately have infection and other issues and have to have the breast or implant removed and wish they hadn't bothered. As you can see there are many pro's and cons - No doubt you will get loads of replies from those who have a recon and those who didn't which is great as it will give you both lots of information to help make this decision but this is along way off as yet. If your partner would like to get this settled in her head now you could have a read of this Macmillan booklet 'Understanding Breast Reconstruction' be aware it does contain post surgery images. As for us, Jackie didn't go the recon route and she is happy with that. After surgery, chemo Herceptin and rads she had by all that time already got used to being boobless one side and being small breasted made the choice easier - if she's happy so am I. If you have any questions regarding starting chemo, ask away - we've nearly all been there, not many dodge the chemo bullet. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: Hi Larner   I would class this as a notifiable side effect, or it could be a reaction rather than a side effect.  I would give your onco unit a ring, they will probably want you in to get this checked out - It may only need something to boost your red cell count, but a blood clot could also cause this breathlessness, so needs ruling out. Breathlessness is quite common during chemo, but it can also be a symptom of other issues that need checking / eliminating. I pasted this in from the Taxol info page - Taxol / Paclitaxel can reduce the number of red blood cells in your blood. These cells carry oxygen around the body. If the number of red blood cells is low, you may be tired and breathless. Tell your doctor or nurse if you feel like this. If you are very anaemic, you may need a drip to give you extra red blood cells (blood transfusion). Hope this is easily fixed, G n' J

Posts.Title: Toes!

Posts.Content: Hiya Dee, As far as I know breast rads are always carried out Mon-Fri but they can start you on any day within that time frame. They calculate the total full dose you need which is divided into safe daily 'fractions' These can work out anything between 15 and 25 days but 15 in the more normal period. I can't recall anyone here having rads at weekends as that is when they 'rest' you to reduce the risk of burning in a delicate area and give your normal cells chance to recover. The Linear Accelerators (Linac) are high maintenance and often breakdown too so any servicing work is carried out at weekends. Have a lovely 'girlie' time during you daughters stay. Take care KiwiCardi  G n' J

So unless you already know the extent of spread you are waiting on results ? Posts.Title: Breast Cancer & HIFU

Posts.Content: Hi  Melvina,  Yes, great idea making notes of Q's to ask - Your'e learning fast  :-)  May also help to take someone with you to help remember all the answers too in case you go into brain fade which is often the case as they say something you latch onto and whilst thinking about that you then miss most of their conversation.   After surgery depending on what else they have planned for you because of the rarity of your tumour you may be asked about trials. The Onco specialists, drug companies and anyone else with an interest are always keen to learn about dif ways of treating anything unusual. Which is great if it is to your advantage without compromising the normal treatment they use. So if you are offered to go on a trial make sure you read up on it and get as much info as you can, weigh up the pro's and con's so you can make the right choice for "you"   Around 25% of folks get asked about various trials as it is, so that figure may well be higher in your case. Oh, and don't worry yourself about Radiotherapy it's not as scary as it sounds. Lots of new members worry themselves silly about having rads only to find it was nowhere near as bad as they expected. Try not to fret too much, we know it's hard not to at the start but worrying won't change anything and only makes you feel worse -  and another big no-no is not to google anything. There is a helluva lot of outdated and wrong information out there, so stick with Macmillan and breastcancercare uk. If you need more info phone the 0808 number on every Macmillan webpage - The Maccy nurses are brilliant.  Take care G  n'  J

Posts.Title: Secondary Breast Cancer with Bone and Lung Mets.......feeling very...

Posts.Content: Hiya, At 44 your breast tissue will still be quite dense that is why it's harder to get accurate mammograms and more difficult to feel anything.  Sounds like they are going to see if the chemo will shrink it down (which in most cases it does) so you can have a lumpectomy rather than a mastectomy. You won't get any further grading / type results until after any removed tissue is examined in the path lab. This is standard practice so don't have any fears about not being told much as yet. It's just some have surgery before chemo and get these results quicker. The ct / mri scans are also standard it gives them more information so they can tailor your treatment later on specifically to you so get used to them as you may be given several scans of various types during the course of any treatments. So basically you are special (to your family and us here) but will get the same sorts of treatment regime as the rest of us with just a few personal tweaks because as yet you don't know if you will be ER/PR (oestrogen and progesterone) positive or HER2 positive which means more treatment tweaks but all do'able. Just concentrate on this in one step at a time for now, don't let this affect your family Christmas. Have a great day tomorrow, G n' J
Posts.Title: Just joined the roller coaster - help !

Posts.Content: Morning Lisa  /  LisaD81  Warm welcome to the group, not that we like seeing so many new members :( You don't mention which chemo drugs regime you are having but if it is the more usual FEC or EC yes after a week that is about it. Pleased to read it seems to like you well apart from the dry throat. Are you drinking plenty of fluids (at least 2 litres a day) ? Do keep an eye on your throat as oral thrush can be a chemo side effect - the steroids they give you can wipe out your mouths good bacteria which normally keeps your mouth and throat healthy. There is a regular monthly chemo club in the breast group where those on chemo chat about experiences and exchange tips to ease any side effects - you can find Octobers Chemo Club clicking here. Novembers will be up and running by Tuesday. Chemo is a weird beast most find their first session is the worst as it comes a shock to the system but others find the sessions cumulative so they gradually get more tired or achey.  If you haven't been it may help you to keep a chemo diary, not only for all the appointment times but it's a reminder of how the chemo affected you day by day so you know what to expect and when next time around and a good reference to go back to if you need any specific info at a later date. Look forward to chatting some more, take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: bra's to wear after surgery

Posts.Content: Morning Bat, More than one in ten people taking Herceptin will suffer this now and again. It can become a problem as a lot more often get the drippy nose thing but it's only when you go to wipe or blow you realise this time it's red. It's down to a few factors - the lack of nasal hair, vulnerable capillaries from chemo and Herceptin reducing your platelet count so your blood doesn't clot as easily. You could also get bruising more easily due to a drop in platelets – bleeding gums after brushing your teeth, or lots of tiny red spots or bruises on your arms or legs known as petechia. You can always try making some cash out of the deal by saying it's a cross between Red Nose Day and Movember  :-)  Jackie still gets a slight nose bleed now, well over a year since finishing Herceptin. Maybe a coincidence but no way of telling for sure.   Providing it doesn't happen often enough to make you slightly anaemic it's a problem you may just have to tolerate for a while. G n' J

Posts.Title: update on my op yesterday which I was really anxious about

Posts.Content: Hiya Lou, Any Chemo / Herceptin isn't usually started until around 4 weeks post surgery so you have some time to let the diagnosis dust settle before checking that part of this Runaway Mine Cart Ride out. The mastectomy is more scary in your head than in reality - The emotional side of losing a boob can take longer to adjust to but at the moment it's slowly trying to kill you so it's better gone :-( Sorry to be a bit blunt but it's better to be honest.... It's been caught early and everything is in your favour. BC has a very high recovery rate currently around 90% and most of the other 10% have other ill health treatment issues or the cancer was found when already quite advanced. You mention checking your lymph nodes during surgery - This is called SNB (sentinel node biopsy)  They inject you with a blue tracer dye and track the dye back through the lymphnodes and remove the 2 or 3 nodes small nearest the tumour. As yours is early they may well be clear but if not you will be called back to have more possibly all removed for them to double check them. It is not unusual for there to be a few cells trapped in the nearest node, it is what they are there for (trapping infection) so do not get alarmed if this is the case. You could have a read of this 'Your Operation and Recovery' while you get to meet us all to give you an idea of what to expect. As for reconstruction, there is detailed info within Macmillan about the various types but you need to ask if you will be having radiotherapy at a later date - recon's can be carried out at the same time as mastectomy but radiotherapy can damage the recon tissue depending on which type of recon you go for. Some surgeons will not do an immediate recon because of this and make you wait until any rads are complete - you need to ask your surgeon his views on this and check it out with your breast nurse too for her views. They are a brilliant group of ladies here and we all help each other through whatever stage you are at. There's always someone here having the same treatment at the same time. Best wishes, G n' J

Posts.Title: Just joined the roller coaster - help !

Posts.Content: Morning Forza  So sorry to read about your father in law and seeing you having to join us here. How unlucky is he, one of only around 500 men a year in the UK diagnosed with breast cancer, it's triple negative and signet cell too :( There have been a few fella's with breast cancer here but they have completed treatment and moved on although if any still keep an eye on the group and notice your message may reply. The treatments are basically the same as for women so being triple negative this could mean, surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy, although not always in that order. Signet cell cancer is a rare type of cancer found most often in the glandular cells lining the stomach. But it can also develop in the bowel, breast, pancreas, bladder, prostate or lung. It also has a tendency to spread to the lymph nodes more quickly than other breast cancer types so this would explain the 38/44 score. You can find more information about Breast Cancer in Men - Just click the cover image. You can either read it online or download and save it for reference. If you would like more of an insight into Signet Cell Breast Cancer select this link. It refers to women but the info is identical as the chances of another man finding themselves in the same position as your father in law is so very uncommon. Hope this is of some help for now to get your head around all this, do keep posting if you have more questions or worries and keep a look out for the December Chemo Club discussion where you can get support and tips to help with the FEC-T chemo. Hugs, G n' J

Posts.Title: Hot Male Models & Cat Counterparts :-D

Posts.Content: Hi lilleximum, Won't say welcome as no one really wanted to become a member here. You have found a great place for support and friendly advice. It is a very active group where you can come to scream, cry and ease your worries - we even manage to have a few laughs along the way. No doubt your head is full of questions and worries at the moment. It's early days and the waiting for results is terrible on the emotions and everyone here hated being at the stage you are at now. Mammograms are not as accurate as ultrasound scans for younger women as the breast tissue is a lot denser - Hence why you were really squashed during yours. You almost certainly will have some biopsies taken so please be aware of this. Which can leave you a bit sore for a few days afterwards. Please understand that if your fears are confirmed BC has one of the highest recovery rates of any cancers almost 90% so don't have fears for the future. The treatment can be tough but is do'able. You may find this a good read 'Understanding Breast Screening' just click the green text link. It covers just about everything relating to screening. No doubt you will get lots of reassuring replies from the other lovely ladies here so I'll just leave you with a little advice. Please don't Google too much. A lot of the information out there is way out of date, or misleadingly wrong. Stick with reputable web sites like Macmillan and Breast Cancer Care UK If you have any questions at all however silly you may think they are, just holler there is always someone around here to help you. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Weird few days

Posts.Content: Hi Joey - Sarah,  First off thanks for coming back and giving us an update on how you are doing. Don't ever feel the need to say sorry here we all know how tough this is to take in :-( If you do get panicky or it's all starts getting to much to cope with contact your CPN or use the Macmillan free phone 0808 808 0000 number for a chat to one of the nurses, they are great. As for your four year old there is a book titled 'Mummy's Lump' you can view and download to read with her. Just click the title to check if you think it is suitable for her. If it's of any help there is a support website for teenagers who have a parent with diagnosed with cancer called Rip Rap you can take a look by clicking the link to see if you think she may get some help from it ? It is based in Sheffield and has been checked out by cancer research uk as a safe site. Good luck with your results and your pre op appointment. George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Weird few days

Posts.Content: Bloomin'  Great News Susie :-) Can I donate some 'Nuclear Jelly Shots'  Have a magical evening, hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: I did it too!

Posts.Content: Hi Supermom Nystan usually is enough to hold this back, maybe you need a change to something else like Fluconazole ? but still give them a ring and see what their opinion is about this. G-CSF drugs force the large bones to produce more white cells and they certainly let you know they don't like the extra work :( G n' J
Posts.Title: D of chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon, Yes, it's a bit of a bummer when you physch yourself up for it and it gets put back a week. It's not just your blood count they consider, it's the recovery of your liver which has to process the poison, er, sorry chemo. A weeks wait is a lot better than risking any liver damage - Well, you do want to have a celebration drink with that meal when you have finished all your chemo  :-) Make the most of your extended feeling good week, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: Chemo delayed

Posts.Content: Evening Lucy, Sorry to see you joining the club no one wants to be in. Breast cancer is very treatable it's one of the more common types and has had more research than practically any other which is good because there are so many varied treatment options. There are loads of women here who have had treatment and are now classed as NED (no evidence of disease) They will never say you are clear but in around 90% of cases you come through it all to enjoy your new life. Jackie (my wife) was diagnosed stage 3 in May 2012 and although the treatment isn't a walk in the park, it is do'able.  It's hard to say try not to worry or panic as it won't make any difference to your results but that is a big ask early on waiting for diagnosis info. Once your treatment plan is in place everything happens so fast. Some have chemo before surgery, others surgery then chemo. Others who are luckier have surgery and radiotherapy with no chemo. Everyone is different and they tailor your regime to you and your specific tumour. No doubt you will have loads of questions, so just post away we are all here to help you through this with friendly advice and support. Best wishes for good luck tomorrow, do keep us informed. Take care, George & Jackie
Posts.Title: I'm panicked and feeling desperate.

Posts.Content: Hi Kath, The Anal Groups rugby team doesn't have that problem.... They are called the 'All Browns'  :-) I can hear the 'Bumlanders' chant - Crouch, Touch - Engage!!! G n' J
Posts.Title: why do England wear white!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hiya Jo, Yup,chances are it's down to the Docetaxel as a fairly common side effecting the nerves. It's a bit like when you drive through a tree lined road and the sun is low and bright, either that or you are turning into Inspector Dreyfus in the Pink Panther films :-) It's annoying but does go away after a while, well J's did..... G n' J
Posts.Title: Twitches

Posts.Content: Hi DL   Sorry to see you are having Taxotere / Docetaxel issues so early on :( Pineapple juice could help as would pineapple chunks from the fridge, be careful with pineapple though if you mouth gets sore from mouth ulcers (another common side effect with T) The oral thrush meds should hopefully start to clear that up, but a bit more of a concern is the soles of your feet being sore as this could be a sign of Peripheral Nuropathy (info link) which can be induced by some chemotherapy drugs; Taxotere being one of them.  Are your fingers starting to get sore as well, or just the nails for now ? You should contact your Onco Unit and tell them about this pain/soreness in hands / feet - it may be the dose of Taxotere is a tad too high for you and they can reduce the dosage by 20% for your other sessions as this can get progressively worse even leading to the skin on your feet cracking or peeling skin making walking and stairs a nightmare :( A 20% reduction is sometimes enough to ease the problem. Something which may help for now is to cut down on anything that causes friction like footwear that is too tight, gripping/screwing actions when unscrewing bottle and jar tops etc Vitamin B12 is supposed to help and be careful with water that may be hotter than you think it is as the nerves in your hands and feet may be slightly numb. Swapping your Co-Codamol for and non-steroidal anti inflammatory like Ibuprofen may be a better option as this can help with nerve pain. Please get this checked out as PN can take ages to recover from post chemo, my wife still has slightly numb big toes from 2012 Hope this helps a bit, take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi EJM60  Your BCN was right - it takes 3 or 4 weeks to get fully into your system and another months worth at least to see how any side effects start to pan out. If you start another brand so soon you won't have anything to base the differences on :( Besides Arimidex® the original maker there are now at least another 8 generic brands. Some have been lucky enough to get Arimidex prescribed but at £80 compared to under £10 for the generics they are the lucky few. It would be worth explaining to your pharmacy you are new to these and your breast care nurse recommends the same brand until you get settled on them, but they may hand you the 'they are all the same' chestnut... Several ladies here get on well with Teva but they are not for everyone - what brand have they now given you ? G n' J
Posts.Title: Different manufacturer of anastrozole

Posts.Content: Hi realtin  Can't really add anything to Weeblemum 's reply, re making sure you are well hydrated and warming your arm/hand. The NHS really needs to make PICC Lines etc standard practice prior to administering chemo... The world has moved on, It isn't 1975 anymore :( G n' J
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: and there was you thinking Dye was the Welsh anaesthetist :-) Hevbo - I didn't get where I am today by being sensible! Soz.....  G n' J xx   (Breast Group - May Contain Nuts)
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday - need mastectomy August 19th :-O

Posts.Content: Hi Joey-Sarah, I can see where you are coming from. If it was a printed book you could skip those few chemo pages making it easier but online it scrolls making it tricky. Have they not mentioned anything about chemo to you as yet ? or will they figure that one out when they examine the tissue removed during surgery ? Some get given chemo and some don't. Good luck for the results on the 10th. This may be where they fine tune what treatment you may be given. Young kids have a great attitude eh :-) G n' J
Posts.Title: Weird few days

Posts.Content: G'Day Wink  About time you came and said hello  :)) There are a few ladies here who have had TAC but it isn't one of the more common chemo regimes in the UK. I think sue G had TAC and one of the Breast Champs Kacang who also lives in Oz had the AC regime. I've tagged them so they will spot your message above :) There is an info page about TAC on the Macmillan site you can have a look at by clicking the link. Dunno if there is better TAC info on the Australian Breast Cancer Support site ? Don't be put off by the long list of side effects, most only have a few but they have to list them all :-/ Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi silkpainter, If when you had your mastectomy the node biopsy was termed a 'Sentinel Node Biopsy' (SLNB) this will mean they would actually remove 2 or 3 lymph nodes nearest the tumour not just take needle core samples . Did you get a blue dye injected prior to surgery ? Nerve damage repairing itself after surgery can feel weird and can be anything from feeling hot, cold, little zap type shocks and even feel like it is wet ? It can take a while for breast / armpit nerves to settle down after being disturbed. Good luck with your results, hopefully the node check will come back clear so you won't need any others removed. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: burning

Posts.Content: Morning Kimbeeloo  Warm welcome to the group.... I don't know if you have underlying health problems that make chemo a risky scenario, but do be mindful to read up and info grab HER2+ Positive (link) before thinking about ducking out of chemo... Around 15% of those with BC will be found to be HER2+    Ten years ago HER2+ positive was considered to be one of the more agrressive types of breast cancer get diagnosed with a higher % chance of recurrence either locally or as a secondary cancer within 5-10 years - The biological targeted therapy Herceptin was introduced and changed all that and is a real game changer for HER2+ BC but to get the Herceptin it has to be given alongside chemotherapy, you cannot have it on it's own. Even better now the newer Perjeta can be included as well. My wife was HER2+ back in May 2012 when Herceptin was still quite new and was the original postcode lottery drug - she was still no evidence of disease at her 6 year review and it is scary to think that without chemo and herceptin she may not have made it this far :-/ Know it is tough when you are told you will only need radiotherapy and possibly 5 years of tablets only to get hit later on with the you need chemo news. There probably isn't much info out there from those who are HER2+ and refuse chemo/herceptin as given the option most find the odds are too high to risk it :( Probably not what you wanted to hear but you need facts to make an informed decision and sugar coating 'stuff' isn't always the best option. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Refusing chemotherapy after Her2+ results

Posts.Content: Hi tarneh  The only daft question is the one that isn't asked  :) Noticed you are taking Tamoxifen - Your friend could be post menopause and is going to be taking either Letrozole, Anastrozole or Exemstane as her ovaries won't be producing the oestrogen? Those types of tablet can cause bone thinning which can lead to osteopaenia and a Dexa scan checks bone density to keep an eye on this. They perform the first scan before starting the tablets to get base line figures, then again after 6 months or so to see if they are causing any bone density change. You don't get this problem with Tamoxifen so unless they change you to those mentioned above in a couple of years (which they sometimes do) it isn't a concern :) Hope this help, G n' J
Posts.Title: Bone density scan, should I have had one?

Posts.Content: Hi Supermom Docetaxel can cause bone / joint aches and is one of the more common side effects - are you also having the injections to increase your white blood cells,? as those can cause aches in the lower spine, pelvis and thigh bones as well. You should contact your chemo unit about the white tongue, as it sounds like an Oral Thrush type yeast infection. There are several meds they can give you to help with this - If you leave it it can eventually cover the throat too and can lead to mouth ulcers :( You will normally feel a little like yourself around day 10'ish with Mr. T (tax) Have a look through the back pages in the September Chemo Club here - to see if it is mentioned there. G n' J
Posts.Title: D of chemo

Posts.Content: Evening tarneh  Oncologists have an odd opinion of menopause. Some wait until at least 6 months plus without a period in case you are what they term peri-menopausal (an inbetweeny) - others accept that treatments will push you into the menopause meaning they all have varying ways of doing things. If there is the chance your ovaries are still producing some oestrogen tamoxifen is the better one, post menopause most oestrogen is made by the adrenal glands and some from body fat cells. Perhaps they have recommended she has a Dexa scan for some other reason but still related to bone density or is she taking other meds to 'switch off' her ovaries ? Get her to ask and compare notes :) Even minor differences in diagnosis can cause a change in treatments, and everyone's breast cancer is slightly different. Take care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Bone density scan, should I have had one?

Posts.Content: There is a lot of confusion with this grade and stage grouping headache. There are 4 stages but only 3 grades Stage = Spread Stage 1 – this is divided into two groups as follows:     •    stage 1A the cancer is less than 2 centimetres (cm), the lymph nodes do not contain cancer cells and the cancer has not spread outside the breast.     •    stage 1B no cancer is seen in the breast and there are a few cancer cells in the lymph nodes under the arm. Or the cancer is less than 0.2cm with a few cancer cells in the lymph nodes under the arm. Stage 2 – this is divided into two groups as follows: • stage 2A – the cancer is less than 2cm and the lymph nodes under the arm are affected. Or the cancer is more than 2cm but less than 5cm and there are no cancer cells in the lymph nodes under the arm. Or although no cancer is seen in the breast, there are 1–­3 lymph nodes under the arm that contain cancer cells or in the lymph nodes near the breastbone (sternum). • stage 2B – the cancer is larger than 2cm but less than 5cm and there are cancer cells in the lymph nodes under the arm or in the lymph nodes near the breastbone Or the cancer is larger than 5cm and there are no affected lymph nodes under the arm. Stage 3 – this is divided into three groups as follows: • stage 3A – although no cancer is seen in the breast, cancer is found in 4–9 lymph nodes under the arm or in the lymph nodes near the breast bone Or the cancer is larger than 2cm but less than 5cm and cancer is found in 4–9 lymph nodes under the arm or in the lymph nodes near the breastbone Or the cancer is larger than 5cm, there are lymph nodes under the arm that contain cancer cells or in the lymph nodes near the breast bone • stage 3B – the cancer is fixed to the skin or chest wall with no cancer cells in the lymph nodes under the arm. Or the cancer is fixed to the skin or chest wall, with up to 9 lymph nodes under the arm or the lymph nodes near the breast bone affected. • stage 3C – the cancer can be any size and has spread to 10 or more lymph nodes under the arm and near the breast bone, or to nodes above the collarbone (supraclavicular fossa nodes) or below the collarbone (infraclavicular nodes). Stage 4 – the cancer can be any size, the lymph nodes may or may not contain cancer but the cancer has spread to other organs of the body, such as distant lymph nodes, lungs, bones, liver or brain. If your cancer is found in the lymph nodes under the arm but nowhere else in the body you do not have stage 4 breast cancer. More confused now than before ? - I'm not surprised  :-) Grading = Cancers are graded according to how different they are to normal breast cells and how quickly they are growing. In your pathology report this may be called differentiation. There are three grades of invasive breast cancer:     •    grade 1 (well differentiated) the cancer cells look most like normal cells – for example, they are of similar size and shape to normal cells – and are usually slow-growing     •    grade 2 (moderately differentiated) the cancer cells look less like normal cells – they are often larger and show variation in size and shape – and are growing faster     •    grade 3 (poorly differentiated) the cancer cells look most changed and are usually fast-growing. With ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) there also three grades, but these are usually called low, intermediate and high instead of 1, 2 or 3. Treatment options People with grade 3 invasive breast cancers are more likely to be offered chemotherapy to help destroy any cancer cells that may have spread as a result of the cancer being faster growing. Info taken from breastcancercare site, G n' J EDIT - Snap Helen - Wow!  That's what I call Teamwork :-) Cancers are graded according to how different they are to normal breast cells and how quickly they are growing. Posts.Title: Grade 2

Posts.Content: Hi shirleymac, There are a few ladies here who have had cellulitis issues so I'm giving this a 'bump' hopefully you get some replies soon :) G n' J
Posts.Title: Cellulitis after effects

Posts.Content: Afternoon Jo, Sorry about the reply delay, we had to go into town for the weekly shop :-( Seeing as you were given nothing in writing you need to start off getting all the info you can about your diagnosis because everything from here on hinges on those facts and figures. Firstly stage and grade then lymph node involvement (sounds very much like none) which is good. The biopsy may have been grade 1 but that sometimes gets upgraded to a 2 from the pathology dept's more thorough checks. Lower the stage number the slower the cells grow. The surgery has removed the cancer and with clear margins, so everything you are being given now is to help avoid against any re-occurance. As they hinted you are hormone receptive you will need to know if you are either ER+ (oestrogen) and /or PR+ (progesterone) receptor positive - you could be one, both or neither. There is also a scoring system for how receptive but a lot don't pass on this info, they just say positive or negative not mentioning if this is strongly receptive or not.  If positive you will  be given aromatase hormone inhibitor tablets, you can be on these for five sometimes ten years. Depends on which type of tablet you are being given and that depends on if you are pre or post menopausal and a few other factors. There are about four different types you can read about those here. If pre menopausal the tablets are different because your ovaries will be producing oestrogen too. I would have thought if you were HER2+ someone would have mentioned it as the treatment for this is Herceptin which is given for HER2+ results - this is usually 18 x 3 weekly sessions but it is given with chemotherapy so if you are not having chemo then you will be HER2 negative. You can ask just to see what they say about it ? So, onto the radiotherapy - The usual regime for this is 15 sessions mon-fri x 3 weeks. They give you a break over the weekends. The first appointment is what they call assessment and planning and is usually one week or thereabouts before treatment starts. You will have a question and answer this is your chance to ask about anything rads related before your sessions start. At this planning appt they will show you the room and get you on the linear accelerator table and measure you up very precisely for the exact area needing treatment - they will then give you some very small pin point black tattoo marks. These are used to line you up at each session to avoid having o go through all the measuring again. For most the worst part of rads is the daily travelling and what feels like sunburn.  Most radiotherapy patients get free parking but you can ask about that at the assessment later on. Hope this helps a bit, fingers crossed you'll get some more replies mentioning anything I have missed out :-) G n' J
Posts.Title: Knowing the right questions to ask

Posts.Content: Just to help understand these are roughly the NICE guidelines for having Perjeta / Pertuzumab pre, or post surgery and is nearly always given in conjunction with Herceptin and a 2nd and 3rd line chemotherapy regime. 2nd line chemo is an Anthracycline like Adriamycin (chemical name: doxorubicin) and/or Ellence (chemical name: epirubicin) 3rd line chemo is one of the Taxanes, Taxotere (docetaxel) , Taxol (paclitaxel) or Abraxane (nab-paclitaxel) G n' J Who might be offered perjeta / pertuzumab? Only people with HER2 positive breast cancer will benefit from having pertuzumab. If your cancer is HER2 negative, then pertuzumab will not be of any benefit to you. Before surgery in primary breast cancer Primary breast cancer is breast cancer that hasn't spread beyond the breast or the lymph nodes under the arm. Pertuzumab can be given to people with primary breast cancer before surgery (known as neo-adjuvant treatment) for: inflammatory breast cancer. breast cancer that’s at high risk of coming back (recurrence) Before surgery in locally advanced breast cancer Locally advanced breast cancer means the breast cancer has spread to the tissues and lymph nodes around the chest, neck and under the breastbone. Pertuzumab can be given to people with locally advanced breast cancer before surgery (known as neo-adjuvant treatment). Secondary and locally advanced breast cancer Pertuzumab can be used to treat secondary breast cancer (when cancer cells from the breast have spread to other parts of the body such as the bones, lungs, liver or brain). It’s also used for locally advanced breast cancer that can’t be removed by surgery. Pertuzumab is only suitable for people who haven’t previously had targeted therapies such as trastuzumab (Herceptin), or chemotherapy for secondary or locally advanced breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Refusing chemotherapy after Her2+ results

Posts.Content: Morning Kimbeeloo  Warm welcome to the group.... I don't know if you have underlying health problems that make chemo a risky scenario, but do be mindful to read up and info grab HER2+ Positive (link) before thinking about ducking out of chemo... Around 15% of those with BC will be found to be HER2+    Ten years ago HER2+ positive was considered to be one of the more agrressive types of breast cancer get diagnosed with a higher % chance of recurrence either locally or as a secondary cancer within 5-10 years - The biological targeted therapy Herceptin was introduced and changed all that and is a real game changer for HER2+ BC but to get the Herceptin it has to be given alongside chemotherapy, you cannot have it on it's own. Even better now the newer Perjeta can be included as well. My wife was HER2+ back in May 2012 when Herceptin was still quite new and was the original postcode lottery drug - she was still no evidence of disease at her 6 year review and it is scary to think that without chemo and herceptin she may not have made it this far :-/ Know it is tough when you are told you will only need radiotherapy and possibly 5 years of tablets only to get hit later on with the you need chemo news. There probably isn't much info out there from those who are HER2+ and refuse chemo/herceptin as given the option most find the odds are too high to risk it :( Probably not what you wanted to hear but you need facts to make an informed decision and sugar coating 'stuff' isn't always the best option. Take care, G n' J

Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi bloojools  Peanut11 Depends on what LVEF figure was given at your last Muga or ECG scan ? The pressure of blood being ejected from the lower left side chamber. A normal LVEF (lower ventricular ejection fraction) figure is only between 55% and 75% anyway so if your normal figure is at the lower range to start with, it doesn't give a lot of wriggle room; meaning quite a few ladies only have half or so of their 18 sessions as the cut off figure is mostly 50-51%    Below 50 and you are in heart attack risk territory. If your figure is starting to drop a couple of weeks break can see the figure rise back up a few % to resume Herceptin but if it doesn't you will be taken off it because if the heart gets damaged it can be permanent. Lowering your salt intake can help raise the lvef figure a little. What figure was quoted at your last check ?  J had a 2 week break after about 6 herceptin as her lvef dropped to 51% (it was 64% at the start) and was given an ACE inhibitor - after the break it went back up to 55% and stayed at that level for all the other sessions. As mentioned earlier NICE are going through the figures and data of the Herceptin (Persephone Trial) and will probably recommend that 9 sessions is just as effective and will replace the 18 sessions as standard practice, and at £1,200 per dose you can maybe see why. Hope this helps a bit, G n' J
Posts.Title: Herceptin - how long for?

Posts.Content: Hi  Lizzie,  I'm fairly certain that if you have, and are being treated for cancer, and even after treatment you are covered by what was the Disability Discrimination Act (now known as the Equality Act I think ) as you are regarded as being in remission so depending on the circumstances regarding your couple of days off, they may be legally wrong by pulling you up over it.  There is a whole shedload of information regarding coping with work issues on the Maccy site, with a menu on the left hand side of the page, I'll paste in the link below...... As for the Tamoxifen it affects everyone differently, like all of these hormone tabs they do come with baggage, some seem to suffer a lot worse than others and 5 years is a long time to be suffering. Dunno about the immune system, but why not, they seem to effect everything else.  Do have a word with the lovely Maccy nurses on the 0808 number, maybe they will advise you to contact your Onco Dr to see if there is an alternative tablet you could try if only to see if the different side effects from that are easier for you to cope with ? The pasted text below is taken from Macmillan's equality act leaflet. "What are reasonable adjustments for disabled people" ? Employers have a duty to make ‘reasonable adjustments’ to workplaces and working practices to ensure that people with a disability are not at a disadvantage compared to others. There is no fixed definition of ‘reasonable’. What is reasonable will depend on all the circumstances, including practicality, cost, and the extent to which business may be disrupted. Any planned adjustments should be discussed with, and approved by, the employee concerned. Reasonable adjustments for someone with cancer might include: • letting them take time off to attend medical appointments • modifying a job description to remove tasks that cause particular difficulty – either on a temporary or permanent basis • being flexible around working hours, or offering the option to work from home • allowing extra breaks to help them cope with fatigue • adjusting performance targets to take into account the effect of sick leave/fatigue etc on the employee, or giving them a post with more suitable duties • moving a work station, for example to avoid stairs • ensuring easy access to premises for someone who is using a wheelchair or crutches • providing disabled toilet facilities • allowing a gradual, phased return to work after extended sick leave • changing the date or time of a job interview if it coincides with a medical appointment. Just one or two little changes could be all it takes to help an employee stay in work. Hope this helps, best wishes,  George & Jackie http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Livingwithandaftercancer/Workandcancer/Supportforemployees/Workcancer/Workcancer.aspx

Posts.Title: I had a clear blood test for Tumour Markers

Posts.Content: Hiya Kate  Peanut11 J is still in bed - I'm always around early a lifetime of shift work will do that to you :-/ I do the posting and J makes the tea and cakes - we are so thankful for the help we got from the Macmillan oncology unit at our local hosp we like to help out where we can here as J had everything including the kitchen sink thrown at her for 15 months. I firmly believe they saved her life. Back in 2012 there was no Perjeta and Herceptin was given slowly using the same pump and bag delivery method as chemo over a 40 minute period. Giving that way the only side effects were a bit of a runny nose and the occcasional very minor nose bleed. It was only when they introduced the sub-cut injection method patients started noticing hip, upper leg and pelvic aches. So in our minds slower and being more at room temp helped.  Letrozole on the other hand is a force to be reckoned with. J finished her 5 years on Letrozole in June (hooray) although she was lucky enough to be on Femara they were still buggers for bone / joint aches.  She used to take Meloxicam NSAID (non-steroidal anti inflammatorry drug) and Amitriptyline to help ease the aches and now letrozole has left the party she hasn't needed those now. A lot of people underestimate Letrozole and think it is just another Tamoxifen looky-likey but it is given to some patients to actually shrink tumours down prior to surgery if for whatever reason they cannot be given chemo - so, a tough little cookie. If you are not taking any anti-ache meds and don't mind adding to your bag of Skittles see your GP for something to ease them. You don't get any medals for suffering  :) Take Care, G n' J
Posts.Title: Herceptin - how long for?

Posts.Content: Hiya Jo,  Just trying to get my head around where you are treatment wise. Can you fill us in a bit ? So you have had a lumpectomy (WLE) Assume you had your results appointment by now where they tell you about what they found from the tissue in pathology regarding stage / grade if any lymph nodes were affected etc ?  Are you ER, PR or HER2+ (positive) or do you not know yet ? Notice you don't mention chemo... Did you have this before surgery or do you not need it / or are having it next ? If you are to be given chemo they will discuss this as the next step as chemo is usally given before radiotherapy but if you have dodged the chemo bullet your next appointment will be to check your surgery for any problems like healing ok, no seroma or lymphoedema check for scar tissue forming checking for any other problems.  Then it will lead onto discussing your radiotherapy sessions. If you can let us have some more details it would help us compile a few questions you could ask, but we don't want to explain all about rads if your next stage is going to be chemo. Sorry to be a bit vague - we'll get back to you when we know where you are on the roller coaster. Take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Yay, Nice to see you made it over the fence to come and say Hi! Katie. Are you starting FEC on Tuesday or something else ? Just wondering as most have fec-t but there are other chemo combo's and they all behave a little differently. How on earth you and your sister are going to help and support each other when both suffering from chemo brain - sounds more like a script for a comedy series..... Neither of you will remember where anything is and your conversations will be like listening to Yoda  lol. Seriously though you have had some great advice but some of the side effects your sister is having / had may not be the same as yours even if you are on the same chemo drugs as they do seem to have a mind of their own and you just won't know how it will treat you until you have had the first one. A few like hair loss, whole body tiredness, mouth ulcers, oral thrush, bone muscle aches, constipation or the opposite can be common others seem really random like dry eyes, losing some finger and/ or toenails etc - So be prepared for anything. Take all your steroids and anti sickness tablets even if you feel ok. Try and work the times out so you don't take the steroids after 4pm if you can as the later you take it the more chance there is you will have trouble getting to sleep. They can also give you the munchies and you'll want to nibble snacks all the time. They are always given with chemo along with the anti sickness tablets they do help with the side effects a bit so keep taking them even if you feel fine because if you are sick it will be too late to take them and keep them down. It may help if you get some mouthwash with Chlorhexidine in, if not from the onco unit get some Corsodyl from a pharmacy because mouth ulcers and oral thrush are quite common with chemo. If this happens and your sense of taste goes weird try a bit of pineapple or a ginger nut biscuit before you eat to give your taste buds a kick. Grab a couple of tins of Pineapple chunks and juice or ginger beer too. You can fridge or freeze the chunks on cocktail sticks - they help with the furry tongue and gunky mouth feeling which also helps your taste buds.  Get some other pain relief that doesn't contain any paracetamol so you can alternate tablets 2 hourly and not overdose on paracetamol until the chemo headache or other aches and twinges subside. Another couple of items to put on your list is a soft toothbrush for sore gums in case of above and a thermometer to keep an eye out for temp spikes (signs of infection) when white count is low. Do use the thermometer first thing in the morning before you have taken any paracetamol first or you'll get a false lower reading. If your temp reaches 37.5 or higher phone the onco unit as it could be a sign of infection when your white count is low (days 7-14 middle week)   It may help you to keep a treatment diary so you can keep track of how you feel day by day and note your temps and appts in. Any probs or other Q's you need answering, fire away. We're all here to help and only a couple of clicks away. Hugs to you and Big Sis, take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: Grade 1

Posts.Content: Just to help understand these are roughly the NICE guidelines for having Perjeta / Pertuzumab pre, or post surgery and is nearly always given in conjunction with Herceptin and a 2nd and 3rd line chemotherapy regime. 2nd line chemo is an Anthracycline like Adriamycin (chemical name: doxorubicin) and/or Ellence (chemical name: epirubicin) 3rd line chemo is one of the Taxanes, Taxotere (docetaxel) , Taxol (paclitaxel) or Abraxane (nab-paclitaxel) G n' J Who might be offered perjeta / pertuzumab? Only people with HER2 positive breast cancer will benefit from having pertuzumab. If your cancer is HER2 negative, then pertuzumab will not be of any benefit to you. Before surgery in primary breast cancer Primary breast cancer is breast cancer that hasn't spread beyond the breast or the lymph nodes under the arm. Pertuzumab can be given to people with primary breast cancer before surgery (known as neo-adjuvant treatment) for: inflammatory breast cancer. breast cancer that’s at high risk of coming back (recurrence) Before surgery in locally advanced breast cancer Locally advanced breast cancer means the breast cancer has spread to the tissues and lymph nodes around the chest, neck and under the breastbone. Pertuzumab can be given to people with locally advanced breast cancer before surgery (known as neo-adjuvant treatment). Secondary and locally advanced breast cancer Pertuzumab can be used to treat secondary breast cancer (when cancer cells from the breast have spread to other parts of the body such as the bones, lungs, liver or brain). It’s also used for locally advanced breast cancer that can’t be removed by surgery. Pertuzumab is only suitable for people who haven’t previously had targeted therapies such as trastuzumab (Herceptin), or chemotherapy for secondary or locally advanced breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Refusing chemotherapy after Her2+ results

Posts.Content: Morning Gina, Really feel for you this has been such a long wait and it isn't over yet :-( A lot here only have a 2-3 week wait between getting a diagnosis confirmed and either chemo or surgery being started. The extra time you are having to endure playing this waiting game is emotionally cruel - It gives you way too much thinking time and there's no real way of escaping that. You can shove it to the back of your mind while you are busy but it keeps rearing it's head as soon as you get a free moment when you could relax :-( You say you have to be strong (why?) and can't let folks know you are terrified, but you can let on how scary this is for you without causing too much alarm within the family. You need more support than you are letting them give you by trying to be strong all the time, it bubbles over and causes panic attacks and major teary spells and makes you feel cr*p. Don't look at all those days left on the calender, take the wait one day at a time mark them off with a big cross you'll soon find you only have a couple of days to go, then the surgery anguish starts but everyone here will tell you all their surgery fears were unfounded, a lot are well enough to come home after a mastectomy the next day. You're doing great honestly - everything you are feeling is totally normal. It's just a bummer it has to be that way. Hugs, G n' J
Posts.Title: Struggling on the inside

Posts.Content: Evening Forever Lucky, Does it feel warm like you could have an infection starting ? This certainly doesn't sound or look right if it's starting to ooze a bit, and obviously you don't think it does either.... I would start taking the antibios, they won't do you any harm if it isn't an infection but if it is the start of one it will keep it in check until you can get your gp or onco to have another look seeing as you say it is worse now than when your onco checked it. If you have a thermometer keep an eye on your temp regularly and if it gets to 37.5 or any higher ring the unit. Are you still on chemo ? Fingers crossed it will be ok, but if you don't take the tablets you could end up in hosp on antibio drips for 3 days or so if it takes hold. Take care, George & Jackie

Posts.Title: achey legs and fatigue on Herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Ajem, Welcome to the breast group - Must admit after reading your profile I thought you had posted in the wrong group..... Great to read your husband is doing well, he certainly went through it fairly. When you say radium I assume you mean radiotherapy - Like as in possibly 15 daily sessions over 3 weeks (mon-fri) ? The side effects are different so as far as I know there is no reason why you cannot start the hormone inhibitor tablets straight away (which tablets are they) as there are 4 main types.... The side effects from radiotherapy are mostly tiredness (all the daily traveling doesn't help) and slight sunburn effects but is very do'able. Think you'll find most here were well into any hormone therapy prior to rads and it made no difference. Hope this helps, do reply with more questions, you must have several floating around ? Take care, G n' J
